Refusing to provide drugs of a certain kind is not an effective tactic in forcing states to abandon the death penalty. First of all, put yourself in the perspective of a pro-death-penalty person. Domestic drug companies now refuse to supply the drug you need, and EU countries refuse to export it. Is the *inconvenience* of having to find another drug or another method of execution going to stop you from executing people? Or is it going to further your resolve to do what you think is right despite the interference from these outsiders?

Second, the people actually administering the death penalty have no choice: the legislature has made the death penalty legal and a court has imposed the death penalty--so unless you take away every legal means of carrying out that execution, they're still compelled by law to do it.

Ivory is cut up and used to make items, repairs, etc. Thus the serial number would remain on one piece and not the other pieces. Thus by your suggestion rendering them illegal to possess. It's a far more complex problem unfortunately.

This article describes a slippery slope. Even the title is provocative. As a physician, I can categorically say that I have never lied to my patients, ever. Part of the art of medicine is to how best to explain the diagnoses, treatment and prognoses of a patient's conditions that gives the patient a fair assessment of his or her situation but also reasonable hope for the future (including planning for one's death). Nobody said that it was easy. The principles of medical ethics (beneficence, non-maleficence, autonomy, justice) means that we need to consider the risks vs. benefits of the approach that we take. If a physician is truly worried about possible self-harm due to a patient knowing the truth, I would suggest consultation with a psychiatrist, the physicians who are the experts on these issues and who may be able to offer treatment as indicated.

The bottom line is that lying to patients is a losing proposition. It essentially breaks trust and makes all future interactions suspect in the patient's and/or physician's mind. As for the specific case of the young man in this article, ultimately the truth was told to him, but nobody said that it would be easy.

The irony is that there are no good investments because the investing class demands low taxes, and so governments cut funding for basic science, education, the arts, infrastructure and other projects that could connect the people who can build new industries that are worth investing in.

We have all these dollars chasing the next big thing, so you have fraudsters out there willing to suck up money for worthless projects. How is that any better than government waste or another Solyndra? It has been shown that government research can spark whole new technologies. We know that we need to educate our children to be able to take on the future. But somehow we can agree to make the investment in that. So much better for the investing class to spend their money on fancy tulips.

This is a start, and I see nothing wrong with it. However, it's clear that young men in general are falling behind in terms of education, earning power and basic employment. If this broad problem isn't addressed, the President's new initiative will have but a small effect on the achievement and wealth gap. The elephant in the room is employment. What do we expect and/or want young men and women to do? Be doctors? Lawyers? Software engineers? That's a very limited percentage of the working population, and the President himself has noted that college may not be the answer for many young people looking to plug into the workforce for the long haul. Racism is very real and it has very real effects. But let's look at the big picture as well. Non-military national youth service requirements could go a long way toward creating a more equitable, more harmonious society. Getting big hitters to think about how to shape a 21st century economy that works for the broad swath of people would help all young men and all young women as well. Furthermore, why not make the promise to establish an in-house mentoring programs a pre-requisite for winning significant government contracts? Theoretically, our business leaders believe in the future
of big-A America. Let's have them prove it by helping more young men and women get a legitimate shot at the American dream.
get

These recently reported international gun trials, where an innocent is killed for walking in their neighborhood, texting in a movie theatre and now playing (loud) music in one’s car, eventually will become too much even for Disney World tourists’.
This Jacksonville defendant’s defense trial demonstrated what is tactically the safe proclamation for the shooter after a killing: you felt your life threatened and believed the (soon to be victim) had a weapon. How can you deny what a person says was in their mind; truth serum? But recall even in the Wild West, liability for, killing an unarmed man was not excused based upon that shooter’s imagination. The gallows were the ultimate arbiters for that determination.

We can't be sure how much fuel was actually on that plane. The 777-ER is capable of a range equivalent of an LA to Tokyo flight. Supposedly the plane only had a fueling range of 2,500 miles, standard for it's destination. Given all we don't know, and all the misinformation to date... I would consider the amount of fuel an unknown.

Which means the plane could be anywhere.

If it had fuel for only 2,500 miles and if it did turn West at a steady heading, last seen on radar 200 miles north of Penang, then that puts the plane somewhere to the West of Sri Lanka, in the Arabian Sea.

If it had more fuel than reported, it could have landed on the African continent (Somalia) or potentially turned again to the north and landed in the Middle East.

Another theory, if the radar data being released by the Malaysian military is the missing planes and the plot points are accurate, than it might suggest the plane was turning in an arc, counter-clockwise, at least for that time period. If that arc did not deviate, say if no one was at the controls, it would have again appeared on radar repeatedly as it circled Indonesia. If that heading was irregular, or was corrected, the plane could be in the South Indian Ocean, regardless of it's fuel load.

Mr. Brooks psychological fantasy is utterly unnecessary (and dangerously misleading).  One needn't imagine a psychological pathology to explain Russia's reaction to the situation in Ukraine.  Crimea is Russia's second most important naval base -- its only access to the Mediterranean.  From Putin's point of view, the US (which controls NATO) is an increasingly aggressive (and somewhat unpredictable) power, willing to invade whomever, sometimes on transparently false pretenses.  Kiev wants to join NATO which Russia rightly regards as a US dominated military formation.  Crimea is historically a part of Russia (it was ceded by the USSR to the Ukrainian Socialist Soviet Republic when such things were meaningless).   If we want to have a realistic, functional foreign policy that actually secures our real fundamental interests, we need to be cultivating Russia (and China, for that matter) as a partner, not rattling sabers when Russia acts to secure what it (reasonably) regards as an existential interest.  The fulminations emanating from Washington are worse than pointless.  They undermine our most important foreign policy interests.

I had two black friends with middle class wages and good insurance. But both women had grown up poor and were responsible for family members. Therein might have been the problem. They both had breast lumps that they chose to put out of their minds because they felt they didn't have the time to be sick and who would take care of them anyway. When the disease became too serious to ignore, they discovered a whole group willing to help, but it was too late. And very, very sad.

It is important on what this says about our news outlets when even Fact-based News on NPR/PBS is not getting through to viewers? It is a sad state of affairs that people are more informed about world, national, and even local events from two comedians (Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert) than from "national" media sources like CBS, NBC, and ABC. But it is even sadder that people are not demanding news sources report facts rather than sound-bite opinions that they can answer yes, I agree or no, I don't agree (yes, I'm pointing at CNN). Read the report.  It does not say that any jobs will be lost.  It projects that many people will opt not to work or will reduce the number of hours they work because they no longer need to keep the job just for the insurance coverage.  This is a voluntary action on the part of workers and does not affect the need for work to be done, i.e., jobs.  As people leave jobs voluntarily, the vacancies will be filled by people currently unemployed who are looking for work, thereby reducing unemployment.  If the projection is true, that will be good news.

"Marijuana, even if consumed by children in high doses, poses few of the grave dangers of overdosing on alcohol or drinking household chemicals."
A quote from the article confirming something is wrong with our childrearing; chemical abuse is a result.
Modern society: a good or bad environment for children?
We have to decide how children are raised. Today's default is making children secondary to almost everything.
If a parent is to stay home during the school year - certainly a way to cut down on all this crazy use of chemicals - the question becomes how to we make a homemaker an enjoyable vocation? What happens during and after the child rearing stage of life?
Now we seem to abandon the homemaker during and after: what can our American society do to raise children and provide sanity to the homemaker?

There's zero discussion of the tens (more likely, hundreds) of billions of dollars Ukraine's leaders have funneled into personal bank accounts or firms. The new government (led by men who worked for an infamously murderous and kleptocratic former President named Kuchma) has even admitted that around $70 billion dollars of state assets vanished during Yanukovich's tenure. As a Ukrainian emigre, I can assure readers that this is not a singular event, but the constant the state of affairs in Ukraine since independence, irrespective of which political clique is in power.

Using a mafia with international reach, corrupt police forces, and the secret police, the political class of Ukraine (including most of the previous and CURRENT governments) has "privatized" state assets, stolen money, and extorted or ruined both domestic as well as foreign business competitors.

Freezing and starving Ukrainians (who once enjoyed first-world living standards and economic security undreamed of in the West) is not the solution. The solution is forcing the government to immediately have parliamentary elections and to run vetted technocrats instead of kleptocrats as candidates. The West should then guide that government on how to claw-back the ill-gotten gains of corrupt politicians and oligarchs, then on how to invest that money in rebuilding the country. As an added bonus, Ukraine will finally be in a position to pay off all those loans it owes us!

Except in the world of the rich today, no amount of money is enough money and losing any of it is anathema to the likes of Mr. Snyder.  An even simpler solution is for most of the fans of the team to realize they really can get along without football or can change their allegiance to the Ravens without traumatic results (or if there are, they might consider getting a life) resulting in attendance of 12,000 or so at home games.  If it sounds like I am against pro sports, I am not.  I try to listen to as many Yankee, Met and Mariner games over here in Tokyo via the MLB website as I can.  But all winter, when there are no Yankee, Met and Mariner games, life does indeed go on without trauma.  Washington fans might consider sending a message to Mr. Snyder that he needs them more than they need him.  What chance of that in a country in which people remain docile as long as they remain entertained?  Precious little, I admit.

Our commitment to religious freedom and to individual liberty defines us and inspires the world. Let's not trade one for the other.

We have already agreed that we should outlaw discrimination in employment, housing and public services, and by businesses which claim to be open to the public, on the basis of race, ethnicity, national origin, age, gender, and now increasingly sexual identity. The proposed Arizona law was too broad and a step back toward a time when there were signs in shop windows like Whites Only or No Irish.

We should also protect the right of people to worship as they please when they come together for that purpose. No church, mosque or temple should be forced to accept the membership of or to marry anyone who does not believe as they do. Similarly, this 70 year old gay retiree who is now ordained and performs gay marriages does not want to be forced to marry anyone.

Let's find a way to celebrate the growing acceptance of the civil rights of all people while we honor our historic protection of the rights of everyone to worship as and if they please. Let's be guided by what brings us together instead of what pushes us apart as we move forward.
By this logic a Hindu vegetarian should not be compelled to support government food programs that include meat.

Given the history of the C.I.A. and of the actions of Bush's Administration in response to the 9/11 attacks, this spying on the Congress makes sense.

The C.I.A. was supposed to be the point at which all the intelligence and coordination of intelligence gathering and covert operations of the U.S. government came together but the Defense Department successfully prevented that back in the 1940's. The result has been the C.I.A. mostly serving the Presidents since 1947, with covert activities and intelligence gathering at the behest of the White House, with little Congressional oversight until the mid-1970's. The C.I.A. as undertaken myriad tasks in response to one President's concerns after an other to the point of weirdness and to the failure to really understand much about the world otherwise leading to decades of one surprise in foreign affairs after another.

In this circumstance, the C.I.A. undertook interrogations methods with no proven track record and sacrificed the tried and true in hopes of quick results in response to the panic driven Bush Administration. Now they feel that they are becoming scapegoats, which they very well might be. Naturally, they want to know what kind of repercussions to expect.

I normally make it a practice not to reply to Concerned Citizen but the assertion that Medicare Part A pays for almost nothing is wrong. Absolutely wrong. Yes, a person would hope that they do not use it because what it does pay for is hospitalization, lab tests, skilled nursing and home care under certain circumstances, and some other things that you would really rather not to have to use. For example, it pays in full for the first 60 days of hospitalization after a deductible of about $1,000.

My total monthly costs in NY - a relatively high cost state - are $105 for Part B, $50 for Part D, and $230 for Medigap option F (high end). I could have gotten cheaper basic Medigap which still covered potential catastrophic costs or a cheaper Medicare Advantage plan that rolled everything into one but restricted my choice of health care providers. I am glad that I don't have to use the Part D (drugs) at all, in part because it is indeed "insanely complicated", among other things essentially requiring that one predict what drugs one might need during the next year when shopping annually for a Part D plan.
This "search" sounds so limited. What about someone well-liked and capable like Jane Lynch, David Cross, or Jeremy Piven? Why no one of color? Dave Chappelle, Don Cheadle?

And sometimes "Nazi" is precisely the wrong word and definitely over-used by those whom you'd never suspect of a tendency to over-use it.

My mother-in-law was a "survivor", a Jew who lost her entire family to Nazi murders, was imprisoned, in her case, in three Nazi camps as an adolescent and survived the experience to finally come to America via Canada after liberation, make a life, marry and rear a family. She used to characterize anyone with whose ideology she disagreed as a "Nazi". Every Republican was a "Nazi". Before she learned to tolerate me, imagine what she thought of this Republican with a German last-name who isn't even Jewish. It took awhile, but I won her over. Did I mention that it took awhile?

Israelis certainly have the right to criminalize hate speech in their own country, although it seems a trifle too official and certainly strident to an American (even though we do it ourselves). But, on reflection, it really is understandable. As time separates the younger Israeli generations from the horror of the Holocaust, which very few now alive experienced first-hand, the tendency is to trivialize the word "Nazi", when the reality is that the word stood for an ideology and actions that personified evil and nearly destroyed European Jews.

"Nazi" really isn't a word that should be trivialized.

The following seem legitimate needs to me.

a) The desire on the part of many Ukrainians to have closer ties with the EU.

b) The desire on the part of Russia not to have a hostile military alliance at their doorstep.

c) The desire on the part of Russian speaking people in Ukraine to have their rights respected and to retain closer ties with Russia.

All these desires are abosolutely compatible and it would be great if Obama and Kerry (and the editorial board) could show a little wisdom.

You cannot "punish" a major nuclear power, especially if some of the things that they say are legitimate. You cannot brush the Russian speaking Ukrainians under the carpet by repeating the mantra "Putin is a bad guy."

Please, please try to think constructively. Putin may have the troops but it is you who have the arrogance.

From reading this, I'm getting the idea that the test writers are going to a philosophy of "even when you're wrong, you're right." Quote, "The revised essay, in particular, will shift in that direction. Students now write about their experiences and opinions, with no penalty for incorrect assertions, even egregiously wrong ones." This philosophy has been slowly creeping in more and more into our society and it seems more detrimental than anything. I mean, in math and science, you're either wrong or you're right. There is no middle ground in these fields.

I think a better idea would be to have separate tests for 2-year and 4-year schools. The 2-year school test can be more tech-based like the 2-year schools teach and more comprehension. The 4-year school test could be more of a critical thinking test that most jobs these days demand. There could even be a separate 4-year school test for the math, science, technology, and engineering majors, since these majors already demand that you know a great deal of knowledge already.

The worst thing about these tests is that one test judges a whole population of people. I mean someone who's excellent in one area of the test is technically "not as smart" as another person who's maybe excellent in two or three areas of the test. That person who is maybe only good in one area is the future math or physics doctorate that gets high test scores in math but not so good in other areas.

While I agree that the death penalty has little deterrent value,  I still don't think that the death penalty is barbaric when applied under the most compelling circumstances and the defendant is guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.  Societies have for millenia reserved the right to put to death those of its members whose conduct was so far outside the bounds of tolerance as to be shocking to one's sense of civilized behavior.  Taking away one's most precious treasure -  one's very existence - was the ultimate statement of society's outrage.  It is vengeful, but it is justice nonetheless.  If we can indulge in the human emotion of compassion when administering punishment for crimes, we can also indulge in the human emotion of revenge and ultimate punishment.  "Getting them off the streets" is just not good enough in some cases, as here. Was was barbaric about the death penalty in the past was that it was applied to petty crimes as well as the most serious ones.  Provided that its commission by a defendant if factually correct, then it is appropriate to apply it in the most heinous of circumstances.

De Blasio's aggressive attention to the affordable housing problem was a major reason why I voted for him. Development is booming in this city, and I doubt very much that an inclusionary requirement for affordable units will slow that at all. After all, neither rent control nor rent stabilization discouraged development until the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970s, which was used as an excuse to gut the one, and weaken the other.

But it is absurd and defeatist to shrug and say that "federal aid for public housing is unlikely to come back." No doubt, before Section 8 came into existence in 1937, it seemed unlikely too. But federal housing support was a robust program until Reagan began to gut it in the 1980s.

We have lived through 30 years of federal neglect of cities - where 80% of Americans live. (The 2012 GOP platform did not mention the word "cities" at all, except in a single passing reference to crime.)

It's time for mayors, governors, and the Democrats in Congress to begin mentioning cities - and housing - in Washington now and then. I have some hope that De Blasio will be a bit louder on this topic than his predecessor.

The BDS does not have a secret agenda to end Israel as a Jewish state; this objective is quite explicit. As a committed Leftist, I encounter the argument against a Jewish Israel almost daily from many of my friends and academic colleagues. The recent endorsement of BDS by the ASA gives equal weight to the end of the occupation AND the end of "apartheid" inside Israel. (You can read the often contradictory claims for yourself on their website.) The Electronic Intifada site is equally clear: the authors regard Israel itself as an apartheid state and explicitly aim to end its Jewish identity.

There is an appealing logic to the argument, which sets out from the observation that the era of the nation-state is closing and that nationalisms in general promote ethnocentrism incompatible with open, pluralistic democracies. From this vantage, Zionism looks a lot like the last vestige of colonialism and ethno-nationalism. A Jewish state looks like an ethnocentric project of domination. And this line of reasoning is laid out explicitly by many leading intellectual supporters of BDS, many of them Jews, who regard Zionist appeals to the long history of anti-semitism as rationalizations for a form of racism.

Those of us who support both pluralistic democracy and the notion of a Jewish homeland are challenged to reconcile Zionism's nationalist discourse with our ethical aspirations. BDS was designed to exploit this difficulty. Its overt aim is not peace but the end of Jewish Israel.

I noticed when I did temp work that there were certain jobs that were always filled by a constant flow of temps. I remember working very hard to get hired on at a couple of places but right at the 3 month mark I would be let go. This was the routine. Why hire fulltime workers who will qualify for benefits if you can use temps constantly. One of these jobs I had required working with a printing press. On too many occasions I encountered a fellow temp itching to start the press back up (production work is fast paced) with my hand in the machine. I was lucky enough to stop that with the safety bar, but not lucky enough to have health insurance and the job paid only about $7.50 per hour. The company owner was there and his hands were a visible warning of the potential for losing fingers, yet he had a constant flow of temps there with no experience and no health insurance.

This is just one of my many work experiences and it is just one of the millions of workplace stresses that labor has to deal with daily. Honestly, I don’t understand why the Republican Party has any support when they promote idiots like Paul Ryan who mocks American workers with talk of hammocks, or Eric Cantor glorifying employers on the one day of the year set aside to honor employees. President Obama and the Democratic Party are showing us that we can do better and we should. The ACA is a proactive, positive step forward and no amount of Koch brothers funded negativity will be able to stop a good thing.

Every financial transaction on Wall Street goes untaxed. Yet, consumers pay as much as 6, 7, 8 percent sales tax on the goods that they purchase, everything from daily necessities to luxury items. Rep. Keith Ellison has introduced the Inclusive Prosperity Act to tax trades. It’s a modest tax―0.5 percent on the purchase of stocks, 0.1 percent on bonds, and 0.005 percent on derivatives―which would generate $350 billion a year.

The US had a financial transaction tax until 1966. 40 countries have implemented an FTT; 11 European countries will be phasing in a tax this year. Countries that have the most rapidly growing stock markets (China, Taiwan, South Korea, Indonesia, and others), are operating with a tax on trades. For the average investor it is not a burdensome tax.

With the extra revenue we would not have to cut food stamps, unemployment insurance, meals on wheels or home heating assistance; we could increase much-needed funding for education and infrastructure. School budgets have been cut, teachers have been laid off, class sizes have increased, and schools are in disrepair. According to the American Society of Civil Engineers, $3.6 trillion is needed to fix our crumbling infrastructure. Kicking the can down the road will only make fixing our roads, bridges, tunnels, water systems, airports, and electrical grid more expensive to repair.

Wall Street must start paying its fair share. It would make the economy more stable by curbing speculation and high-frequency trading.
We need to change how we get our energy.

The Malaysians are in a bit of a pickle, hence the announcement at this time. They mismanaged the initial search, had no control of their air space and repeatedly made numerous mistakes in assembling and communicating - and often retracting - "facts" so that in the end nobody knows anymore what is fact and what is fiction. They owe it to the families to obtain closure and are now left in the unenviable position to make a leap of faith to stand by the, admittedly most likely, scenario that the flight crashed in to the ocean and that there is no hope to find survivors.

If they did not come out now, then the Aussies or Chinese would, based on the circumstantial evidence they have collected. De facto, most of the world has already arrived at the same conclusion, so there is not that much risk anymore saying it.

Still, the main thing that remains is to find out exactly what happened, so that we can learn from it. If there was a systematic problem, it could repeat itself on another flight, with the same disastrous consequences. As a frequent flyer, including in the 777 type, I for one want to know!

The investigators must not leave one stone unturned and one detail unevaluated. We may never know for sure, but we will uncover and eliminate the potential for future incidents that could end up similarly catastrophically.

Life is a series of probabilities, almost never certainties. Let's keep the probability of a fatal design flaw or human mistake as low as possible.

After being invaded, just when Puerto Rico painstakingly had concluded negotiating autonomy from Spain, the United States in 1898 invaded Puerto Rico and made it a key naval strategic point, not just for the Western Hemisphere, but for the eastern Atlantic Ocean, as PR is the easternmost point of the US.  Unlike the Philippines and Cuba, which it let go of, the U.S. kept PR.  In 1917, Puerto Ricans were made citizens to fight in WWI. Then and thereafter, Puerto Rican blood has been spilled and sacrificed in great numbers in every single US war since WWI-- with honor and gratitude.  Doesn't that count for something? Haven't Puerto Ricans earned their citizenship fighting for the red white and blue? Puerto Ricans have been admirals and generals, and they gallantly continue serving in our military.  It is quite true the people in the island must do a lot more, but the U.S. can assist Puerto Rico a lot more than it is currently doing by : a) permanently defining its status;  b) growing its manufacturing and agricultural sectors; c) using the Dept of Justice more aggressively to root out political corruption. After China, Canada, Mexico and the EU, PR has been one of the largest trading partners of the US for decades. Puerto Ricans are extremely talented and a warm people with a heritage centuries older than the U.S. They will figure out a way out of the crisis, but let's remember they are not strangers. They are Americans.

Hi Eric, Tonight my husband and I drank the Jean-Paul Brun/Terres Dorées Côte de Brouilly 2011.  The aroma was fruity and grapey but less so than the Juliénas.  It had a nice taste, very soft.  The taste was more vibrant than what we would have expected from the aroma.  It felt smooth in our mouths, not at all complicated.  It felt alive and vibrant, but less so than the Juliénas.  It stays consistent throughout, with food or without.  It made us feel good -- it's upbeat, light, and cheerful.  The two Beaujolais that we drank -- the Juliénas and the Brouilly -- are both nice, pleasant wines but you don't engage with them as you do with a Bordeaux, a Burgundy, or many other wines.  The bottom line is that both wines are very nice, fun, upbeat, easy to drink, pleasant, and make you feel good -- but they're lightweights compared to many other French wines.  These are not memorable wines but they are good value and would be great for aperitifs/cocktails, and especially for outdoor parties.  They were better than we expected from Beaujolais, and we were pleasantly surprised.

A pathway to citizenship means comprehensive reform of legal immigration. The system now lets in 1 million annually, with a per-country quota of 25,000. If the undocumented who get legal status go to the back of this queue, and if millions of them are from Mexico alone, how exactly would they ever get citizenship under the existing scheme? There has to be a special pathway or, practically speaking, there is no pathway.

From a Republican point of view, the undocumented are unlikely to ever support their party and so leaving them without a vote is the best bet. That keeps the status quo on the jobs front. not satisfying but not inflamming those who object to illegal immigrants competing for scarce jobs in the lower tiers. It also enables them to say they have stuck to the no-amnesty principle; the way they see it, Reagan's amnesty has just led to more crossing over. They don't see the Chinese/Asian immigration analogy as apt; the numbers involved were quite small and there wasn't an ongoing influx for the obvious reason Asia is at the other end of the world.

The Democratic position is pretty much the mirror image: they are certain any new votes from this will be theirs and they have espoused a path to citizenship for a long time now. Traditionally the dems have been the party immigrants have gravitated to (think Tammany Hall). While the undocumented have broken laws, most have done so to better themselves and in the process, per the Democratic view, have bettered us all.

The real problems are not so abstract. As I understand it , the finance industry takes 2% each year of our total retirement savings in "management fees". That is the average people actually pay in fees. Those fees, like medical expenses, are paid with tax free dollars taken out of the retirement account. The result is that the money managers get a far larger tax benefit from "tax deferred" retirement savings, than the people saving for their retirement.

You can understand why they don't like Social Security. It costs less and provides greater benefits in retirement than individual savings. But it doesn't generate that 2% in fees for the finance industry.

The real crime is that the industry's propaganda about retirement savings gets repeated over and over again in the media. It has become the truth, even though it isn't true.

It takes a true fantasist to regard the poll numbers for both ObamaCare and Mr. Obama himself to be a positive sign for Democratic prospects in the mid-terms because they've "stabilized". As to ObamaCare, number of sign-ups is hardly an indication of building success, as people are required by LAW to sign up. The question is how ticked off they are at the program itself once they've complied with the law, and the polls are telling us that they're not happy.

Since the very first Earth Day in the70's, we have been told that it is time for us to change our ways; clean up our act; move forward with new, clean technologies that might stave off us polluting outselves into extinction. I was in my 20's then, and in my 60's now, and we have not changed. We have not moved forward one bit. Maybe sidewise somewhat, with new wind technology and more energy efficient transportation, but we are stuck on the brink like lemmings. What happened to the high speed rail initiatives put forward by our President? Who killed them? Why?

It is not the politics that lead this self destructive movement. It is the money, pure and simple. The industrial revolution in the 1800's all the way up to the end of the 20th Century has been fueld by cheap carbon. Coal, oil, gas; all gave us factories and freeways and huge sprawling cities. We are a Nation built on carbon; cheap carbon. Fortunes have been made.

Because the changes in our environment are slow and multigenerational, we are slow to react. The air only looks thick on still days. We are not choking, most of us, yet.

Until we decide that we must move, and move quickly the money men and "leaders" they pose before us will win the day. Even now I have a co-op here in Northern Minnesota railing against the cost of converting their coal fired plants, as if there is a choice; as if there is no need. They say it is going to cost a fortune. Whose fortune? What is the cost if we don't?

Tom, here is a proposal for your "space race" one using existing Swedish technology, not future dreams.

For me, an American living in Sweden, from an energy perspective this is such a good place to live, I cannot imagine living in an America depending on antiquated early 20th century technologies. First technologies, then benefits.

1) The "fjärrvärme" system (muncipal waste incinerated to heat water) that heats Linköping and Gothenburg.
2) "Bergvärme" (ground-source geothermal) on all scales.
3) Wind
4) Solar
5) Biogas
6) Water and nuclear.

Advantages of 1+2+5
No oil trucks, no explosive gas lines, no fumes, only small white heat exchangers in the basement, no separate hot water heaters, no landfills, reliability I never experienced in the USA. No ground-water contamination. Food waste etc turned into biogas.

Tom, never have I read in the NYT any careful presentation of the Swedish mix. All I can read there is Keystone, Keystone, Keystone.

Most Americans simply want the equality of opportunity and not equality of outcomes. Yet, they see middle class jobs shifting overseas to the lowest bidder as their own job opportunities disappear, incomes across all but the top levels stagnant, government services being cut while corporations find new ways to evade taxes, banks getting bailed out while homeowners are left to fend for themselves, and a general sense that judicial and legislative actions continue to stack the deck against those who are fighting to get by. In other words, what to Mr. Books appears as Americans wanting income redistribution is actually a yearning for a level playing field.

Unfortunately, politicians supported by his American Enterprise Institute are fighting tooth and nail to prevent the leveling of that playing field: they are fighting any effort to increase minimum wages, to prevent corporate tax evasion, to free people from getting locked into jobs for want of a safety net or because they need health insurance, and so on.

And to improve our lot in life, Mr. Brooks offers coded words that we have learned all too well imply tax cuts for the wealthy ["regulatory and tax reform … to spark hiring and entrepreneurship at all levels"] and cutting of government services for the rest of us ["education reform … through choice"]. As if more tax cuts will magically make minimum wage workers into wealth entrepreneurs and allow the poor to send their kids to private prep schools.

Cicero warned two thousand years ago about the dangers of handing the reins of government to a ruling class empowered only by their wealth. He saw as the forces of plutocracy tore apart the Roman Republic, leading to the violent upheavals between plutocrats and populist demagogues that completely eviscerated the form of government he fought to preserve.

It's well past time that the Democrats started fighting to save our republic from the same fate. And however reluctantly, I see no choice but to stand with them.

Second, The Internaitonal Energy Agency October 2013 report has proposed four policies that if implemented now could keep the GHG driven temperature increase below 2°C. I encourage President Obama and Secretary Kerry, President Xi Jinping and Foreign Minister Wang Yi to aggressively adopt these policies rather than the somewhat lame efforts of the June 2013 US China Working Group. While the US and China must adopt aggressive national laws and policies to address climate change, the US and China can lead with the EU, BRIS, and the UN. YOR COLUMN RELATES TO MY DISTRUST WITH REVOLUTIONARIES . . .

During the counterculture days of the late 1960's some on the left were talking about the need for radical change; and, now some on the right speak of radical change -- sometimes back to the past.

But, I've always asked these people: what kind of change? Back in the days of Abby Hoffman, Jerry Rubin, Tom Hayden, Jane Fonda, SDS... Some behaved in a "crazy" manner. Yes, their objections to many aspects of American policy and culture were right on. But, they only offered vague prescriptions for amelioration which made me left off.

Firstly, don't act irrationally. And, be clear as to what your new and improved agenda will consist of. Being against all sorts of things is easy and often healthy -- but, my question is: what do you intend to replace it with?

All I'm doing is making 'a modest proposal.'

I think inmates need a reasonable way to prove themselves, not only to us but also to themselves, when they are released. I realize that plenty of Americans who have not been imprisoned are also looking for work, so in this job market I don't know how we would accomplish this, but when a prisoner is released, it seems to me that they need not only bus fare, but, if not a job referral, then at least some kind of path towards employment that is viable.  I don't see how we expect them to have a reasonable chance of not relapsing into patterns of behavior that lead to re-imprisonment, if they can't get a job.

I located a Chateau Clarke, Baron Edmond de Rothschild Listrac-Medoc 2009 ($30). Being a sub-appellation of Haut-Medoc, I went for it. Paired with a tri-tip beef roast with roasted veggies and morsels of Cacao dark chocolate for dessert. Served slightly chilled and decanted only about 10 minutes. ALONE this wine was smooth in texture, balanced acidity, flavors were complex, but a little overpowering. Not much fruit on the nose, but the dark fruit and long finish were greatly enhanced by the food. It was a savory wine and was more fruit forward when paired with the dark chocolate. Very different experience from start to finish.

NOTE: We also experienced a Chateau Greysac, Medoc 2009 ($20) which was an interesting side-by-side tasting. Medoc vs Haut-Medoc has some very notable differences! The Greysac was more tannic and acidic with a short finish. Understandable there would be a $10 price difference between these wines. Is this typical of these two areas of the Medoc region?

There is a simple reason why Italians use fork and knife with their pizza, one that no one has mentioned but which Mayor De Blasio learned as part of his upbringing: Italians are very scrupulous about their appearance and the care of their clothing. Americans who visit Italy remark on how well turned out the people are. One eats food so that clothing is not soiled. This applies to many foods. Italians cut peaches, apples and most fruit over a plate and then eat it with knife and fork. As a New Yorker, I am well aware of the visceral pleasure of folding a slice of pizza lengthwise and having a bite. But there are consequences: the hot greasy liquid (not found on most pizzas in Italy) can slide down your hand, wrist and arm, giving you a burn and messing up your clothes. And that bite of scorching hot pizza burns the roof of your mouth (New Yorkers know pizza burn as much as the freezing burn that comes from eating ice cream in big slurps). Italians eat their pizza by fork so that it can cool for a moment and not cause that burn. Many of them prefer the coppetta (little cup) and paddle-like spoon for their gelato so that they stay clean and don't get gelato burn. Put another way: Italians savor their food. We Americans wolf it down, getting more pleasure in rapidly filling our stomachs than experiencing the flavors in our noses and mouths. Part of what makes Italy so wonderful is that it always has so much to teach us.   Fred Plotkin (Author, Italy for the Gourmet Traveler)

A number of people commenting have suggested that the "microaggressions"  are not really aggressive but just rude, or signs of being inarticulate.  But they are part of the language, and I tend to believe that language reflects attitudes and attitudes become part of the fabric of our culture.  So if people in the community and people you work with feel the need to express their surprise that you are "articulate for a black person," then haven't they made  assumptions about you based on your skin color without even talking to you?  Now this seems pretty benign, but I think it has an economic affect.  A person of color, or a woman for that matter, is still affected in seeking employment until they convince a potential employer that they are just as smart, articulate, able to handle pressure and work hard as the white man applying for that job. He just has to present his resume, not climb over the wall of preconceived notions first.

Bwana Currin, and others are trying to grind some other axe, not related to the impending extinction of the elephant.  The guys at FWS are pretty good at telling old from new ivory though if the animal died within the last 30 years it's not very easy.  Ivory loses fat as it ages and dries so it cracks longitudinally and radially. Finding the cracks is one way of telling, within scores of years, if your piece is old or not.  Patination is another way though we have seen some very inept fakers of patinas here in Kenya.  Back in the 1930s, there was a fashion in Great Britain for ivory handled cutlery. At that time, some of the early plastics were made to look like ivory so we know that even then there was some concern.  No works of art should be destroyed  They just should not be allowed to move, change hands, travel to other museums, cross boundaries.  AND - Prince William should give up the idea of destroying his family's ivory artifacts.  They must be kept as esthetic treasures.

Does anybody who knows a little physics understand how Inmarsat could have got more info from the pings?  Were last week's the northern and southern arcs obtained from radio wave travel time to the satellite? Or were they from the signal power which presumably depends on the orientation of the antenna on the plane relative to the satellite?  And now some sites are mentioning 'Doppler effect' - uh? - that plane's speed is a mighty small fraction of the speed of light. I wonder if any finds it amazing that I was only issued pepper spray when I worked for the Department of Corrections/Juvenile Division in California. That's it. If a riot broke out? That's all I had to try and keep some type of control until the calvary arrived. And if you ran out of pepper spray? That happened to me 5 times. Then you really understand the meaning of being backed into a corner. And many times we were out numbered 6 to 10 to 1. If myself and 2 coworkers can hold our own with 3 cans of pepper spray then I fail to see why a teacher would have to use a taser. is disgusting. If we had tasers and used them the every time a fight broke out or a guy was out on control they would have been used multiple times every day. Police have it. Understandable. But to use it in a school? Are you kidding me? We only use pepper spray as a last resort. Because there will be an investigation and they will question the use of it.
Even in a riot I never woud have tasered a guy, even if we had that available. There is no way I would ever do that to an inmate. Riots were isolated instances. How do you work with a guy if you've used a taser on him? Chances are he will sue and they will tell you to stay away from them.
I also would have been fighting for my job, as I should be and facing criminal charges. I dealt with guys that were extremely violent and I never had to use more than pepper spray to get the job done. If I could do that wtih inmates? They don't need it on kids

Stability, in so far as rights are protected, justice is fair, laws are predictable, and some dissent it tolerated, is frequently more important than democracy for democracy's sake in developing countries; especially if the alternative is chaos and spiraling civil blood shed.

While every society deserves the blessings of freedom, the path to that outcome isn't always straight and clear... I believe the military and a great number of citizens correctly realize that the path to lasting peace and freedom does not, can not, go through the Muslim Brotherhood. Did the military overreact? Maybe. I guess we will see.

More than anything, Egypt needs time. Time to develop coherent parties. Time to educate its overcrowded masses. Time for the economy to improve and tourism to return. It is hard to make important decision under the stress of a collapsing failed state. Like any constitution, changes can and will happen if necessary. Leaders will come and go, injustices will be routed out, peace and prosperity will return, the question is when, and at what cost?

As an anthropologist I bristle at this simplistic rendering of "culture." The authors would do better to follow the money. Immigrants who come middle class tend to stay that way and achieve. Immigrants who come poor tend to stay that way, too. There are exceptions, which the authors note. However, groups that succeed in this way were usually preceded by members of their ethnic groups who were better off when they arrived. Middle-class German Jews arrived in the US in the mid-19th century and the poor Russian and Polish Jews who came later worked in their factories or benefitted from the mutual aid societies they established. The first Cubans who arrived were middle class, too, establishing businesses in which their poorer compatriots worked when they arrived. Peter Kwong has done ample research on how this has worked among Chinese Americans.

Culture is complex and dynamic. Any group of people with a name for themselves has some theory of exceptionalism, otherwise they wouldn't come up with a name to distinguish themselves from others. Similarly, most everywhere you go in the world there are admonitions against being too full of yourself (though what constitutes "too full" varies). The authors' appeal to culture is piecemeal and simplistic. It is a line of argumentation that is divisive and both socially and intellectually unproductive. It will no doubt sell books, because most people like one-liners to explain complex social processes, but it is not helpful.
The ones at the bottom pay "NO" taxes. No skin in the game is part of the problem.

2009 Chateau Cantemerle: Tried this with veal chops with a Dijon mustard sauce. The wine was decanted about 1.5 hr before the meal. Out of the decanter the wine had a pleasant fruity aroma with a little added complexity from the oak. The wine had a nice mouthfeel with a good balance of dark fruit and good tannic structure, again with a touch of oak. It ended with a lingering finish of dark fruit and wood. The wine didn't change much with the meal, still exhibiting fresh fruity flavors and good structure. After sitting overnight in an open carafe, the wine was still going strong the next afternoon with lots of fruit left and a hint of some developing green characteristics. Overall a very nice wine. At the $41.50 local price, it was a better value than the Sociando. However, of the three I still rate the Bernadotte as the best value ($25 local price). In overall quality, I would give the Cantemerle the edge.

In today's world the purpose of an at home suspension is to remove a threat to safety from the school building, return a child to the custody of those who have the most legal authority/responsibility, and have time to pull all the major stakeholders together in order to plan an effective intervention. Whatever behavior/s caused the need for suspension, the problem will require the energies of parents, guardians, the teachers, the support staff, the administrative staff and likely the community and the courts in order to resolve it.
As an administrator who needed to call parents up and have them pick up their kids (Head Start) and occasionally call the police to arrest trespassers (emancipated minors who refused to leave the building after being suspended) suspension was NEVER a punishment. It was the beginning of due process.

It is true that one cannot associate any particular extreme weather event with global warming. Global warming is a relatitvley slow process that changes only the average and that change will remain hidden under natural fluctuations. However, when one changes the mean of a distribution it necessarily leads to higher probability for what were low probability events to occur. Scientists are correct in predicting that what used to be rare will occur more frequently. We know how expensive extreme weather can be, thus the economic cost of continuing to increase the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere can eventually overwhelm even developed countries. Those most vulnerable (like Bangladesh) will become basket cases.  This article would have been much more useful if it had bothered to make that point rather than insist that raising the alarm does more harm than good.

I grew up with a father who sailed and a mother who hated it. One summer we took our small sailing boat up to Block Island. That said, the sense of adventure and the ability to deal with fear and risk, these are key parts of who I am today. I am sorry you had to experience this. No one should be touched against their will.

I had a similar experience occur in NYC nearly 15 years ago when I lived there. I did not report the incident to police. I merely walloped the offender over the head a few times with my bag (to the cheers of nearby women who could guess at what had just occurred) and hurried in the other direction towards an appointment. This incident occurred in Manhattan, however, not in a gentrifying neighborhood. I associated that assault with the offender, not with the neighborhood where it occurred or with his race or even his gender, as most males clearly do not engage in this behavior.

For that reason I find it curious that you connect your sexual assault with gentrification. Had you been assaulted by a white man in a neighborhood where whites are the majority would you have felt as conflicted as you do? I doubt it. And even if you are part of the force of gentrification you have to know you shouldn't expect assault.

That being said when you move to neighborhoods that are not as safe you do have to stay aware of your surroundings, put on your "don't mess with me face" and attitude on as you are out in the streets and be prepared to get aggressive to scare a potential offender off. NYC is still the big city. I applaud you on beginning the work of unpacking this experience, and encourage you to continue on that journey as it is clear that you are still grappling with it.

I attended Howard University from1979 - 1983. I share my reason for attending Howard with students in this article . I graduated from a predominantly white high school. It had a strictly engineering and science curriculum that was short on history and non- existent on African American history. In fact , my entire educational resume at that point was void of any African or African American history. I needed to know who we were and from where we came. My grades and SAT scores afforded me the opportunity to go to a variety of very good institutions. I did not plan on going (to my parents well hidden dismay) to any other school. In my freshman year I enrolled in Black Diaspora taught by Pro. Suggs. It validated my choice of schools. I became a committed fan and a respectful servant of my race and racial history. Although I was an economics major and business minor, I continued to pepper my course load with African studies where I could. On summer break and weekend trips home, I tired my parents and family with the vast history of our race. A history that was lost on students of public or private education, at least in my city.
I give to Howard, as well as my law school ( University of Maryland School of Law) on an annual basis. I will, without hesitation increase my assistance to Howard. Howard instilled a pride in me that invigorated my life and influences my idealogical beliefs and daily pragmatism to this day.

A few relevant background facts on the religious nature of this issue:

Under religious law, the husband has to give the "Get" fully willingly in his heart, in order for it to be valid. If he gives it under duress of any sort, financial pressure, public protests and embarrassments, or threats of (or actual) violence, then the subsequent Get document is invalid under canon law and it is as if it was never given and the couple remain married.

Canon law does not require a husband issue a Get simply because his wife wants one. Depending on the circumstances of the individual case, canon law may or may not require the husband to provide a Get to a wife who is requesting one. If religious law is being followed, a demand for a Get can only be implemented if it meets religious laws requirements that allow it to be involuntarily demanded.

There are some very rare circumstances where religious law permits coercion on the husband to compel a Get. Although under these exceedingly rare circumstances even physical coercion may be permissible under canon law, due to civil secular law prohibiting the use of violence it is not an available option.

In the U.S., civil law and authorities are not an option in compelling a Get be issued due to the Constitutional separation of Church and State provisions.

Mr. Krugman conveniently forgets the Japan Story. They have been trying to stimulate their economy for 20 years. in fact, the first 10 years of that program are known as "The Lost Decade". Stimulus creates artificial demand. It's akin to blowing air into a balloon with a hole in it--the second you stop supplying air, it deflates. Now, Japan has a national debt twice the size of the U.S., exacerbated no doubt by the earthquakes and tsunami. But Abe's attempt to re-inflate the economy with stimulus spending is failing--and now economists are talking about "The Lost Decades". Artificial is artificial--it never works. It can't--it's artificial.

If we truly want to re-inflate our economy, there is only one sure-fire way to do it--cut government spending to the bone--stop confiscating 35% of all paychecks--and drastically cut payroll taxes--so that employers can afford to pay their employees more. If you let Americans keep more of what they make--there's one thing we know for sure---they WILL spend it. And that's the only kind of stimulus we need. When real money is spent by real consumers for real things they want and need, THAT is stimulus, not phony, artificial government spending stimulus that Mr. Krugman prefers.

The authors claim: “[A]s recently as 2007, close to 92 percent of law-school graduates reported being employed in a paid-full-time position nine months after law school. True, the employment figures had dropped by 2012, the most recent year for which data is [sic] available, but only to 84.7 percent.”

They’re misreading the chart.

ABA data for the class of 2013 (http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/administrative/legal_educatio...

Nine months after graduation, 57% of graduates had long-term full-time (LT-FT) jobs requiring bar passage. Another 5% held part-time or short-term positions.

LT-FT “JD Advantage” jobs went to another 10.1%. The category includes positions for which many graduates are now asking themselves whether law school was worth it.

Another 4% got law school funded jobs.

Unemployed law graduates seeking jobs increased to 11.2%.

Average law school debt exceeds $100,000. The rate of tuition increase in law schools between 1998 and 2008 exceeded colleges and medical schools.

For 33 out of 202 ABA-accredited law schools, the LT-FT JD-required employment rate was under 40%; for 13 schools, it was under 33%. Federally backed student loans that survive bankruptcy fuel a dysfunctional system that has prevented the very “market mechanisms to weed out the weakest competitors” that the authors cite as the ultimate cure.

If those don’t add up to a crisis, what will?

Look at it this way: Any liquid nicotine excesses from over-production can be converted to insecticide.

That stuff will probably kill bugs and varmints faster than anything currently on the market.

The article is accurate, but the issue more deeply rooted.  Hong Kong has no child care system.  That means people wealthy enough to employ domestic helpers can get child care, and people not wealthy enough have virtually no other option besides one of the parents staying home and not being employed, which is a good way of keeping poor people poor in one of the most unequal societies in the world.  Then, the people who can afford domestic helpers get them from countries far away, largely the Philippines and Indonesia.  Many helpers are themselves mothers who leave their own children behind to take care of other children in Hong Kong.  Taking care of other people's children  might make sense if, at the end of the day, you can return home to your own children, but the law in HK requires employers to allow the helpers to return home (and pay for the trip) only once every two years.  Helpers are on special two-year work visas and are not eligible for permanent residency as virtually all other foreigners are.  If they lose their job for whatever reason, they have two weeks to find another or else they must leave Hong Kong, making it very difficult to leave an employer, even one they might not like.  Hong Kong has a large class of low-income full-time workers living in poverty (most poor people in Hong Kong work full-time jobs), on top of which it imports 320,000 domestic helpers. It is able to do this because of systematically exploitative labor practices across the region.

The most meaningful thing Steyer could de to address climate change would be to address the root cause of climate change, economic growth. "Unlike the Eastern European countries that have been incorporated into the European Union and NATO, Ukraine shares much of its history, and industry, with Russia ..."

This is all the more reason why the West, especially the United States, should be, not only sensitive, but more importantly wise in dealing with the current turmoil in the Ukraine, if we are to avert another cold war, which may escalate into something more serious.

Immediately after the collapse of the former Soviet Union, our previous Administrations rushed into approving the incorporation of several of the Eastern European countries, that were part of the former Soviet Union, into, not only the European Union, of which Russia might have been understanding, but also into NATO, which Russia viewed as a challenge and a threat to its own security, which it has not gotten over until this day.

We need to avoid repeating such a challenge, which Russia might this time find intolerable, which we should want to avoid, if we are earnest about maintaining good relations with Russia, and are serious about wanting to avoid a dangerous confrontation with Russia.

We should therefore work very closely, not only with our European allies, but more importantly with Russia, in order to find a peaceful outcome to the conflict in the Ukraine.

I have many colleagues in Germany. They are physicians and psychologists. They all have private solo or small practices. There are some geographic restrictions on specialists in each area, but it is based on patient need.

Germany is a primarily single payer system although there are numerous insurance plans. They are not primarily for-profit, however. Medical care in Germany is excellent. If you are accepted, medical school is free. Physicians are highly trained, more than US: MD's must also do PhD level research dissertations (not required in US). Medications and procedures are similar to, and often more advanced than US.

Health plans cover more services that US, including rehab, post-natal, post-surgery programs, etc. Each town has a mobile ambulance that goes to the home and provides most care; the ER's are used only for true emergencies. Of course all this is paid for by taxes but most citizens are quiet pleased with the care they receive. This system has existed for decades and is not related to employment, as in USA. There are no "networks"; you can choose any MD you want and stay for years if you want. There is little "corporate" medicine.

I have received some superb medical care there while visiting, and I know my colleagues' abilities and training are excellent. Paperwork is simplified (even in Germany!) and costs are reasonable since there are not huge exec salaries, lobbying costs, advertising costs, network maintenance costs, etc.

Can we learn from this?

I think you have confused the physical printing of text on paper with a book.

I own far more books than I can fit on shelves. I would have thought this a not uncommon phenomenon. All of them have been read, many multiple times, but it is now the case that I can't even remember what I own, nor find an old book when I need it. Many of these are soulless mass-market paperbacks, spines broken and dog-eared from being pushed into a pocket as I leave the train.

My Kindle changes all that. It's always with me, small enough to slip into my coat pocket every day, allows me to pick up a book to fill any dead time rather than spend it idle. It's completely changed my purchasing habits; I now buy books at a much higher rate, and always new, which I believe is better for the authors.

I believe that paper books will benefit, just as vinyl records have, from the removal of the mass market. Volumes will decline, but expensive and beautiful hardback editions will dominate the market, for printed books will have become true luxury items.

It is arrogant and ridiculous to conflate the issues in this article - about long-form literature - with the debate about whether that is best expressed on cheap paper between cheap covers, hand-inscribed upon vellum, or presented upon a screen. The story is the important thing; to deride the story as "just words" is to miss the point altogether.

Three huge, insurmountable, issues for ESOPs:

1. They aren't really portable, while also requiring some period of consecutive work in order to achieve vesting -- five years, typically, at a minimum. The companies set this parameter, and can set it whatever works best for them, not the employee.

2. The corporate board or management ultimately holds all the cards in these arrangements, and can change their terms whenever it suits them, not the employees. Very few -- if any -- companies would willingly put salaried or hourly workers on their boards to represent their interests.

3. These programs only apply to private sector companies, and gives them enormously beneficial tax breaks to set up ESOP.s No such tax break applies to the employees, at least as most such programs are structured. Guess who wins in that trade off?

We protest Russia's anti LGBT hate campaign not because they are the worst, but because they are a world leader among nations who are reversing course on basic human rights. We protest because the rest of a homophobic world, that criminalizes love, looks on as Russia is honored with hosting the Olympics in defiance of the Olympic Charter, while encouraging atrocities against a vulnerable minority. Celebrating Russia while it conducts a state invoked hate campaign against gays is atrocious. Pouring development money into any nation that abuses the weakest among them defies all morality.

We have few means to leverage human rights in nations where longstanding human rights abuses are codified into laws and institutions of government, but we had the chance to deny Russia the international honor of hosting the historic Olympics. The world turned the other way, and is complicit in the horror unfolding there today.

Take action now at Sochi. The world is watching. All those other nations that criminalize love take note which way the wind is blowing, and people of good will who stand up for justice and human dignity must speak out loud and clear that state sanctioned hate crimes will not be tolerated, and the perpetrators will lose all standing and moral authority among nations.

Russia is not the worst, but they are leading the world in a most dire direction.

The letter quotes prices/kwhr for future nuclear use at 8.4c/kwhr which is not greatly different from current best residential solar power installations (12c/kwr) They mention the accidents, including the three meltdowns at Chernobyl and Fukashima (2 cores) but point out that loss of life has not been huge. What they do not include in their cost analysis is the cost of clean-up and the permanent loss of homelands to thousands of people and the massive disruption of the regional economies that these disasters cost. The forecasted clean-up cost for Fukashima is estimated by the authorities at above $5B dollars. This does not include the economic or social costs of the ongoing displacement of 200,000 people. You could argue that with over 400 reactors in operation, the cost per reactor from disasters is not high but the failure rate is certainly very much higher than claimed.

Nuclear power gets enormous subsidies from governments when they pick up the costs of insuring and regulating the industry. It makes sense that solar and wind power sources be equally protected. These types of power production are heavily capital intensive with low operation/fuel costs. While they make sense over the long run, the risk from short term energy cost variability frightens off investment.

As has been pointed out, you are never going to see a headline "massive solar spill kills thousands."

As Devinsky and Friedman know, the underlying causes of many convulsive disorders are difficult to specify and the choice of the medication(s) for treating such disorders is empirical (if it works use it). Many of the medications available do not work or work only poorly for many individuals with epileptic disorders, which is part of the reason that the search for better anti-convulsants continues and many drugs are introduced that add only minimally to the ability to control seizures in the general population (me too drugs). As one responsible for teaching anti-convulsant medications to students in the health care professions, I am often skeptical about the value of new drugs that don't produce effects better than drugs that are already available, and are usually cheaper. Sometimes, however, the new drug will produce remarkable effects in a patient who is refractory to other anti-convulsant medications.

Cannabidiol may well fall into the category of providing considerable relief to only a select few patients, and be only minimally effective in others. This is what science and research will clarify. To claim that the drug has not been compared to a placebo, however, is inaccurate. Charlotte has been administered many powerful anti-convulsants, and for her these are the placebo. CBD for her is therapeutic.

Would the Supreme Court rule against the 36 states who are ignoring their Constitutional mandate to secure lives? No.

I am not sure the Heritage Foundation was ever seriously research driven, but it certainly isn't now. But those who say that DeMint's foundation isn't driven by ideas are wrong. The problem is that the foundation's ideas are so pernicious.

A deeper problem is the tax exempt status of essentially private political organizations, regardless of whether they are conservative or progressive. Under the influence of a conservative Court, we have bought into the idea that funding of essentially ideological organizations is good for democracy as long as it is even-handed. Why should we think this? The best even-handed way for a democracy to deal with private political organizations is to require them to pay their own way. This applies both to Heritage and to Brookings (though I believe Brookings is devoted to research). We have, or are supposed to have, universities that are devoted to research. Public universities are supposed to be impartial think tanks. Let's make them work.

Inequality is an after the fact, outcomes based measure of opportunity.  America has always been seen as the land of opportunity and most of us grew up believing that we could surpass the successes of our parents if we applied ourselves in school and later in work.  The growing inequality of outcomes suggests that this is no longer the case in America, if it ever was.  Wealth, not hard work, begets wealth, and the political system is rigged in favor of the wealthy and powerful.  Solutions to America's growing inequality problems lie less in the areas of taxation and redistribution which do nothing to address the root causes, and more in the areas of reforming the electoral process to give every citizen equal voice, eliminating the pernicious effects of gerrymandering through non-partisan redistricting, regulating lobbying activities to ensure that the will of the people is not overwhelmed by a few billionaires in setting government policies, and leveling/integrating the education process to ensure that everyone gets the same shot at success regardless of social and financial inheritance.  It's more complicated than this but significant reforms in these areas would go a long way toward restoring the self-reinforcing perception that America is truly the land of opportunity.

I can't help noticing that that no mention was made in Brooks' essay of the Prodigal's reform. "When he had spent all, he began to be in want. And no man gave unto him." He was so broke that he was living in a pigsty, a particularly repulsive image to a Jewish audience and eating "husks". But no one enabled his pseudo-wealth by "giving" or lending to him. But he had good basic upbringing by a father who was confident enough of his values and teaching to let this bright, attractive, impulsive boy grow up in his own way. Maybe that is why the parable could stipulate that "when he came to himself " he could turn around. "I will arise and go to my father, and I will say, Father, I have sinned against heaven and in thy sight: make me as one of thy hired servants."

Brooks doesn't note this, only that the father receives him joyfully, having recognized the metanoia that has taken place. He is restored to full status in the family. The Elder Brother's pique is understandable, but the dad could have told him up front instead of finding out from a farmhand; that side of the story stumps me, and I've played every role in this story except the fatted calf !

To apply this to society. We know the values, as we have played the Father. We need the reform, as we play the son. We are in the right, as the Elder Brother, but we have to temper our outrage even as we assert our rights. Then we can find ways to find that our real "portion" is fully available.

“The main task of the court is to confer legitimacy on the fundamental policies of the successful coalition,” according to the author's demi-god Robert Dahl. I disagree, 100%. There is no support for this position whatsoever in the Federalist Papers or any other recorded Constitutional debate. The mission of the Court is to be the final arbiter of disputes arising under Federal law, and to resolve disputes between sovereign states. The whole "checks and balances" tri-partite form of our government tells us that the drafters of the Constitution expected there would be times when the Court would issue rulings counter to the prevailing Congressional or executive mood of the day. (Remember Andrew Jackson's displeasure? "The Supreme Court has made their ruling; now let them enforce it.") This is why the Dred Scott and Korematsu decisions are universally regarded as the worst decisions ever to emanate from the Supreme Court, because in each instance, the Court put the Constitution aside and demurred to popular passion. Look at Miranda, Gideon v. Wainwright, Loving v. Virginia, Brown v. Bd of Ed., or Roe v. Wade as examples of the Court going where it thought the Constitution required, regardless of whether the decision might be viewed as popular or predictable. Is the Court "political?" Yes, because judges are human, and humans are politicial. But that's not why we have a Supreme Court.

And yes, the willingness of English people - and it was mainly the English - to vote for Tories led by a Toff like Cameron shows that they haven't learned anything from their past (not that many countries do). Meanwhile the current PM leads a privatization of the NHS which few people support, while offering no more leadership in building Britain's future than fatuous cheerleading for a "march of the makers," without any coherent plan to make it happen.

Scotland can do better then this, even with RBS to worry about.

There is one thing that this Opinion Article overlooks.

The author of the article assumes that, whenever the US administration issues "threats," it means them (or it should mean them). Hence, the article calls them "empty" when the US does not deliver on them.

But what if the US issues warnings without the least intention of acting on them? There can be many valid reasons for issuing stern warnings that the US knows (and the nations on receiving end know, too) that it will not fulfill. And it is not as if this is the first time such war of words have happened. It is not what one says, but what one does, that matters.

For decades, the EU dangled many carrots before Ukraine but scarcely delivered them. The EU was prepared to go only so far. Unlike in the Balkan war, which was really a European problem but the US sorted out on behalf of Europe in the name of NATO, the US will not agree to be entangled in the Ukrainian matter. Europe should sit up and recognize that, to the US, it is becoming more like an ex who only embarrass the US.

At least, the gloves are off now and the US and Russia will not tiptoe around each other pretending nice any longer. With the pretenses gone, the US and Russia might even become the new best friends.

All "system 1" pretending to be "system 2", the essay about depth is superficial. Imagining that "nature" relegates us to instinct while the pre-frontal cortex elevates our capacity is a captor of Cartesian duplicity: mind/body alienation contrived to further scientific inquiry and escape the inquisition. The big breakthrough, for some, in neuro-biology is that there is no mind absent a brain and that brain is as objective as is the liver. The distinction that our large brain provides is both advantageous and strangely self delusional. We can plan, based on memory and experience but must recognize that our memory of our experience is largely and invention with little resemblance to the events. Simply put: our thoughts are a fabrication of our thoughts and what governs what we think is shaped by processes that are as instinctual as they are "deep". More disturbing, even our deepest thoughts likely arise from derailed instincts, delayed and reflected upon reflexes.
The theme in this column and in David's agenda is to provide a narrative that justifies greed and privilege. Complexity causes "cognitive fatigue" which often relegates our "system 2" intent to "system 1" impulses. "when we say someone is deep, that they have a deep mind or a deep heart, we don’t mean that they are animalistic or impulsive." but we should recognize that they are animalistic and slow thinkers.

Here is how dumb opposition to PK's argument is.

Basic math - from BLS 2012 numbers
3.4MM minimum wage or less workers
Avg 28 hours work week
50 weeks/year (assumption high side)

Total wage base is $34 billion very high side - figures 1.9MM under minimum wage workers at the minimum.

Even if you double the wage...With a total GDP of over $16 trillion - the cost of doubling the minimum wage is $113 per capita (total population 300MM,) or 0.21% of total economy/year - spare change.

I would bet that 95%%2B of that money would be directly returned to the economy, in purchase of goods and services. Great for growth, no?

This article is all about tactics and implications of tactics. It doesn't say much about whether there is a fundamental US national security interest justifying intervention in the first place. There is no doubt the events in Syria are horrifying - a President engaged in mass murder and destruction of his own people and country for the sole purpose of clinging on to power at any cost. This must reflect how much of their own malfeasance the Assad family does not want revealed in the event of an ouster scenario. All that said, unless the fundamental security interests of the USA were at stake in the outcome of the civil war in Syria, the case for external intervention is difficult to establish; alternatively, there would need to be a UN Security Council mandate based on international agreements protecting civilian human rights in a conflict situation. The fact that other countries have already intervened in the Syria conflict does not necessarily justify US intervention, again unless there were basic US national security interests at risk. To date, as far as I know, we have not seen that argument played-out. All that said, one wonders how this carnage and wreckage will end and a country somehow restored so that refugees can go back home, rebuild their shattered lives and live in peace.
