Why, Mr. Brooks, must it always be "either-or"?
Is it not possible to embrace aspects of the Johnson and Montaigne philosophies - to have a personality and points of view that are broader and more inclusive than an absolute? To continually probe and constantly re-examine - and not merely stake out a position and hold it in a vise? To embrace "and" if you will.
For example, we can protect citizens' privacy "and" prevent terrorist attacks. We can have sensible gun legislation "and" protect the rights of hunters and sportsmen. We can make sure children aren't condemned to poverty "and" have a robust economy. We can have gender equality and religious freedom. In encouraging a choice between Montaigne and Johnson (and leaning toward Johnson), Mr. Brooks is casting his vote in favor of the polarization that is crippling our country.

The map accompanying the article is extremely revealing in that it shows that those areas which have witnessed demonstrations and civil unrest fall almost exclusively within the western and central Ukraine west of the Dnieper River. Historically, much of this region fell within the territories of the Kingdom of Poland and later the Austro-Hungarian Empire and today they contain majorities of Ukrainian speakers. The eastern (lands east of the Dnieper) and the southern Ukraine, including the Crimea, appear to be relatively quiet.  These regions have majority or significant ethnic Russian, Russian-speaking populations.  Significantly, voting patterns in recent years mirror these historical and ethno-religious divisions in Ukraine.  For example, majorities in the western and central Ukraine in the last election voted for Tymoshenko, while the majorities in the eastern and southern Ukraine voted for Yanukovich.  Historical experience and the ethno-linguistic demography of Ukraine are thus key to understanding current developments.  The lands that formerly formed parts of the Kingdom of Poland and the Hapsburg Empire, not surprisingly, feel an affinity with Central Europe, while the lands east of the Dnieper and south (the lands to the north of the Black Sea known as New Russia in the late 18th and early 19th centuries) are more closely linked to Russia.

There is little to argue about when it comes to the righteousness of the cause of investigating and vigorously prosecuting sexual assault in the military or anywhere else for that matter.

However, there was no injustice in this particular case. The sexual assault component of this case fell apart because the credibility of the accuser was lacking. She was reportedly revealed to be a untruthful about a number of important elements of her claims. The case collapsed because the witness's
story collapsed. This case was no failure of the system, no failure of policy, no failure of effort by the investigators.

Sometimes those who are accused of wrongdoing are not guilty. It doesn't mean other cases should not be investigated or that sexual assault is not taken seriously. It just means that in this case, with these facts, with the evidence available here, the the proofs were insufficient and the accused pleaded guilty to only those charges for which there was adequate proof.

Next case.

I read his piece and also found time to watch his presentation. Some of the key points I drew from the video were not what he emphasized in his article, not surprising when summarizing a book, and when some of the interesting points were actually in the Q&A after his talk.

He points out that energy presents other problems besides climate change, that are separate drivers for de-carbonizing the grid:

1 - inexorable rise in price of commodity fuels when there will be 4 billion more consumers than now

2 - Moore's Law-style advances like those that have collapsed the cost of PV panels simply don't apply to fossil fuels because so much of the fossil fuel cost is tied up in extraction, delivery, cleanup of pollutants.

3 - wastefulness is expensive to profit-driven corporations. An interesting example: Walmart only sells concentrated detergents, since they don't want to waste truck fuel and shelf space for bottles mostly full of water.

He does also point out that governments, esp. resources like US research programs and universities, are a critical part of both the technological development as well as the legal and managerial know-how that needs to be developed - fast.

The other important bit is that, with the world globalizing rapidly, making the cities ever-more efficient will be crucial. We should be aiding developing nations to develop efficient, cheap ways to build durable AND energy efficient buildings and city infrastructures.

In the good old days, a dictator had more freedom to articulate power through without much immediate rebellion from the masses. The American people (and leaders of foreign governments deemed friendly to American interests) are being asked to accept the NSA's program, and the validity of its underpinning legal foundations on faith. It's a "debate" without facts that comes down to our government saying, "trust me."

We all know there are people out there with a strong desire to terrorize our country. We also know that what distinguishes us as a nation is our Constitution and the protections we all grew up thinking would protect us from unwarranted (no pun intended) intrusions upon our privacy.

Given the debacle that is our Congress, and the polarization of our political leadership and fellow citizens, is it really so difficult to prove to the American people that this program is worthwhile? The argument is that the government would have to release classified details to do that. Hogwash.

While I don't know the best way to do it, I do know that common sense says it can be done. Instead, on one of the most important matters affecting this generation and their children to come, we get bland reassurances from people no one trusts. This is what bothers me most - that we aren't considered trustworthy enough to be given just enough information to prove, or disprove, why this loss of our privacy is necessary.

I love my country and that includes the rights I was born with as an American. I would be flexible to protect us but can't be flexible when I'm told I'm not trusted enough to know why I have to be.

Rather than using pre-existing conditions to "blame the victim" here, it seems clear to me that the conclusion is that military experiences, predictably, further aggravate such disabilities. As with any profession and probably especially in the military due to self selection and limited life choices, some recruits will have few coping skills, resilience or other personal resources to begin with, and of course they will be more vulnerable to problems.

Many veterans I have encountered with mental health issues have had non-combat stresses or trauma, through training accidents, workplace bullying, sexual trauma, motor vehicle accidents, etc. etc. Unstable personal relationships (a break up with a significant other) and impulsivity, often escalated by substance use, often seem to be "the last straw" that causes someone to talk about pulling the trigger. Chronic pain issues don't help - individuals may feel their pain is being "undertreated" when only opiates seem to help, or else they are vulnerable to all the risks that come with these medications.

Impulsivity is key - given enough time to work things out, I believe most people really can figure out how to live with their problems. But one "bad day" or moment can end it before they have the chance.

"We should particularly recommend the printing and circulation of a recent communication made to the Academy of Medicine by Doctors Piedelièvre and Fournier. These courageous physicians, having examined, in the interests of science, the bodies of the condemned after execution, have considered it their duty to sum up their terrible observations thus: ‘If we may be permitted to present our opinion on this subject, such spectacles are horribly painful. The blood rushes from the vessels according to the rhythm of the severed carotids, then coagulates. The muscles contract and their fibrillation is stupefying. The intestine undulates and the heart produces a series of irregular, incomplete, and convulsive movements. The mouth tightens, at certain moments, into a dreadful grimace. It is true that the eyes of a decapitated head are immobile, the pupils dilated; fortunately, they cannot see, and if they exhibit no signs of disturbance, none of the characteristic opalescence of a cadaver, they at least have no capacity for movement: their transparency is that of life, but their fixity is mortal. All this may last minutes, even hours, in a healthy subject: death is not immediate. . . . Thus each vital element survives decapitation to some extent. There remains, for the physician, the impression of a hideous experiment, a murderous vivisection followed by a premature burial’ . . .

==Albert Camus, Reflections on the Guillotine

The flaw in the research here lies in its apparent assumption that the Hebrew word used in Genesis for the animal under discussion, "Gamal," was always meant to refer to the animal we call a camel. But traditional Jewish Rabbinic sources have always admitted to their own confusion about the correct translation of the animals referred to in the bible, particularly in Leviticus 11. The contemporary translations of many of those animals is entirely unclear. The fact that Ben Yehuda, in constructing modern Hebrew, decided to call a shafan a "rabbit" does not necessarily mean that the shafan in Leviticus 11 is actually a rabbit. Likewise, the gamal referred to in Genesis is as likely today's "camel" as it is a horse or some animal we are unaware of today. Basing archaeological conclusions on the vagaries of modern Hebrew usage discounts the often arbitrary nature that went (and goes) into the construction of modern Hebrew. In this particular case, Ben Yehuda may have thought the "G" of gamal and "C" of camel somehow made it an easy match, and I can relate to that temptation on his part, but it was probably either a guess or, at best, a tenuous connection. Any Rabbinic scholar who was showed this article or the research would say, "So what? Whoever said a gamal is a camel? Let it be a horse." Translation is always inherently flawed and necessarily inaccurate.

I'd suggest that we avoid the temptation to charge a technology with social aims. The potential for immense social distraction in an arms race to better censor on one side and to protect against censorship on the other misses the point, which is that some societies are by nature abusive and some are not, and it is these basic characteristics that we should parse and not the technology itself. Use of the technology will naturally follow more fundamental social compulsions.

As a general matter, we should develop far better protections against denial of service attacks, because these permit abusive societies to impose their will on communication within non-abusive societies. But, as a general matter, the notion that a technology should not be controlled by a society in its use within that society is highly suspect, not to mention probably pyrrhic -- the problem from liberal western precepts is far deeper than the technology.

It should be up to Russian and Chinese citizens to determine what is appropriate for them to do, not a west insistent on its own values. Having already made our own decisions in this matter, we should focus on supervising our own governments to assure that our own elites are not imposing their will over us; and leave Russia and China to those populations.

I am a Russian-American living in the U.S., and have been reading NY Times coverage of the Winter Olympics during the past few days. While I am not a supporter of president Putin's government, far from it, and am very aware of all the problems that Russia faces today, I am disappointed with the NY Times coverage of the event.

I was not expecting to read glowing reviews about the organizational aspect of the games, but NY Times (and many other sources of U.S. news media for that matter) seizes every opportunity to present Russia and its culture in the negative light. Whether it is making snark remarks about the opening ceremony (which was stunning), or about the Russian food (which, naturally, is not catered from McDonald's) - the NY Times has presented Russia to the American readers just like, I dare say, during the good ole Cold War days.

It seems as if being in Russia is a very painful experience for the NY Times reporters covering the event, and I am sorry that this is the case. In case you were not aware, Russia boasts a rich culture, worth an article or two. Integrating so much politics into a great sporting event is not necessary.

While I am honored to be American, I am also very proud of my Russian roots. I wish that a trusted news source, such as NY Times, would dedicate some of its reporting to that as well.

I have had MS for almost 19 years now, diagnosed at age of 30. I was a competitive runner in college.

Kayla, you really got me with "Coach, I don’t know how much time I have left, so I want to run fast — don’t hold back". If if you are reading this - don't stop what you are doing. Live your dreams. There is no guarantee about anything in life. Yes, what you are doing now could have a long-term consequence - but it may not as well. If it does have a long-term consequence - you will look back on these times with great pride glad that you made this choice, that you showed the world what you are capable of while you still could.

I am fortunate in that I can still run, but only when it is cold. I do it not for time any more - but to say that I still can. It is a great feeling. I hope that 20 years from now you can still run, not for time - but to show that you still can. And as you run, think back to these times and smile with pride that you did it while you still could.

I've worked for over 20 years in both magazines and on the web. I believe you've idenfiied some interesting differences between the web and magazines, but you've focused on the wrong problem.

The problem is not long-form or some web sites' desires to now offer long form, whether it's a fetish or for whatever other reason. Good for us.

The bigger problems, as you do seem to identify, are bad judgement on the part of the journalist and bad editing decisions. On top of that, is the way people now respond to an article -- on Twitter rather than after weeks of chatting at cocktail parties and the water cooler and maybe writing a letter to the editor.

There are hundreds of homophobic and transphobic and racist articles littering the patrician magazines of yesteryear, and they all occurred for the same reason as this one did -- bad, biased judgements. Instead of taking to Twitter, groups of people privately praised these articles, and wrote letters to the editors, while others -- often members of the offended groups -- became angry and wrote letters or even staged protests. Sometimes they all engaged in discussion but maybe it was four to six months later.

So, the problem here is lack of education about transgender people, that's it. And, rather than playing out over a period of months, an effort to educate actually occurred much sooner after these very bad editing decisions, and people were informed more quickly and hopefully some learned from a tragic situation.

Virtually none of the posters here make any serious attempt to grapple with the tough constitutional issues raised in this case. Hobby Lobby is a privately-owned company whose owners do not believe women should use contraceptives that disrupt already-fertilized eggs. The gov. says that Hobby Lobby must nonetheless provide that type of contraceptive to its employees free of charge, under the provisions of the ACA. You are free to hate Hobby Lobby, free to boycott it, and its employees are free to quit or to pressure the company to change its policy. Regardless, the question remains whether the gov. in this instance has a sufficiently compelling interest in forcing a private business owner to violate his religious beliefs.

Friedman confuses two entirely different sets of issues.  He is dead on in his criticism of the folly of our government in expanding NATO to the East without including Russia.  But he is dead wrong in seeing Putinism as the cause of Ukraine's plight.  Ukraine got itself into the mess it is in without assistance from Russia.  It is now on the verge of becoming a failed state, and it is understandable that Russia would be alarmed about this.  The United States would certainly be alarmed if a similar situation emerged in Canada or Mexico.  The issue of protecting the rights of Russian-speakers in the former Soviet republics has been a central concern of Russian foreign policy since the collapse of the Soviet Union. These people woke up on January 1st 1992 as inhabitants of foreign countries that were hostile towards them.  In an article published in 1993 in NATO review, the strongly pro-Western former Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev naively expressed his hope that NATO would help Russia in addressing the problems of former Soviet citizens who had lost their country.  NATO did not help, and Russia was to weak to help.  There are serious flaws in Friedman's general analysis of Putinism, but this is not the place to deal with them.

From a strategy perspective with insight gained from having a son being deployed, I suggest the following:

The strategic goals sold to the American people were overly ambitious. We cannot transform a tribal society in a very poor country with no resources, no traditions of centralized government, and myriad ethnic groups. Nor can we convert a conservative Muslim society to a 21st century worldview.

Military solution is the wrong paradigm. There is literally no ribbon, medal or promotion for withdrawal. The US Military command is not designed to pause, reflect, and withdraw. They're a hammer and they seem to focus on nails, asserting that with just a bit more time, personnel and resources they can win.

On the other hand, the boots on the ground are trained tactically to consider the goals of the mission and avoid unnecessary risks. Of course, the boots have 100% of their skin in the game.

From recent books (Sec Robert Gates) and other reading it appears to me that Obama had a clear view of the likely outcome, but was willing to give the military and their very vocal supporters the opportunity to find a "victory" among the potential end states. "The enemy gets a vote" is one way of viewing the changes. "The citizens of Afghanistan get a vote" is actually more important and something we avoid considering.

Perspective matters. Putin sees rabble-rousers that threaten his military intersts in Crimea. He also sees and hears Ukraine Russians declaring their loyalty to Russia and asking for help. That's how he's legitimizing his actions. He knows that the we, in the West, value human life and human rights and believes what he's doing is what we might do if the shoe were on the other foot. After all, he concludes, Crimea used to belong to Russia.

On the other hand, we in the West fear that Putin is out of control and will go further if he's not stopped.

Thus based on our dire perspective comes a need for threats that make no sense to Putin's perspective. We and Putin are simply not on the same page. And that's probably the reason Angela Merkel stated Putin "isn't in touch with reality." He's not. But it's the West's reality he's not in touch with.

And rather than making rash statements, we more than likely won't follow up on, we must do a better job ourselves with communication and managing conflicts like this. We need to consider all factors involved iincluding relevant history, as well as the personality, psychology, and nature of acting-out world leaders. Beating our chest does little good regarding this situation and the ego needs of Putin. As difficult as it might be, active listening and respectful dialogue plus objective professional mediation with Putin, that saves face, would have probably been the best way to go.

What a good selection of interesting, intelligent comments on the inflammatory issue of guns, which often provokes mere shouting matches. It looks as if mandatory sentencing is approved of by just about no one in the general public whom it ostensibly is designed to protect.

I'm sympathetic to Mr. Shuler, who's a good case for why judges need discretion and why the prison system should be humane and give individuals a real chance to do better. I must disagree, however, with the writer's statement that "'violent' crimes, a category that encompasses a range of charges, such as breaking and entering, … may involve no actual physical violence." In the legal tradition, crimes committed "per vim", "through force", would include actual violence but also physical coercion, such as waving but not discharging a gun. You don't carry a gun while breaking and entering unless you think you might use it, and people who hear their home being broken into in the middle of the night do indeed experience that as an act of violence.

If you carry a gun, you've declared your willingness to do violence, even if you've never before committed any crime. Judges shouldn't be compelled to impose unjust mandatory sentences, but the convicted criminal who carried a gun during a crime should face harsher penalties as posing a greater danger to society. We ban guns for parolees because we recognize Second Amendment limitations in connection with criminal activity, potential or actual.

I was an exchange student in Dublin in 1978-79, and spent St. Patricks' Day 1979 there. Half of the participants in the Parade on O'Connell Street were American. And the locals were a little honked off that a holiday that many saw as American in emphasis required the closing of the pubs (which is no longer the case). The REAL St. Patrick's Day Parade is a solemn march to the Shrine of St Patrick in Knock, in the West of Ireland.
One of my professors at Trinity College was openly gay, which, in 1979 in Eire was a big deal. I understand that he went on to become a Senator. He was also an expert on the writing of James Joyce, and we spent a couple of weeks on Ulysses in his class. His name is David Norris, and he's a far better exemplar of what being Irish should be than Timmy Dolan is, and it's not even close.

Ezekiel Emanuel and his brother Rahm were the leading White House opponents of single payer and public option.

The plan the Emanuels gave us was the right-wing Heritage Foundation plan.

As a result, the costs of Obamacare are twice as much as Canada, or any other developed country. If (or when) you have a chronic disease, you pay $8,000 a year.

The burdens are greatest on the middle class -- they're the ones with the money.

The biggest problem is that people in the Medicaid plans won't get access to specialists at academic medical centers. If they have cancer, or multiple sclerosis, they can no longer see their own specialists.

The other problem is enormous co-payments. If you have chest pains, and call an ambulance, you can pay $300 out of pocket.

Emanuel is correct that people are less likely to get recommended preventive services if you charge them for it. However, Obamacare also imposes charges which discourage people from preventive care. If you get a free mammogram, and it's suspicious, you then need a biopsy, which can cost you $2,000 out of pocket. Asthma medication is also preventive care, but under the silver plan you have to pay for that out of pocket, so people skip medication and wind up in the hospital.

The surprising fact no one has responded suggests many things here. But the statement about the Thomas hearings that "...feminists tried to bring down a Supreme Courts nominee for sexual harassment--but really for his conservative stances..." threw me. Always a bit concerned when anyone lumps "feminists" into one group, whether it's a Rush follower or a more liberal-minded sort. But the idea that outrage about the brutal treatment of Anita Hill by Clarence Thomas, congressMEN, and the public at large was just a cover for outrage about (vaguely suggested) conservative stances sure misses a lot of nuance--and truth. As for Clinton, plenty of feminists were indeed outraged. Yet are we to sit out an election for "feminist principles"?

That "feminists" might support a Bill Clinton or anyone else often has as much to do with the alternative. A person can vote or sign legislation in ways unrelated to their personal behavior--for better or worse. In terms of the official roles they have occupied, Clarence Thomas behaved badly AND is unlikely to do anything to support "feminist" arguments; Bill Clinton behaved badly, yet was quite likely to support feminist positions in his public role. That too many men lead with their "little brain" and too many women let them is unfortunate. But that Dowd agrees that feminists "betrayed their principles" in a political world where pragmatism about policy is what gets things done (when anything can get done) means Paul's redirect worked...on her.

There have been several times in my life when a loved one or co-worker suffered a terrible injury or death. I found myself paralyzed, unable to to call or visit. When my mother was diagnosed with breast cancer I pretended it didn't happen.  I was racked with fear. I assumed that if I ignored my mother's illness then it didn't really happen. Or that I didn't want her to see me worry. It's a crazy reaction and I understand how loved ones seem to disappear when something bad happens. I'm ashamed of my behavior but somehow I convince myself that I couldn't have handled it any better. Yet in the case of my coworker, I want so desperately to talk about her loss. To tell her how incredibly sorry I am for her loss. But it comes back full circle and I figure it's better to say nothing at all.

Warnings of dire consequences can produce remarkable social changes. Publicity about the consequences from smoking brought about a such a significant sociological change that it defies common logic. Only a few decades ago people smoked st their desks. Business meetings were characterized by their "smoke filled" rooms. The air in restaurants and bars was saturated with fumes from burning tobacco. University students were provided ash trays on their desks. Even many physicians smoked.

However, scare tactics worked. We live now in virtually a smoke free world. Reflecting on the way it was it is truly stunning to consider what a huge reversal occurred in our daily existence. It is almost unimaginable that such a sweeping change could have been engineered and executed. But it happened because of relentless dissemination of information about the consequences of public smoking.

It can happen again concerning global warming and the climate. Scare tactics about something as devastatingly consequential as this make sense (and experience teaches us that they can bring about revolutionary change).
Right about that. A total contradiction in terms.

Mr. Blow posits correctly that it's easy to demonize an unknown other but asserts that "it's in this context that we can keep having inane conversations about the 'habits' and 'culture' of the poor and 'inner city' citizens." However, my personal experience has been exactly the reverse.

I was raised and schooled in economically (though not wholly racially) segregated enclaves of San Antonio, Boston, and Connecticut. Being an open-minded person with liberal values, I would have argued vociferously against such "inane conversations," citing structural and historical disadvantages against minorities. After all, any minorities I knew around me were of the same education and socioeconomic level as myself. I couldn't see that we were fundamentally any different, skin color notwithstanding.

Then I moved to NYC. Living and working in various areas of Brooklyn where gentrification and housing projects coexisted and co-mingled changed everything. I worked as a branch banker with low-income customers and co-workers who'd grown up there; I met them, heard their stories, saw how they managed their lives and finances. From my own relationships and observing parent-child and social interactions around me, I began to realize: "Wow, we really are different."

I absolutely do believe now that there is a culture of poverty, not that I blame any of those raised in it for their circumstances. I just hope innovative programs like KIPP and Providence Talks can help make a difference.

Compare the speculators with people like Elon Musk who bet everything he had on innovative manufacturing start-ups Tesla Motors and Space Exploration Technologies (SpaceX). His motivation wasn't money (though that for his first entrepreneurial adventure, PayPal, might arguably have been); it was to speed the introduction of an environmentally friendly mode of transportation in the first case, and to help make humankind a multi-planet species in the second. He believes, rightly, that unless our species spreads out from Earth, we are doomed at some point in the future to extinction. People like Musk use wealth as a tool to improve the world. The Dark Lord of Redmond is similar. Bill Gates v.2.0 has been giving away billions to fight diseases and spur education. If your only goal is to become rich, then speculating in the market and cashing in on 3 milliseconds worth of advance knowledge may seem like a worthy and worthwhile occupation. But don't think you're smarter or better than others because you've caged a golden goose. You haven't added liquidity to the market place except in the sense that you've made it diarrheic.

Rita:

No, the Endangered Species Act is not to blame for people building in dangerous places. However, the people who seek to limit legitimate and lawful use of land, through repeated, expensive and excessive court challenges to support conservationist causes may well have a lot to do with it.

A lot of voters just don't trust such environmentalists and conservationists any more, and their excesses have poisoned the well when it comes to rational land-use legislation. Yet rational land-use legislation on a national basis is precisely what's needed to minimize occurrences such as the Oso, WA landslide catastrophe. Frankly, I think such legislation could pass, but only if it's clean and not confused with other, highly controversial objectives.

Hydraulic Engineer:

You merely argue your ideology (and your occupation), while I took some pains in my comment not to attack it but to assert that it's controversial because it accepts just about any social and financial cost for what many believe are excessive protections and meager results. But I came to praise uncontroversial land-use legislation, not to bury conservationism. Your ideology isn't the point. What is the point is that we probably could get that rational land-use legislation if only we don't adulterate it with other, far more controversial objectives.

IMHO, all HS college applicants should spend the first year at a community college.  Some of the best teachers I ever had taught in a community college.  It was upstate CT, bucolic, and many retired professors and NYC police brass were my teachers.  They wanted to live there, exquisite lake in town, and I learned more about the real world, the law, and NYC than I ever thought I could, along with the standard model of Western education.  I also met my partner and his partner (complicated) who were the first gay people I ever thought I met.  I am sitting in our house, 40 years have passed.  And the NYC police people were real world, enjoyed the friendship of my New England teacher friends, were scholars in the vernacular of my youth, and in the law, and in retrospect it was wonderful.  Yes, freshmen year, attend a community college. When the teachers ask you to come to dinner and if you can remove some downed trees from the chicken coop roofs, say, "Yes!"  Benedictine after prime rib is very tasty when you are a young eager student.  My English professor used to say, "This is all part of your universal college education, dear."  He certainly was correct.

One of the usually unspoken reasons our criminal justice system, especially our prisons, is largely dysfunctional is that we do not have a consensus as to what the system is supposed to be doing.

The varying names we use make that clear: prison, correctional institution, rehabilitation center, penitentiary, etc. Each implies a different purpose. Are we mainly trying to punish people, prevent them from committing more crimes, deter others from committing crimes, rehabilitate people, extract vengeance, assuage the pain of victims, provide justice, or what?

Unless and until we have a broad and fundamental national discussion regarding objectives, we will get nowhere with "reform." It is not sufficient to know where we want to leave, if we are trying to develop the political will to make change. We also need to know where we want to go.

The criminal justice system has numerous constituencies, from those who stand to profit off the misery of others to those who have a passion for justice (that in itself a collection of variously defined constituencies) to those whose approach is primarily moralistic (also variously defined) to those who fear becoming victims, and many others.

Bill, I hope in your new capacity you will advocate for a clarification of purpose, before you get totally immersed in policy. We need to all be speaking the same language when we speak of "criminal justice", before we can be successful in creating the political will to make substantive change.
We still haven't even sorted out how to distinguish a non-patentable discovery of a property of nature from a novel means to exploit knowledge of a fact of nature.

Welcome to our Police State here in America. To our dishonor, 9/11 has become an excuse for law enforcement and our criminal justice system to ratchet up brutality -- even when it comes to misbehaving children. We have allowed our fear of the 9/11 bogeyman to goad us into allowing sadistic law enforcement personnel to brutalize the population. The United States was already the most violent nation on earth prior to 9/11, but post-9/11 we have blithely embraced our demons and don't hesitate to unleash them on anyone (inside or out) that we perceive as a threat.

The United States, like all great empires, is in a steep decline, and it shouldn't be too many more years before we find ourselves at the mercy of all the people and nations we've bullied over the past 40 or 50 years.

Texas appears to be a paragon of tolerance compared to Arizona and fellow traveler states. Moving to Texas during 1968's turbulent Vietnam polarization and outrage over the anti-war agenda of hippies, we thought it best that my husband shave his beard for the long drive through what might be hostile territory. After all, the news covered a Midwest incident in which a long-haired white man, wrestling with a gang slashing at his hair with scissors, was rescued by a group of young black males who knew all too much of discrimination. We were relieved to find little animosity to our early Northern 'invasion'. The state really was 'Texas Friendly'.

So, these decades later, the politics of polarization and demonizing 'the other' have gained sway in Arizona: the business community rides to the rescue, saving the rights of citizens from outrageous tampering.

This time the diabolical splitting of the voters by the party of Divide and Conquer centers on gay rights. News anchors have questioned where such a law would ultimately end: how much diversity should a person have to 'tolerate' if religious beliefs were offended ?

In a country priding itself on freedom of belief, this is democratic heresy in a war waged against the very freedom they defend. The irony would be amusing were it not for the deeply disturbing politics it exposes for all to see: open discrimination and intolerance.

This story in not yet finished, and already the Cassandras are predicting a dire end (yet again) for Ukrainian democracy.

Putin has spent his last shot. He had, arguably, the right to defend Russia's only exit to the Mediterranean Sea as a strategic necessity. He might even be able to convince the Crimean russophiles to vote for rejoining Russia. (After all, the Crimea as a Ukrainian entity was designated by Khrushchev during the period of the Soviet Union, which no longer exists.)

But, if the Ukrainians of the east decide, in a similar vote, to remain within the Ukraine, then our story stops there - and Russia will have to accept a new status-quo. That is, no russophile oligarch running the Ukraine from Kiev.

It's worth stating the real cause behind the bigotry that Bruni so wonderfully skewers here -- and why this discussion is such good news.

Homophobia is the product of the enforcement of a limited set of male characteristics that define who is accepted and who is not. What homophobia does is make the homophobe afraid of being identified as homosexual, and, therefore, cast out from the group. This is why gays may always have been present in a bigoted environment, but the status quo was maintained as long as they stayed closeted.

The good news is is that as more gays are accepted into previously closed arenas, the equation changes. The fear of being cast out for being perceived as queer is reduced, even eliminated, and the enforcement of a homophobic regime becomes unnecessary. Indeed, increasingly it is the bigots that will be mocked and shunned. Times change. Hallelujah!

I agree with commenters who balk at the prospect of getting rid of the test all together. The problem is not that there is an objective test. It's that the test was measuring little—and very precious little that relates to college-readiness (i.e., critical thinking). Please, keep the test—throw out grades! They are certainly the least dependable of all national measures of graduating high-schoolers' thinking abilities.

You know what they should bring back? Analogies. Although the author mocks them for using ten dollar words, an analogy's structure tests the ability to make difficult, non-obvious logical connections, to read carefully, and, yes, to retain information and meaning of words. Plus, they were darn fun (sometimes you learned a new word or three). Those "tall weeds of nuance" are exactly what I wish my students would attempt to familiarize themselves with—because when they do, they end up thinking.

I was a freelance for many years, and I loved it despite the financial uncertainty. When health insurance costs began to spike out of control in the late 1980s I had no choice but to become a fulltime employee. To link one's health needs to a particular place of employment never made sense.

The possibility of losing one's job - and therefore possibly one's health and life - has created a work atmosphere in which employees are constantly afraid. One doesn't raise questions; one takes the cautious route; one does not risk disagreeing with a colleague or boss. Because without that health insurance, you could die. Or your kid with a medical condition could die.

Now I can afford to go back to freelancing for the first time in 20 years. I don't plan to - I like my job. But I am free to speak up more, to exercise my judgment. I will do better work as a result.

The Tsarist dreams of a powerful and expansive Russia live on in Putin's policies. Russia has desired to move to the center of the world stage since at least the time of Peter the Great. Expansion of its domain from a bleak interior to the seacoasts, and holding sway over all the Slavic-speaking peoples, has motivated its rulers, reaching its glory days in Nikita Khrushchev's ("We will bury you") Soviet Union. One senses that Putin is trying to resurrect this Russian dream of hegemony after the turmoil following the breakup of the USSR. And he's willing to call on any philosophic writings that help further that end.

Will he succeed? The U.S. and most of Europe will oppose him at every turn. Neither wants Russia to become a powerful state that dominates Western Asia and Eastern Europe, as it did formerly. Russia might be tolerated in that role if it were a true democracy. But a regime that stifles dissent, as Putin's does, is democratic in name only.

Russia has long been an enigma. It is one of the most cultured countries in the world (think of ballet, for instance), but has also been dominated by thuggish rulers with an appetite for viciousness. It has aspired to being a world leader but has been held back by feelings of inferiority. It pinned all of its hopes on an idealized communist system, only to have it collapse. Now, Putin is trying once again to make Russia a world power.

I have an MBA from Harvard (was there with Bill Ackman as a matter of fact) and I have worked for a Hedge Fund. I've heard both sides of this argument. One that he is immoral and should be put in jail. The other that he is just legally operating in the system that is out there (so therefore not his fault). I do not buy the latter argument. In our ethics course at Harvard we were taught not to think just about the letter of the law, but to think about how something would look on the front of the Wall Street Journal (in this case it's the New York Times). The bottom line is that whether or not this falls on the right or wrong side of the letter of the law, it does not pass the smell test and looks awful on the "front page of the Wall Street Journal". Again, forgetting about the letter of the law or what's allowed and what isn't, both Bill Ackman and Linda Sanchez should be ashamed of themselves. The financial system that I learned about and loved has disappeared. Banking and finance are a service to help our economy function properly. We have more than enough evidence that regulation in its many different shapes and forms does not work (LIBOR scandal, mortgage derivatives, etc), so it's time to do what Obama should have done in his first term which is to nationalise the banks. Banking needs to be boring and (only) slightly profitable again - only then will it properly serve the people it's meant to serve fairly.

Only then with additional efforts at cutting costs and improving preventative care, the US could approach the lesser cost and much better health care outcomes provided by numerous other countries with single payor health care systems. I became an amateur astronomer at 15 and worked as an aerospace engineer for thirty years on mostly NASA projects, occasionally even rubbing shoulders with an astronaut or two. I spent several years working on Viking, the original project to put two spacecraft on Mars. I think highly of all or efforts to get and maintain a human presence in space. However, I have never though that long-term missions such as putting an astronaut on Mars would be worth trying until we have someway of creating artificial gravity. And once on Mars the problem doesn't go away. Gravity on the surface of Mars is only one-third of that on Earth. The Moon of course is even worse. Only one-sixth of Earth's gravity.

To understand the true significance of this, I think to we have to realize that not just mankind but all life and life's process evolved under the influence of gravity at a specific level. The fact that humans walk upright speaks to a concept that is meaningless in zero gravity. The shape of the human body is a tribute to gravity. To speak of colonies where humans would live for extended periods without some form of gravity approaching that of Earth's to me is unthinkable. To put an astronaut out in zero-G space, and then patch up the body to make it tolerate the condition for years or perhaps even permanently I see as a futile exercise. We should understand and know how to treat the conditions, but end the end, astronauts need gravity. It is indelibly a part of who we are.

These revelations strengthen the case that Gov Christie is unfit for office. Thank you for pursuing this.

But what took me by surprise was how Gov Cuomo himself partnered with Gov Christie to manipulate public opinion on toll increases, so as to jointly burnish their image:

"The day before...the vote on the increase, Mr. Christie and Mr. Cuomo released a letter declaring that they had found a way to lower the toll increases — for cars, the cost would go up $4.50 by 2015, rather than $6 by 2014. 'We are pleased that our work together resulted in lowering of the original toll increase,' they said."

This is appalling: a pair of governors from two different states knew full well that they did no such thing, that this was a total lie, and that the entire set of events was orchestrated just to fool NJ and NY voters, treating us all like rubes.

This is an assault on integrity in public discourse and is far more serious than a mere toll increase. How dare they?

Gov Cuomo needs to answer for his own role in this charade.

The thing about lying in politics is that once a politician is caught at it, nothing else that he or she says can be trusted.

Gov Cuomo may have just reached this point, fittingly, in a team effort with his good friend, Gov Christie.

Now let's see him talk his way out of this. Because the evidence presented here doesn't look good, and we New Yorkers are entitled to answers from our own governor for his role in this outrageous attempt to dupe us.

While I agree with the authors that many of the arguments against GMO food are more emotional than fact based, there are some things about GMO seeds that are truly objectionable.  To start, the traits of these seeds easily spread to other plants, and Monsanto has been very aggressive in suing farmers when those traits appear in fields that have not been sown with purchased seeds.  Such cross pollination is inevitable, and not always desirable -- a farmer growing for the organic food market really does not want his/her crops to have those traits, and beyond that the legal action taken by Monsanto needlessly increases the cost of those organic foods or forces the farmers out of business.  Even more objectionable, though, is the fact that some GMO seeds are designed to produce crops that do not themselves produce fertile seeds, and that trait has also been shown to spread to other plants.  This is clearly insane and a great danger to the entire world's food system.

One significant difference between the old and new Port Authority is that, prior to the mid-1970s, when the administration that had operated the old Port of New York Authority for thirty years retired and new managers took over, the PA promoted from within and remained independent of most political influence, a negotiator with its own assets that could not be pushed around by either the governor of NY or NJ. The managers came up through the ranks, with loyalties to the organization rather than partisan political interests, and were well-versed in their respective areas of expertise: i.e., they were professionals.

When the old guard left, the politicians took over -- exactly what the former managers of the old PA warned could happen -- with the result that money was wasted on pet projects, politics governed what was or wasn't built, funds were mismanaged or wasted -- and the public interest fell by the wayside.

The blueprint for a reformed PA is already in existence; it's the professional, independent PA, with strong leadership, that built airports, bridges and the WTC. The old leadership warned against bringing in politicians to run what was then a successful agency with abundant funds and a public mission. The politicians could not wait to get their hands on all that power and money, and crumbling airports and corrupt managers are their legacy.

If you live an extremely high rent city but are not enjoying a well above average income, then move! That is something that I and many of my contemporaries learned at least two generations ago while living in NY as young business execs and professionals. We enjoyed being in NY, but realized that -- while it was a great place to cut your teeth for experience -- it was a place to leave once affordable housing for a growing family was a matter for serious consideration. Most of us (recent vet/college grads) did move, and we prospered thereby. It was true back then and apparently is no less true now.

About the only ones in my immediate group who stayed were those working as Wall Street traders, who were on the way to making big bucks in a locally centered industry.

Then again even Warren Buffett moved back to Omaha and continued to do well -- after Columbia B. School and a few years of working in The Big Apple. Same school, same age, but not one of my old acquaintances, I regret to say.

The fact is that most others can earn as much or more elsewhere, where the money goes much farther. Don't cry: make tracks! You will not regret having done so.

Failure to report accurately about enrollment by most of the media, from across the entire political spectrum, is truly disheartening.

#1. It does not matter how many "young people" sign up. All that matters is how many "currently health people" sign up. Under ACA, insurance companies can (and do) charge older people 3 times as much as young people. Therefore, one healthy older person is worth three times as much to the insurance pool as a single healthy younger person.

#2. Under ACA, "young people" can stay on their parent's (typically) large company insurance plan for a major portion of their "young people" life time. Therefore this insurance improvement provided by the ACA actually results in a decrease in the percentage of the "young population" that would sign up on the exchanges.

#3. Those who do not qualify for Medicaid subsidies are likely to sign up "off exchange". The "off exchange" market continues to exist just like it did before. A person only needs to use an exchange if they want Medicaid subsidies. That requirement is to help ensure Medicaid dollars are not spent on "junk" plans. This also means the exchanges will show a disproportionate level of Medicaid subsidized sign-ups which actually means nothing because non-Medicaid sign-ups are simply happening "off exchange".

#4. Under ACA, the insurance companies are allowed to risk share between their plans, so an imbalance in plan sign-ups is not hugely significant.

One obvious exception to the fallacy of Say's law is innovative new products. Innovation gets people to part with their money!

When it was introduced, the iPhone was a new category of cell phone. iPhone sales grew rapidly in the midst of a deep recession, making Apple the world's most highly valued corporation. Other companies introduced other iPhone-like smart phones and the iPhone-like smart phone market grew rapidly.

So, the key to growth is innovation. The key to innovation is innovation funding. Unfortunately, too little has been done to increase innovation either in the United States or abroad.

A primary investment tax credit would rapidly increase overall innovation and this would result in much greater economic growth.

The US passed the Jumpstart Our Business Startups Act, which removed imaginary barriers to angel investing and, as such, might not increase angel investing as much as hoped. Angel investors were able to invest as much as they wanted to without the Act. So, what difference will it make? It does nothing to give Angel investors any more incentive to invest than they already had.

A primary investment tax credit would give Angel investors greater incentive to invest. It would also give investors more incentive to put money into venture capital funds and for corporations to invest more in innovation.
This would greatly increase overall innovation, which would, in turn, create rapid economic growth despite the fallacy of Say's law.

I taught special ed students in Chicago Public Schools, both elementary and high school  I also taught in a suburban system and a university reading clinic.  I am now retired.  Mental health needs are not limited to "inner city schools" and poor parents, as everyone should know.  There are also less expensive ways of dealing with both family and student problems.  The need is the WILL to do it.  It is also true, as I found out, especially in the high school, that the school is a needed refuge for students who live in dysfunctional families.  What is needed is redirecting the money to what is really important -- children's needs-- not tests which service the politicians both in and out of schools who claim they are for education, but starve it.  Bring the community and the schools together and work on the problems together, including ways to help students who may need to be separated from their peers for therapeutic, not punitive reasons.  The mandates of Public Law 94-142 have been distorted to support Inclusion of all in one classroom as the interpretation of "less restrictive environment." " Less restrictive environment" really should mean what is best for the particular student's needs, not putting a needy student back into the general classroom that did not provide for him before.  Policies at all levels, including federal, state, and municipal, need to be changed.

Charles, lets talk about what fundamentally needs to change for families stuck in the cycle of poverty (regardless of race): most important, parents need to pass down and enforce the right values to their children - hard work, focus on school, no free time until homework is done, etc. We have seen first-generation Asian immigrants, often poor, do this flawlessly, and their children end up going to great universities and becoming highly economically successful.

There's no reason why other "inner city" communities can't have the same level of success, but it has to start with the PARENTS. And if the prospective parents don't have the skills to enforce these values in their children (perhaps because they never learned them themselves), then we either (1) should ensure that they "get educated" on how to be good parents or (2) find ways to discourage them from parenting until they can be good parents. Otherwise, we're just creating another generation that won't be prepared to succeed in a very competitive world.

Education needs to play an important part, but without parents enforcing these values, even great schools can't enforce these values onto students. And all of the other issues you mention will disappear once great parenting - and subsequently, great education - become realities for this community.

So stop spending time on sideshow discussions, and help figure out solutions to truly break the cycle of poverty in our "inner city" communities.

El-Sisi will undoubtedly win the election. That's typically what happens when the main opposition party is outlawed and its members are hunted down and killed in the streets by the hundreds. And when he does, the U.S. will likely recognize his government and restore whatever aid was lost in the interregnum. Because that too is how it works. Soaring rhetoric notwithstanding, the rulers of the US prefer a reliable strong-man in power in Egypt to the messiness of a real democracy.

It is not surprising that El-Sisi has an amen chorus here singing his praises. Bloated by billions in annual aid from the US, the torture-happy Egyptian military dominates large swathes of the Egyptian economy, and decades of military rule have fostered strong habits of allegiance to the armed forces, especially among the propertied classes who view it as their best protection against the unwashed rabble of the urban and rural poor.

There is little question that Morsi was bad news as well. But by outlawing the Muslim Brotherhood, the armed forces have sent a clear message that no serious political dissent will be tolerated. The causes of the 2011 Revolution, however, have not disappeared. And if the workers and students and other ordinary Egyptians feel that they have no real chance to express their will through the ballot box no one should doubt that they will find other ways to fight for their rights.

It's not a matter of ignoring the Jones Act. Typically, States and counties get salt supplies based on an average winter.
This year, winter is much more severe, and salt supplies have been depleted earlier than usual. They need to resupply, and to do this they need to ship from wherever there are salt inventories immediately available.
If, as in this case, salt is located close to a US port that is not regularly served by US flagged vessels, they are indeed stuck by the Jones Act. But if one had to plan systematically for this kind of rare catch 22 situation, states would have to get large oversupplies of salt, which would be costly to store for all the winters when it would not be required.
In passing, note that salt is also supplied from foreign sources, including far away ones such as Chile, South America; but this requires a long lead time which is not workable for emergencies.

Jack,
"With this kind of logic states should take care of their own national security." No. Federalism divides power between the states and the Federal Government). The constitution gives the Federal congress ENUMERATED powers including the following and more related to national defense:

To declare War, grant Letters of Marque and Reprisal, and make Rules concerning Captures on Land and Water;
To raise and support Armies, but no Appropriation of Money to that Use shall be for a longer Term than two Years;
To provide and maintain a Navy;

The Tenth Amendment clarifies that most of the rest of the powers not enumerated for the United States go to the states as follows:
“Amendment X
The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people.”
In my opinion, Federal power has been stretched over the last 100 years by interpreting certain enumerated powers like the commerce powers to be much broader than intended.
Prior to the 17th amendment the Senate which makes and pass Federal laws and confirms SCOTUS judges was appointed by the States. Now with Senators elected, the states seem to have less influence though the constitution did not change much.
John

To move the convergence ahead and preserve the Jewish identity, Israel needs to come up with Knesset2.0. Ditch the British style parliamentary system for the American model. Strong leaders have been the norm as Prime Ministers, so make them Presidents. No coalition/unity govts., just congress-style majority/minority rules. No proportional representation, winner takes all. In 1948 it may have made sense to give a voice to every group and sect in Parliament. Now as a mature nation that can go.

PropRep leads to identity politics, winner takes all leads to more centrist politics. e.g., if we had Proprep in the US, David Duke and the KKK would be in Congress, as would Sharpton & Black nationalists, plus assorted sectarian groups. Make Tea Party look good.

This might help Israeli politics match its citizens better, and lead to better things. 1968 to today the US has come far, so can Israel.

While I like Francis-- for his humility, amazement and disgust at his "stardom," and views of mega wealth as a religion all its own-- I find his characterization of the sexual abuse scandals jaw-dropping. At a minimum he should have admitted the church's culpability in shielding priests and paying huge sums to settle nasty lawsuits. The whole debacle is a blight on the church and key reason for the mass exodus of congregants.

So I certainly wish Francis had owned up to these crimes in addition to blasting love of money and trickle down economics in countries like the US with growing poverty levels.

But the other thing I find fascinating, more from a cultural perspective, is this oblique nature of his words. The author's statement “But his words are always calculated and a bit enigmatic.” couldn't have been better described. This leaves us with a world full of weary and spiritually longing Catholics reading whatever they want into Francis' "elliptical" utterances.

Folks have made Francis a blank slate on which to write their own deepest desires: for more pragmatic views on sexuality, marriage of priests, ordination of women, and everything else "modern" they want to see in Catholic teachings and practice.

And I think is very dangerous, because words only go so far without action to back them up. It could create further backlash and alienation of Catholics if they don't see real changes regarding the roles of women and men in the church.

When 80 years ago I was an Irish boy of five I was taken on vacation from my Lower East Side home to a farm owned by an old uncle. He showed me his horses that stood in the barn like giants one of whom looked down at me as if he knew something that I didn't know. The horse suddenly reared and let out a terror of a cry, leading my uncle to say that I had an Irish gift for being forewarned by horses of impending dangers that will befall others. Speaking out of years with that gift, and having seen Liam Neeson, I advise our Mayor that Neeson has spoken to the horses, he has that gift,  and should the Mayor fail to listen to Neeson's advice, the Mayor may end up on a farm for retired horses,  shoveling manure in the rain, all as foretold in an Irish superstition.

So why is this ridiculous cost passed on to the consumer?  It is fine to ban plastic bags.  But to pass the cost on to the consumer is a regressive tax.  The author quotes a television writer as having 40 replacement bags at home.  That’s great for her.  Curious how many lower income folks have these bags lying around? Why not ask instead merchants to give customers using their own bags a 10 cent discount? For an elected body to mandate (yes, mandate) that the consumer pay a fee is an outrageous abandonment of their constituents.

The ADA is a bad law, so no need to ratify it as a treaty as well.  While full of good intentions, it is a classic case of what happens when you separate cost from benefit.  The federal government requires everyone to spend large amounts of money to build or retrofit buildings and other projects without any regard for whether the cost is really worth the benefit.  At one place I worked, they spent days and days, and probably thousands and thousands of dollars, to make sure the elevators would beep each time it went by a floor, to help blind people.  In ten years, I never saw a blind person use those elevators.  I bet if the federal government were required to pay for that retrofit, it might have decided that that wasn't really worth the cost.

As Hannah Arendt argued as she reflected on the atrocities of WW2 and specifically of the fascist genocides, the "banality of evil" is the most insidious there is. It creeps up, it slips in, it sneaks and crawls into the life of an entire nation, until it becomes part of the normal and unexceptional daily routine and way of thinking of that nation.

Those who do not understand the problem of the banality of evil are doomed to repeat it.

And that, right there, is our problem. We have no understanding of how evil does not always come in epic forms, but more often creeps in on cat's feet into the soul -- and the laws and the prisons and the politics and the values -- of a people.

It's been public knowledge for many years, and he did speak about it with regret. From today's piece in the Times magazine: "Matthiessen’s double life in Paris would come to an end in 1953. He began to be disillusioned by the C.I.A., which in his estimation was filled mostly with Ivy League stuffed shirts who didn’t know or care anything about the poor people whom the communists were trying to reach. He was also repelled by the anticommunist witch hunts taking place in the United States. The environment as a whole 'pushed me leftward,' as he put it. He has said that his stint as a spy was the only of his life’s adventures that he regrets." (You can read the whole article, which has more detail, by clicking the link in this obituary.)

I would argue that Mr. Matthiessen was indeed a great man, because he spent the rest of his long life not only writing beautifully but also advocating for the environment and for human rights. And maybe one reason he did that was because he was so unhappy about that early mistake.

I remember buying "How We Die" on a Saturday afternoon and learning via phone the next morning that my father had died in hospital in Trinidad. In great distress I flung the book across the room, denting the spine. My mother, knowing I was unable to travel home to be with father, (with whom I had been very close), had chosen not to tell me that he'd been in hospital at all. The  irony was too much. Later, I read the book with deep fascination. Culturally, I had been exposed to death from an early age and the physical decay Dr. Nuland detailed actually helped my grieving process. My sister and my mother had been able to care for my father, even in hospital; reading the book somehow grounded the experience that I hadn't been able to share.

More than a few have probably noticed how Christie bears a behavioral as well as physical resemblance to the most reviled of leading conservative promoters and operatives: Ailes, Limbaugh, Gingrich, and Rove. All of them bullying, conniving, and ultimately repugnant. Together they remind one of those Gilded Age caricatures of political hacks and robber barons that so influenced public sentiment. It's not without humor, but still an unpleasant association.

Regardless of what legal consequences Christie may eventually face, for quite some time he will be paying a political price, perhaps enough of one to end his career. Like the Watergate timeline, Bridgegate will have a long unfolding. There will be hearings, grand juries and in time criminal trials. The hope of his backers is that well before the presidential race begins the scandal is resolved, Christie escapes serious harm, and the public's memory fades. That's not going to happen. The Democratic NJ legislature will drag this out for maximum effect, both in-state and nationally. Right around the primaries is when we'll see Christie's aides and appointees trotted off to prison, just like we saw with Nixon's staff, including his attorney general. That will certainly make the news or come in debates and interviews.

Rather foolishly for a politician, Christie seems to have made just as many, if not more, enemies as allies. And so who will help him; who helped Gingrich? We all know how well being a bully worked for him.

All but two of the seventeen cantons which voted yes have lower-than-average rates of immigration. Unemployment in the country is 3%. Their companies in the drug, banking, and food industries have many foreigners as clients, workers and customers. The quotas, per the initiative, will apply to cross-border commuters, and not just those seeking to immigrate. The countries most directly affected are actually Germany and Italy, which is where most Swiss exports wind up. The initiative likely was not aimed at Germans and Italians but the government will have a difficult time adjusting quotas to include the preferred and exclude the pariahs.

From a numbers point of view the Swiss right wing is aiming for the America model: 0.3% permanent-resident immigration a year (1 million per year in the US). Switzerland, however, is no US. Its companies depend on foreign markets to a much greater degree and it has many bilateral agreements with EU member states likely jeopardized by this vote.

Arguing with conservatives over a minimum wage of $10.10 is a waste of time, and by itself a victory for the greediest people. (If the debate were over a minimum wage of $25 per hour, then at least a positive outcome would make a real difference.)

A better approach is to tie the minimum wage to the highest federal income tax bracket. For example, set the rate to 90% for twenty times the income of a full-time worker at the minimum wage. (If you object that twenty is too low, then set that factor higher, but it should certainly be a two digit number.) If we did that, I suspect that conservatives would be arguing for a higher minimum wage.

For example, if the minimum wage were $25 per hour, then the high marginal rate would not kick in until a person earned over $1 million per year. Likewise, if the multiplier were 50 and the minimum wage was $15, then the marginal rate would start at $1.5 million.

Mr. Katz presents the conundrum of Europe versus the U.S.  In Europe, restaurant service tends to be a real profession with training that reflects the pride shown in restaurants and even bistros. Yes, to my shame I invariably tip 20 per cent or more mostly out of pity (even in Oregon, which eschews the ludicrous Federal tipped minimum wage).  Call it social liberal guilt notwithstanding absence of illusion that this post-paid stipend has little connection with quality of food or service.  As is evident from many of those who comment, wait staff is populated with people who are looking for something better to do while trying to survive.  And it is unlikely that conforming to "normal" minimum wage will do much to improve either quality of life or professionalism among staff.  That responsibility -- including adequate compensation -- rests with owners.

What a life he had! I met him once after a performance at the Three Little Baker's Theatre in Wilmington De. The Immediato family of performers had founded a bakery and a theatre…they had been a gymnastic act that performed frequently on the Ed Sullivan Show. They all knew each other over the years. His show was terrific in 2004 or 5..but he was weary and short of patience when I met him back stage. The bus waited in the parking lot for him, and I couldn't help but be struck by what a hard life it must be for an old guy to keep up. He and his partner, headed for the bus across the foggy and misty parking lot under the glary street lamps close to midnight. We should somehow be able to take better care of our national treasures such as Andy Rooney. For that matter, all of our old people are treasures. We need to do a better job of appreciating them. Andy Rooney's talents are preserved in his film performances, treasured by me and many many others. He added light and sparkle to our lives. While he may have become a cynic, with the sturggles of his life, his work and exuberant talent has left a very positive mark.  RIP Andy Rooney!

What is arguably the most important criminal justice reform finally beginning to pick up steam across the country comes ironically, not from either the federal or the state governments but instead by a group of people who saw injustice & committed to doing something about it.

Project Innocence (and other organizations dedicated to the same principles) has doggedly pursued what should be but often isn't a basic right of those convicted of a crime - the right to be exonerated as a result of DNA testing that wasn't technologically possible at the time they were convicted. There is also a growing body of evidence supporting the phenomenon of false confessions coming from particular individuals and under certain circumstances. It should sear the conscience of all of us that there are people sitting in a jail cell, many of whom are minorities and some of whom, at least, are on Death Row.

Texas, and Dallas specifically, have been open to Project Innocence and has led the nation in these long overdue exonerations. One recent case of prosecutorial misconduct uncovered during the process resulted in a criminal conviction for the prosecutor.

All the other reforms are important, of course, but they ring a bit hollow if we ignore this.

As a landlord I have occasionally worked with tenants in doing construction on houses I rent to them. This has worked very well for me. My tenants are happy and my property is improved. Sometimes, as a landlord, you don't know what needs to be fixed until someone is living in the house.

In one case, it was obvious the kitchen was inadequate. I worked with a contractor to make a few changes which I paid for. During the construction, I reduced the rent for the tenant because of the inconvenience. In another case, the driveway of a recently purchased rental home was woefully inadequate and got so muddy cars couldn't get out of it. The tenant volunteered to pay for part of the construction of a new driveway. How could we refuse? The house now has a great driveway and good drainage system.

Another plus to improving your rental property is the owner gets a tax deduction.

Note to landlords: Provide a water softener that is included in the rent. It's a small expense, but will save lots of money as time goes by. It prevents build up of deposits in your water pipes and alleviates problems with faucets. And the tenant will be very happy.

So while I'm happy to work with tenants regarding changes in the property I won't allow doing something that is not up to code. That would create more problems than I'm willing to deal with.

It not that hard to reconcile the results, because the situations studied are very different.  The mammogram studies include all the women who get the delayed treatment, along with all the ones that get aggressive treatment, all the healthy women who never get a bad mammogram, and all the women who get a suspicious result that turns out to be benign or easily curable.  The mammogram studies just compare the death rates and the time of discovery, while Freeman's compares treatments in a sub-set, the women who need treatment ... the women mammograms are intended to identify, the women for whom the detection turns out to be crucial.  The mammogram study just looks at the death rate like a snapshot.  It is what it is.  It's only when you start comparing treatments, and populations, that the facts Freeman sees come up.

I am so much happier making so much less money as a writer, it's crazy. (Full disclosure: I was a summer intern with Sam at CSFB).
