As a senior in high school, I've experienced many of these lockdown drills. I know that they're for my own safety and lessen any mass chaos that could happen if danger was in my school.
I think the main problem is that by publisizing these shootings so much, we're communicating to these depressed, desperate, angry, and unstable people that this is a good way to get attention in the world today. A majority of school shootings today are done by students who feel this way. We need to be careful about what we say and how we say it. If we could reach out to our peers and children and teach them self-worth, patience, and kindness, I believe we could dramatically reduce the number of kids who result to shooting as a venting of bad feelings. It takes a village to raise a child, we can all make a difference.

I remember reading a couple of years ago, when supply and prices for rice were quite unstable, that part of the problem was that a lot of rice growers in Australia, which even then was in an extended drought, had given up trying to grow rice and planted vineyards instead.  Growing grapes for wine instead of trying to grow food is apparently a rational response to extended drought.

Rat is offensive, of course, not sure what part of Moscow Michael is from, but as a Russian person, I am sorry that games are not perfect and people are displeased with the quality of the facilities, etc.
Yes, we've spent $50bln on the games,but we can afford it. Our finances are all right.Russia's external debt is $200bln and is under control, we've repaid soviet debts (which we volunteered to take after the collapse instead of dividing it among former soviet republics), we have accumulated several trln.$ over the years and put them in into the Welfare Fund to make an investments for the future generations, we have been investing this money all over the world and even forgave several underdeveloped (yes,more underdeveloped than we are) countries. We have over a trln$ still sitting in our coffers.
$50bln is going towards not only building the stadiums and hotels, but also improving infrastructure, etc.Surely, American readers can relate, granted the comparison might notbe correct, but more money was spent on rebuilding New Orleans. Corruption in construction is hardly news! Try undertaking such an enormous project without findingout that half of the work has been outsourced to fishy subcontractors.
We have done so much, and still some see us as a drunks, sitting in our Gulags,waiting for the world to blink, so we could bring Lenin back to life and raise our old red flags. Watch the games, don’t bring politics to sports event, waging blame wars never leads to anything good.

Next you are going to tell us that prisons should reform people and help them return to society.

Congratulations - one of your more thoughtful columns.

Big Pharma has a lot of the blame here. They pushed their opiate-based painkillers on the American population and pretended they were non-addictive solutions to chronic pain. They have done very well off of these opiates which they know are heavily abused. Heroin has become cheaper than the oxy-class drugs in many drug markets, as laws begin to slow the flow of these harmful drugs from pharmacies -- that's why heroin is currently having a surge in demand. Now, Big Pharma will do well selling its maintenance drugs (like suboxin) to a large population in recovery. Then there's the ancillary problems of drug addiction that Big Pharma will get a nice slice of: Hepatitis-C, HIV-AIDS, etc. You've got to take your hat off to these aggressive, though immoral, capitalists: they know how to create markets.

A cynical sellout - you have to wonder what he might do with those extra millions. Certainly not invest in a custom display case for World Series rings. Yet another sad example (Albert Pujols) of the way that money has completely corrupted this game.

A sidenote: Great to see all those super-expensive seats empty at Yankee Stadium tonight. Time was when a Yankees-Red Sox game on a Friday night would fill very seat and the air would be electric. No more. Yankee Stadium is one more monument to the unintended consequences of too much money in too few hands.

I'm strongly in sympathy with the fact that acting is work. People who've never worked in theatre don't know - they just assume you get up there and do what you feel. It's hard work, skilled work, and work most people can't do. (If you doubt acting is work, look at any cable commercial for a small business that uses non-actors.) Over the years i've met, and sometimes worked with, actors of all stripes from young novices working toward an Equity card to famous names. The majority of professional actors are, well, professional.

Last year Mr LeBeouf was replaced in the Broadway show 'Orphans' (citing that all-purpose euphemism 'creative differences') and also in the fourth Transformers movie after starring in the first three. That isn't just strange behaviour like performance art with a bag over your head. I don't know the story behind his dropping out of those productions, but this suggests a pattern of unprofessional behaviour. If so, he'd better watch it. Judy Garland couldn't get away with it, Marilyn Monroe couldn't get away with it, and sir, you are no Monroe nor Garland. Show up, on time and sober, hit your mark, learn your lines, and don't bump into the furniture.

Hi Mia: You think your situation in Los Angeles is the same as mine in Hungary? And you want ME to get some perspective?? People aren't advocating a buildup of missiles and troops on Hollywood and Vine. They're advocating it right here in my backyard.

And In 1956 the Russians didn't invade Burbank, they invaded Budapest. So please, pour yourself another Perla del Mar and chill. Your "facts" are nonsense.

It always feels strange for me reading a piece like this. I know I'm supposed to feel pleased at the author's epiphany. But I don't. I feel angry. It's nice that after making more money than I've made in my life the author was willing to walk away. It's nice that he was able to become sober, though i doubt there would have been many repercussions if he hadn't. It's nice that he went on to perform charity work. But he still seems to be an over-privileged person. Most regular people who are squeaking by can't afford to think less of money. They might want to. But money is their ticket to survival. Nor can they afford to mess up with drugs and alcohol and get multiple chances in life.
It's a rich person's dream to have a less materialistic world.

Now if the author had done something to actually help take down the capitalist system in which he so readily participated? Then we could talk about what a mensch he is. In the meantime all I can say is I hope he realizes he owes society a lot more than what he describes in this article. I know he is doing charity work and I applaud that. But honestly, we need to have fewer poor people so we don't need charities. Charities, for all their good, are also a capitalists way of not feeling guilty. Sam had (and has) a chance to do more. I hope he does.

Careful reading is important. The risk associated with twins has nothing to do with their frequency relative to the general population, but to the risk of one twin being affected if the other is diagnosed with autism. There is no data listed that suggests being a twin by itself increases the risk for developing autism spectrum.

It should be pointed out that the AIPAC lobbying group is the strongest supporter of this bill and has been pressuring Senators to vote for the bill. AIPAC supports legislation which it deems is favorable to the interests of Israel, as that is the specific mission of this lobbying group.

Israel's position on Iran has been much more hawkish than that of the United States and Israel has criticized the diplomacy surrounding the negotiations with Iran.

The bill includes a non-binding section which advocates that the US should unconditionally give military and economic assistance to Israel, should Israel find it in its interests to attack Iran.

We need more people who will publicly separate the interests of the United States from the interests of Israel, not attempt to conflate those interests as if they are one in the same.

Years ago the Metropolitan Museum (NYC) had one elegant cafeteria for everyone rich or poor. There was a large beautiful fountain in the center and a waiter would come and take your tray and leave you a cloth napkin and silverware. All for a very modest price. The pay what you wish entrance fee was clearly displayed not hidden as it is today. Most people are unaware that they can pay as little as a penny to get in. (the building is supported by tax money)

Fast forward to today...high entrance fee, rich people eat upstairs at high prices...regular people eat in the basement windowless fast food cafeteria.

Even the New York Times is starting down the road towards a two tiered news service. Lord, save us from the "Times Insider".

So it goes in the land controlled by corporations and no longer by the people.  Caveat emptor is the only governing rule of the day.  Did GM engineers really anticipate that none of us would ever place our car keys on a heavier key ring along with  other keys and maybe even a small pen knife or an LED flashlight?  This was seemingly a failure in adequately specifying design margins and developing a test to fail plan during product development and reliability testing.  Doesn't GM use six sigma quality control in their manufacturing processes?  I thought they invented it.  That would have necessitated ongoing reliability testing on every lot of components from its suppliers.  This is typically done at the supplier's facility.  Where are the records of this testing for the component in question?  Can you say coverup?

"Arcane words".  So who decides what's an arcane word?  I'm a Latin teacher.  There aren't too many arcane words to me.  The word "arcane" comes from the Latin word "arca" which means "box", as in the "ark of the covenant", the box in which is was kept.  Arcane things are secret or discreet, such as you might keep in a box somewhere.  Do we really want to go there and take another big step down the road towards a drastically two-tier education system?  I guess the kind of kids who will be competing in the Hunger Games will not need to know big words.

I'm proud, again, of this persident. His speech and plan are noble and human. Courageous, too, becaue the "social Darwinists" and nay-sayers were bound to deride his intentions. The race for the American Dream is loaded nowhere more than against poor African Americans. We throw sops at the problems and think we're wonderful--while the GOP goes on reducing even those sops. Why brothers and sons, and not sisters and daughters? The women of Black communities are a marvel, and they are not the ones sitting in inordinate numbers in our prisons. The Obama plan may have a multiplier effect, with a cadre of young leaders recruiting others and giving hope and purpose to lives dominated by the ephemera of modern life.

This article does a disservice to Michelle Obama.

It emphasizes the superficial, the materialistic, the lifestyles of the privileged elite.

Michelle Obama is highly intelligent in addition to her character strengths, a sense of duty, teamwork, positive attitude and resilience.

She is and can be so much more. She has an opportunity to work towards uniting Americans towards peace and justice for all. She still has time.

Having grown up during a time when “duck and cover” was a very fresh memory, there is something particularly insidious about our new fear. We are no longer a target of an external existential threat, but one particularly home-grown and deeply divisive.

In the suburban public elementary school where I volunteer, we’ve already had two lock-down drills since the beginning of the year. In brief, informal discussions with some of the teachers, the feeling is that if bullets ever do start flying, all bets are off and the standard procedures of “shelter in place” will be unheeded in favor of getting out by any available exit. So much for planning.

The safety drills we carry out at our church, now that many houses of worship are targets of murderous rage, have been sobering. Arming congregants doesn’t square with the deeply held beliefs of our church. We can plan and strategize ‘til kingdom come, but ultimately a man with with a gun and an agenda calls the shots until the ammo runs out or until sanity prevails in public life once again.

Our public spaces are being turned into war zones. It’s abundantly clear who is harmed by the proliferation of these killing machines. But who benefits? Those who do should be publicly shamed at every opportunity, though only the bravest among us will welcome such a confrontation.

We can, as Americans, face this existential threat with sane gun legislation and collectively deciding that it’s wrong to live in fear.

The story that has been released regarding Inmarsat's analysis is fatally incomplete. Waving the magic wand of Doppler effect does not explain how the northern direction was "eliminated". The satellite is geo-stationary so the two arcs are mirror images of each other as are any potential flight paths. I can imagine only two possible analyses that would differentiate between the two paths but both would require time clock measurements orders of magnitude more precise than needed for measuring the relative speed of a plane since it would involve the comparison of two measures that are very close to each other. One would be if the satellite had a slight rotation or wobble and if they could tell which direction it (the sat) was moving at the exact moment each ping was received. The other is if the slight difference in the distance of each arc from the equator combined with the equatorial bulge of the Earth made a slight difference in the predictions for the two arcs. Either of these would require a degree of precision that it is hard to imagine in a system that wasn't even designed for these purposes. It is absolutely criminal that the Malaysians and other authorities including the US are dismissing the northern possibility w/o even revealing HOW (in principle if not detail) Doppler measurements were used to support this conclusion. Until the specific method is described people will have every right to disbelieve the claims that the northern route has been eliminated.

Rae Le Roy is my Mom. Long before we met with palliative care doctors, we had many difficult conversations about Mom's medical directives and wishes -- always wanting to honor and support HER wishes. When Mom said to me, "How many times does a person have to keep on trying?!?" -- after 3 hospital stays and return to a rehab/nursing facility, as hard as it was, I said, "Mommy, you don't have to keep on trying if you don't want to." I am grateful we were able to give her the gift of feeling in control of her choices and living on her own terms, not ours. We were seeking peace... not fighting battles -- very hard for our current medical model. Thanks Paula for shedding light on this topic. Let's wage peace!
And conservative republicans worry about government death panels. What a horrific tragedy, created by religious political extremists.

I do not necessarily have a problem with their irresponsibility as parents- I look in grocery carts that put children in more danger than the sailing trip- but I DO have a big issue with cost.  Will they pay for the rescue?  They must have means to pay for it considering the trip in the first place.  I am offended that because of their big desire for a round the world trip that neither child will remember, that the NAVY had to rescue them.

This is a dilemma of knowledge and wealth. If there were no gene testing available in this case, the couple might choose never to have children. If I
came from a family with such a severe, adult-onset disease, I probably would have chosen to never have children. We are indebted to this couple for telling their story so we can think through the implications.
Since birth control is available and effective, our society has a clear duty to make sure birth control is available and affordable for every woman who wants it. A genetically damaged child may suffer, but an unwanted child almost always suffers because of the higher risk of neglect and abuse. A woman should always have the right to choose, hopefully with her partners support and consent, but it is always her decision because there is no one else with the right to decide for her.

Obama's choice comes down to having the Canadian oil refined either here in the US or in China .  Five years of study have conclusively demonstrated minimal environmental effects of the proposed pipeline ; if the oil goes to China it will be refined in a rudimentary, dirty fashion.  And as we all know, noxious air circulates around around the globe.  As a scientist,  I mourn the complete  absence of rationality from what  should  be  a scientific discussion

Fact of the matter is, Wendy meant this book to be read only by 'scholars' & 'academics'. Not for unwashed masses of India. This is why now Penguin is put in an embarrassed position. Now the publicity will indeed garner interest in the book & it is freely available to anyone on the internet. More Indian folks will read it & 'appreciate' the western, white scholar's 'sophisticated' views on Goddess Kali's sexual orientation. They will finally be educated on the nuances of Ganesha's trunk - finally realize it is all about either male or female private parts. One of the orifice at the best.
May be they will ask a question or two to a visiting Americans about it.

We are better than this! When we execute, we are the parent who is saying "do as I say, not as I do". We all know how well that works out. If we want to teach that killing is bad, then we must set the example. Oh - but what about revenge? That's the only motive satisfied when we execute. That only breeds a vicious cycle of guilt which we must defend against with increased denial, rationalization and ultimately more brutality. The state gets to murder while preaching the opposite. I am embarrassed by my country's brutality in this and other areas. We are behind the times. It's time for us to give up the distinction of being the only industrialized country with a death penalty.

This is a succinct description of a multi-layered, grotesque complex set of problems facing this nation. There is no one single, no party answer than can address all the issues satisfactorily for the entire nation, but that cannot prevent the conversation from happening.

Perhaps it's time to consider the symbiotic relationship between employers and the working community. Perhaps it's time to alter the mindset about the gestalt of earning profits and paying wages. The bottom line is that if people don't earn enough to keep a roof overhead and food on the table, there won't be a whole lotta disposable income...the kind that helps the overall economy to recover and grow. To do, though, you have to have corporations willing to protect their own workers. The lower the worker's level, the more protection should a company provide.

Seems like shareholder right trump worker rights, and therein lies the problem. The shift that must occur to spur on the economic recovery is the one where the worker comes before the shareholder.

It's only one aspect of this, but it's a really important change; We, the People need to insist that the shift happens sooner rather than later.

http://wifelyperson.blogspot.com/

This is the most important column any newspaper has published in years.

It goes to the heart of what it means to be American today, and is part of our American story.

How could any American continue to be indifferent about the massive waste of talent and intelligence that each black and Latino man who goes prison represents? For every one who loses his way, perhaps sometime during high school or shortly thereafter, is another black man who's not writing a screenplay. Another Latino man who is not working in the kitchen of a five-star restaurant as executive chef, when that's he wants to do and would be unbeatable in. Another black man who's not developing a game-changing app in Silicon Valley.

In "Decoded", Jay-Z mused that almost all of those who survived and even made it out as giants from hip hop have at least one thing in common: they did not have fathers, or lost them at a young age.

This is a daunting and complex task. And yet tackling this as a country may be our equivalent to JFK's moon challenge. It's got to be done. And when we do, we won't just be doing something for this generation of black and Latino men. We'd be doing it for the generation we don't even see yet.

If we could change the trajectory of just one generation of black and Latino men -- just one -- nothing can stop us.

If you have been diagnosed, treated and lived through a bout with breast cancer that started with a mammogram, you are for the test. I am for the test - both my doctor and me missed a small lump through self-examination. On my side of the argument, I have no choice but to encourage women to get an annual mammogram. After a lumpectomy, chemo and radiation, I have been in remission for 12 years. However, all women should have the option to be tested. By the way, if my breast cancer had been detected sooner, it would not have spread to the lymph nodes. The study is compelling and I can just imagine that women all over the world would be happy to give up the barbaric mammogram. Trust me, chemo is worse, but both saved my life.

If Ryan is not a conscious racist --- which I believe --- then he is criminally naive. However, that's not my point here. We keep ringing our hands about "creating jobs." When are we gonna get it through our heads that today's corporations do NOT want to create jobs. Employees are a drag on profits. Employees need benefits. Employees are HR hassles. Whet corporations want are contingent workers; people who can be applied to a particular task for a specific time and then can be cut loose when that task is done. When we need to be talking about is how our laws and policies can be adjusted to support the self-employed, not how we can "create jobs."

A quick glance at the article leads me to believe that the SATS are simply being dumbed down in order to accommodate our dumbed down school system. Fine. Reminds me of the teacher who intoned that "big words" (the word in question was "stow") could not be used when addressing high schoolers "because they don't understand them".

LBJ saw the error of his ways and left office a broken man, refusing to run for reelection. It can be reasonably argued he willed himself to death over his vast remorse for the lives his decisions cost. His historic civil rights and other landmark social legislation have improved the lives of tens of millions of Americans ever since.

G.W. Bush has remains cocky and in denial to this day. The worldwide disaster that was his presidency still has crippling effects throughout our society that we never fully recover from.

They both have the legacy of a disastrous war hung around their their necks, and they both came from Texas. The similarities end there. The Bush team worked day and night to successfully rig the economic game for the top 1%. LBJ singlehandedly browbeat, arm twisted, and blackmailed both houses of congress to get life saving, life improving, and voting freedom legislation passed for the 99% of Americans. BIG difference there my friends.

If you're hearing voices that compel you to do something, particularly if it is to harm yourself or others, perhaps you should be required to take medication. But thinking you can make someone's problems all go away by taking a pill is no more rational than telling someone they must drink wine to help with a rotten marriage. Drugs can make severe mental illness easier to handle, but it won't change that they need a strong support network and/or trained counseling - which is what the problem is now.  We don't have that for enough of the people who need it.

I disagree with James Franco’s explanation of the events in question. First of all is my concern about plagiarism. The “borrowing” of material was not done unconsciously and as a public figure, it is obvious that plagiarisms will be found out quickly. My judgement is that the decision to plagiarize the apology for plagiarism is neither “clever” nor “pathological.” It was more of a subtle demonstration for his belief that plagiarism is OK. Perhaps in retaliation to the consequences, it seems to me that he is using “I am not famous anymore” and “I am sorry” as punchlines to jokes. LaBeouf knows that these “abnormal” activities will cause a public frenzy. The joke is on us now, because we pay attention to these events and in a twisted way, acknowledge his stance on plagiarism. He says that he’s not famous anymore which in turn makes him more famous. He says he’s sorry but instead brings more publicity to his indiscretion.

Secondly, not to discredit fame, but the vast majority of people are not affected by the lives of actors. Most of us enjoy the magical world that is created through film for a couple hours and then it’s back to the grind. To think that an actor’s “persona” is something that many normal people internalize is slightly pretentious. If as James Franco deduces, LaBeouf’s decisions are to prove that he’s an artist, his actions are rather coming off like a temper tantrum thrown by a child who wishes to be seen.

Two guys go for an all expense's paid Holiday to Thailand and just by chance happen to find someone to sell them two forged passports, with there pic's in them, they only bought them because they where buy 1 get one free, they just wanted Asylum in Europe, so why not do what the rest of your countrymen do an just come to Britain, this government loves immigrants legal or otherwise. yes you don't need papers, just ask for Mr Cameron, PM. that Plane is in Cambodia  that's the Logical place for it.

I would think that the high divorce rate among poorer people reflects the fact that, economically, they need their marriages to function at a different Maslov level -- as in earlier times -- and the expectations created by advertising, TV, movies, which are based on the "self-actualizing" marriage, are impossible for them to meet.
I am waiting and hoping that direct proof is found about Christie's prior knowledge and go-ahead on the bridge  lane closings. Christie is an arrogant man, not fit to govern.

Decades ago, when my job came under the Writers Guild contract, part time and hourly workers were given 19% more pay in cash to cover insurance and paid time off they didn’t get. You lose a significant amount of money when you lose your benefits. Part-time workers today aren’t recompensed, and make far less per hour then their fulltime co-workers. Now you have to factor in the new premiums people have to pay for health insurance. Remember subsidies are tied to a percentage of income, so I don’t see how this disincentives low-income people. Futility kills our motivation to work harder or seek out new work, not lack of punitive measures for being poor (there’s never a dearth in that category)

Most of this nonsense about worker’s freedoms and choices is folly for people who make significantly more then they need to spend. (Like politicians, political pundits, and newspaper editorial boards) Most Americans are not this well off. More workers are living paycheck to paycheck then anytime in our living memory. We live in an age where total compensation has been shrinking, year after year. Be wary of people using statistics to assign some group rationalization that in reality is pure psychobabble. Most often people find positive aspects to the work situation they have, they don’t design the job you want.

Our brain chemistry doesn't distinguish between which opiates are "legal" pharmaceuticals and "illegal" street drugs. The belief that one form of opiate is different from another is a moral rationalization that our society makes to shame drug addicts.

Any of us recovering with the help of Narcotics Anonymous have known this for decades.

If the US was truly an honest broker in this and willing to fairly and equally apply pressure to both sides in this dispute, there would have been a resolution years ago. But, instead, the US refuses or is unable to use the enormous leverage it has over Israel and is only prepared to talk tough with and punish the Palestinians, who are (by far) the weaker partner in this dispute. Until the Americans are willing to cut funding to Israel and make it clear that there will be costs for Israel's intransigence, the Israelis will simply wait this out, knowing that they can count on the Israel Lobby and US domestic politics to keep the Americans at their beck and call. I'm afraid that there is not much hope for optimism here. This either goes on to the one-state solution - which is unworkable, at least for now - or Israel will simply become a more and more ostracized state in the world as its treatment of the Palestinians gets worse and worse.
I wonder how Slomo, the fascinating roller skating doctor, who thinks far outside the box, would fare in today's workplace?

The measurements over the decades due indicate that the mean temperatures are rising and much faster than research into historical warming trends have in the past. It is also a fact the glaciers around the world are shrinking. It is also a fact that carbon gas levels have increase faster and achieved higher concentrations since the start of the industrial revolution than at any previous time. So rational people who are not afraid of their assets invested in fossil fuels have concluded that human activity is the biggest factor in driving this degree of warming.

How bad will it get? Nobody knows. Can we just wait and see? Well if you think that you can remove exacerbating contributors to global warming in less than decades, you just don't understand the problem. To avoid the worst outcomes we must prepare for them in the understanding that waiting to see what will happen means just letting it happen.

Nuclear fuel? Great stuff. Most efficient way to boil water people have ever found. The down side is that the waste products are so deadly to life on this planet that it must be contained and watched closely for up to 100 centuries. The longest written records we have go back 50 centuries. No government of the size needed to babysit this waste has lasted more than about 10 centuries. So is nuclear fuel and rational alternative for mankind over the long run? Is it a way for one generation of people to indulge themselves and leaving many generations to deal with the consequences?

Who cares if Russia annexes those areas in eastern Ucraine which are Russian anyway? Not a darn thing will be done about it anyway ! Crimea (Russian) and east Ukraine(Russian) are NOT worth shedding a drop of European or American blood. (For one thing, America is too busy empire-building in Iraq and Afghanistan ,which is a bit like the pot calling the kettle black).
Let the European Union deal with the situation. The EU helped start this debacle by trying to entice Ukaine to join the EU! Europe is now concerned about their Russian gas supplies rising in price in retaliation for their actions regarding Ukraine. They should have thought about this scenario when they started buying hydrocarbons from Russia. Now they expect the US to fill the void? Ridiculous!!!

Maybe the attitude toward congressional Republican obstructionism has freed President Obama to be more cheerful and to sound less strained and annoyed than he sometimes has in the past.  Partway through the speech I thought, "Hey, no one told him he's supposed to sound resigned."  He seemed to me pretty upbeat and full of energy to move forward where he can and hope others follow.  Good for him, and I hope his attitude helps get everyone to do their part to help us make more progress.

Where David Brooks sees an opportunity to smash two things together, I see a situation that might allow a person to merge patterns together or to apply a pattern from one context to another one where it might be helpful.

I mention this because when I read a column like this, I am pretty sure that I am not understanding it the way it is intended to be understood, that I somehow am not on the same wavelength. And I don't want to be criticizing a speed skater for not doing triple Salchows.

So I'll just express my gratitude that the view from the columnist's perspective includes a place for skills that humans do better than computers. While I was out shoveling snow earlier this evening, I couldn't help thinking that on a cold winter's night, a warm body (whether's it's a human, a dog, a human pretending to be a dog, or a dog pretending to be a human) is quite preferable to a machine.

The contradiction here is that Putin is attempting to achieve world standing and recognition of Russia’s reemergence; however, each action Putin takes, the further he becomes isolated. Despite his cavalier attitude toward the G8, it was a missed theatrical opportunity for Putin to show his nation he is standing next to the man (President Obama) whom he had blatantly disregarded. But once the wind of his country's nationalistic fervor is over, it will become apparent to Putin that sanctions may soon affect his inner circle.  It was announced that the G8 meeting was moved from Sochi to Brussels. Sochi was heavily invested in by Russia’s oligarchs; and it was Sochi that was to hold future sporting events and other world events; but if sanctions and deepening isolation progress further, Sochi will become a financial bust!   The U.S. and Russia must cooperate on issues that are both in their nation interest (Iran and Syria) and engage in frank discussions on self-determinism. Putin reminds me of Khrushchev, volatile, pugnacious and unpredictable. He witnessed his beloved Soviet Union dissolved and deteriorated into a country that resembled a Russian circus bear, big, powerful and comical. With the reemergence of Russia, Putin's actions are his way of correcting the wrongs and injustices inflicted upon his Russia.    Simply put, will sanctions and isolating Russia stop or embolden Putin to continue in his version of Manifest Destiny to counter western insolence?
A tax by the way that many won't have to pay.

As part of the minimum wage issue, when did so many temporary summer and after school jobs for adolescents, teens and young adults become permanent jobs/careers for adults?  When I was 11 and 12 years old in the 1960's I delivered daily newspapers.  Between the ages of 13 and 17 (high school years) I worked for a landscaper/nursery.   During my summers in college I worked as a line cook in a restaurant where 90% of the staff were under the age of 23.  Now most all of these jobs are being done by adults as permanent jobs.  My newspaper is now being delivered by a man who is my age now - I am 55 years old.  What gives?

The Democratics ( yes I wrote that on purpose since all of the wailing and gnashing of teeth over being called the Democrat party ) are dealing with the consequences of their  hard  left turn. I am an immigrant from S. Korea and proud of my cultural heritage, but I do not want it replicated here. I think the “liberal” view on immigration overlooks the importance of assimilation at both the community & national level. The fact that I do not have close friendships with recent immigrants is not racist. It simply points to the obvious truth that for bonding to occur, you need similar values, interests, and most of all – a common language. It’s akin to forming friendships. You bond w/ whom you communicate at a personal level.

New immigrants will often only interact within their own and replicate the old homeland. Especially w/ new technology, it is very easy to geographically live in the US but be an active citizen of another. Suddenly your neighborhood is filled with people w/ whom you cannot communicate, your favorite cafes & shops close down & reopen catering to the new group, & schools are diverting dollars from your kids to teach the English language. Why would anyone welcome this? Like any good thing, immigration needs to be moderate and w/ time for the cycle of assimilation to kick through.

Communities, and nations, do not become strong and united through platitudes of "we need to come together" speeches. We become as one through shared values, interaction, and a common language. The fact that this is becoming harder and harder for people in many places I believe should be discussed, and without guilt.

I lived in Russia for several years, have a master's in Russky linguistics, and have worked for people like Putin's campaign manager.
What I think is important:
1. Every educated Russian I ever met thinks Putin is the next coming of Ivan the Terrible. He plays on the sentiments of those outside the major population centers to lend an air of credibility to his "elections" and is casting this debacle in the light of protecting Russians to shore up opinion with them to help preserve this neo-Soviet space he has fantasized into reality.
Why? Slow decay is consuming most of his country. Most regional governments are not even funded enough to plug the holes in the pipes these days and so he's out of moves in his power base.
2. He must ask himself what he will do when the Ukrainian Army marches through its own territory. It appears he's already been stupid enough to give permission to his troops to fire. If full-scale war breaks out, it will demolish his stock market and possibly lead to a coup as all those rich people that keep him propped up lose billions. Rock and a hard place. How is that the upper hand? He's gambling.
3. American will soon sell large volumes of natural gas to Europe, decimating Russia's income and all those plans Putin has for rebuilding his military.
4. Russia will see another revolution brought on from up high, as always. So goes Russian history. War with Ukraine will only make it happen faster. This roll of the dice has already moved up the timeline.

When 55, there were 2 job offers available to this American, one in the international community, the other in the corporate world. However for the first time, I was facing surgery and it took a friend awhile to persuade me that until I went to a doctor for an evaluation, I had not yet made a 'choice'. I believe today she saved my life.

It was with regret that I had to keep a focus on my health, and turn down the above positions. I have not worked, or made a salary since, but have been living on my savings, which I am fortunate to have although they are dwindling. With a pre-existing condition, my individual Health Insurance monthly premium escalated yearly, an increasingly hard one to meet. By the time, it reached over $1,500/monthly this Summer last, my life savings were now seriously at risk.

The Affordable Care Act has now offered me far better options, and I was also able to look at other viable insurance plans, thanks to the new laws that have dismissed pre-existing conditions. Does this mean that I never want to work again? On the contrary, but in the meantime I feel an unnecessary and wasteful financial burden has been lifted from my shoulders, and I feel less stressed and better.

As for some of my friends' grown children who are working, they now have health insurance for the first time, and none of them are planning to retire in the near future and live on the fat of the Land. They are moving forward, with a mind to look after their own parents one day.

My husband and I just drank the Chateau Cantermerle 2009 wine with our dinner.  Here is our reaction.  Before eating:  Aroma deep, fruity, rich, full grape smell - smells like a good Bordeaux.  Smells smooth and mellow and fruity.  First taste before eating:  More savory than sweet; rich, smoky.  Texture - medium tannins with a little acidity.  While eating roast chicken and roasted root vegetables:  When it first goes on the palate, it tastes a little acidic, then becomes more earthy.  It's both tannic and acidic, but more tannic.  After starting to eat, it tastes smooth with a little zing.  When it first goes in the mouth it's smooth.  Then you feel an earthy zing.  It's more smoky than fruity.  The more I drink, the more it opens up in my mouth.  By the second glass it really opens up like a flower opening up in your mouth.  This wine is great with goat cheese.  It tastes sweeter with the cheese.  The texture has a snappy vivacity - it makes you want to savor it and take another sip.  We also tried it with dessert, an apricot pistachio tart.  I thought it was a nice counterpart to the sweetness of the tart, but my husband thought it did not go with the dessert.  We finished the bottle and overall we loved the wine.  Tomorrow we will drink the Chateau Sociando-Mallet Haut Medoc 2009.

House Unamerican Activities Committee August 18, 1955

Mr. SEEGER: I am not going to answer any questions as to my association, my philosophical or religious beliefs or my political beliefs, or how I voted in any election, or any of these private affairs. I think these are very improper questions for any American to be asked, especially under such compulsion as this. I would be very glad to tell you my life if you want to hear of it.

Mr. TAVENNER: My question was whether or not you sang at these functions of the Communist Party. You have answered it inferentially, and if I understand your answer, you are saying you did.

Mr. SEEGER: Except for that answer, I decline to answer further. . . .

Mr. SCHERER: Do you understand it is the feeling of the Committee that you are in contempt as a result of the position you take?

Mr. SEEGER: I decline to discuss, under compulsion, where I have sung, and who has sung my songs, and who else has sung with me, and the people I have known. I love my country very dearly, and I greatly resent this implication that some of the places that I have sung and some of the people that I have known, and some of my opinions, whether they are religious or philosophical, or I might be a vegetarian, make me any less of an American. I will tell you about my songs, but I am not interested in telling you who wrote them, and I will tell you about my songs, and I am not interested in who listened to them. . . .

Having seen the first episode of "Years of Living Dangerously," I strongly disagree with this op-ed. Yes, scare tactics backfire, but the authors do serious injustice to the series, which raises questions rather than presenting doomsday scenarios.

The first episode explored the link between drought and the Syrian civil war, investigated deforestation, and probed the impact of a drought upon a small Texas town.

The Texas segment included fascinating interactions between an evangelical scientist and evangelical believers—to make the point that people are most open to new information from someone who is like them. Climate change deniers are most likely to see the light when it's explained by someone holding similar political and religious beliefs—someone who speaks the language they speak, which is that of faith and morality.

That point is a long way from the "scare tactics" this op-ed decries. It's what's known as a "solution"--and it's disturbing that the authors view the show through the filter of their own prejudices and tar it with their own bugaboos.

I have no connection with "Years of Living Dangerously"; I defend it simply because I have the deepest respect for the way it puts flesh on the abstract concept of climate change. It brings a disembodied idea to life by giving it vivid images, human faces, and authentic emotions.

I therefore urge everyone to watch the show before passing judgment.

I wanna reiterate something I said earlier only I wish to stress it even further, maybe even as one of the most important barometers about the science of climate change and the uncertainties that go with it. It's all summed up in one statement, "Worse than previously thought" or "Much worse than previously thought". We've all heard this many times and afer awjile you gotta start drawing some conclusions, like, this deal is 'much worse that we previously thought, humm?'
Think I'm kidding? This phrase is why I am so adamant about serious action, right now. It isn't the predictions themselves that scare me, it's that we keep coming up too conservative on the science. The frequency of the phrase is the proof.
I did a search on these two phases, "Worse than previously thought, climate change" and "Not as bad as previously thought, climate change" . The first got 372,000 results and the latter got 42,000 results. Yeah I know this ain't much of a test, but it says something nevertheless.

Armchair flying is a hobby for me.  I have read numerous reports of crashes and their causes.  More often than not it is pilot error. Here again, commercial airline planes have to adhere to a vigorous maintenance schedule.  This 777-200  is of recent design and build with the latest in avionics probably worth far north of a million dollars.  The plane in question made a change of course and lost altitude  and headed west towards land.   This sounds like the protocol for a mechanical failure of some sort.  The FAA and its counterparts in other parts of the world will search tirelessly to find what ever they can of this plane and work to solve this puzzle.  Waiting is only the start of the painful process until it is discovered.

A brief lesson in antiquity analysis. In the period of time from the actual event and the death of eye witnesses, historical legend development begins. Since Jesus died in approximately 33 AD (confirmed in non-Christian texts like Josephus, Pliny the Elder and Tacitus), the early church only accepted text written within the lifetime of the eyewitnesses to His life. So, the New Testament texts start around 50AD and end around 80AD. Only direct eyewitness accounts were accepted into canon (current Bible). There are roughly 24,000 texts and pieces of texts from that period to support the current New Testament. The next closest document in antiquity with that amount of written evidence is Homer.
The Gnostic gospels (Gospel of Thomas, others) which are so famous today, were written between 200AD and 800AD. Because they were written long after the eyewitnesses had died, they are biased by historical legend development. That is, they are based on hearsay. The reason the Gnostic gospels were not selected for the New Testament was the lack of eyewitness testimony.

The reason the US Court system accepts eye witness accounts and not second hand accounts is reliability. That is, the eyewitnesses were there. Otherwise, it is hearsay evidence. That is why the early church did not accept Gospels written 200-300 years later. It was the lack of eyewitness testimony, not some Dan Brown like conspiracy. The New Testament is the most attested document in history. Enough said.

Another thought regarding how the online generation has redefined mourning...  One of my best friends, "BG", died 2 years ago.  He had a Facebook page at the time and I admit that he wasn't the most active online person I ever met.  However, after he died, something drove me back to his Facebook page just to see if it was still active...and, if it was, to re-read some of his posts, view some of his photos.  To my shock, not only did I find that his page was still "active", I found more than a few posts that were written by other friends after his death.  The comments that his friends left were so touching, I was moved to leave my own comment, something I had never dreamed of ever doing.  Prior to my friend's death, when visiting him for what would be the last time, I met his father for the first time.  We bonded immediately and have remained friends ever since.  Several months after "BG's" death, I sent his father, my new friend, a gift:  a fountain pen.  We keep in touch...by hand written letters sent via snail mail.  I love it and "BG" would have loved it as well.

So we've established that lethal injection - now more than ever - is cruel and unusual. Let's see the next best options:

Hanging - Not the best. You don't die right away, even as you stop struggling. It takes about 10-20 minutes to die.

Electric Chair - This can take 10-20 seconds, but most feel that the ease with which it can be botched outweighs the benefits.

Firing Squad/Guns - One of the better options. A firing squad runs the risk of missing, so point-blank is the best option, preferably with multiple guns at once. Chances are very good that their agony will end almost immediately.

Guillotine - One of the better ones. Death is instantaneous as your blood drains too swiftly for your brain to react, though residual neural activity (ex. eyes continue moving after beheading) can be kind of freaky. Just make sure the blade is sharp!

My earliest years, in the 1950's, were spent as a privileged white child in a wealthy Florida panhandle town. There African Americans lived only in "colored town". The streets were unpaved and there were no streetlights. My all white grade school was new and modern. The grade school in "colored town" was a 19th century clapboard shack. There were never any black customers in the shops or restaurants. Even the Halloween and Christmas parades were segregated: there were no black faces to be seen.  Revisiting as an adult I learned that rather than integrate the public schools, whites had fled en masse to private segregation academies, and the town defunded public education and closed most of the schools, actually selling some off to the segregation academies, rather than educate its black children.  These are memories from my life. Yet Haley Barbour doesn't remember it as being that bad. Not for him, I guess.

JP said: "Why is Medicaid needed if the health care coverage is free to the less advantaged among us?"
* * * * *
Because the standards set in this country for poverty level income is unrealistically low. There are many working poor, technically above the so-called poverty level and yet don't meet traditional Medicaid standards....so in states that refused to expand the program, these families can't get Medicaid or afford insurance premiums. They're left in no-man's-land by their governors and/or state legislatures who refused federal money to pay for the expansion of Medicaid under the ACA.

Bottle: 2009 Haut-Medoc from Chateau Caronne Ste. Gemme.

1) Smell and Taste: It wasn't what I expected. I expected an unready wine, overly tannic. I opened it at 5:30 and drank a bit on its own: there was some fruit, maybe even licorice?

2) There was astringency, but not as much as I expected. Later that night, I made a very simple dinner: steak (just salt and pepper, no sauce or marinade), mashed potatoes, green beans a la plancha. It really was a very pleasant pairing. It's not a world-class wine, and it wasn't a world-class steak, but together they were greater than the sum of their parts.

3) By 8:00, its structure was beginning to fall apart. The elusive balance between tannins and fruit lasted only so long. Was there some smoke in my third glass?

Final thought: Here in Michigan, the bottle set me back $30. That's an awkward price point: not "bargain" but certainly not "high end." I can think of it as a model: this is what the region can produce. It was an instructive experience, particularly since my tastes gravitate towards Bandol, Rioja, Burgundy, Priorat. I'm not a Bordeaux person, and the Bordeaux I know is mostly Right Bank stuff. So I'm learning. I can see what a good Left Bank Bordeaux might taste like. It'll be a good enough measuring stick.

Now it's off to read the comments of others. Thanks!

I'm a science professor at a small private research university that values teaching. The points raised in this article merit comment, several of the ideas are reasonable, and several of the assertions are fallacious.

Unproductive tenured faculty can be problems in universities, but typically research inactive faculty are also poor teachers. The assertion that there is zero relationship between teaching and research is nonsense. In the sciences, if you aren't doing research, your knowledge and teaching are going to be dated within 15 years. Having a research track and teaching track is not going to address faculty who become deadwood, nor will it address the need to refresh knowledge.

I agree that bright motivated students will give rigorous professors good teaching evaluations, but unmotivated students give rigorous professors bad evaluations. Students are not passive receptacles for knowledge, they have to participate in the process.

Research in education, like all research, requires testing and verification. The mid-90s study suggesting large dropout rates for women from stem fields was widely cited as a need to revise how we educate female students. The journal Science recently reported that followup studies showed the dropout rate for women from stem fields was balanced by enrollment of women leaving other fields.

Tenure does need examination. We lose women in academia at the pre-tenure level, when they have to balance the demands of family and career.

Healthy people will not sign up for something that costs them thousands of dollars a year when they spend hundreds or less a year for health care and a couple of hundred a year for the fine. It is a simple fact, not a complicated issue.

Just look at the numbers. The Silver program, the next to cheapest, costs $5,500 a year and you are responsible for 30% of your medical costs. Even if you make $100,000 a year, a 1% fine is $1,000.

You have medical costs of $5,000 a year. With Obamacare Silver you spend $5,000 plus 30% of $5,000, another $1,500, a total of $6,500. With no insurance, you spend $1,000 plus $5,000, a total of $6,000. You can still go to the emergency room. Got the picture yet?

Of course, the lady who spends $19 a month, $228 a year has someone else paying the rest of the $6,500 in the above example.

The estimated cost for Obamacare this year is $200 Billion and still increasing. At $5,500 each, you could insure all $50 million uninsured for $250 Billion. Where is the money going?

Mr. Cohen presumes Twitter bashing to be a generational rant against new cultural norms when, in fact, its critical commentary agains the very narcissisim he confesses to later in the column. I am a Generation X'er, we of the marginalized group between Boomers and Millenials, and I enjoy Facebook as a way to interact with people far and wide. I can make comments of any length, attach any item I wish, load up pictures that people will see, (not some mawkish link to the ether) and most importantly communicate with my friends. The great flaw with Twitter is that it serves as a personalized Entertainment Tonight or TMZ like link to celebrities. Who are Twitter's staunchest defenders? Media types like Mr. Cohen and other celebrities like Ashton Kutcher or Shaquille O'Neal, who need to keep a pipeline open for the next project or to promote new product. This is why Twitter will be marginalized a la MySpace - there is very limited need for a ticker featuring very limited information and mostly commercial endorsements.

Adam Leib only explains where the scores were different, he doesn't explain whether those score discrepencies were justified. Because his score graph doesn't distinguish the base score and the grade-of-execution score, it obfuscate the more generous GOE scores that Adelina received, which as been them main point of contention. The problem is GOE scores seem marked up for one, while marked down for the other.

Furthermore, if technical difficulty is just the question, then Asada Mao, who had eight triple jumps (one more than Adelina, including the most difficult triple-axel) and had a clean performance, should have received the highest technical score. And yet Adelina scores higher than Asada. What gives?

And then there is the even more contentious and baffling component scores which are not included in Adam Leib's explanation. Most commentators have mentioned that Costner as well as Yuna had more elegance, grace and flow - and expected their components scores to be higher than Adelina's Yet Adelina scored better than Costner and was only a fraction of a score lower than Yuna. As Weir has gasped, it was "very very very generous." It's made figure skating legends like Dick Button shake their heads.

So, Adam Leib's piece doesn't explain the issues and questions commenators had and have raised, and only misguides the causal reader.

As a matter of fact, Crimea is already an "Autonomous Republic" within the Ukrainian state. Additional devolution of power to Crimea would further empower the ethnic Russian majority, and in the current circumstances few could argue this would be a good idea. Already for fifteen years now, despite a Russo-Ukrainian treaty of friendship and cooperation which explicitly recognizes Ukrainian sovereignty over Crimea, Moscow has been granting Russian passports to Russian-speakers in Crimea, just as it did to south Ossetians and Abkhazians to incite anti-Georgian separatism and undermine the Georgian republic. That led to war between Russia and Georgia.

While ethnic Russians currently constitute over half of the Crimean population, one-quarter is Ukrainian and almost fifteen per cent is made up of the original Crimean Tatar inhabitants. In 1944 the entire Crimean Tatar population was ethnically cleansed by Stalin (and replaced by Russian colonists), during which almost half the Tatar population died of maltreatment.) Only in the final days of the Soviet Union were Crimean Tatars allowed to return from central Asia to their homeland.

Given the placement of the Russian Black Sea fleet in Crimea, along with the large number of Russians who chose the temperate Crimea for retirement, Crimea is an inviting soft spot for Moscow mischief making. Greater autonomy would leave Ukrainians (24%) and Tatars (15%) in Crimea even more exposed to ethnically-driven neo-Soviet imperialism.

In contrast, yesterday's Chicago Tribune ran an article titled "Poised to Spend" with the cutline "Americans hung on to their old sofas and tvs amid the slump, but that may soon change." The thinking is that people have held off on major purchases for so long that there is pent up demand in the system and that Americans are taking on household debt again to fix and replace things. Contrasting the two articles is fascinating.

Personally, I am in the midst of downsizing my home and am planning to use an estate sale service to rid myself of furniture, possessions and clothing that I don't use or need anymore. My fourteen year old car has started every day, despite the record cold in Chicago and I will hang on to it until I can't drive it anymore. I find myself thinking about every purchase - large or small - much more than I did before the recession.

Yes, the economy is stacked against the middle class, but I also think the middle class has had a serious shock to the system and that people are going to be more cautious for the rest of their lives - just as those who survived the Great Depression were.

As a hanging-on disciple of the two screens, and also sometimes having to work with just my laptop screen when on the road, I am not swayed.
I am very conscious of the focus issue, and I can agree that keeping an email client open on one screen while working on the other is a waste.

However, the value is not the more, but the independence of the displays. I have not seen anybody use multiple windows effectively on one screen. I do not know why that is, as that is supposed to be a feature, but at least for me it does not work.

Using two individual screens allow me to look at two different aspects of my work, without having to switch. Think the first application ever, CAD drawing on one screen and the command and control on the other. Or reviewing one document against a file of notes or a different version. Or a raw measurement data file vs the interpretation. Or some scientific work in progress vs. the source documents. I am doing a lot of things that show this dual structure, and I am very happy not having to switch back and forth.

Ross Douthat gets nothing right despite being on the fringe of the far right (he admires Ryan's views on taxes).  He writes "policies championed on the right — mass incarceration in response to the post-1960s crime wave," made life and marriage hard for the poor.  The right (led by Reagan in California) made "tough on crime" and long prison terms a political tool, not an answer to a "crime wave."  The war on drugs invented crimes--taking drugs less dangerous than tobacco became a felony, drugs less dangerous than alcohol made you eligible for life in prison (especially if you were black).  Usefully, convicting blacks of felonies took them off the voters' role for life--another "wrong" vote denied. The war on unions brought wages down (as did inflation control that aimed only at wages) and made marriage a risk since employment became tenuous and increasingly underpaid.  The children of two parent families will have better chances if, and only if, the family income rises above the poverty level.  Better one parent with a good income than two working long hours but living in poverty.  Can Douthat find no more recent study than Yellen and Akerlof of 1996 to suppport his views?  Their claim (as Douthat reports it) that the sexual revolution “made marriage and child support a social choice of the father," seems bizarre: child support is legally required in most states.  Those laws can't give the father an income however.

I began having children in 1970. I had three children; 1970, 1976, 1978.

When I went to school individual effort and achievement were highly valued. Group problem solving was not. Thus we, as students, were encouraged to act independently. Well, except for some science projects. Being in the gifted art class my education may have been a bit different but except for science I was never encouraged to work with a group on anything. I remember quite distinctively that the only people who relied on group thinking were believed to be scientists, sports teams, and astronauts. So when it became the 'new' thing that education would force children to be taught to learn to act in groups I thought it was a mistake. I haven't changed my mind.

Children are not able nor capable of making decisions based upon acquired experience. They rely on peer pressure to guide them and placing them in a setting where all decisions are based on a group of peers is like rounding the loaded syringe among 'friends'.

This 'new' educational goal just sounds like more of the same. Instead of teaching children the basics of research, discovery, and individual thoughtful conclusion we are going to teach them to be zombies following blindly whoever is in the position to lead. In a country that use to pride themselves on innovation, that harbored and encouraged Graham Bell, this is a significant indicator that the fall has become a slide. There's no innovation when everyone is the same type of thinker.

A primary function of companies like Apple, Microsoft, Verizon, Sprint, et al., is to act as conduits of our private information. For the most part, we don't communicate with them, but through them. When I write, or call, friends, or search the internet, I reasonably expect that communication to only be read/hard and retained by the intended recipients. Just like when I use a landline to call, or send a letter, I intend that no one other than the recipient retain a copy of that communication for some undisclosed later use. I did not buy my I-phone so the government can more efficiently track and monitor my every move. The camera on my computer is not intended for the government to use and watch me. Yes, they have developed the capabilities to do all of these things and more.

The right to privately communicate is sacrosanct. Many may shrug their shoulders upon learning of NSA's total surveillance capabilities, but ask your son or daughter for their smart phone, contact list, and access to all of their text messages last night and see their reaction. In the abstract many don't care, but in reality, we all shudder at the thought of someone getting into our inner most thoughts.

The reality is the NSA has no right to obtain our private communications without an articulable suspicion we have committed a crime. That is the way it should be as a democracy cannot exist without unfettered privacy.

Jerry Brown has nothing like this underway. His high speed train project is a massive boondoggle. While nothing gets done out in the San Joaquin Valley, Los Angeles County spending on transportation infrastructure remains sadly lacking in state and federal funding. Jerry Brown's energy policies are resulting in California's rapidly escalating electricity costs, increases that are projected well into the future, while the rest of the nation is benefiting from lower energy costs.

We used to have a wonderful small independent bookstore in Hingham Centre.  At the time I was working full-time and still able to drive, I'd spend several hours on Saturday afternoons at this store, Bookport.  The owners knew me, and I could sit on an old sofa & browse through beautiful art books while listening to classical music floating through little speakers mounted near the ceiling.  I purchased all my books there, and when I wanted one Bookport didn't carry, they'd order it for me at no charge.  Alas, those days are history.  I am now obliged to order my books on line.  Books have been a passion and a refuge for me since childhood.  Bookport is now a pricey boutique.  Like Manhattan, Hingham Centre has become a shopping area for the very rich.

What is misunderstood is that profiling has been a great tool to use to catch criminals when it is used correctly.  If most criminals of one type of crime are 90% white criminals, then profiling white people for that crime is appropriate.  Ditto other races.  The problem arises when police stop EVERY person of every race or sex, just because they are that color or sex.  I read where one of the people suing in NYC was arrested again, for selling fake products.  The profile worked for him BEFORE that arrest, and the arrest validated the profile.  If taught properly and used properly by police, profiling works.  If the feds had listened to the actor who saw the 9-11 killers on a plane from Boston to CA a week or two BEFORE 9-11, many people would be alive today who went down with the Twin Towers.   The idea is to NOT use profiling to stop all black men on the streets or driving down the highway, but to use it as a tool to observe and determine if further investigation is necessary.  I worked with Marconi who deliveloped the airport profile search many years ago.

Very well said. Unfortunately, your comment is just the tip of one iceberg when there are many such icebergs over a whole range of issues. Selectivity in citing facts and statistics - whether in news stories or on the editorial page - are the bane of news and opinion consumers. What's really in the media's best interest is to earn and maintain consumers' trust. You don't accomplish that by sidestepping inconvenient facts to make your case look stronger. Sooner or later those facts come out. I urge anyone interested in this issue to read the opinion piece in Tuesday's (April 8) Wall Street Journal editorial section. It is a brilliant, well-documented rebuttal to the view expressed in the present editorial.

My husband is highly educated and trained with decades of experience in his IT field. We absolutely need to change our currently system. I've been married 8 years, and spent the majority of that living in his country. When we wanted to come back, we were told that I had to come back here first. His petition being in process means that it's almost impossible for him to come visit. By the time he finally gets his visa, it will have been over a year since we saw each other.

Oh, the irony, as most of that time has been spent with the USCIS trying to determine whether or not we are actually married.

My husband doesn't want to come here because he wants to "steal" American jobs. He wants to be here with his wife and two small children. I wanted to return to my country, and we wanted to stay married. (We're so crazy.) He just wants to support his family and be a father to his children.

When you require married couples to be separated while you attempt to prove that they're actually married, something is very wrong with the system. Even worse is when the customer service people mock and belittle you when you call up looking for information after 9 months of waiting because you miss your spouse.

When you can't get any information out of the system about your case while it's in process, something is very wrong.

If your case goes beyond normal processing times, they just move the date so that you're not beyond normal processing times anymore.

The system need to change.

You are wrong. From Matt Taibbi's article, "Nobody should shed a tear for JP Morgan":

And remember, this sort of liability was basically the only risk Chase took in these deals. The government took on most of the rest, in order to make the acquisitions happen.

Chase got to buy Bear Stearns with $29 billion in Fed guarantees, with the state setting up a special bailout facility, Maiden Lane, to unwind all of the phony-baloney loans created through Bear's Ponzi-mortgage-mechanism described above. So Chase got to acquire one of the world's biggest investment banks for pennies on the dollar, and then got the Fed to buy up all the toxic parts of the bank's portfolio, essentially making the public the involuntary customer of Bear's criminal inventory.

Later on, Chase took $25 billion in TARP money, bought Washington Mutual and its $33 billion in assets for the fire-sale price of $1.9 billion, and then repeated the Bear scenario, getting another Maiden Lane facility to take on the deadliest parts of Washington Mutual's portfolio (including, for instance, a pool of mortgages in which 94 percent of the loans had limited documentation).

Incidentally, the notion that Chase was somehow dragged kicking and screaming by the government and forced to buy these two massive companies essentially for free is almost as laughable and ridiculous as the oft-cited explanation for the financial crisis, that the government forced banks to lend to the poor."

Rule 9.02 (a) reads, "Any umpire’s decision which involves judgment, such as, but not limited to, whether a batted ball is fair or foul, whether a pitch is a strike or a ball, or whether a runner is safe or out, is final,"; therefore, this column gets it wrong. The home plate umpire's call on balls and strikes is always right

Not only that, it's based on misleading data (i.e., the use of high speed cameras) because there is more to a pitch being a strike than in-out and/or up-down. The strike zone, by definition, "is that area over home plate the upper limit of which is a horizontal line at the midpoint between the top of the shoulders and the top of the uniform pants, and the lower level is a line at the hollow beneath the kneecap. The Strike Zone shall be determined from the batter’s stance as the batter is prepared to swing at a pitched ball." The strike zone moves as the batter moves. Those pitch zone boxes superimposed over the picture are based on a static strike zone, which as is clear from the definition, does not exist.

Sorry, fellas, but the umpires never get it wrong, you only think they do.

I'm reminded of a story my grandmother told about an experience she had after she moved to a rural community in the 1930's.

"Tell me, do you consider yourself Jewish, or American?" a woman asked.

"Do you consider yourself Presbyterian or American?" my grandmother replied.

"I never thought of it that way," said the woman.

I think it's a good example of how unintentional slights can be an opportunity to break down cultural barriers when those who deliver them are well-intentioned rather than malicious.

Do we live to work, or do we work to live? When you have the choice to cut your hours, you can work to live. When you're stuck with an ever-increasing workload consuming most of your time and focus, you're living to work.

People having the option to work fewer hours and still be economically secure is a benefit of the new system, not a bug. We have too many people chasing too few jobs right now. Employed people choosing to work fewer hours gives some unemployed people a chance to rejoin the labor force. It also gives the people making the choice more time to live their lives. Raising families, creating art, volunteering in their communities, playing games--some are more societally productive than others, but all can provide some personal satisfaction. Working to live can be satisfying.

The Founding Fathers felt that some leisure time was essential for people with the franchise, at the very least so people could be aware of their communities, learn the political issues of the day and vote on them using sober and measured reason. It's hard to pay attention to the issues or be connected to your community when you work 60 hours a week, spend 10 hours a week in transit, and spend some time unwinding from your stressful workweek and commute.

I find myself aligned with Maureen Dowd/Jon Stewart on this one, which (in the spirit of the occasion) I would label as the immoderately ridiculous faction. The essential question is which potential GOP presidential candidate will bring the most delight on a nightly basis to hard-core Comedy Central aficionados. Based on the current field of improbables, I'm likely putting my money on The Cruzer. Truly speaking he's probably a tad too bright to be a perfect Republican, but his ability to take his own nonsense seriously puts him in a class by himself. On the other hand, I'm certainly prepared to jump to Michele Bachmann or Rick Perry if either of those two inspiring luminaries were leap into the ring. I'd also include The Trumpster if he weren't such a shameless tease. If I'm going to go the tease route, I'll surely hold out for Sarah Palin.

It should be fun. I just can't wait for 2016 to get here. At any rate, it sure beats moping around trying to solve all those nasty problems cranky liberal eggheads are always whining about.

It's also one of those problems that begets further problems: I think fatherless families get treated worse than families with fathers -- that's certainly what happened to our family after my husband died. Teachers and other school personnel treated us much worse than we had been treated as an "intact family." I once heard a school director quote, as she was reading from some notes on a school registration form for one of my sons, the social work terms they used to describe our family's fatherless status, and while unfortunately I can't remember the exact words, it was clearly condescending and unflattering. And in our case, it was difficult to see what moral inferiority could be attributed to us on account of a death of a parent from (a fairly rare) cancer.

My point is that I suspect there's also an element of picking on the vulnerable just because we are vulnerable, including vulnerable to being treated badly. Parts of the Social Security program, it is my understanding, were put together to address some of that. I think it's a factor we shouldn't overlook. We can help strengthen fathering while we also address the situation of families in which there is no father available.

It's fascinating to see Mr. Douthat all but accusing non-conservatives of not valuing work, an attitude that he well knows is anathema to virtually everyone. At the same time he can smugly proclaim that his conservative brethren "tend to see work as essential to dignity, mobility and social equality" while entirely ignoring the reality that it is not work that enables these noble values: rather, it is the decent compensation for work that enables them. (Well, uncompensated work may provide dignity, but that dignity will be hard to maintain if you can't go to someplace you can call "home" after you're done working.)

When Mr. Douthat can explain how the unbridled, unregulated capitalism so prized by the far right can of itself guarantee a living wage for everyone who needs it (in exchange for a reasonable amount of labor), maybe a meditation like this will be worth reading. Note that even Adam Smith, he of the market's invisible hand, couldn't see a way to make pure capitalism meet that requirement: that role he left to government.

I had no problem picking up a bottle of Louis Jadot Beaujolais-Villages (2011) and a bottle of Jean-Paul Brun, Cote de Brouilly (2012). For the third bottle, I had to substitute with Grands Vins Villa Ponciago, Fleurie(2010).

Honestly, I was never much a fan of Louis Jadot wine. My first sniff and sip of the current bottle reaffirmed my memory! It's nose reminded me of some cider, flavour quite thin and flat! And it tasted more alcohol than it is. But I decided to stick to the bottle when we were having baked pork back ribs in Asian spices. That was when the wine had a sudden change of personality! Even though its nose remained the same, the flavour became more assertive and the texture more velvety. It was certainly complementing my spicy and gingery ribs! I was pleasantly surprised!

Some people suggest that Beaujolais should be served slightly chilled. Do you agree with that, Eric?

It's a form of age discrimination either way. By giving insurance coverage "equally to all employees", you are giving them a benefit whose value varies considerably. For one employee maybe it is $15,000 a year, for another perhaps $7,500. The variance exists both for your actual cost of providing the insurance (baked into rates before the ACA, and explicit or baked in after), and for theoretical replacement cost to the employee of the benefit.

In a certain way, giving them all the identical subsidy is actually more fair. Any discrimination occurring is done by insurance providers, and in this context such discrimination is legal and the basis of risk-based insurance.

My children were raised in the town of Hanover PA. The town was all white, the schools, churches and every other social institutions were all white. We bought a house there because it was affordable and we had no clue about the lack of diversity.
I taught at a private Catholic boarding school that took kids from all over the world. I took my kids with me (I taught art). My children grew up listening to different languages and seeing faces of different colors.

When my oldest son came home from his first day of kindergarden he asked me what "a word for blacks" he had never heard in his young life meant. The concept of calling a person of color a name like that was something he could not comprehend.

The only solution for this is to live with diversity. Yet we see gated communities around golf courses springing up everywhere and I am pretty sure they are not diverse communities. That is the reason people could think Travon Martin had no business walking down the street of such a community and see him as a criminal.

I live in Oakland now, a place of rainbow colors and I love it.
