Leaders' salaries come out of the budget that these schools get from the public. How do the leaders' salaries compare to the teachers' salaries? Starting pay at most charter schools (success academy included) is one tenth of Moskowitz's salary. The reason for the high turnover is that these schools have very demanding cultures, where young people fresh out of college jump on board, and then get ground down by incredibly long work hours, an expectation that all the parents in their class will have their personal cell phone number so they can call and chat about homework in the evening, on and on.
As Moskowitz says "this isn't a gig!" by which I guess she means we are doing something big for students. But the commitment to a regimented curriculum and to high test scores doesn't translate to high salaries for the teachers. Their pay is pretty close to the average for public school teachers, who have clearly defined work schedules and days off, and usually a much more relaxed atmosphere at work. People who have a choice leave and go work where their days will be easier.
These issues aren't irrelevant, they are legitimate roadblocks to the success of this education model. The idea that all public schools are bad and all charters are good is silly, they both have things to learn from each other.

Thanks, Gail, for the reminder that Gloria Steinem's birthday is this coming Tuesday.  I and my husband will break open a bottle of champagne Tuesday evening, to toast Ms. Steinem.  Growing up in the 1950's and 60's when I didn't know any women who worked and thought my adult life would be so horribly boringly limited, the feminist movement saved me just as I entered college, showing me that doors could be opened for women, and we could do so much more with our lives.  I have always thought that I owe so much  of my life to Betty Friedan and Gloria Steinem, and, too, to the millions and millions of women all across this country who stepped forward individually and together in the late '60's, '70's and '80's to change their lives and this country.  Yes, Tuesday evening, my husband and I will toast Gloria, and Betty, Shirley Chisholm, Robin Morgan, Eleanor Holmes Norton, and all us ordinary women who together accomplished a revolution.  (And we will offer prayers, too, that more younger women wake up soon and continue this work.)

Whenever I read an article about prisons, I always think about the fact that prisons "house" hundreds of thousands of humans . Most of who are there because they have committed nonviolent offenses. But prisons are not run to make sure that offenders spend their sentence in a safe and humane environment; they are virtually allowed to run themselves witht e most violent offenders being able to prey on the weak. I would like to see the test be untimed--or, in practical terms, test-takers be given more than enough time (i.e., 5-6 hours max.).

It would be a fascinating large-scale pilot to compare the scores of groups of matched test-takers who took the test under various timed conditions, even just the current allotment and twice that amount. Some interesting patterns might emerge.

I understand that speed is one factor in "measuring" cognition, but if the redesigned test truly does attempt to approximate real-world thinking and tasks, then it makes sense to do away with the artificial time constraint. Yes, people in the real world work against deadlines and need to have some degree of automaticity when it comes to applying their skills to novel situations. But usually not with the amount and kind of content students are asked to consider under timed on-demand testing conditions.

This case is indeed cruel, and frightening, but it is indicative of a trend among pro-life and disability-rights activism (I'll even go ahead and call it what it is becoming--pro-disability activism). The complete disregard for the quality-of-life, well-being, economic circumstances, and human rights of the people involved (women, families, children themselves) to make private decisions by the pro-life camp has reached an unthinkable level of perversion.
Having children is perhaps the most personal decision any of us will ever make, and I believe it is a basic human right. It requires the most complex calculus of personal beliefs, bodily autonomy, and sacrifice. I would never stand in the way of those who choose to bring their children into the world at risk of grave impairment (though personally, I think it's often cruel and irresponsible). But many people fighting the birth-at-all-costs, life-at-all-costs battle completely disregard the real concerns of pain, severe disability, and economic cost that figure into these kinds of decisions, write them off as insignificant (or even champion them in an effort at righteousness) and do stand in the way of those choosing to not give birth to children who face impairments. How on earth have they talked themselves into this corner, and why do they face so little opposition?

Young officers in combat units are not typically desk jockeys. The Army truly expects leaders to lead from the front. The leadership culture in the military in general is one that emphasizes mission and men before self. Corporate America and especially Congress could learn a thing or two.

Be that as it may, as an enlisted Veteran with two Iraq campaign medals to my name, I share in the general opinion that it is a good thing that a new generation of officers and enlisted will not serve in war. From their perspective, it is hard to be the new kid without a combat patch. But most everyone with one will tell you war is not something to aspire to. It is inhuman, it is a waste of life and potential. It should always be our last choice. That choice lies with our country's leaders.

It is on these young officers to diligently catalog every lesson learned from 13 years of war, to ensure that this time the institution does not forget the full range of unconventional war tactics and strategy. They must do this while ensuring the force regains its conventional war readiness, and retains its leadership culture. All this in a time of budget cuts. It's not glamorous. But it's vitally necessary.

In most cases, preschool teachers are very low paid and have minimal training - in some cases, they may make close to minimum wage and be paid only for a few hours a day. It's not set up as a career.

Further, in most cases, kids do not have a right to attend a free and public preschool, as in kindergarten and up. Thus, there is generally no mechanism to pull those kids out and resolve the problem - even a school that wants to doesn't usually have the funding or the staff to deal with issues. It's thus not a surprise that they'd jump to expulsion and suspension.

The data doesn't lie and it's obvious we have a problem that needs to be addressed in all grades. Giving all kids the right to attend a free public preschool and integrating them with elementary schools would help too.

I vaguely remember the speech my dad  gave about what it would be like as a African teenage boy moving to America. I sat through it thinking "what is this man yapping about now?' Within three months of getting here I was arrested by metro transit police in Atlanta. I woke up that Saturday morning and rode the bus to the arts center to do a paper for my art 101 class. On my way back from the museum, I tried to use $100 bill to get into station not realizing that the machine didn't accept bills that large. I had just cashed a traveler's check from home. So I walked around the corner to buy a gyro to make change.On my way back into station a police officer arrests me for "stalking the machine" (using a fraudulent card to let people into station in exchange for cash). I was searched and held for about 4 hours  because no one would explain to this international student what it meant to "stalk" a token machine.  It didn't help that I had all this cash on me. Eventually somewhere between the "witness" refusing to sign the subpoena saying he did not think I was the suspect he reported and the incoming evening officer finally explaining to me what I was accused off and the tears as I explained and pleaded that I was just a foreign student and I had never seen a transit card in my life, or ridden the train. I was finally let go. I took a taxi home and have never been on the train again. That was this african boy's first encounter with American law enforcement. Have been allergic since

I'm a big supporter of annual mammograms, one saved my life.  When I was 50yo, a suspicious mammogram lead to the discovery of a 7 mm lump that turned out to be invasive ductal carcinoma.  It was too deep to be discovered through self-exam. I ended up needing an MRI guided biopsy because the doctors could not feel it either.  Had I NOT had my annual mammogram, it would have been absolutely massive by the time I discovered it on my own.  i would undoubtedly have needed chemotherapy, something I was able to avoid by discovering the lump early.  And it probably would have spread to my lymph nodes.  By the way, I also had extensive ductal carcinoma in situ in this breast, a condition this study said is overdiagnosed.  Well, I think I could make a good case for the fact that one of my little DCIS specs probably grew into my lump. I would MUCH rather have a needless biopsy and overtreatment than months later hear my doctor say, "I'm sorry, you have a cancerous lump and the cancer spread to your lymph nodes."  I have two friends that passed away from breast cancer and I'm sure they'd agree with me.  If only one in 1000 woman is saved from eventual death by a mammogram, well....I don't know about you, but I don't want to be that one woman.

Franco may have changed the time zone, but I suspect that the Spanish rhythm predates Franco. It would have been interesting to hear an account of the rhythm of Spanish life before Franco.

I spent about 6 weeks in Spain in 1968. We lived with a family in Madrid for part of that time. The daily schedule was exotic indeed. Breakfast was light, and lunch was indeed at 2. The working members of the family returned to work at 4. Dinner was at 10. Department stores and such all closed for several hours in the afternoon. Movies and theater performances began at 11. People were always out and about, such as walking their dogs, at 1 a.m. Every aspect of the culture in the city revolved around this rhythm. It is hard to imagine that this schedule was legislated to begin with or that a change could be legislated all at once.

Though Mr. Blum is all about race, college admissions rarely are. Building a freshman class is a nuanced thing-- you don't want all white, all African American, all asian, all girls, all boys, all east coast, west coast, middle, gay, straight, poor, rich, middle, musicians, mathematicians, or artists. The best freshman classes are a mix. A diverse (not just racially) group of students can gain experience, knowledge, and empathy from each other. They can add to each others' education that are intangible and beyond the grasp of Mr. Blum.
Also, good students get into good schools. They may not get into exactly the school they (or more likely, their parents) would like, but if they work hard and keep an open to experience they will be fine and do well in life. 'You Don't Always Get What You Want" is also a valuable life lesson.

This is the irony of Americans running around the world preaching the gospel of “democracy”. I live in Texas and like four-fifths of the American people, my vote for president had exactly zero effect on the outcome of the election. Neither major party candidate even bothers to campaign in all but maybe ten states.

American political campaigns have always been a bit tawdry, but not since the Gilded Age have they been so nakedly putanesque. And with Citizens United, secular simony is now on steroids. The 2012 election is a watershed in the final transformation of the American experiment in democracy into a rank kleptocracy, minus the sex appeal of a shirtless Vladimir Putin.

Americans now seem content to allow the highest office in the land to become an object of dynastic inheritance. It is not at all uncommon to hear ordinary voters opine on the great future Chelsea Clinton or George P. Bush have as future presidential candidates.

In 2000, the entire world watched the spectacle of the Supreme Court impose a President who lost the popular vote after a ridiculous debate over hanging chads and butterfly ballots. With complete stasis in Washington, a never-ending war in the middle east, and an out-of-control security establishment, why does anyone think the world wants what we have?

If there is credible intelligence that a member of a terrorist organization has concrete and actionable plans to kill Americans, and is actively working to carry out those plans, they should be terminated with extreme prejudice *especially* if they are an American citizen, not *except" if they are an American citizen.

Why is so much time in the US media spent on discussing Putin’s views and Russia’s perspective? This all distracts from what’s really important here – that the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine has been violated, as was the right of the Ukrainian people to decide for themselves what they want. Why not talk instead about the dangers of redrawing national borders from the outside and the consequences of yielding to the aggressor who blatantly and cynically violates all international laws?

How to increase opportunity--get decent jobs for the non-rich.

Suppose you run a business. You make cars. You cut lawns. Are you going to hire more people, build more factories, or buy another mower, if you can't sell more cars or cut more lawns? It's true that people want a new car or their lawn cut, but they don't have enough money to pay for the car or the lawn service. Too many are out of work. Too many have low paying jobs.

It's not taxes or regulations that are holding the economy back. It is the lack of money on the part of those who would like to spend it. There are only two sources of money.

1. The Rich have a lot of money. They could afford to pay their workers more, build new factories, hire more people, BUT they are not going to do that until there are people who can buy more stuff.

2. The only other option is the federal government. It can borrow & print money. It can spend money. There are many worthwhile ways to do so. It can fix our roads and bridges, build a new power grid, give grants to the states to help with education, sponsor research, etc., etc., etc.

As a percentage of GDP our public debt is about 40% less than it was in 1946. From 1946 to 1973 we increased the debt in dollars by 75%. BUT we had prosperity. Real median household income surged 74%.

After WWI we had 10 years of balanced budget. We decreased the debt in dollars by 40%. This was followed by the worst economy in our history.

Those who don't learn from history are ...

Politicians have always been bought and sold on the market, and to pretend that they haven't been is to act the fool.
Now it is confirmed that it is okay and legal and it also confirms what almost everyone has always feared.
When money talks, morality often walks. When money talks beginning in 2014 we will begin to watch Democracy walk out the door into the ether.

Where I'm from this is called "ignorant" plain and simple.  Many years ago I worked at a management consulting firm where most of the young new hires were from Ivy League or top tier schools.  Not one of them had a sprinkling of culture which I define as knowledge of history, art, music, philosophy.  And please don't get me started on their lack of table manners and social graces (knock before you enter a room, eat with a knife and fork, say good morning).  My plumber and cleaning woman in Barcelona had more culture and manners than any of these kids.  I just couldn't believe what I was hearing/seeing.  In most Western European countries, a young person with an equivalent education would be versed in world history, speak a 2nd or 3rd language and have decent manners and social graces.  If this is the future of this country, then I am glad I have dual citizenship because I certainly don't want to live in this country when this generation comes to power.

This article touched a nerve - not because I attended a HBCU, but because I graduated from a women's college (in 2007, for the record).
The school I attended, throughout the four years I was there, addressed head-on why, given that the proximate reason for the establishment of women's colleges - mass refusal of universities to admit women - is no longer an issue, why women's colleges still exit. It is a complex issue, and as Dr. Wilson mentioned in the article, many women's colleges have responded to the shifting climate by going co-ed or by closing. While the issues are certainly different at HBCUs, the analogy can be drawn.
The conclusion my alma mater came to: while a woman can attend Harvard, or Yale, or Columbia, or almost anywhere (last I heard, there were four men-only colleges in the US), there is still sexism. It remains an issue for women and girls. And while you can certainly make the argument that removing oneself from the scene is perhaps not the best way to address the issue, my alma mater made the argument that the women's college still has a place, if for no other reason than as space where it is safe to be female.
So, to complete the analogy: for so long as racism exists, and remains an issue for people of color, HCBUs have a place. If for no other reason than for the sake of their being a place where it is safe to be a person of color.

Education should be more than a homogenized slice of cheese. While the SAT tests are not perfect, they do provide a basis for what a student has accomplished.
It is wrong to think that by eliminating essays, and a broader scope of vocabulary, school boards are "improving the situation". They are not. They are, through budget cuts and administrative squabbling, creating cookie-cutter students, who will become cookie-cutter citizens; circling the drain of the lowest common denominator.
Our centers of learning need to focus more on personal motivation for students. Education is NOT regurgitation. It is learning HOW to learn, and making that immediate and exciting, so that students become inspired adults, willing to make a positive difference in the World.

Imagine the immediate aftermath of the Boston marathon bombing.

The police quickly found the Tsarnaev brothers as the potential culprits from (private) video footage (that filmed everyone in the area without due cause).

The next step for the police at that time was to locate them, while they were at large causing further carnage, killing a security guard, etc.

What the police needed most at that point was to locate their friends and ask them 'where to look?' - their phone records. The phone company already had that record.

Police had two options - go to a judge (in the heat of things) for a warrant to get the phone company records, or have the records in their hands already to do the search and locate their circle of friends.

I am not sure if there is a big difference here - a private company or the government having this database. In terms of timeliness in police work the difference is big!

It is meta-data. This database is a collection of 'who-called-who'. Not the contents of their conversation.

I realize that we as a nation are paranoid about 'government-overreach' and what I am trying to say here will be unpopular.

If you think that it is OK for phone companies to have this database and exploit it for any number of profitable reasons, and that the government shouldn't have it to keep us safe from terrorist, then so be it.
Wouldn't it be nice if people like you mentioned that idea to teenage boys?  Why don't we ever hear anything about that?

It is incomprehensible to me that anyone would want to corral them into a cove and then slaughter them merely to capture a few young ones, who after this trauma are condemned to a horrible fate among mankind. Much is made of protecting First Amendment rights and Second Amendment rights. It is difficult to understand why protecting the Fourth Amendment became less than a priority over the past 25 years.
People say, "well if you don't have anything to hide why should you care if your privacy is invaded?"
One social media founder was even quoted as saying, "privacy is no longer the norm."
But in a society that questions much, we seem to have lost the ability to ask the right questions - questions like, "okay, if we do that, what happens when it's done for an improper purpose? [or] Who's to say what is and isn't proper in the shadowy world of eavesdropping?"
"An American law firm was monitored while representing [a party] in trade disputes with the US."
Since the Patriot Act Presidents, Congress and sadly, the Courts have offered thin justifications for acts and laws that intrude into our private lives.
These justifications have eroded our incredibly important Fourth Amendment rights like polar ice caps in the 21st Century.
Why are we still there?

I am one of those for whom the "false" claim is true. I believed a lot of people in this country make WAY too much money and that it is in itself a problem. I DO want redistribution.

See, the overall economic pie is the size that it is. Whatever size that may be, when one class increases the size of its slice, less remains for the rest. Take a look at this:

In 1960, the average CEO pay was 20.1 times the average worker's pay. The top marginal tax rate was 91%. Our growth rates dwarfed those of today.

In 1978, the average CEO pay was 35 times the average worker's pay. The top marginal tax rate was 70%. Our growth rates were not as strong but still robust.

In 2010, the average CEO pay was 234 times the average worker's pay. The top marginal tax rate was 35%. Our economy is struggling to maintain any growth at all.

Think about what that means. I believe there is a cause-and-effect relationship between the rich getting too much richer such that it causes the failure of the remainder of the economy.

Remember, the Great Depression, when many Americans subsisted on what they could get from the bread lines, was the era of the Duesenberg, Auburn and Cord. And income inequality was less pronounced then than it has become today.

We are cruisin' for a bruisin' if we keep this up much longer.

For 25 years my husband and I have paid taxes to support our California public schools. I am sure that any potential slot for him in our public school system was prioritized to someone from out of state or out of the country for their higher tuition.  Why are we doing this?  Shouldn't we be educating our best and brightest with the obligations to our tax payers and the future of our state and country?  Our only choices are now private schools, some of them are elite and all very expensive.  At a moment when we should feel like the reward for his hard work and dedication is an affordable education, we are faced with decisions weighed heavy on the cost. That balkanization trend has good and bad effects. People have a wider variety of entertainment choices, and greater spectrum of artists reach an audience. In a long-tail age, niche audiences find the sound or story that suits them.

Unfortunately, our popular culture gets diffused. No more water-cooler show. Fewer artists are known and revered by all. Fewer films and music define an age. Fewer public intellectuals and critics have the power to shape opinion and taste. Our society's becoming like a suitcase college or college in a big city: the pull of life off campus is so great that the on-campus social life can disappear at times.

If you can't identify any landmarks in your country's culture, it's harder to identify with your culture. People are less willing to think about what they can add to a community and are more focused on their private rights and privileges. Public goods and public works don't receive as much support. Last year, I went through what I believe was a completely unnecessary needle biopsy, followed by surgical removal of the tissue which was all that remained of the cyst that had been biopsied. As a result, I have a permanent scar. I also had severe bruising from the needle biopsy. During the entire I was completely terrified that I had a malignancy. That is because the radiologist exaggerated the risk posed by the tiny cyst that she had discovered during the sonogram.

Moreover, I felt that I had fallen prey to a breast cancer industry, and was on a conveyor belt that would lead to treatments that could injure me. It was very frightening to feel that I had become not a person, but a product. I did not like that feeling -- it was as though I was being worked over.

Fortunately, I had a great surgeon, who made the experience as tolerable as possible for me. When I went for a follow-up mammogram, however, I was once again put through sonograms and worry, as the new radiologist questioned whether my curremx-ray was identical to my previous one. My feeling is that I never want to go through this again. Told my gyn, however that I would never have another mammogram, because it was not worth the terror and pain, she looked at me as though I were crazy. I don't think I'm crazy. I think I'm right.

Here are some of the comments that I have heard throughout my life as a Black Female:

You don't talk black.
You don't look black.
I don't think of you as black.
You're not really black.
You're not black enough, Oreo (from the black community and some family members)
You have very European features (implied: for a black girl).
What ARE you? No, I mean, where are you FROM? (US, born and raised, fyi.)

These are ignorant and sometimes hurtful statements, but I never felt they came from malice or an intention to hurt. My parents made it very clear to me at a young age that as I moved through the world, it would fall on me as a black woman to face down stereotypes and work to change them. Sometimes by pointing out language or words that were racially inappropriate or ignorant, but mostly by just showing myself to be different from people's pre-conceived ideas. This breaking down of stereotypes was not to be done just on behalf my own group, but for any group that was being talked about derogatively or ingnorantly in my presence.

As much as I consider my own speech and behavior in our diverse world, I too have been educated for words I have spoken out of my own ignorance. (Luckily, with good friends, they gently and compassionately let me know where I'd gone wrong.) It's important to remember that we all have our blind sides and lack of exposure, but as long as our hearts and intentions are good, we can all learn from each other.

Jack Matlock, ambassador to the USSR from 1987-1991, points out that the US has been poking its finger in Russia’s eye since the end of the Cold War. He writes:

“President Clinton supported NATO’s bombing of Serbia without UN approval and the expansion of NATO to include former Warsaw Pact countries. Those moves seemed to violate the understanding that the US would not take advantage of the Soviet retreat from Eastern Europe.

“When terrorists attacked the US on Sept. 11, 2001, Vladimir Putin was the first foreign leader to call and offer support. He cooperated with the US when it invaded Afghanistan, and he voluntarily removed Russian bases from Cuba and Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam.

“What did he get in return? Some meaningless praise from President GW Bush, who then delivered the diplomatic equivalent of swift kicks to the groin: further expansion of NATO in the Baltics and the Balkans, and plans for American bases there; withdrawal from the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty; invasion of Iraq without UN approval; overt participation in the color revolutions in Ukraine, Georgia and Kyrgyzstan; and then, probing some of the firmest red lines any Russian leader would draw, talk of taking Georgia and Ukraine into NATO. Americans, heritors of the Monroe Doctrine, should have understood that Russia would be hypersensitive to foreign-dominated military alliances approaching or touching its borders.”

The battle against climate change cannot solely be waged on the field profit driven capitalism. Any investment a company makes to reduce carbon emissions will have both an immediate negative impact on its bottom line with the results benefiting its competitors. We will have to move beyond capitalism to a new global economic system that rewards process over profits. We have to develop a new metric that assigns prosperity to processes that reduce carbon emissions instead of just making the cheapest goods. Otherwise, there is no mechanism in pure capitalism to create the incentives for these kinds of investments.

Furthermore, this is global problem. We will have to develop trade organizations that dictate where we import goods from based upon associated carbon. Price can no longer be the sole factor.

A carbon tax is insufficient as it is a negative incentive that can be overcome with higher profits. We must move to a global system that gives preferential treatment to processes that reduce carbon regardless of profit.

I'm thinking outside the box here toward a permanent solution. So long as the cheapest energy rules, carbon fuels will reign supreme. All governments will have to get involved to develop a positive incentive based trade system to reduce emissions.

If Coca-Cola and others really want to help, they must use their financial clout to get politicians elected that will move toward these goals.

The root cause of violence is the indellible influences humans receive as infants or toddlers from their parents (or parent). Spanking is violence. To a 20 or 40 pound human, a tap on the bottom is like an adult getting hit by a Buick. Furthermore, the spank enters the child's learning process never to be forgotten, "hardwired" as it were. The learning includes a message that violence is an appropriate and effective way for the spanker to get what the spanker wants; that physical pain is certain to help change behavior. Nothing can be further from the truth. But that's only the beginning.

Emotional violence is quiet and insidious by comparison, but no less harmful to a child.

Transfering a culture of violence (in the form of spamking for example) is socially problematic for all children. Why it should be more important to black children is for those experts to say. Nevertheless I propose an end to parental physical and emotional violence to black children as a starting point toward ending the tragic imbalances Mr. Blow identifies.

I worked in a ground breaking initiative called iCARE at an elementary school in Middletown,CT. It was a partnership between school,community and health care system. The premise of the initiative was to address issues at the elementary level and prevent incarceration later in life, especially of minority students. The support we provided to the families included three staff members who worked in the school and community. This program is inexpensive compared to the cost of incarceration later in life. This is the kind of support that public schools need to address social/emotional issues for students who do not receive special education services. In many cases parents refuse to accept help and the student continues to escalate which can result in suspending children if they are not safe. Suspending children is not ideal and programs like this can decrease suspensions dramatically.

From a distance, the issue of Kashmir appears to be more of an imagined cause of Pakistan's instability and violence.

The root cause may have more to do with the tension created by the intrusiveness of Modernity into a traditional culture. In this case, Pakistan's traditional islamic society cannot cope with the difficluty of adjusting to the freedoms, the excesses and the responsibilities placed on individuals in modern societies. pakistan is a relatively new nation and it would seem that its national consciousness lacks the cohesivenes,strength, and social capital that other Islamic nations with greater historical depth have. Its national consciousness is shaped more by its sense of being a homeland for muslims of the subcontinent, a refuge for the believers among a huge mass of unbelievers. Pakistan seems to have had a sense of being beseiged, culturally as well as geographically, since its recent birth.
And because its birth, its reason for its existence, is tightly linked to creating an Islamic state, Pakistan is unlikely to have the peace it seeks until Islam itself finds a way to make its peace with Modernity. That is unlikely to happen anytime soon.

I am an alumnus of UM -- I was able to attend on scholarship and was thrilled to be a part of the school and the campus, particularly its activism. However, I have to say that day to day race relations on campus during my time there (early 90s) were dismal. Many of the white students came from majority-white suburbs. Many of the black students came from majority-black Detroit. Generally speaking, the black students hung together very tightly. There was an underlying hum of racism, confusion, defensiveness, and tension on campus, despite the best efforts of the university to celebrate diversity.

In a more mixed environment, with greater percentages of each group, those in the minority feel safe enough to reach out. Those in the majority are forced to learn some of the basics about other groups. It wasn't just the black students. Students who were first generation college students (regardless of race), students from working class backgrounds (regardless of race) -- many people felt alienated at UM.

I don't fault the administration for their efforts. But Detroit is Michigan's largest city. It is less than an hour away. It is 80% black. Do what it takes -- before people get to college -- to serve all of the citizens of the state.

My spouse and I are healthy and in our 50's.  I wouldn't characterize our experience a horror story, but it was incredibly frustrating considering that we have always been supporters of universal health care.  When the ACA was enacted this year, our individual policies were cancelled by Anthem; not because they did not meet the requirements of the ACA but because Anthem decided to not offer the policies any longer in our area.  In searching for new insurance we encountered a very concerning situation.   The new policies provide unsatisfactory coverage, for example, contracts with one hospital, but none of the doctors who had privileges at the hospital.  Additionally, the provider lists are woefully inaccurate and it appears that a number of doctors on any given plan that we can access are not taking new patients.  We finally settled on a new policy, which costs 50% more than we used to pay and does not cover most of the doctors that we previously had relationships with.  Not horrific, as we are healthy, but so disappointing.  It did not have to be this way, while the ACA is a great idea, it is a sloppy and poorly implemented law that unnecessarily creates more chaos and confusion for everyone involved.

Thanks for another informative piece. Granted, economic trends in America grossly benefit the extremely wealthy at the expense of any plausible notion of a middle class in the US. Should the standard of living for middle class Americans be expected to rise with each generation?  Is that version of the American Dream consistent with the meaningful dreams of a better life of people in developing countries?

First, a few words about testing. The students who do best on standardized tests are the ones who were better educated in the first place. If you've taken tests like the SAT, GMAT, LSAT, GRE, etc., you already know this. And, if you've taken test prep courses for these tests, you know that the preparers don't teach you how to read or do math, although math reviews are generally fairly thorough. What they do do, however, is teach you how to be more likely to select the correct answers. That's what test prep is and should be about.

But in K-12 schools, the tail is wagging the dog in that students aren't receiving enough time to learn in the first place as all of the emphasis is placed on test prep. That's wrong in so many ways and will never be the best way to teach kids how to read or think critically, write well, analyze, etc.

And, to lynninny below, I agree that much of the public school model is broken. However, a lot of what's needed to fix it is known and has been available for some time. We need to address lifestyles and cultural values that undermine education in the communities where students fare poorly. And, no, it's not poverty in and of itself, though that's certainly an issue. Many poor students do well in school because education is valued in the home, and their home lives are fairly stable. If we get at the root of why children in certain communities continue to fail, we will be able to repair this broken model.

Terribly misleading. I checked my two doctors - one my "primary" (Board-certified Internist) and the other a pulmonologist. Medicare throws everything under the doctor's name. So the total "amount" Medicare assigns to each doctor has little to do with what the doctor actually earns. For instance, my pulmonologist proscribes a flu shot every year for his patients. (I have COPD) Although Medicare "assigns" this fee to my doctor, he himself never gives me the flu vaccination - his aide does.
And although my Internist routinely (once a year) proscribes a chest x-ray, cbc and an ekg, he himself does none of these tests. (I am 83 years old and have high blood pressure, high cholesterol and am a cancer survivor). The amount of money Medicare claims they have paid my doctors is vastly inflated to include all and sundry medical personnel who have been involved in my health care as well as various medical procedures. I find the reporting of these figures misleading and intrusive. I believe most of the problems in this program result from the way Medicare was designed and is administrated and only rarely from fraud or greed on the part of hard-working and ethical doctors.

I do feel empathy and compassion for so many millions of unemployed people, but I think the outrage expressed in these comments is misdirected. What we should be asking is why, in this, the richest country in the world, is there a lack of jobs for those who are willing and able to work. Jobs creation should be at the forefront of the country's demands from the government. Extending unemployment benefits indefinitely, as someone suggested, is no solution, unless we want to bring welfare to a new level. And that should require means-testing to determine who, in fact, depends on unemployment benefits to survive.

I don't mean to sound cynical or cold-hearted but I can visualize a situation where, in a two--income family, one of the earners is unemployed but the other is working and earning more than enough to support the family. In such a case, is the unemployed spouse entitled to receive extended benefits? Perhaps he or she doesn't mind staying at home raising their kids and have time to pursue activities one could not indulge in when working full time. Not to mention the savings (transportation, restaurant meals, day-care, and so forth), which would compensate for the reduced income. Searching for another job, therefore, might not be such a pressing matter.

Historically, unemployment benefits were meant to provide a temporary income after we lost a job, and even though these are tough economic times they should not be expected to become a permanent entitlement.

I moved into a poor, ethnically diverse neighborhood because, as a public school teacher, I wanted to live among the families of students I taught. I also wanted a short commute. My wife, a highly paid executive at a major film studio, was apprehensive but agreed to give it a chance. We are relatively well-off financially and are by far the richest family within blocks, though I have been surprised a bit by the economic diversity here. Not everyone is abjectly poor. We are also the only Anglo people on our block and on several blocks surrounding.

We've lived here twelve years now, and I wouldn't trade my house or my experience here for a mansion in Bel Air or Beverly Hills. People watch out for each other in my neighborhood. People pay attention, and when someone is in special need, emotionally or financially, neighbors reach out and help as best they can. This is the safest and happiest place I have ever lived in.

If you want to learn to swim, you have to stop fearing the water and jump in. We'd have a much safer, better American if we hadn't segregated our cities socioeconomically in the latter 20th Century. Too bad we couldn't see that.

I think if Eich had changed his mind, and said so, we'd have a different outcome. That he didn't do this indicates that his opinion hasn't changed.

While I also don't want to see intolerance on the pro-gay-rights side, I see this episode as legitimate protection of their rights. A CEO has a big effect on company policy and culture, and if I were gay and a Mozilla employee, I'd also have wondered if Eich would have sought to affect employee benefits policies, for example, and whether or not I'd be able to advance up the corporate ladder in the same way a straight person would. This doesn't look like intolerance to me, but defensiveness.

Eich wasn't persecuted, just ousted from a job where the match was very bad. On the other hand, Proposition 8, which he supported, would have withheld rights from fellow citizens, which is closer to my idea of what persecution means.

Eich will do fine. He'll get a job at a company whose values are more in line with his own and will probably make a bundle.

As a "self-sustaining public corporation" it is only accountable to itself and therefore has no legal incentive for transparency.  It's time to end the free lunch, also known as the Port Authority and create a governing body that can be held accountable for its actions by the public who pays the tolls.

At what point in human history, in the face of object war, did unilateral treaties get replaced solely with weakened diplomacy? Russia has put their troops on foreign soil in direct military action against our ally. If our ally asks for help, we will help. There is no UN security council resolution we need for that. Our friend is in need of defense against a stated enemy. If other nations want to talk about it, they are welcome to equivocate their need to participate. But our position in the world was built on our word. It was built on the world knowing that we stand by our friends and allies through their difficulties. That is how trust is formed. That is how relationships are formed; trade partners are made. That is how the world moves forward.

What is the NYT editorial board's expertise to opine on the retirement of the A-10 fleet? There is no modification to the DNA of the child itself.  Each human cell has a few different mini-organs, called organelles.  The purpose of one of these organelles, the mitochondria, is to take sugar that you eat and turn it into energy that the cell can use.  People with mitochondrial problems cannot do this and suffer greatly because of it.  Mitochondria contain their own DNA that is used to make things specific to the energy conversion that occurs in the mitochondria.  An embryo contains its mother's mitochondria, and therfore its mother's mitochondrial DNA.  All that researchers are proposing is taking the defective mitochondria (along with their mitoDNA) of a fertilized egg and replacing them with functional mitochondria (and their respective mitoDNA).  This is similar to replacing a defective screw in an engine, the screw makes the engine function properly but you're not changing the engine itself, just preventing it from falling apart.  Is something like this expensive? Probably, but so is the screening that already occurs for a number of genetic disorders like cystic fibrosis.  Parents who know they both carry the CF gene (and therfore have a 25% chance of having a baby with CF) can have IVF done and have each embryo screened to see if they are affected. Only the non-affected embryos will be implanted, preventing the parents from having to watch their child slowly die before their eyes.

This essay rings with powerful nostalgia and heart-truth for me. I grew up in the South of the 1940s and 50s, and left as soon I could. I really cannot go back. Too much brutality, too much ugliness still remain, more than ghosts. Yet the landscape, the sounds - why, the smells that rose out of my grandmother's basement when I opened the door - earthy, mushroomy, faintly musty, like mice - and the way the sun came through the curtains in the hall window - all these sensory experiences are forever home to part of my mind. Today I live in a beautiful little farm in the Sierra foothills, and am comfortable and surrounded by beauty. But at night, when I drowse before sleep, I go back . . .

I can't say I disagree with anything David recommends, but when building a house the first thing you start with is the foundation. As someone who has a well-paying middle-class job, I think back to what my own parents did right. Although they were not particularly well off, they provided me with a stable environment where I could incubate my own learning. In practical terms, this meant they gave me a secure space at home that was quiet, well-lit, comfortable, and near enough to the (stocked) kitchen that I could take snacks whenever I needed. In this "room of my own" I taught myself to code on a (now) laughably underpowered computer, but those self-taught skills are the basis of my well-being today.

It's important--and essential--to give children love, structure, and social support. But, you can't raise a successful child if she can't learn because her stomach is always rumbling or she's shivering in an unheated apartment because her parents can't afford the electric bill. I know that I never would have learned to code--which requires deep and sustained concentration--if I hadn't enjoyed that comfortable spot of my own.

I don't have a magic answer, but we should make it a national priority to ensure that all of our children don't have to worry about essentials like food, heat, and shelter. If we can meet this bare minimum, and give kids a quiet space to learn, then we may find that many of them (like myself) are able to pull themselves up by their own bootstraps.

RE the jaywalking ticket initiative, in my experience, the most dangerous part of crossing the street is turning cars, especially ones that are *behind* you. When I cross at the corner, I am at risk from cars making turns who, as a general rule, do not yield to me as they are supposed to. I believe the statistics on pedestrian deaths bears this out. So in addition to narrower, safer and better landscaped streets, we need much stepped up enforcement as well as a public health campaign reminding drivers to yield when turning.

The right to free political speech is the most important right in a democracy. Without it, when oppressed voices are silenced by the government, the society ceases to be free. I have the absolute right to stand on the corner of the street and express political speech. But I also have the absolute right to pay someone to stand on the corner of the street and express my political speech. Or to pay someone to print pamphlets that express my political speech. Or to give the money to a group which expresses political speech. Or to give the money to a political campaign which expresses political speech.

Saying "money is speech" is a gross oversimplification. Spending money allows me to express my protected political speech. And as long as the money being donated goes only towards expressing political speech, the Supreme Court's ruling is congruent with both the Constitution and American values.

I would, though, be first in line to support legislation requiring more clarity in the reports of how campaigns spend their money.

No. There are 7 million people who have signed up for Qualified Health Plans (individual insurance) through their state exchanges or through healthcare.gov. This includes people who have signed up but whose first insurance bill has not yet been sent or is due yet. Of QHP enrollments where insurance premiums were due, 90% to 95% have been paid -- the unpaid rate is pretty much the same as it was in the individual insurance market before ACA. After all the people who were able to start their registration before midnight March 31 but not finish get signed up (they are being given two weeks to complete), the final tally of QHP sign-ups could be over 8 million. Overall, the ACA has resulted in 15 - 22 million people gaining health insurance who did not have it before. Best non-partisan information is available at ACAsignups.net.

As a radiologist, i can affirm many of the points in this article.  I regularly saw overuse of CT scans in our hospital and often found it difficult to persuade my fellow docs to use an alternative imaging approach.  However, as a sister, I found out that my brother endured two years of US and abdominal xrays for his 'stomach pain' before someone finally ordered a CT scan and discovered his Stage 3 testicular cancer.  Risk vs benefit.  We must be bold and prudent at the same time. The European radiologists and regulatory agencies are much more on top of this than we are and have been for years.  Patient dose is tracked and emission from CT scans is known.  This is a serious issue in this country and I applaud the authors for stepping into the controversy.

Mr. Brooks misses two important contributors to income inequality:
1. The "Financialization" of the US economy over the past 30 years: Example 1: hedge funds take on huge debt to purchase a stable profitable company that actually makes or does something of value, strip mines it to artificially increase profits, make huge payouts to themselves financed by debt loaded on their new acquisition, then sells the company to the public where it struggles until the inevitable bankruptcy. Example 2: The Greenspan/Bernanke) “put” where huge losses by both banks and non-bank financial organizations (e.g. LTCM) are covered by taxpayers, who also bear the economic devastation, gains are kept by the financiers, and huge bonuses are paid regardless of the outcome.
2. Toleration of China's economic growth policy of the past 20-30 years, where Chinese workers’ wages are suppressed to subsidize the export economy and infrastructure growth, resulting in significant US trade deficits for most of this time. China is effectively importing demand from the US (and the US is exporting demand to China), and in the process the US manufacturing economy is enervated. The jobs thus lost employed middle class people in the US, and this relentless export of demand contributed mightily to the “growing class of people stuck on the margins” that Mr. Brooks mentions, and the hollowing out of the U.S. middle class.

So Rutland is emblematic of the drug epidemic in Vermont, and it seems all of New England?

What I don't see in this account is much to do about the elemental problem of hard core drug addiction. It seems like much of the effort in Rutland is directed at the physical dimensions of the community rather than the crucial human dimension.

This leads to the question of just what the options are for successful intervention and recovery from heroin addiction? Refurbishing a neighborhood is one thing, reclaiming addicted human beings is something altogether different and much more complicated.

Unfortunately this piece had little to say about this core aspect of the tragic problem of addiction that has plagued America for many decades. War on Poverty. War on Drugs. War for its own sake (Vietnam, Iraq, Afghanistan). All failures in very elemental ways. We desperately need to take an entirely different tact.

Should we be surprised at anything Putin has done since the violent overthrow of the democratically elected government of Ukraine?

Putin's immediate reaction had to be: "Could this kind of thing happen to me?" Putin next considered Russia's Black Sea fleet based in Crimea, a region that had been inexplicably transferred from Russia to Ukraine in 1991 but remained dominated by the Russian military and a population that regarded itself as "Crimean" with close links to Russia.

Once it became clear to Putin that the US and Europe would take no military action to prevent Crimea from re-joining Russia, Putin knew he had restored another piece of the former USSR -- just as he had in Georgia in 2008.

Putin now has to deal with threatened economic sanctions by the US and Europe. But how effective would those sanctions be in practice? Ukraine, our supposed ally, could be devastated by retaliatory Russian sanctions. Then what? Massive US/EU aid to Ukraine? That's perfect from Putin's perch: Let the West get Ukraine out of debt to Russia and in good financial shape before Russia makes its next move to protect the "indigenous Russians" of Ukraine.

Good point! However, there are also deeper reasons for linking Catholicism with the bishop of Rome (apart from the pope literally sitting on the bones of St. Peter and Paul [possessing his bone]). For one, the early Western Church Fathers like St. Irenaeus (130-220), bishop of Lyons, France, linked Catholicism with the Bishop of Rome. Until the Reformation, Catholicism and the bishopric of Rome were synonymous institutions. Anyway, it is all very interesting, the article. As independent forms of Catholicism bloom in the US  alongside American Roman Catholicism (24% of the public) and the unaffiliated (20% of the public) and Protestantism continues to decline (less than 48%, according to Pew Researchers), the dominant US religion in the coming years just might become Catholicism (Roman and non-Roman and the 23 Eastern Catholic Churches in communion with Rome) alongside the ever increasing unaffiliated block of citizens. Ironically, Montesquieu predicted this ( i.e., Catholicism would become the majority religion of US in time) centuries ago (only for him, the only Catholicism was that church in communion with the bishop of Rome). With that said, the article by Peter Manseau is great. It gets you to think.

In the spring of 1974, as a student intern in the office of (the late) Congresswoman Shirley Chisholm, I helped organize hearings before her subcommittee on the problem of student "push-outs" - the disproportionate number of students of color who were being suspended or expelled from school for offenses and behavior that rarely triggered the same penalties in whites.

For those counting, that was 40 years ago this spring. Since then, we have heard more and more about racially-disproportionate and racially-misapplied death sentences, drug sentences, traffic stops, vigilante murders, profiling, etc etc etc etc ad nauseam.

Why are we not only still talking about this stuff, but watching it grow worse and more pervasive? Why does it take so long for us, as a society, to effectively act on such injustices? When will we confront, in our hearts and our heads, the truth that an unjust society severely retards its own progress?

We think of ourselves as an advanced society; I would beg to differ. Our ability to destroy and our primitive urge to victimize - fed not just by bigoted fears but by demagogues with a larger agenda for dividing us - has outpaced our study of human behaviors and motivations that could help defuse these behaviors.

But the modern world amplifies the potential for instability that comes with injustice. We have a lot of learning and eye-opening to do - and fast.

Thank you, Charles Blow, for pointing out the need so effectively.

Sure gender pay gaps are unfair. But let’s ask--In order to have decent living standards and financial/psychological security, why should mothers have to make exactly the lifetime wage as men?

Why must we put such pressure on women with children? In nations with modern social safety nets, women raise their kids without the huge burdens, anxieties and even poverty that millions here are subjected to.

In many countries they have good day care affordable for all, freeing women for work or school. Here, child care is too expensive. Wages may not cover child care, plus trans & clothes for work.

In many nations mothers get cash benefits to offset the cost of clothes, food for their kids. No politicians complain about school lunch programs. Their pre k programs are accepted and financed, not argued over. Their govts finance public schools adequately, without our fights over charters vs private vs public. There are housing allowances for both low and middle income families. College is low cost.

Both parents get paid maternity leave. Their generations- long national health care protects families from early death, disability and bankruptcy. Meanwhile we argue about gender pay parity, while leaving millions in peril of uninsured illness!

To confront this lack is to confront our power structure’s huge opposition to higher wages, & govt spending and taxation needed to ensure more economic equality.

Easier to scold the gender pay gap and not confront the bigger issues.

These restrictive laws would have meant my mother would not have been able to vote - a woman who at 87 had never missed voting in any election. She could no longer drive, and so had no valid photo ID. Her passport had long since expired, and we had no idea where her birth certificate was. Yes, we most likely could have gone to the expense, time and trouble to get a copy, so that she could somehow get that ID, but why should we have to? Do you think she's the only one in these circumstances? Yes, more of us should vote every time, just like my mother did. So why make it harder to do so? We should be making it easier.

I just find all generalizations about how religion affects society pointless.  As though there is a monolithic entity called "religion". That leads to even more fatuous commentaries on how "religious thinking" compares to something superior called "scientific thinking", as though "religion" in all its forms and permutations is somehow antithetical to science.  I have been a part of or observed various religious communities in different cultural settings.  Some of those communities foster trust, integrity, generosity and compassion in their members.  You could ask their neighbors whether or not they contribute to the welfare of society and get a resounding positive answer.   Some communities foster fear, a sense of entitlement, or magical thinking and hostility towards outsiders.  Let's talk specifics, not vague generalities.

I did poorly -- basement-bad poorly -- on my SATs. What exactly is being measured? I felt shame with my scores, and all of sudden very much the inferior to my higher scoring peers. Perhaps the reaction was nothing more than ego, teenage self-centeredness, and an inability to accurately comprehend my academic strengths and weaknesses. Whatever I felt, it was more than 40 years ago.

The SATs were an obstacle and nothing more. Just one of a number. Instead of college, I joined the military. During part of my service, I was able to take a few courses at a local state university. I took economics and history and did very well.

When I sat down with a college admission officer shortly after my discharge, I felt a little uncomfortable because of the SAT scores. But they didn't matter, I was told. The only thing that counted were the grades I got at state university while in the military. The SAT past was erased. College was completed.

The SAT's won't tell you how some will do in college. They won't tell you how a life will turn out. They won't tell you a thing of any real worth, of that I'm convinced.

Thomas notes that he was the first black kid in an all white school. As such he was not a threat and accepted because he was just one. But I bet there were many in that school that started thinking "there goes the neighborhood."  I remember I lived in what I thought was a diverse neighborhood: there were Jews, Polish, Italian, a few Hispanics. There were no blacks. Then one day the Polish woman from whom we rented, sold the house to a black family. I can tell you that such a move set off a panic and the whites in the neighborhood soon all left. So for Thomas to say that race was not an issue in his day shows you how completely clueless he is, including on the bench where he says nothing and follows Scalia wherever he goes. Thomas also places all northeast liberals in one pot--and those remarks are in themselves stereotypical---and shows where his opinions are when they come to the court. Interesting that Israel is contending with "free speech" issues. The willingness of a nation to suffer and protect offensive and infuriating terms is in indicator of its basic embrace of democracy. That Israel hadn't already banned the N- word is actually quite amazing, and admirable. One hopes this law is squashed.

In the US, on the other hand, our N- word is essentially banned from use except in its corruption by the aggrieved minority. Bit steps by bit the US tramples on free-speech with idiocies such as criminalizing "hate-speech" and the imposition of "hate-crime" penalties on top of a criminal sentence. These appear as fair attribution and emotionally satisfying actions to advocates but are democracy diminishing in the long run.

Free-speech is always endangered. Even today our Supreme Court tackles the issue in which an anti-abortion activist is legally banned from effective expression because - well - some might be inconvenienced by her voice.

Democracies reacting to nasty or impolite expression are treading a needle and doing flip-flops attempting to distinguish allowed vs prohibited. Of course, an impossible and destructive task that wouldn't even be considered in a genuine democracy.

I am Russian. My family still lives in Russia. I spoke with my father yesterday. His commentary on the events in Crimea was short: “Enough humiliation!” To understand this, consider how the US treated Russia since the collapse of the Soviet Union. Here’s a quote from http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/63008/dimitri-k-simes/losing-russia

“Clinton administration officials expected the Kremlin to accept the United States' definition of Russia's national interests. They believed that Moscow's preferences could be safely ignored. Soon, however, even Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev - known in Russia as Mr. Yes for accommodating the West - became frustrated. As he told Former Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, "It's bad enough having you tell us what you're going to do whether we like it or not. Don't add insult to injury by also telling us that it's in our interests to obey your orders."

But such pleas fell on deaf ears in Washington, where this arrogant approach was becoming increasingly popular. Talbott and his aides referred to it as the spinach treatment: a paternalistic Uncle Sam fed Russian leaders policies that Washington deemed healthy, no matter how unappetizing these policies seemed in Moscow. As Talbott adviser Victoria Nuland put it, "The more you tell them it's good for them, the more they gag."”

How would you feel if your country was treated like this?

20 years later, the same Nuland was plotting a coup in Kiev. Another helping of spinach...

If you want to make a significant impact on low SES children, you have to start well before age 4. And you have to spend well over $8,000 per child per year. My estimates are closer to $14,000 per year for 4 years. But if you do that, the returns to society are enormous in the form of more taxes paid over a lifetime and reduced safety net and criminal justice system expenses, as well as less obesity, less smoking, and breaking the chain of poverty from generation to generation.

Pre-k would be nice. But I fear that society will do pre-k and fob that off as having done something wonderful, then studies will show that pre-k did less good than advertised, and we will have lost another generation of low SES kids and the opportunity to transform our economy through a more skilled workforce.

I hope that writers like Mr. Kristof will not let the pre-k possibility get in the way of their seeing this broader picture. We need a bolder vision.

Another person made this comment, but I would like to highlight it once again: Just because a relationship is/was consensual does not mean one person within the relationship cannot be sexually assaulted. If I consensually sleep with a man 30 times, it does not mean he can force the 31st time. Prior consent does not establish ongoing consent. And--just because a woman loves a man or writes romantically about him in her journal--doesn't mean he is incapable of assaulting her. This is a complicated case, but we need to stop equating a consensual relationship with the inability to be assaulted within that relationship.

I was very struck by the board's reporting on Costco. I live in a dense urban area outside Boston close to both a Costco and a BJ's. Since BJ's was built Costco remains as crowded as ever, and I've always found their employees to be knowledgeable, dedicated, and focused. BJ's, to the contrary, pays minimum wage, and according to reports in Boston media, is being sued for sloppy time records and nonpayment of wages. But even more, as a customer, I see a vast difference in the training and dedication of BJ's employees who seem at times indifferent to their labor.

A decently paid worker with a chance for advancement is a happy worker. An unhappy worker who feels trapped in his or her job performs poorly in terms of customer service.

We have over half the world's lawyers, almost all of whom do nothing substantially useful. But lawyers are corporate chiefs frequently without knowing much about the products of their companies. Thorsten Veblen, who died shortly before the market crash of 1929, noted that it was much easier to get a law degree than one in engineering, but the rewards were greater for lawyers and the engineers actually produced stuff whereas the lawyers did not. We have laws to protect the rights of workers, but these are frequently disregarded by companies such as Wal-Mart who have lawyers to protect their malfeasance. Instead of getting rid of bureaucrats, as the Right would have us do, we should note that other highly productive countries, such as Germany and Canada, do not have legal compliance decided by tort lawyers but simply by effective government enforcement. We have a stock market controlled by shorters such as Einhorn and Ackman. The market is not bssed on economic reality but on perceptions created by speculators. It would be an easy matter to require that all hedge funds reveal their short positions on a weekly basis. Why is this not done? Ask such self-styled liberals as Chuck Schumer, the Senator from Goldman-Sachs. Nobody would consider it safe to have New York without a police department. But the market is virtually unprotected. Bravo Ms. Lee! It is not easy to challenge the recommendation of not only one's physician (and the American Cancer Society) but also one's mother. The history of medicine is replete with treatment and screening recommendations that have been discarded. And presumably superseded by treatment guidelines that rest on evidence based medicine.

The medical profession tends not to do well with ambiguity (and resists change). Witness the uproar with the new cholesterol treatment guidelines, the less stringent guidelines for blood pressure control, and the disbelief that PSA screening should be abandoned. It is hard to tell a patient one day that they need to start taking a statin to prevent vascular disease because the medical literature supports its use, and then have to tell that individual the next visit that the latest treatment guidelines don't support its use.

Ms Lee's experience is an excellent cautionary tale - while we may wish for certainty when it comes to recommendations and decisions regarding our health care, the state of the art in medicine evolves and patients ultimately must make decisions that they are comfortable with after gathering as much information as they can.

Individual salaries are easy to defend. Anyone can parse the wisdom of this particular obscene compensation. I'd rather hear a defense, if one exists, of why the financial services sector has a near stranglehold on all of our lives. Why no one goes to prison for defrauding the American people. Why our cowardly lobbyists masquerading as elected officials have stacked the deck, with the help of more paid lobbyists, so that upward mobility is a thing of the past. Why we have shifted from an economy that makes things to one that pushes things around on paper, including people.

Jamie Dimon's salary might be perfectly reasonable within the context of the cruel and unsustainable reality of our current system. You do not get to design the economy, from scratch or not. Economies are not designed by anyone -- they are the result of millions of individual decisions, with NO overall plan. You can read Adam Smith for more detailed description of how this works. The few attempts there were to actually design economies with an overall plan in mind ended in severe human misery -- look up Soviet Union in history or travel to North Korea for live demonstration.
What you do get to design is the tax code. And, yes, "confiscatory tax rates" implies that taxing away wealth that someone has earned is confiscation -- because it IS. Taxation is a reasonable thing to do if, in exchange for some of the wealth being taxed away, people were to get government services. Then it is not confiscation, but rather pay for service. But if you tax away wealth in order to give it to someone else (redistribution) then it IS confiscation. The wealthy "through using their power to write the tax laws", as you say, do not confiscate the money that the middle class earns, they simply refuse to give away more of their wealth in taxes. Not giving something to you is not the same as taking something you already have away from you. Yes, by influencing the design of the tax code, the wealthy are refusing to give more of their wealth to the middle class. You are certainly entitled not to like it, but you cannot call it “confiscation”.

I'm not so sure that the "It's Russia" shrug meant what the author thought it did. Most Russian Christians are Eastern Orthodox and adhere to a different holiday calendar. Having a Christmas tree up in late January or on Feb. 1 would not have been strange. Perhaps she was just saying, "It's Russia. We're Eastern Orthodox, dummy."

In time, the court decision could empower key political leaders, such as the speaker and minority leader of the House and majority and minority leaders of the Senate, by giving them the considerable clout of campaign money over their rank and file.
Political parties can deliver results donors desire more efficiently than individuals. Party leaders can use campaign money to reward congressmen and senators who follow their wishes and withhold money from those who rebel.
Because of this efficiency, many large donors -- particularly corporate and main-stream business ones -- probably would prefer give big money to parties than to candidates. Large ideological donors would remain, but most would get better results through parties.
This change could loosen the gridlock in Washington. Starved for money, Tea Party favorites would lose influence.
This is far from a fair political world. The middle class and poor still would have serious trouble getting their voices heard because they don't have the money to make large donations. This change would revive party bosses who would control the spending of contributions. The country could have a situation similar to the New York state legislature, a European-like parliamentary system where little happens unless party leaders negotiate deals and the rank and file go along.

The Japanese seem to be mainly hunting Minke whales, which are relatively abundant, not endangered, and hunted by several other nations. Objections to Japanese whaling seem to rather be along the lines that people shouldn't hunt whales for food, but that's easy for us to say since we don't eat whale as a cultural matter. What if we were the only nation that ate tuna, and a bunch of other nations banded together to ban tuna fishing for no adequate tuna-protection reason but just to stop us from eating it? Probably our dander would also be up. If you don't want to eat whale, don't eat it (I don't and haven't), but it's sort of chauvinistic to demand that no one else eat it either in the absence of a compelling conservation rationale.

"If the FMS was reprogrammed 'most likely' from the cockpit, and this is confirmed information, why don't we know the final destination?"

The article says that the experts have deduced that someone in the cockpit apparently entered a new waypoint into the FMS. As far as I can tell, the article doesn't say how they deduced that. I can only surmise that the known flight path makes a gentle turn, which takes it off the normal path, and then proceeds straight to the location of a waypoint, flying directly over it. That's how the plane would behave if a new waypoint were inserted at the top of the list (although the pilot could make the plane do the same thing "manually", with the autopilot off).

This doesn't tell us the final destination because we can't see what was entered into the FMS, but only this indirect evidence about this single waypoint. We don't even know that a final destination was entered, since you can always fly without using the autopilot.

"Could the Flight Management System be reprogrammed remotely? Do you think Free Scale engineers (20 of them) could do this with their technology?"

No, you'd have to have physical access to the keypad in the cockpit. No radio signals are involved in the control of the FMS, so it's not like your neighbor hacking into your home WiFi network. There's a photo of one of these keypads in this Wikipedia article:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_management_system

I agree that transparency is necessary for our citizens, or any other, to debate the merits against the drawbacks. But we need to remind ourselves that the goal of any agreement of this kind is to establish a level playing field for all parties. The first tendency of any "have" society is to be protectionist, and we need to suppress that tendency in ourselves while realizing that even though our middle class incomes have stagnated, these incomes are still 10 times the incomes of the third world for the same type of work. While I support unions in their efforts to balance the power of capitalists, they do themselves a disservice by being so parochial, and they suffer in public opinion because of that. Labor has to realize that they are in this battle together against the money horders. Fighting each other over a small sliver of the pie is not the answer. Together, they need to demand a more reasonable slice that they can share equally.

Maybe the best outcome would be is to get rid of the insurance companies altogether. As you point out, healthcare is not a great fit with healthcare, as we know needs will certainly arise, unlike say car insurance when car crashes are not inevitable, but of course very possible.

We have finally come to a point that we can, as adult Americans, discuss this great need and what we have paid into it. Let's not forget this: We pay for our healthcare coverage. It belongs to us, not the doctors and insurance companies. We pay 18% of our GDP and we had better start to demand something better.

Connect the dots: An important reason that so many American citizens' incomes have stagnated is because of the Law of Supply and Demand. When there is a massive increased in the supply of labor, the price (wages) goes down. In the last few decades, Congress has imported millions of low and high-skilled workers to compete against American citizens and supply cheap labor for American businesses. Let's stop doing this! Check out www.progressivesforimmigrationreform.org

My predisposition was to attack your work. But, you changed my mind in the first few paragraphs. This was one of the best written and thorough pieces I have in the NY Times. Kudos to you.
I tend to agree with your triple threat as the source factors of success. Yes, success takes hard work, but your work explains why certain people work so hard!
Although I agree with the internal validity of your model when using your definition of success (test scores, wealth, power, prizes), I share the same concerns as many others with your definition of success. I know people who I would count as successful and that you would count as unsuccessful. Modest income, modest wealth, and only local level awards but happy, loving, and productive. Prof. Morton I. Kamien was a great researcher, great critic, and great teacher, and he was a lifelong friend and mentor to me. Mort died in 2011, and he was born in Warsaw, Poland in 1938. On his behalf, I would like anyone who will listen to know that Tom Perkins letter is hideously evil propaganda worthy of Joseph Goebbels. Nevertheless, the letter only proves that Perkins is insane. What is serious about this incident is the Wall Street Journal's decision to publish that letter. Surely the WSJ receives ample supplies of hateful vile letters covering every topic and slurring every ethnicity or religion that exists. People need to ask themselves why the editors of the WSJ chose to print a letter that attempts to hijack the public's sentiment over history's greatest tragedy and use it to protect the interests of a few of the smug super rich. Those of us who actually live in the middle of the country don't generally refer to it as "the heartland." We refer to various areas as "Great Plains" or "Midwest." Or we use the names of our states. And in all the decades I've lived here, I have never once heard anyone claim that we are the "real Americans."

When I see the term "heartland" in the New York Times, I can be pretty sure that sweeping generalizations will follow. We're more than tornadoes and farms and oil rigs. There are thriving cities and beautiful lakes and parks. There are liberals as well as conservatives. I hope to someday see an accurate portrayal of the Midwest and Great Plains in this paper.
