Much of what Mayor de Blasio wants to do may founder on funding, where the direct taxation that fuels it must be approved by Albany. Before his eyes get too big, on pre-K, other educational priorities, salary paybacks for municipal union workers, higher child-care subsidies, more affordable housing and paid family leave and a new city-wide minimum wage, he needs to understand what leverage he has in that snakepit. The pre-K initiative is a great example: everyone political is in favor of it, lauds it and wants to claim credit for supporting it, but nobody wants to pay for it. And he runs the political risk of being blamed for its failure because of an inability by all concerned to find efficiencies in other programs to make the lift, or to tax New Yorkers, already among the most heavily taxed in the nation, even more.

The world is not going to be transformed solely on the backs of the 1%.

If the Mayor is serious about his priorities, he needs to look at what the City now pays to do and find those efficiencies, opening up hundreds of millions per year at least to make a start at fulfilling his campaign promises; and to have a discussion with New Yorkers about relative priorities, and sell his. But we see nothing along these lines -- just a demand for more money from a long-suffering tax base.

It could turn out to be at the end of four years a lot of talk and no real changes.

Hollywood makes movies that make money and if that's a movie that masquerades pornography as a "message" movie then so be it. The almighty dollar is key. Why skip a mammogram that might be useful? In my case, it wasn't useful, it was hurtful. I had some suspicious calcification in one breast and my radiologist told me there was only a 20% chance it was cancerous, but I needed a biopsy. The biopsy was an agonizing and painful four hour procedure followed by a month long recovery.  Early detection does not necessarily lead to a more successful recovery. Treatment is what is leading to higher survival rates. Mammograms can lead to overtreatment as well as pain and suffering. Everywoman must make her own decision. In my case, I am going to be very cautious about mammograms.

Part of the reason college expenses are so out-of-control is that our kids have become quite spoiled in the lifestyle area. Colleges now need to have spa-like facilities and they try to create an experience that has nothing to do with intellectual development. It is as if they are marketing a vacation, not an education. Dorm rooms are no longer the single sometimes-shared room with a bathroom/shower for the whole hall that my generation lived in for college - now they are full scale apartments. The food service of my college days back in the 70's was nothing like the food service today, with all the various "stations", etc. Some kids in college are so busy being "entertained" that they forget they are there to study.

There is probably no going back, but I can't help but think that cutting out all the luxuries would help control costs.

I'm 49 and was diagnosed with breast cancer this week. Thanks to regular self-exams and regular mammograms, I know that it was caught early--if you think that early means that, according to my surgeon, I've likely had this slow-growing cancer, undetected by current technology, for five to seven years. The quibble over mammography begs the question: Why aren't there better, earlier detection methods with fewer risks? For all the advancements in diagnosis, treatment, and survival rates, we should not be satisfied nor reassured that mammography is good enough. There is much work to be done (and funded) at the cellular level and smaller. Would I skip a mammogram? Not if I was in a high-risk group (I am) or of a certain age. At least not until there's something better. We deserve something better.

NASA has taken quite a while to open up about the medical problems of sending humans into space. Manned space flight is really a publicity and fundraising effort for NASA. Most of the real science has come from robotic probes which are growing more sophisticated all the time.

NASA has always been dominated by engineering. Medicine and biology, which are all important to manned flights, have taken a back seat.

The Russians have found that it takes a month back on the ground to recover from each month spent on the space station. This is not trivial. With our present technology, Mars astronauts would probably arrive at Mars too weak from the weightless journey to conduct the exploration of the planet.

Star Trek-like manned exploration of the cosmos is a pleasing literary fantasy, but it completely ignores reality. The Milky Way galaxy alone is 100,000 light years in diameter -- it takes 100,000 years traveling at the speed of light (now impossible) just to cross our own galaxy.

Robots make great space travelers and explorers. Human beings should explore the universe from space ship earth where evolution has already solved all the technical problems we need to overcome to survive the journey.

A number of years ago they did a study in Spain regarding heart attacks and life style. Those who took the siesta break and napped had far less heart related problems.  The older Spanish people live life for life.  The breakneck pace of other western nations should take heed and maybe be healthier.  Multi-tasking means you are doing a number of things and not very well at any of them.  Driving while texting for example.

1. Adultery is no longer prosecuted as a crime in civilian life. It should be removed from the UCMJ. That is a matter to be addressed by the couple concerned.
2. Affairs with a subordinate over whom one has supervisory responsibility rightfully leads to sexual harassment charges in civilian life. That should also be true in the military. In today's corporate world it often leads to career ending dismissals even at the highest levels.
3. The military and government have a legitimate concern that sexual affairs or other unbecoming conduct could lead to blackmailing activities to obtain secret information. There are provisions for dealing with that.
4. Removing prosecution of sexual crimes from the purview of the command chain no more undermines command authority than the police investigating sexual assault and courts prosecuting it in the civilian world undermines the CEOs of corporations.

What strikes me as odd about Mr Franco's commentary is the presumption that all actors suffer through this identity crisis. While some actors seem to run on the treadmill of acting out, negative publicity, acting out, and so forth, dozens of others do not suffer this enigmatic crisis. Cate Blanchett seems to live an active life as a film actress, stage actress, parent, and so forth without any problems. Dustin Hoffman is as wonderful actor who leads a quiet life without the press hounding him when he gets the newspaper in the morning. As far as I can tell,most actors lead their private lives as private lives and not as tabloid fodder. Frankly, and perhaps I'm going out on a limb here, I think those 99% of the actors I've known have been very professional about their jobs and their lives. Some have not been so tactful. As they say, if you act like a jerk, you'll be treated as a jerk.  The satirical group, the Washington Steps once sang, "Being famous ain't easy, but it's not all that hard." I suggest they get their act together.

The direction this country has taken under the Republican Congress is all down hill. The Tea Party has coarsened what dialogue they manage to have; they have brought the reputation of governing into disrepute through their lack of intelligence. They brought themselves into a position of being held as contemptible through their insulting, coarse, name-calling of a duly elected President; their repulsive denigration of the women of this nation along with people of color and the poor; their pretense of not not believing in science. No one of intelligence believes a word they say because we can see for ourselves how they run after and kowtow to the rich claiming that this is the way to prosperity while the rest of see what empty bags of air they are. Democracy is gone and plutocracy or corporatocracy has taken its place. But a nation that claims to be rich while 20% of its children live in poverty and hunger is a nation deluded and heading downhill fast.

Where is the righteous indignation of the middle class to this stupidity and viciousness? It is swallowed up by the rhetoric of the Tea Party appeal to white people's sense of being "better than that other guy," swallowed up by this simple divide and conquer language and mentality. But you don't grow tall by standing on other people's heads and you won't grow richer again until you hold the hand of your neighbor, no matter their color or religion, and help to lift each other up.

Don't we all wish that politics only addressed positive agendas? Unfortunately this is not what drives voters to the polls. The only thing that consistently works is to get the voters out to vote against something--usually some dog-whistle issue that will never be addressed once a candidate gets into office. I still remember the union guy in Michigan who had been savaged by Republican restrictions on union bargaining and knocked out of work but was still going to vote Republican to "protect his children" from gay marriage. Really.

Governor Christie is still a likely candidate for the Presidency. Who else do Republicans have? There will be a concerted effort to sweep "Bridgegate" under the rug, and smother all the people who correctly see this event as characteristic of his administration--and probably any Presidential administration that he would head. There is already a litany of misdeeds and petty vengeance spewing out of the Governor's office in New Jersey. We certainly shouldn't want that kind of stuff spewing out of the White House, but by 2016 the voters will likely have forgotten--and they will still vote against their issues to prevent poor people from getting food stamps, or to tilt at windmills over gay marriage.

My dear friend, who happens to be Lebanese, and grew up during the civil war in Beirut told me this:

"You, in the West, had your Dark Ages a thousand years ago. You had your sectarian scisms of Christianity 500 years ago and the hundreds of years of bloody, brutal wars that went with them. You had the Enlightenment that sprang forth from the exhausted ashes of those wars, that had the wisdom to separate government and religion, and the open-minded exploration of science, unsuppressed by religion. We, in the Islamic World, are going through the first two now, forgetting our own Golden Age of tolerance, scientific discovery and peace. Will we reach our own Enlightenment? Who knows..."

I've always thought the only thing that kept people from snooping on us would be the sheer amount of people and data to be sifted through. If you can share it, it can also be taken. I used to say to friends, if you don't cover your web cam ports and disconnect cameras, turn off your microphone, leave your sensitive stuff out there, you deserve what you get. I shut up after awhile because they thought I was being a bit obsessive.

Well I feel vindicated, but not in a happy way. A new twist on an old saying: Just because everyone thinks you are paranoid, doesn't mean there's nobody out to get you.

The concept of respecting and honoring "life" has had its meaning co-opted to simply translate to mean keeping alive. If you respect life, you need to understand that life is about determining how you live, ensuring quality of life, and allowing self-determination. It also means recognizing that death is an inextricable part of life. As a physician who has counselled patients and families at the end of life, and as a person who has seen a number of loved ones pass on, I can say that there is nothing more respectful of life than allowing a person to have a say in the manner in which they die.

This case is so clear in which the science, family's and patient's wishes are completely aligned. Any law or entity that stands in the way of this, well meaning or not, is doing the utmost harm to the concept of respect for life.

Great statement by the interim President. It takes a lot of courage to stand up to Putin's aggression, and the new Ukraine is doing quite well, considering the challenge: the country in intact, there is no violence, and even the Russian forces occupying Crimea are not given reasons to start a full-scale invasion, as they hoped.

To say that one set of criminals has replaced another set of different criminals, and that nothing has changed in Ukraine is a grave understatement. Ukrainians got what they wanted in the short term: a kept promise to start preparations to eventually join the EU (and not the Soviet-style customs union with Russia, where Kremlin calls all the shots); and a chance for an open and free election, something Ukrainians lost under the ex-president (and ex-thug) Yanukovich.

Ukrainians are experiencing many conflicting feelings these days: we are feeling worried, due to foreign forces (not just troops, but hired mercenaries) occupying our land; our people are being lied to by Kremlin propaganda; betrayed by the British and Americans, who had guaranteed (along with Russa) territorial integrity in exchange for giving up nuclear weapons.

Dut we also feel hope and unity! Not the naive hope of the Orange Revolution, but the determination to continue standing up for our rights peacefully, and to continue demanding justice and protection of our rights by hired government officials, who must go when their time is up.

After pouring through a stack of intern cover letters and resumes this week, flavorless is the perfect word to describe most (especially the Ivies and especially the near-perfect GPAs). The ones who cut through are always the ones who show me a glimpse of being a real human being. What inspires you about LIFE, beyond well-organized Excel sheets? What makes you weird? Having visited almost all of the Presidential libraries, I disagree with the prescription to omit biographical exhibits. Visiting the libraries/museums of Presidents Eisenhower, Truman, FDR, LBJ, Ford, and Nixon gave me new perspectives on where these men came from and the experiences that shaped the decisions they made as president. Some of the libraries (JFK, Reagan) are more like shrines. Reagan's looks like it was put together by Fox News. JFK glossed over unpleasantness like the Bay of Pigs. But overall, Presidential libraries, when they are done thoughtfully, are a significant contribution to Americans' appreciation of our history.

Freedom of speech is robust in India. It has been so, independent of political party in power(Congress led governments or BJP led governments -- remember that BJP led coalition governed from 1998 to 2004).

However, in all societies, including the US, there are always individuals and groups who oppose an idea or a thought or a book because those individuals and/or groups feel that the said idea or the book is against an important element of culture, religion, or values -- such opposition may be placed but it happens. What complicates matters -- as it does in lots of societies -- is (mis)application of sometimes well-intended statutes. The Indian Criminal Penal Code which penalizes malicious acts intended to outrage religious feelings is well-intended and one can even make a persuasive argument that it is necessary in India.

But the application of this statute to Wendy Doniger's book, "The Hindus: An Alternative History," does not make sense That is the sad part of it. It is not clear why Penguin Books India felt that it will not be able to argue persuasively to the Indian courts that the statute should not be applied to Doniger's book.

I think that Penguin Books would have prevailed, but they had to make a prudent business decision. But we lost an opportunity to test the statute in the Courts.

A year ago, my son died of an overdose of drugs. When I last saw Jeremy, I kissed him and whispered, “I love you.” Those words were the last words that I said to him. Days later, Jeremy died of an overdose of drugs, suffering for 20 years with addiction. He was 34 years old. In 2010, over 38,000 people died from a drug overdose in the United States. 22 million people suffer from substance abuse. To put this in perspective, 58,000 were killed in the Vietnam War, in 2013 breast cancer killed 40,000.
In 2011, there were 32,000 motor vehicle deaths. There is no cure for addiction. Drug addiction is a terminal disease. We need a societal vaccination that can prevent this disease. We need continuous education starting at a very young age on the perils of drugs. It has worked with smoking. Where are the ads showing EMS responders carrying a body bag out of a house with dead teenager from a drug overdose and crying parents and children? Health insurance offers, a “Band-Aid” approach to the physical and mental issues. Why aren’t the pharmaceutical companies, which create addictive drugs, mandated to develop cures for the addiction they create? Why aren’t they obligated to support treatment centers? Why aren’t they obligated to advertise the addictive side effects and support education programs for our children about drug addiction? The answers need to be found soon or the deaths will continue.

Shame on those who suggest that Dr. Kitchin was initially obsessed with the acquisition of material goods and that he consider getting in touch with divinity. Had the good doctor wanted to become filthy rich, he would have obtained an MBA from a top school, then gone to Wall Street.
Neurologists do what they do because they care deeply about people, they want to help them, and they are fascinated with the human nervous system. They work with patients with devastating strokes, neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's, Multiple Sclerosis and ALS, and must speak with families of patients who have been victims of severe brain injuries and explain that while their beloved family members "look okay", they are actually brain dead and must be removed from life support.
Neurologists are among the lowest paid of the medical specialists, as they do not have any "billable procedures". They do what they do because they love it, not so they can make the "big bucks".
Fortunately for Dr. Kitchin, he most likely started in medicine while physicians were still paid what they were worth, and hopefully, he was able to put aside enough money so he could move on later to enjoy another stage of his life. Physicians who have more recently started practicing do not and will not have that luxury.
Dr. Kitchin has already more than done his good works and and has gotten closer to divinity than most.

Bratton's commonsense evaluation of one of the sources of friction arising from Operation Impact makes me think this was a good time for a change. Ray Kelly gets a lot of credit for introducing a lot of improved strategies for minimizing urban crime while simultaneously dealing with an at-times diminishing force. However, it seems evident his success had led his belief in _all_ of his departments tactics to ossify, rather than encourage him to re-evaluate the fundamental assumptions upon which his original implementation of Operation Impact had relied. A fresh, insightful and experienced perspective coming from Bratton seems to have quickly identified a basic problem that can probably be fixed relatively easily but which had metastasized into a stupid, major political fight.

The one question that looms, however, is whether older police officers are going to want to return to heavier crime areas and presumably more stressful work. Doubtless, one of the main reasons for putting rookie cops into these situations in the first place is that what they lacked in experience, they make up for in enthusiasm and energy. Does a 10- or 15-year vet really want to be thrown back into closer-to-combat situations?

I'm not a hunter, but if you read any of the classic works (from old books to newer such as by Capstick) on big game hunting you will quickly learn that the rhino is classed in the Big Five of dangerous game in Africa. It IS dangerous and presumably challenging, and nothing at all like shooting a dairy cow in a pasture.  A rhino, despite being slow and lumbering looking, can charge out of the brush at you at about 35 mph.  You have to be quite skilled and cool headed to aim and effectively hit the animal, let alone stop it.  Animals the size of rhino have to be shot correctly and quickly or the hunter is quite likely to be dead. They have survived for millions of years because they are superbly adapted to their home range and are indeed very dangerous animals.

In New Jersey, each little township has had its own completely autonomous government and school system. It would be different if there were some VALUE in having the existing system. There is not. You can argue that there is value in having organized labor, or in spending at high levels for education, etc. That's a legitimate argument, and states like Wisconsin and Ohio are engaging in that kind of discussion between Democrats and Republicans. There is no VALUE to the taxpayer in NJ's system, except that it empowers local political elites and inevitably leads to questions of corruption in the selection of public employees and public contracts.

It's time to consider making the federal government the employer of last resort. That idea says the government should hire the unemployed at a wage high enough to live at.

Appropriate on the job training can also be provided. But the key idea is to get the unemployed back to work so they have dignity and suffer less erosion of their skills. Unemployment insurance is ended. Food stamps and other safety net programs shrink. These workers spend their paychecks increasing demand and boosting the economy.

Wages paid by the government are capped at a level lower than offered by the private sector. As the economy improves, the private sector hires them back at higher pay.

This is not a new idea. Aspects of it were tried successfully during the 1930' by President Roosevelt's New Deal. Workers then accomplished much, and much needs to be accomplished now. Economists Hyman Minsky, Paul Davidson, and L. Randall Wray have explored variations of this idea.

The goal is not socialism, nor to compete with the private sector. The reality is we have millions of long term unemployed in dire economic straits. As a society we aren't going to leave them to their fate of homelessness, malnutrition, and ill health. We aren't going to accept the grim future their children face. So, if we are going to help them, this idea of immediately employing them deserves a serious national discussion.

The "study" being reported is based on the same old Canadian data that consisted of poor mammography and poor training of radiologists back in the early 80's.  When you start with bad data, no matter how long you follow the patients, the results will not get better.  The Canadian data has never been able to show a benefit for mammography.  Another problem with the data was that patients with lumps were often ordered to get mammograms and then assigned to the mammography group which increased the number of cancers for the mammography group.  There have been many much better studies done before and after the Canadian study showing the significant value of quality mammography.  The real conclusion of the Canadian study is that poor mammography yields poor results without survival benefits no matter how many patients are counted and no matter how long.

We have a friend who spent the years of WWII in the cellar of an Amsterdam home - not her own. A Dutch Jew, she emigrated to the US following the war.
In a recent Facebook post her daughter noted that her mother resents seeing the term"Nazi" used in connection with people not in any way connected with the actual Nazi-ism of the war.
I understand and support this point of view. How can I even begin to understand the emotional connections that a holocaust survivor has with the word? How can anyone without direct experience of the war relate to the feelings, except by respecting them.
If we wish to be advocates for civilized values, then our first obligation to our fellow human beings is to reflect those values within our own hearts. Relating is far more important than castigating.

Many of the comments and, frankly, much of the international pressure - both state and commercial - fails to engage what seems to me to be the core of Israeli concerns.   The context in which the Jewish state exists is extraordinarily unsettled.   Al Qaida is at the door in the northeast; Iran (through Hizballah) is due north; God knows what will happen in Egypt and Jordan and it seems likely that Syria will be roiled for a generation.  The current politics and boundaries in Israel's neighborhood are utterly unpredictable.   Thirty years ago, it was assumed that Israel did not require "strategic depth" on the ground because future wars would be fought with missiles that made actual borders immaterial.  Subsequent attacks have proved that assumption unreliable.  Israel does, indeed, require strategic depth.  It is an existential issue given Israel's reality.  Any initiative that does not offer strategic depth (control of the Jordan River valley) by some means has zero chance of succeeding.  Israel will wait out the current political/military paradigm if necessary.  Israel is intent on the survival of its people (the Jewish people, like it or not).  That's why it exists.  Those who are opposed to the notion of a Jewish state (or Jewish people, for that matter - and they are legion) will do what they do.  Israel will attempt to survive.

Getting old is not for sissies but it provides one with the dubious benefit of 20/20 hindsight. When I was young, society pretty much dictated that everybody should get married, have kids and take out a mortgage. That sort of thinking led me into a bad marriage that seemingly went on forever. I now see that my life would have been more satisfying if I had taken a course not dictated by society. Accordingly, I no longer listen to the voices of society or religion in making personal decisions.

And your data, or even reasoning?  Even if it was just day care, if that helped parents stay employed or work more hours to help feed, clothe, and care for themselves and their children, would that be bad?
Not one mention of the word "parent" in this entire editorial.

California is, and hopefully always will be, the annoyingly illustrative example of what happens when you leave the bigots and the small minds behind, and work toward a better state of affairs for humanity. It doesn't always work out, but to accept failure as part of the process is uniquely Californian. And to close one's mind to the possibilities, well, that is uniquely Red State.

We just won't go there.

"the West appreciates Russia’s historic ties to Ukraine and has no interest in turning Kiev against Moscow"

What nonsense. The West has been doing everything it can to detach Ukraine from Russian influence. Why should we expect that the intelligence services of the US would cease their activity in Ukraine? Are they even under control of the US President and Congress?

Putin is not as naive as the Times editors appear to be so he will continue to protect what he views as Russia's interest as best he can, while the West will continue to pursue its interests, which include extending its military presence eastward.

Good riddance! I scarcely think our founding fathers envisioned a class of professional legislators who would spend their entire working lives in Congress.

They imagined that voters would periodically elect one of their peers; farmers, merchants & mechanics - to spend a few weeks or months gathered together at the capital to vote on laws to govern them. Certainly not ossified relics such as John Dingell.

I am impressed that there are lawyers willing to represent these defendants despite apparent cultural pressures.  The legal situation seems to me to need to be changed more thoroughly and more quickly, though, in a way that maybe requires the support of social protest, as we've seen in India regarding attitudes towards rape victims.  I hope then relatives will stop feeling a need to distance themselves from family members who need their care and love.

But it isn't a Massachusetts criminal case, it is a federal case being brought by US attorneys, proceeding from a federal grand jury that indicted Mr. Tsarnaev for federal crimes. Massachusetts just happens to be the part of the country in which these crimes against the nation took place. The U.S. Constitution certainly recognizes federal crimes (e.g., treason).

The purpose of telephone metadata network analysis is to determine who associates with whom. Seems to me, if we could get a real court to look at the program, it would violate not only the 4th amendment, but also the first amendment "freedom of association" clause. After all, keeping track of associations is the purpose of the program. Where is justice?

Hesitancy isn't the same as reluctance. What may appear to be reluctance may be hesitancy to make a wrong move, when a great deal is at stake.

If people are showing up to discuss peace, let's assume they're vitally interested in peace. A small start is often better under these kinds of circumstances. I'm very encouraged that in spite of this mess, people are willing to meet. Why should peace be easy to achieve? True peace is never easy. Their very willingness to talk under such unclear and discouraging terms suggests how highly they value peace.

George H.W. Bush was my Congressman before he became my President. George W. Bush was my Governor before he became my President.
Although I have been a self-described Democrat for most of my life, I wasn't apprehensive with the prospect of either man's Presidency until they were elected.
George H.W. Bush had been in favor of gun control, choice and equal rights before he became Reagan's VP. He famously denounced "Voo Doo Economics" during the primaries of 1980 and, indeed, oversaw a limited engagement in Iraq and a necessary tax increase to tamp down the deficit. I suppose his nomination of Clarence Thomas struck him as a good idea at the time, but has proven to be a disgrace to the court and to the country.
I worked with W's staff in Texas and was a neighbor to several cabinet appointees.
After Bush v. Gore, he became a man I did not recognize. A military adventurist, a deficit-driving tax-cutter, the nominator of a team of ideological hawks and economic wizards who oversaw the destruction of American credibility as a moral leader in the world.
W was captured by the extremists in his own party to such an extent that it is not yet possible to determine if he was a fool or a villain.
Do a majority of Americans want to turn power over to a another man named Bush? why?

Spoken like someone who does not see (or care to see) the families devastated by our self-defeating and needlessly punitive policies. Ross thinks anti-legalization is the populist view ? It isn't -- The Pew Center (the writer seems to accept as reasonable and cited them himself) polling showed only 27% opposed letting the undocumented stay. The majority favored legalization -- not amnesty. Amnesty implies something for nothing, legalization involves registering with the US government, paying fines, having a job/income, proving some proficiency in English and US civics -- and meeting other requirements relating to security.

The comparison to the Reagan era is not apt -- we now have e-verify , a digital I-9 entry/exit system, and far greater numbers of border and interior enforcement agents. Record numbers of Removals have been instituted during the Obama administration. (GWB had strong numbers as well).

The writer's faux concern for assimilation and upward mobility of immigrants is timely in this news cycle -- but it isn't fooling anyone. Allowing STEM students to remain in and work in the USA is a smart policy change; as is allowing more skilled worker visas and is likely to help our economy. But don't think we don't know that your real motivation for opposing immigration for lower skilled workers is the same as the GOP aversion to immigrants in general. It's not that you fear they won't succeed -- it's that they will and when they do, they might just vote for Democrats.

One of my biggest frustrations is how difficult the United States makes it for bright, talented foreign entrepreneurs to come build their startups here. We should be actively courting the best and brightest to not only come to the U.S. for their education, but to stay and help build our economy (and add jobs while they do it!).

Want to hit Russia, China or Iran where it would really hurt? Grant greencards to every qualified Computer Science PhD who wants to come set up shop in the States. Steal Canada's "Startup Visa" program. Bring the best and brightest here!

From what I understand (correct me if I am wrong), the movie had not even started yet - why get angry over it when the movie has not even begun? Especially if (as it seems was the case here), the person is texting to tie up loose ends so they don't need to when the movie begins.

This Reeves guy is a psycho and had no business being anywhere near a gun, let alone bringing it into a movie theater.

Social Security is fully funded by the people who will benefit from it. It should never be part of any deficit discussion. When Bush and the Republican got elected there was a budget surplus. The first thing Bush and the Republicans did was to pass a massive tax cut for the rich. The then started two wars. Passed Medicare part D. And another tax cut for the rich. None of it paid for. And to finish Bush crash the American economy. Instead of blaming the Democrats why don't you find out who is really responsible for the current deficit.
Wilson and his offensive teammates beat the Denver defense. The Seattle defense beat Manning and his offensive teammates. Wilson and Manning were never on the field at the same time.

As adults profess the innocuous effects of pot on stoned drivers, children are listening and receiving a message -- albeit not an unanimous one -- that smoking pot is just fine even while operating potentially lethal machinery like a car, or perhaps a bicycle, power lawn mower or chain saw.

Neurophysiologists tell us that the brain of a person younger than 25 is still developing and studies have shown that chronic pot smoking affects brain development.

At the end of Electric Kool Aid Acid test, the late Ken Kesey sees young teens dropping LSD as just another way to fend off boredom and without any awareness of the drug's potential for insight and understanding. Kesey and Cassidy lament "We blew it" as they see their high-minded vision -- and advertising -- for a "turned on" world spiraling down the drain of the mundane, the cliched, the unrealized.

The positive publicity pot is accruing will have to be judged years from now when its long term effects on the young who are now hearing its praises being sung and its liabilities downplayed are judiciously scrutinized.

Let's hope common sense prevails and our youth are more mature and wiser than their stoned out elders.

And just think, there's no need to burn books anymore. Just drive all the bookstores out, let the public libraries decay, and turn the greatest public research branch library in the world (outside the Library of Congress) into a glorified electro-mall. Down the road we'll only have ourselves to blame for letting this come to pass.

So many here still miss the point. The US demanded in the EU financial package, months ago, a complete turning Ukraine against Russia. Rather than build a bridge between east and west with the package, the US insisted on no Ukraine cooperation with Russia on just about anything. The Russian 15 billion package was without strings attached. The US screwed up here, and we should be taking our own govt to task for trying to alienate the Russians from the Ukraine.
I supported Putin's move in that he didnt take all of the east and south of Ukraine. He can very well do so if the west continues with policies that attempt to push Russia away, disrupt the gas flows, or attempt to make Ukraine into a NATO country. How did that work in Georgia? I dont see any more need to sanction Russia than to sanction the USA, or its rogue underling in Israel, which continues to occupy land in Syria and Palestine

It is amusing that the most often recommended comment, the one from an ophthalmologist, has over 200 'likes'.  Is it possible their professional lobby has requested they all go to the NYTimes to "like" the comment that explains how bad off they are financially?  I would love to see the commenters tax return!  I think he is doing quite alright.

The point seldom discussed is that by doing nothing, the minimum wage is being lowered. Inflation does occur and erodes the little power the minimum wage possesses. The real problem is that the wealthy are finding out they can do without everyone else except the purpose they serve as cheap labor. So, for them no minimum wage makes sense.
Now the wealthy are doing most of the consuming with their vast empires. High end stores do well and very low end are doing well. anything that caters to the middle class is starting to fail.

It is insanity to put gun owners rights before children's rights but nothing will happen unless Americans start protesting in huge numbers about the current situation and demand a safer country for their kids.

The stimulus prevented another Great Depression. However, too many Americans are unhappy with the effects of the stimulus for two very simple reason:

1) None of the perpetrators of the financial fraud schemes that caused the Great Recession have suffered any meaningful consequences for their actions.

2) Not many of the underlying causes of the financial fraud been repaired; in particular, we need the reinstatement of Glass Steagall.

By far, reason #1 is what rankles most Americans, no matter their other political leanings. Had President Obama turned to non-Wall Streeters for economic leadership and directed a different Attorney General (Holder has been a complete disaster) to prosecute the leaders of the financial institutions much more aggressively, many more Americans would be happier with today's situation.

Bread and circuses matter much more than nuanced efforts at political compromise. Republicans understand that truism much better than President Obama's inner circle.

There is an historical deficit that goes on and on in how it affects every aspect of life if your homeland lived under the cultural repression, indentured labor regime and economic extraction of colonial Spain and its church for 400 years.

At the risk of sounding coarse, if my friends are offended or upset by something I say or do with honesty, then they are not really my friends, are they? There is an old saw the "friends are people you know everything about, but still like them."

Although certain things - ridicule, sarcasm, etc. - can be inappropriate (to ANYONE) in given situations - honesty should always be one's policy. If that honesty "hurts," and the one it hurts is offended (even if what is said honestly is wrong), then the one offering the honest comment should first try to get the other to understand the reason for the honesty. If that doesn't work, they may need to re-assess whether to remain friends with that person.

I am one of those who is fearlessly honest, particularly with family and friends. And it has definitely "cost" me at times. But I believe that appeasing people's feelings is dishonest - though, again, all comments, even honest ones, should be made in as loving and humble a way as possible.

EricF, Feb 17th post

Dear Mr. F,

I think you will found very broad support for Mr. Charles Green's statement.

"it is time for theory to be reconciled with the observations."

Amen. Amen.

it is HIGH TIME for the theory to be reconciled with the observations.

There's a lot of insanity happening in education and most of it is coming from people who don't really have a place in education: politicians, big corporations, upper level administrators. Their decisions are responsible for making education a meaningless task of sisyphus for children. These parents who are opting out are heros, plain and simple. Teachers can't opt out of proctoring or administering these stupid tests; we risk losing our jobs.  We can criticize and protest but actual civil disobedience will get more attention. Furthermore, the common core and testing are no longer mutual exclusive, they are deeply involved with one another. The baby must go with the bathwater.  Once the wealthy suburban school districts move against this, New York state will push the common core out.

Great article, thank you. It underscores the importance of having more actual, practicing teachers involved in the process, rather than people who left the classroom to pursue careers in the Educational Industrial Complex (cf. Duncan and Rhee, and I'm sure many who work for Common Core).

You write: "We were protesting the fact that it is our word against the state’s." This is at the heart of the problem. Why can't we listen more respectfully to teachers? They have been pointing out the flaws in the system for years.

I used to be a staunch Republican, raised in a conservative household, and lived the middle class dream.  I changed my party affiliation when the Republicans, along with the SCOTUS stole the Presidential election from Gore and put G W Bush into power.  I have become a Progressive and support the Democrat Party and I will never go back.  I am seventy years old and I cannot believe how extreme the Republican Party has become and I fear for the future of this Nation.

Don't panic everyone.

All that is going to happen is that we are going to get more elite schools - as we always have as our population has grown.

More top-notch PhD's and top notch students will gravitate to the next level of schools and turn them into elite schools.

Time and free choice sill solve the problems of this new development and leave us better off than before.

Very fun, thanks for doing this.  Not finding the published wines, we purchased these 2009 Haut-Medoc's:  Peyrabon, Lanessan and Landat, all of which were in the lower price range and decided to taste them side by side.  What a great experience!  We found differences in all throughout the process and our favorite changed from one day to the next.  Our original favorite was the Lanessan, which we found to be savory with spice and some sour cherry.  It was very tannic, silky and full bodied.  Hardly drinkable straight out of the bottle, it got much more enjoyable with food and we ended up finding it most interesting and complex.  Next was the Landat which started out very closed and a bit musty.  With food we initially did NOT see much difference, however on second tasting more fruit came out and the wine loosened.  The Peyrabon was our favorite on first taste, with a dark fruit and meaty flavor, yet still very tannic.  The interesting thing about this wine was that we thought it really good with food at first, but our second tasting found it un-interesting and had a sour finish. So, it ended up last on day 1.  Just for fun we did a quick tasting from the open bottles on day 2 with our meal.  In short the Peyrabon went back to our first choice, followed by Lanessan and the Landat.  The Peyrabon was a nice glass on its own, dry and very drinkable.  We found the Lanessan still incredibly tight and became our least enjoyable with food. So interesting, and FUN! Thank you.
The reports of more domestic abuse on Super Bowl Sunday are not true.  I just read an article with good citations that debunked this myth, but unfortunately, I do not have them to link.

I served as an Army infantry officer back in the 70's and early 80's.  We had a term for this that is still very appropriate - "ticket punching."  The lieutenants are worried that they won't be able to get the correct punches on their ticket.  Aw, poor babies.  A military career has no guarantees - something these spoiled examples of self-entitlement conveniently overlook.  However, there is also another problem.  That is the disproportionate effect the so-called "special operations" units have over the entire Army.  It never fails - in my day you had to have Airborne and Ranger tabs or your career would stall; now you have to qualify for special operations.  In both instances we see the triumph of the "jock" culture in the officer corps.  Football field heroics triumph over intellect.  May I submit to these young officers that your oath is to serve, not to be fulfilled.  The generation of officer who led in WWII endured two decades of no "hot fire" assignments - but they still learned their craft through hard training and the Army school system.  If they could endure the lack of excitement (and slow promotion), so can you.
"Privacy"? You've got to be kidding me! Every word of these conversations is being recorded.

Unfortunately this perception of Brazil is not correct. One in each 3 Brazilians above 14 years old is not working or even looking for a job. We are talking about more than 63 Millions of potential workers not even looking for a job. You will not find them in any statistics about unemployment and that's why things are looking better than the real thing. FIESP (Federation of Industries of the State of Sao Paulo) alerted the last two presidents (Lula and Dilma) about the desindustrialization proccess that is killing Brazil's capacity to innovate and to create new jobs. Do wanna talk about the real inflation in Brazil? Talk to people on the streets and see what happens.
More than 70% of people with high school education cannot operate basic mathematics or find data in a table to follow simple instructions. More than 44,000 cases of rape in 2011 (official numbers), more than 55,000 cases of murder every single year and I don't know how many cases of other types of crime. Dilma is giving money to poor people only because she knows that she is creating a gigantic mass of people that will vote according to her will. She is deep in corruption scandals (like Lula) the government is wasting money on the World Cup and Olympic games like if we have money for that. We don't have schools, libraries, hospitals and she is giving public money away only to make sure that people without school and critical thinking will keep her and her party controlling the country for decades.

You go girl. I am also numb, and yes, I have MS, but since I started walking it's been a whole new world. I am not falling asleep in the day, I am happier and hey, I've got some great muscles. And yes, Kayla, when we fall down, we are just going to get up and go on. Big smile here. Thanks.

Mr Blow, what is your point? That successful people shouldn't be able to live where they choose to live and can afford to live? You find such self sorting to be perverted? Who anointed you to cast aspersions on people trying to secure the best possible life for their families and themselves?

You need to internalize some basic facts about human behavior. People generally want to associate with other people who share their values; eg, education, hard work, respect for others. People do not want their families to be the subject of social engineering projects; eg school busing. People do not want to live in neighborhoods characterized by higher crime rates, noise pollution and general incivility.

People who choose to live in "better" neighborhoods or other locales do not do so out of fear, they do so out of pride.

There are times when reading the NYT editorials amounts to a mirror image Alice in Wonderland experience akin to reading the WSJ editorials.

This is like saying that if you see a house on fire, the solutions of calling the fire department, evacuating the residents, or keeping it from spreading are societal value judgments.

Mann is right. Scientists need to step up more aggressively on solutions, especially since the press has diluted or ignored the key data.

Doesn't answer the question as to whether there is a correlation between government policy and fertility rates.

Also of interest is quality of childraising. What portion of declining fertility is from single parent households, parents of poverty, parents of low educational attainment and parents of substance abuse.

Lower fertility is not a problem if the children are properly raised. But if they are not, we are setting up a long term problem.
display_name: Keep US Energy in US Hands

commentBody:
I totally agree with you. This complexity of the original bill is so immense that God could not program and develop from this mess !
Most of the core failures are administrative e. .g program management.
The basic mode of computations are not well developed in the core legislation.

The essence of a good deal is value and not price.  New York State of Health is offering us price, but the value is not there.  In fact, the value of service and selection lost, is far greater than the savings in premium.  In the name of lower premiums we have substantially higher deductibles and out of pocket maximums.  We have severely limited choices of doctors and providers, and even medications.  Doctors in greater demand who choose not to participate in these insurance plans are accessible only to the wealthy or those fortunate enough to have out of network coverage.  As one of those with a cancelled policy, forced to replace my coverage through the exchange, I feel like a loser.  To be counted among the 900,000 sign ups that make the New York State of Health a success is infuriating.

Neville Chamberlain has been lambasted for appeasing Hitler in 1938. Today we can clearly see that it isn't an easy option to threaten a dictator with military action without exhausting other options. As Churchill said, 'Jaw,jaw is better than war, war." What has become clear in this current crisis is that Putin IS a dictator with all the instincts of most of his predecessors. This man oozes distain for the West and its values. He uses the pretence of guarding the interests of ethnic Russians in Ukraine. The worrying fact is that there are substantial Russian populations in all Eastern European countries as a result of history and the former USSR's policy of "Russification" in its then vassal states. How can we know that the Crimea is, as Hitler said in 1938, "the last territorial claim"? This may yet prove to be the Ukraine's Sudetenland crisis and we all know what eventually happened after that affair. The NATO countries should be stating their willingness to not only negotiate a solution to this crisis but also a willingness as a last resort to militarily halt any Russian intrusion into Europe. In that respect it should clearly be stated that Russia's days of stunting the democratic aspirations of the people of eastern and central Europe will be strongly resisted.

Events like this are why I am reluctant to go to a movie theater, a shopping mall, and even church. Several years ago, Mayor Bloomberg asked who had to die before gun rights could be curtailed. Whole classrooms of little children and their teachers died in Connecticut, but that question has yet to be answered, it seems, although the US House of Representatives accorded itself special protections after Gabby Giffords was shot. It's time to stop the hypocrisy. Without sensible gun control laws to protect everyone, we are all playing Russian roulette.

Timely essay. After 10 years on the ED/LD frontlines in elementary and middle schools your discussion rings true. Ninety percent of my special ed middle-class students were male, most in a single caretaker home. We seldom knew the exact nature of their home life ("none of our business") but we did know all meds ceased during the summer for most of the students. Therein is the paradox: Normal function out of school for a sustained period, inability to cope in school. The cause may often be the result of turmoil or neglect at home rather than alleged ADHD.

It might be possible to extend the trains and the loading platforms at far less cost. A Midtown platform could be almost two blocks long. Those in New Jersey somewhat more than a block long.

It might also be possible to run NJ Transit and LIRR as an integrated system so trains don't have to back up in midtown Manhattan, speeding up operations. This would also make Newark and the first stop in Queens into more marketable office space real estate.

It might also be possible to extend PATH (and integrate it into Metro North).

New Jersey could also offer to rent new tunnel service at a state fixed price. Let the "expert" financiers that commute into Midtown and are impatient figure out how to make a profit at New Jersey's offer price rather than have the state with a really big pension funding problem dig itself into another financial hole.

Remember that New Jersey wants New Jersey residents to work in New Jersey real estate that helps pays for New Jersey public services.
That would be "Little Round Top."

We too found the Sociando-Mallet in a PA state store with a soft and wine-saturated cork. The wine seemed fine, as well, however.
I would not buy more to cellar though, due to the risk of unpredictable aging with the questionable cork (and not for that reason alone: it just seemed a poor value, compared to say, California or Chile reds. I'm not convinced it would get more interesting over time, just easier to enjoy sooner after decanting...is that how aging would work in this case?).
I decanted half the bottle about an hour before bringing it over to a neighbor's for "school." We thought it was "tight" and not unpleasant, but not particularly interesting. About an hour after that (two hours after decanting) we were eating a roasted chicken/mushroom dish, and the wine seemed was very nice, flavorful, and balanced. I tasted hints of cherry, savory herb, and fresh soil earth (not rocky, not peaty). Like a few other groups, the mushroom pairing was good.
We also had the Bernadotte at the same meal and generally liked it too. It seemed to have less "dynamic" flavor, if that makes sense. There seemed to be less variety, depth, and nuance in the flavors. But that could be that my taste buds were getting tired!
I'm thinking of trying the 2006 Bernadotte at $20/bottle, if I can find it locally.

Since this happened and no wreckage could be found I have been saying for days that that this plane was hijacked or stolen. The pilots were ordered to turn off all radar, radios, transponders and other communication equipment. Probably there were crew members on board who were involved in this act. The plane was then forced to land in some nefarious, rogue place which was complicit in this deed. (Remember the Egyptair jet that was deliberately crashed into the Atlantic off Nantucket by its co-pilot after it took off from JFK?)

The WSJ today reports that the engines continued to emit radio signals for four hours after the plane disappeared. Now we hear that communication devices did not turn off all at once, which would have suggested a catastrophic event, but were turned off serially.

My guess is that it is the intention of the perpetrators to load the plane with explosives, maybe nukes or dirty nukes, and crash it into something.

But for starters I'd be looking real hard in Pakistan, you know, where they hid Bin Laden, and other rogue nations. Plus, I would be trying to detect and monitor every single take-off and landing from everywhere right about now.

This is a long way from over!

As a seasoned professional in the property management industry, I see no doubt that rents have soared. I can only speak for South Florida, in particular Broward and Palm Beach Counties. What the article missed is that the debacle began with foreclosures. Folks who (continue to) borrow too much money for real property and subsequently walk away from their fiscal responsibilities are no longer the pariah of the rental market. In the not-too-distant past, a foreclosure was an automatic denial of one's rental application. With the surge in foreclosures came a mantra in this industry that "everyone is entitled to housing." The cost for the foreclosed individual is a higher security deposit. The cost to those who, for whatever their reason is to rent, is prohibitive rent. No one wins, except the irresponsible. Because in the end, we all need a place to live and as in the cost of everything else (refer to gas prices in SoFla, at .$.50 above the national average) we live with the new normal. We just don't live well.

"All this makes me think that the show we're watching is for domestic politics only. . . . We won't be able to cut down our military spending"

I see the loudest chest thumping as having nothing at all to do with Crimea or Ukraine. It is all about the 40% of the world's military spending we spend, and keeping it, or even growing it.

It is enormously contradictory for the Attorney General to personally oppose the death penalty, but authorize its use many times.  This reminds me of the hypocrisy of those who said they were against it, but made an exception for McVeigh.  This article does explain that fear of killing the innocent is why he feels this way about the penalty, but this is an issue on which personal consistency is key.  Otherwise, a government will always find a reason to commit a person to death.

Your "belief" that the rate of fraud in social welfare approaches 50% is both ridiculous and revealing.

First the ridiculous: I can find no study that shows this assertion to be true. The Atlantic reported that a government study found that fraud accounted for less than 2% of unemployment payments, and that when it comes to food stamps, Beneficiaries intentionally ripping off the taxpayers account for perhaps 1 percent of payments."

Now, the revealing: I believe I am getting the sense that your beliefs are based on a genuine disdain for those who are needy, and an outsized admiration of those who are affluent. On this, of course I could easily be mistaken. That's how beliefs work, though.

Unbelieveable. This disclosure of NSA's activities in the area of economics by gaining trade secrets from "allies" and others and sharing it with civilian government officials is thievery. At home, civil liberties and privacy has basically eroded. Now, who is to say and with what morale authority to the Chinese and Russians about their domestic and international rogue activities.  It all comes at the cost of US losing its cherished prestige. Just because you are able to steal something does not mean you have to. I don't think America has lost its ingenuity in the area of economics and creativity for it to resort to this rogue institution for trade thievery. Congress has to scrub these activities and restore Americans' and the world's trust. America and the world do not need NSA's leadership. We need America's rule of law leadership and its good traditions.

There was a gas smell in my house last year.  PSE&G came to my house a dozen times and still the smell continued periodically in the front of the house. It was very hard to pin down the source and they kept telling me there was no problem as they drilled holes into the yard, the street, the driveway.  Finally, they brought a backhoe and there was indeed a leak, the main pipe into the house was broken.  This took several days to fix and replace, but had I not been persistent, the gas company wouldn't have acted.  They didn't want to find the problem, because then they had to fix it.

I was skeptical reading this because the authors seem much more knowledgable (and concerned) about collectors than poaching, but the authors lost me entirely in the end. The auction of ivory stockpiles that the authors reference as a success was in fact a primary cause for the recent surge in elephant poaching. This one-off event created a legal hoophole for ivory that could be forged with relative ease, and ivory sales (and poaching) surged in response; elephant poaching wasn't much of a problem between the early 1990s until that sale in 2008. If the authors don't know this, they have no credibility to speak as experts on this issue.

Reading the counsel proffered by the vast advice industry that buzzes around public figures reminds me of watching sausage being made. Best avert one's gaze. Also, let's hope much of said counsel is ignored, especially vacuous exhortations such as "be real." Ms. Dowd's rhetorical question notwithstanding, I think we know who Hillary is as much as we can know any potential candidate for public office. Like most politicians who survive in office, she has and will use chameleon capabilities. It's not pretty, but it goes with the job.

What is happening in Venezuela is the same thing that has been perpetrated by the US throughout the world for decades.  Whenever a country votes in a leader or government opposed to US capitalist interests, they need to be overthrown - by a coup, assassination, or military intervention.  Mossadegh, Lumumba, Arbenz, Allende, more recently Zelaya and of course the attempted coup of Chavez - to name a few.  And if assassinations, coups, or interventions don’t work, spreading internal dissent and chaos is the next best thing.  That’s what’s happening in Venezuela now.  Sure there are real issues to be addressed.  Corruption, violence, shortages.  How much is caused by the “economic war” of the opposition as opposed to government incompetence is debatable.  But what is occurring now is counter productive to solving these problems.  These were issues plaguing Venezuela before Chavez came to power.  The current government has had only 15 years to try to solve problems which were endemic to the country under previous administrations.  Redistributing the wealth of a country and establishing social programs to benefit the poor via a true democracy is a dangerous idea in the eyes of the US government and corporate interests.  It might prove to be an attractive alternative for countries which have been exploited for decades or centuries.  Let’s hope Obama accepts Maduro’s invitation to improve relations and to be more respectful of the sovereignty of Venezuela.

Republicans: Attempting to make it trivially-easy to obtain firearms and appallingly difficult to obtain a ballot.

In the developing coutries, doctors are more skilled at diagnosing a disease by  symptoms and examination rather than using technology. They see 100 patients in a general hospital (which is a hospital for the poor and offers subsidized medical care) a day while earning their MDs, getting lot of clinical experience. This experience gives them a good judgement of whether the patient needs any tests or not. This does not happen here. Going to the doctor and thereafter all the investigations that follow, the worrying, the stress and the negative thoughts, that itself will make a person susceptible to more problems. Doctors should at least spend one year in a developing country to get better in diagnosis through symptoms and examination. We will be prescribing less medical tests resulting in lesser medical bills and will have more happy people around us.

Clearly economically and culturally vibrant cities like New York and San Francisco attract "new economy affluents" who are able to disproportionately benefit by monetizing their high-demand skills in technology, media, and finance.

However it is interesting to note that cities where income inequality is the worst are all governed by Democratic mayors and/or progressive city councils, with the exception of Miami. In my view this is hardly surprising - efforts to reduce income inequality through progressive governance typically result in a fleeing middle class as taxes rise, public schools deteriorate, and infrastructure suffers as public unions grab a growing portion of municipal tax revenue, crowding out stuff the middle class cares about most deeply. This is precisely what has happened in San Francisco over the last 20 years, and what you are left with is an out-of-touch, super-elite group of 1%-ers, and a lower class unable to move, with nothing in between.

I was involved in this case. I remember getting dropped off at court ordered therapy. I don't remember the sessions but I have seen the macabre pictures I drew. I have read the accounts the therapist wrote down for me as I detailed the abuse.  It is my belief, after years of treatments centers and therapy, that nothing physical happened to me personally. Mentally, well, that's a different story. How about paying attention to the kids that were scarred from this therapy? Do you think that just because there was most likely no physical abuse that we didn't still suffer? Eating disorders, alcoholism, depression, anxiety...we suffered. I lived in fabricated fear. I have a vivid memory of one teacher telling us that she would come to our house in the middle of the night and shoot our parents if we ever told them what happened. This memory, which I now assume was a dream, was the one thing that kept me questioning for years whether or not this happened. So, while I now believe that the memories were unintentionally implanted, I still lived the nightmare through stories and drawings. To those questioning the parents who believed their children...if your child came to you and told you that he/she had endured satanic abuse, that you would immediately tell them they were lying? I hope not. Healthy skepticism, fine. But total disbelief, that's a great way to damage children that are already clearly in need of help. So stop being SO shocked that a parent might believe their child.

I'm not sure why rails-to-trails should have any impact on the decision. What isn't clear is whether the railroad owned the property or whether it merely had an easement to run a railroad across the property of the landowner. If it was the latter, clearly the landowner gets the property.

I suspect it was more complex than that, and perhaps the railroad was there before before any of the land was owned by anyone but the government. (I'm ignoring the obvious claim Native Americans might have.) But that doesn't change the respective rights of the landowner and railroad. If the government eventually sold the land around the railroad under a contract that EXCLUDED the railroad right of way, the landowner has no claim. If the land was sold in toto, subject only to an easement for the railroad right of way, the landowner gets the property. I know it wasn't the purpose of her commentary, but it would have been nice if Ms. Greenhouse addressed these issues.

George Lakoff is an excellent analyst of the way the GOP uses rhetoric to get around reason. One reason the President and the Democrats don't do that as well is that the best arguments for good policy are NOT emotional. What the ACA has going for it is precisely that it is a sensible policy (not perhaps as sensible as single payer, but in the sense that it is politically as far as we can go at this time).

Good policy is hard to sell with mendacity. To extend Mark Twain's famous remark, just about any boots will fit a lie on its way around the world. There are a million ways to sloganize against something when you're just making things up. But as Obama discovered, it's trickier when facts can catch up to you. Look what he paid for the "if you like your plan, you can keep it" meme, which was just not true for everyone. There can never be such a moment of falsification on "Death Panels" or "It's socialism!" When you have convinced someone that something exists that does not exist, it's non-existence ceases to be evidence against it.

I worked with Mr. Thomas when he was a rising star, of sorts, in the GOP. Though I can't think of one single matter of politics or policy that we agree upon, I do have respect for him. He watched my back. One doesn't forget that. I am not, however, his apologist. But reading this article made me consider a theory:

Thomas was born and raised in Pinpoint, Georgia, a very small town near Savannah that was settled by freed slaves. His grandfather, who raised him, was a very well respected member of the community. And Thomas himself was smart. He may not have grown up with indoor plumbing, like many other semi-rural African Americans, and may have suffered many injustices, but as a child, he may have been in a relatively or comparatively privileged situation and remembers it as "racist free."

My parents grew up in the depression and while they tell horrifying stories of struggles, they never said that they felt poor as a child. But they were.

Is Thomas crazy? Were my parents crazy? Maybe. But more likely, just like all of us, they didn't have the capacity as children to step back and make comparisons of their situation. Like my parents, Thomas has personally told me horrifying stories. Like my parents, he doesn't see a problem with it because it's all he knew while growing up.

I have lived in Vermont since 1992, working as a newspaper reporter, an author and now a town clerk. I have some cred.
First, Rutland is Vermont's most Republican area, hardly the seat of Socialism. More importantly, it is more "urbanized," with a working class population that has been set adrift by the changes in our economy. It is closer to I-87, which allows for easy-in, easy-out interstate traffic and it has pockets of poverty and destitution. Those factors combined make it a breeding ground for heroin.
I have no doubt the ski areas and tourism industry went ballistic over Gov. Shumlin's heroin-focused state-of-the-state address which hardly comported with the Bob Newhart, snow-frosted-cabin-maple-syrup-ayup image that has made Vermont a destination vacation for New Yorkers.
But that's Vermont - we're honest like that. We are a state that had no truck with slavery or homophobia and banished both not through court decisions, but through legislation.
We are communities that meet annually in school gyms and town halls to sort out budgets and settle disagreements with our neighbors face-to-face before sitting down to potluck suppers.
We are a state whose respected Republican U.S. Senator left the GOP because his conscience couldn't toe the crazy conservative line. And when Irene hit, we brought out our tractors and trucks and saved one another without the feds.
We will overcome this, too, because we are Vermont strong. Just you watch.

"Many here and in other media consistently blame the "Malaysian authorities" when they do not release premature information and then again when they do."

No, that's not it! What the Malaysian authorities are being condemned for is that they can't even get the crystal clear information straight that they do have. They have all the radar and ATC recordings. All it takes is a single competent person to sit down, and check off when exactly the events that are being mentioned have taken place. Last communication with ATC, check! Last SATCOM transmission, check! Last transponder response, check! Last altitude reporting, check! First occurrence of UFO on primary radar without assigned transponder code, check! Progress of said UFA and loss of radar return at specific time points, check!

All of these data they have and they could and should and actually did have them in hand within hours of the jet's disappearance. What this back and forth of contradictory information shows is that there is no functioning command structure in place. The right hand does not know what the left is doing, nobody with any credible professional credentials in in charge and the entire search is going nowhere.

The affect of a higher, and humane, minimum wage will be more jobs, not fewer. One must be weary of Republican economic logic. Here's why: Republicans say that raising the minimum wage will cause a loss of jobs because the employer will have no choice but to cut a worker to help cover the cost of paying other workers more. The problem with this logic is that the jobs at the bottom of our economy are necessary. In other words, the manager of a MacDonald's in Podunk or NYC only hires what they need per shift. Altruism isn't part of the hiring policy for fast food restaurants and other small businesses that pay minimum wage.

That said, it will cost employers more, obviously. So they will have to raise prices or find other ways to economize. Still, the net result is more money at the bottom of our economy and even though Republicans, thanks to Reagan, believe that money trickles down, the truth is that it trickles up. A higher minimum wage is good policy in America and Republicans should stop blocking the path.

"I'm shocked, shocked to find that gambling is going on in here!"

What? You can make more money by rigging the game than by simply playing it? Do ANY of today's gamblers remember when the stock market was about raising capital for ventures that were just too large and risky?

While I agree that high-frequency trading is a problem, I think it's only a secondary aspect. The real problem is that the capital markets are more and more like a friction-free engine. As it revs up faster and faster, at some point the engine has to shake itself to pieces. It's like a roulette wheel that is trying to spin faster than the speed of light. "This won't end well." Too big to fail? "You ain't seen nothing yet."

Before the system collapses with a splash that's so big not even the government's horses and men can put it together again, we need to get the system under control. Time constraints on high-frequency traders would help, but I favor the more capitalistic solution of a transaction tax. This engine needs a little grit in there to slow it down.

My understanding of the 23andMe issue--and I bought tests during the covered time period, so I got the mass email from 23andMe--is that the FDA had tried several times to get 23and Me to state what its error rate on various tests was, and after a couple of years of 23andMe declining to do so, the FDA told them to quit providing test results.

In other words SD is basically right--as things stood, people had no way of knowing how likely it was that the 23andMe result they got was correct vs. incorrect.

I last wrote that I had hunted down all three bottles recommended by Eric. Menu set, we were ready to go to wine school. Onion Tart, Porterhouse Steak, asparagus, roasted potatoes and rosemary, and a salad of lettuce and radishes with a classic French dressing. ...and crepes with strawberries for dessert. We decided to open two bottles for comparison. I opened and poured four glasses each of the Bernadotte and the Sociando-Mallet. They "decanted" for about two hours. My husband and I took a taste of each right from the newly opened bottle. Our collective thoughts over the course of the night:
The Sociando was at first sharp and tannic, but mellowed and became smooth and fruity as the hours and courses went by. The Bernadotte started out with a creamy feel in the mouth, not sweet, but fruity with a taste of plum (one of us tasted heavy, salty and savory.) Three of us tasted the similarity in the wines, tending to drink Italian not Bordeaux. When my husband (the bourbon and white wine drinker) declared that he would not be able to tell the difference I pulled out an Italian primitivo and we all tasted it and he realized that there was a huge difference. Definitely both bottles of wine became smoother (more open?) over time. We just finished the two bottles off at dinner the second night with a chicken curry. Very interesting how different it tasted with the spicy curry. A hint of licorice??? It is a good thing that we aren't getting a grade at wine school!

As a person who until 1993 lived in Russia I assure you are wrong. There was unbelievable amount of good will towards West in general in US in particular during the late 80s early 90s. You may choose not to believe me  but quite a few Russians back then –yours truly included - could  not wait for the RF to get out of the USSR. The reasoning behind it was, that we were a large republic with whole lot of industrial capacity,  with well educated population, a wealth of natural resources and the only reason we are not enjoying living standards on  par with that of Switzerland is because of them goddamned communist old timers in Kremlin (Gorby included) and them bloodsucking minor republics of the USSR. The West was supposed to love us and would sure help us in transition. Nothing of that sort of course materialized.  The West in particularly the US - for the domestic policy sake in my opinion –decided that the narrative of “we won the cold war” is much more beneficial than “the cold war is other”. The second version is really not all that satisfying –it is really anticlimactic. The “victory version” however allowed politicians claim some credit for it and it looked much more impressive with vanquished enemy to point at. That role was assigned to Russian federation - because it was easy since Russia and USSR were used as synonyms since 1924. The realization of this reality took a while to set in for Russians and it was very disheartening.

Mr. Friedman asks us to look at history, so let us look at history. Since the time of Kievan Rus, Russian rulers have tended toward absolutism. It is a history of top-down despotism.

Henry Kissinger noted that you can’t expect individuals to change their ways—so forget expecting whole nations to change their ways. NATO expansion was predicated precisely on that thought. Also, NATO is a defensive alliance. If the Russian elite wanted to make Russia into a Western democracy, or into an dynamic economy like China, they would be doing everything they could to bring it about. And we would get along fine.

I expect rather that Putin will aim at unhinging NATO. I think he will do it by pressuring the Baltic countries. The Germans will dither—and NATO will become unhinged.

Putin is an admirer of Peter the Great, not a victim of Western injustice. For readers who don't know much about “Pyotr,” as the Russians call their greatest tsar, I suggest you read the first stanza of Pushkin’s “The Bronze Horseman.” Overpowering in Russian, not so much in English. But you will see my point.

I think another part of the puzzle is that the remaining middle class is more conscious of quality than it used to be. Many middle class people I know, from peers to aging members of my extended family, don't want to pay $20/person for a chain-restaurant meal that isn't very good. But they like splurging occasionally on a really nice experience. When they need a new refrigerator or washing machine, they're willing to spend a bit more to get exactly what they want, since they're already shelling out a ton of money for a piece of equipment they'll likely be using for many years. And if it's something where quality doesn't matter very much (like paper towels or other staples), they go for very low cost places like Wal-Mart or the 99 cent stores.

Undoubtedly the "middle class" has shrunk to some extent, but I also think it has changed in ways that make targeted middle-class products and services less needed/wanted.
