We like this type of homework and have very diligently worked on the assignment two week-ends in a row.  The group so far consists of three novices in the language of wine tasting; but long time passionate of red wine. One of us found the Bernadotte in a quaint shop in Jackson Heights which we tried the first week.  The meal (at a restaurant that allowed us to bring our own wine) consisted of mixed ceviche as an appetizer, Churrasco and salad for the main course and Flan for dessert.  The first tasting which was after about five minute airing time was fruity, dry with a nice feel. As we progressed through the meal, we noticed the change in the dryness and felt it smoother and softer. The experience the second week was with one not on the list but from the same region and year - Chateau LaRose Trintaudon. The meal for this one was at home with seafood Paella. Olives and Peccorino cheese for appetizer.  We felt that this one was similar to the Bernadotte.  The difference with this one was that we enjoyed the first glass with  just a couple of olives and endured the fruity and dry feel of the wine, which we agreed was the best of the wine.

No, more college won't change the economy's low-wage trajectory for most of the jobs offered. But, then, neither will policies that lift wages or more muscular unionization.

In the end, if what you focus on is traditional work, it's under immense pressure from automation -- the higher mandatory wages and other benefits become, the greater the market forces to turn to automation instead. That simply adds to the downward pressure on wages as more and more commodity labor is made to compete with far less expensive hardware and software.

Whether or not gifted and hard-working people go to college, they will find a way to relative prosperity, even with traditional classes of work. But the systemic solution for the vast majority of people needs to be attention paid to defining NON-traditional classes of work that are not easily automatable and that can be performed by the many, not just by the few; and in finding ways to compensate them through the tax code and wage subsidies.

These are uncharted waters we head into, that are ill-suited for navigation by people with classical ideological labels, such as "Democrat" or "Republican". And we'll need to find a definitive solution sometime in the next two generations, or we're headed for global social destabilization.

Can Republicans get behind immigration reform that looks like this? It would remove illegal aliens from the work force at the same time as getting people off the dole. It seems like this would satisfy their populist wing, but it would certainly satisfy the business and oligarchic wings.

Reform would really be job reform. The US government would use mandatory e-verify to remove aliens from employment, and provide relocation and assistance in training for their American replacements. Some Americans might need skill training, while others would need to get in better physical shape. Many people would need to relocate. The goal would simply be to reduce the number of people on the dole, while it would have the side effect of removing the income of aliens. Maybe the Democrats could sponsor an amendment that allows aliens a grace period to get their affairs in order and even provide a ticket home, while not prohibiting those being repatriated from applying through existing immigration channels.

This plans solves two problems at once, and should result in dramatically lower social program spending - something everyone can agree on. It would force certain businesses to pay more and work within the law, but they should do so anyway.

While I agree with Mr. Friedman calling out the members of Congress, especially those on the right who are always willing to declare a new war to be fought with someone else's kids, I disagree that the US should become an energy exporter to counter Russia.

We need to save our energy resources for ourselves. Just like we exhausted our energy reserves last century until shale and fracking bought about a renaissance, this too may not be as long lasting as currently understood. Let us also not sweep aside the environmental cost of these "clean" reserves.

One point Mr. Friedman misses is that this is an European crisis and a part of the blame lies with Western Europeans who are hesitant about integrating former Soviet states fearing a pull down effect on their economies and a swarm of immigrants. This is especially true of countries like Rumania and Bulgaria.

Insisting on these former Soviet satellites making massive structural changes without providing too much support as a requirement for getting into the Euro zone opens up a Russian toehold into these economies and populace.

Western Europe needs to court these countries more actively with the same weapons Russia is using - money. It would appear that the people of these countries would prefer the West, but the leaders are influenced by Moscow.

While Putin will ultimately fail, eastern Europe will still suffer.

My son is a Trekkie. He has been one all his life. He wanted to be an engineer on the Enterprise. He wanted to be an engineer. I got him into the Math and Science Academy hoping he would get the education needed to be an engineer. When I saw his math grades I despaired. I am a financial analyst but saw my son had inherited his father's math skills.

This spring my son will graduate from the American Academy of Art. That's right an art school. At the Math and Science Academy there was a wonderful art teacher that sparked his creativity. He found out he could draw and he found his passion. If the principal of the Math and Science Academy had not felt that art was important my son, with a lot of tutoring, may have ended up a very poor engineer. Time will only tell if he will end up a great artist but he deserved the chance to find his passion and pursue it. I'm a nerd but I understood that not everyone is. I believe like Einstein: "Everyone is a genius. But if you judge a fish on how it climbs a tree, it will live it's life thinking it is stupid." The nerds try to make life easier to live, but the creatives make life worth living.

It does seem passing strange the Mr. Levinson and Ms. Broadhurst are proposing a broad brush, dragnet approach to what is undoubtedly a problem, but a problem with a small proportion of the overall population of health workers, while completely ignoring a much larger systemic problem in the field - that of adequate sleep.

They state that by federal law, many workers in transportation and other safety-sensitive areas are subject to random drug tests. Also by federal law, big rig drivers are allowed 14 hours of duty after 10 hours off, and are not allowed to be actually driving for more than for more than 11 hours of that 14. In 2011, the ACGME issued new guidelines for the work hours for medical residents that specify that a first year resident may not work more than a 16 hour shift, and that residents beyond the first year may not work more than 24 hours in a shift (plus 4 hours to "ensure appropriate, effective, safe transition of care after 24 hours"!). What's worse, attending physicians who came up under the guidelines from 2003 and earlier (that were even worse) routinely push the residents to ignore even the 16 and 24+4 guidelines.

The problem of doctors treating patients without adequate sleep isn't confined to isolated rule breakers. It is the rule. I hope the column's authors open their blinders to address a very real and very widespread problem, along with proposing a much more nuanced approach to the problem the cite.

We have become disconnected and turned a blind eye to the maltreatment of farm animals, farm workers, migrant workers, immigrant farm labor, and those who work in horrid conditions at processing plants around the country. In Finland (where the "smartest" kids reside), just the opposite happens. The teachers refuse to take background into consideration when assessing a students work. They don't want to prejudice themselves and henceforth set lower standards for the "poor" students. The truth is, expectations lead to reality. Let's not squelch our most vulnerable children with our limited "compassion". Then we can all rise, together.

Hey, it's great that it worked out for Waffle House. Hooray for team spirit! But there's no shame -- no lack of team spirit -- in taking the advice of experts and closing down early or even pre-emptively. If you've ever spent 4 to 8 hours trying to crawl home on the highway in bad weather, you know what an absolute misery it is. If you've ever tried to get to work under those circumstances, with the threat of disciplinary action if you don't make it on time, then you've really experienced misery. Add in the stress and frustration of trying to arrange emergency child care during a snow or ice storm when schools are closed but the boss says you've got to be at work. That's the kind of stuff that eats away at team spirit, even if employees aren't willing to let it show at work.
To answer your question - in a word, "no."  Truth telling is frequently the last thing a boss wants to hear from a subordinate.  Period:)

Citizens United isn't really about speech, it's about money. It is based on the absurd idea that handing over cash is a "speech" act. The problem with it, quite obviously, is that it allows those with great economic power to easily convert their greater wealth into greater political power, and the design of our campaign finance system aids and abets the Koch brothers and others in their pursuit of ever further consolidation of the product of the many into the hands of the few. This is the opposite of elitism: it's a concern for the interest of the many in not being lied to and deceived by well-funded ad campaigns that sell harms as benefits.

Nothing new here, unfortunately. New Rome, Ohio did the exact same thing in early 2000, and it sounds like Hampton used New Rome as its a template for abuse and corruption. A village of 60 residents, New Rome set up speed traps and wrote tickets for minutiae such as dusty tail-lights amounting to fines of over $400,000. Virtually all of it went to fund the police force of 14 part-time officers. Auditors uncovered malfeasance similar to that of Hampton, including questionable charges of $120,000 on village credit cards. Thankfully, New Rome was eventually legislated out of existence by the state of Ohio.

Most of the income accruing to the top 1% (and even a higher percentage for the top 0.1%) is extracted from the 99%. This cannot be measured, but can be deduced using common sense. Obviously, if CEOs accepted lower compensation and paid their workers more, the corporate profits would be the same. Likewise, if hedge fund managers did not reward themselves so much, the capital gains and dividends not taken by them would go to people who probably earn less than the hedge fund managers.

Now, when I make this argument, conservatives usually retort that without the very high income, the CEOs and hedge fund managers would not be as productive, because they require the incentive of hundreds of millions of dollars. Then I say that there is no evidence of that, and if there were, I would happily take the job of the CEO or hedge fund manager who walks away from it. Of course, the conservatives mock that, because they cannot imagine ordinary but intelligent folks doing those jobs at the same level of proficiency, but again they have no proof that the high extractors are also the most proficient people for those jobs. (I suspect that CEOs are actually the most proficient people at becoming CEOs, and not the best at running corporations. As for the successful hedge fund guys, I suspect they deal in insider trading, which is illegal but difficult to prove.)

Unfortunately your assumption that all Latinos or Latinas are foreign born (so you are actually complimenting them on their good English) reveals your ignorance or built in prejudice, Indeed, the records of the first Latinos in what is now the United States (Florida) date back to the late 1565, showing they have been "native" since before the Anglos arrived on the Mayflower ( 1620) or even the lost Virgina Colony (1587--assuming there were any survivors). Per the latest census, f the 48.4 million people in 2009 who identified themselves as having Hispanic or Latino ancestry, nearly two-thirds (62.6 percent, or 30.3 million) were native-born U.S. citizens. In other words, they ARE native English speakers.

Note: Hispanic or Latino are an ethnolinguistic group of Americans with origins in the countries of Latin America or the Iberian peninsula. Hispanic is a narrower term and refers mostly to persons of Spanish speaking origin or ancestry, while Latino is more frequently used to refer more generally to anyone of Latin American origin or ancestry, including Brazilians.

I grew up in America since I was 3 and consider myself American but of Chinese descent. My grandparents fled Shanghai in 1949 days before the Communists entered and took over the city. They left behind my mother (18) to watch over her grandmother and my uncle (17) in the care of relatives. My mother lived under the Communists until leaving with two young children in 1960. I grew up respecting my elders, eating dim sum on Sundays, watching Chinese TV soap operas on Friday nights, shopping for groceries and catching a double feature (costume/action and modern romance/drama) in Chinatown on Saturdays. I learned it was important to excel and that propriety mattered. In between, I watched the Brady Bunch, I Dream of Jeanie, Creature Features and read Superman comics. I married a Caucasian man who was born in MN but grew up in CA. Our daughter was born in Portland ME (yay, Portland!) where my husband had attended Maine College of Art. Our daughter identifies as American but when we moved to Europe and she entered the school system, she immediately got classed as Asian based on her features.
I was viewed as an immigrant as opposed to an American ex-pat. Talk about identity issues. We are all different -- what is necessary is respect for those differences and to stand up for yourself. Relax. A secure and loving family is the most important.
I read books about China just like everyone else and don't read or speak Chinese. Better to be a kind human being wherever you're from.

In the early 90's the US Department of Defense gave Russia urgently needed help in retrieving the widely spread stockpiles of USSR nuclear warheads in strategic installations stranded in former Soviet republics. In 1994 the United States, Britain, Russia and later France and China gave Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan assurances of territorial sovereignty in exchange for handing over large nuclear warheads that corrupt officials in these countries would have sold to terrorists (so the US believed). These guarantees were extorted from Russia and the United States in the dire emergency created when the USSR simply lost control of its nuclear weapons. So enough about guarantees. Certainly the United States had no intention at the time of giving Ukraine a guarantee against Russian intervention in a fascist putsch.

Ukraine is a Russian province that serves vital Russian interests. It is deeply within the Russian sphere in a relationship without parallels in western Europe or North America and is therefore difficult for us to understand in our terms. What should be easy for us to understand is that Russians (not its leaders but its people) believe their survival depends on keeping foreign influence out of places like Ukraine (or Georgia or Azerbaijan or Kazakhstan or Belarus, etc.). Russians see this as a struggle for survival and if their history is a guide, they are not wrong.

This will backfire on us and undermine our European alliances.

Maybe a comparison to smoking will be enlightening.  In 1954, around when I was born, smoking was at its highest rate, at 45% of adult Americans smoking.    After the health hazards became known, public education was undertaken, but the rate did not start to decline until after Congress passed a public health anti-smoking initiative, and in 1971 bans on advertising on  television and radio took effect.  The rate continued to drop to its present 20%.    Certainly Michelle Obama is to be commended for shining a light on this public health problem and being a role model in educating both parents and children.  But unless we do something about advertising, the vastly more influential and well-funded program of counter-education, we will probably not see big results.  Perhaps just as a start we should get the soda dispensing machines out of schools.

Shipping natural gas overseas is a very expensive proposition. First, it requires the construction of expensive storage containers and conversion facilities. (Natural gas must be converted to liquid form for shipping, which requires a temperature of -260 degrees F). It must then be transported in costly specially made containers. There is NO way the US could ever ship a sufficient amount of LNG to Europe to supplant the gas that Russia provides thorugh pipelines. What it WILL do is cause an increase in the costs that Americans pay for natural gas.

I am a scientist who is watching first-hand how the NIH cuts are killing science. These private endeavors are great, but most are not going to fund basic science that lack a splashy finish in the next 5 years. That's a problem because that's where our future lies. Last year, funding for NIH grants for basic research was 6%. At that rate, excellent scientists are dropping out (for example, you can read Leon Avery's blog for his description of why he's quitting) or they are moving abroad. Students and postdoc fellows are switching to alternative careers. I read about STEM education, training the next generation, and it's a joke. There's no job for most of these people at the end of the training. We as a country appear to prefer baseball players and start ups to long-term research that can keep this country great.

I was in China this past year, and China is pouring money into science. It's a shocking contrast after the USA, and it bodes poorly for our future.

As a woman who worked on the business side of tech for 25 years, it's disheartening that it's gotten worse than when I started. Among my ten best women friends in tech, none are in the tech field any more. Meanwhile, many of the men in tech I knew are still in it, most of them as VCs. My husband, whom I met when we we both worked at MS, is still happily in tech.

I honestly think that for most women it's death by a thousand cuts. None of them are that serious, but collectively, they take the heart and drive out of you. Twenty years ago, while working at a major high tech firm, I tried a few times to explain to senior execs that it was unfair for them to open meetings talking with male peers about the early morning basketball game they played together since of course I (or any other woman) was never going to be invited. Mostly I got blank stares, but other times, I got the clear signal that I was in danger of being labeled as "too sensitive" or worse, as some kind of troublemaker. I quickly backed down.

I really, really like most of the men I worked with, and I know they're good people, but there can be a collective blindness where they talk business and tech with each other, and then, with women - enter a completely different zone. I wouldn't even notice the difference except that my husband is still in tech and it's something we talk about.

It's a problem. I don't have good answers, but a solution starts with acknowledging that the problem exists.

Since Justice Scalia and the Court previously ruled that religious freedom does not exist for those whose religion includes ritual use of peyote, why should it exist for those whose religion includes enforced pregnancy for employees of that religion's adherents? In the prior case, individuals weren't allowed under law to practice their own religiion. So now we're to suppose that individuals with a religion can impose its practices from anyone who'd work for them, even if the employees themselves have religious or moral beliefs that favor birth control in all its forms? What's the common thread here? The government can strip your religious rights, so corporations should be able to, too?

Or should we say that, contrary to Scalia's opinion on ritual peyote use, and contrary to the likely outcome of this case, the Constitution was crafted to enshrine individuals' rights, not the power of either government or corporations to remove them, especially not in the name of religion? Since Bush v. Gore we've known our top court was fundamentally corrupt. How much farther will they go down their dark road?

I had some trouble finding these wines in Denver, so I went with a Chateau D'
Arcins '09. I had read a lot of the comments about the need for decanting, so I did an extra long decant (nearly 4 hours). Also, slightly chilled to enhance, though I didn't check the exact temp. I did try it just after opening and as my favorite descriptor goes, it was "green and grippy."

I served with a strip steak, roasted kale salad and asparagus. It did loosen up with the significant decanting, but it was still very "tight." Even pairing with the dinner did not significantly enhance this one. This was a hard wine to enjoy, maybe it would be more pleasurable to drink after some cellaring.

Overall, noticeably high alcohol content, very tannic, with the more subtle notes overwhelmed by the alcohol and tannins. I have a '10 Chateau Aney and '06 Chateau Fourcas-Dumont to go, but since those are a bit off the "wine school" prescribed list I'll just be (hopefully) enjoying those.

Oh Andy, you made me cry.  The last time I saw Pete Seeger was several years ago at the stone church in Garrison where we were gathered to celebrate the passing of a mutual friend.  My husband  and I were in the last row when Pete and Toshi came in just a little late.  She sat in her wheelchair in the aisle, he sat next to us.  The choir sang To My Old Brown Earth to close the ceremony.  As we all joined the chorus, there he was, radiant, joyful, one friend come pay to say goodby to another.  He and Toshi were frail. I sensed as he sang the words that  he sang for himself as well as for our friend.  That is how I will remember him, knowing his time was coming, still full of joy, still singing.

I completely disagree with the Times on this question. It has gone away beyond the available data concerning the benefits of bulk data collection. For evidence, it does not cite any data (it doesn't have any; it's secret) but simply the opinions of a judge and two panels. Against these, we have the judgement of the President, two congressional oversight committees and the FISA court whose members have been selected by the Chief Justice. All these have found sufficient merit in the bulk data collection warrant sustaining it despite the threats to our privacy. I think we must rely on those we have elected to deal with secret data.

I'm not so sure that Russia's methods will backfire at all. And our own president needs to be very careful that he not, by words or actions, put a dangerous adversary in a corner from which his options become limited to caving before the world while abandoning critically important assets on one side, and invading and subjugating on the other ... not in Italy, France, Mexico City or Sheboygan, but on his very doorstep.

Russia has indisputable and massive interests in eastern and southern Ukraine, certainly in the Crimea, where at Sebastopol they base their Black Sea fleet. Ethnic Russians are thick on the ground in these areas, where the newly formed and not-yet-effective central government is despised, distrusted and regarded as illegitimate.

There is no end-game here that cedes effective control of these areas, these assets and these Russian populations to a power that is actively inimical to Russian interests. And if there were, it would merely inaugurate an insurgent war à la Kosovo or even Iraq, in which many would die.

Russia's aim is to establish a reality on the ground whose outcome the world eventually will see as inevitable: Ukraine needs to go the way of Czechoslovakia and partition, creating two nations. The western part will align itself with Europe and prosper with it, while the eastern part will become a Russian client or even be annexed, and take its chances with the bear.

I really like cash. When I use it I don't have to worry about being hacked, or have a bill to pay. And on most large purchases I get a discount just for asking. We had a manufacturing base back then, too! These were jobs that paid 3 or 4 times minimum wage--easily. This meant many people had the choice of going straight to work out of high school, or going to college.

Howard is exhibiting the strains that many small, private undercapitalized colleges are experiencing. Prospective students, particularly the most competitive applicants, are increasingly motivated to weigh alternative options, whether lower cost in state tuition at a public university or the allure of larger private schools with the capacity to offer grants and scholarships. There is a slow and painful shakeout coming and some schools are already merging functions and operations. Absent a very successful endowment drive, they are going to struggle.

I don’t understand why so many people seem to be puzzled by Putin’s actions. As former head of the KGB and a Soviet insider, he personally witnessed the destruction of the Soviet Union as a world power. I can image this must have deeply affected him personally. He has watched the U.S. and its western European allies threaten Russia’s remaining influence in their own backyard. The West has made what Russia must perceive as provocative overtures to Kiev, influencing pro-western factions in Ukraine to seek EU and NATO membership, threatening Russia’s hegemony. Think about how we felt when the USSR made overtures to Cuba in our own backyard. The U.S. was rightfully indignant. Russia feels justified in its indignation as well.

Put on top of this the U.S. ill-advised and quite frankly illegal Iraq war, the meddling in Libya and Egypt, and our own selective support of dictators while condemning others, and you can see how Putin has lost respect for the U.S. and the West generally. Russia’s deep sense of loss of prestige and disrespect heaped upon them can no longer be tolerated by Putin or his people. Arbitrary borders drawn in the mid-20th century do not trump millennia of cultural and historical ties within the Crimea and the region generally.

The U.S. and Europe helped make this bed. Putin feels pushed to the brink and the West does not have the moral credibility it thinks it has.

Ms. Torres defines a legitimate social challenge we face and that will worsen in intensity as our population grays, at least until the boomer generation goes the way of all flesh: disengagement, and the need to somehow re-engage. Senior centers efficiently put the aged together but must focus resources on addressing needs most intensely felt by the greatest number. That leaves out a lot of the merely lonely.

What kept my mother most engaged in her eighties and nineties (she passed at 93) was access to online facilities, news, opinion, special-interest communities in which she could participate with comments. Not that this can fully take the place of physical interaction, particularly intergenerational interaction, but it could enrich lives, give the elderly an avenue of re-engagement, and lessen the demand for physical facilities to satisfy the need for being in a crowd, which never really goes away.

How about a room in senior centers dedicated to subsidized or free online access -- PCs as well as a hot spot for those who bring their own? Advice as to communities they can join to offer experiences and counsel to younger people in need of such counsel? Re-engagement.

I work for an agency providing residential care for minors, having previously worked within foster care. So many of the familial crises we see stem from people not knowing how to be good parents. Often, the pathologies start in pregnancy, when the mothers-to-be are unaware of what they need to do, including prenatal care and abstaining from smoking, drinking and using drugs. Babies born from harsh in utero environments are then disposed to a host of physical, cognitive and behavioral difficulties, which the parents are unable to cope with. In addition, many parent/child interactions lack important aspects like holding, reading, talking. Relationships between the mother and father are often strained, especially when one or both parents has multiple children from other partners (which also makes marriage less likely).
My recommendation is for more education about parenting, beginning within schools, including taking care of a pregnant body. Additionally, I'd offer free counseling centers to those of all ages and even throw in overview sessions akin to Driver's Ed and Defensive Driving . More people, male and female, married and single, would be better parents if they had knowledge and resources.

Mr. Friedman wants another moon shot, not a cold war. Then he wants a race for new technologies in clean, affordable energy production. It won't happen. The space race and competition provided America with feelings of great national pride and accomplishment. The space race in which initially, America the underdog, was first surprised by the launch of Sputnik, then energized by our fear of Soviet supremacy in space and space technology, was a race for survival in a world threatened by nuclear war. From space nuclear weapons could be rained down upon the U.S. without warning.
There is no such compelling fear today. We're too smug in our lead in technology and advanced weaponry. Mr. Obama is too young to remember the space race or the nuclear arms race. There is no context in which he can place the comparison of the need for energy policy to isolate Russia or advance American interests. When President Kennedy announced that we would land a man on the moon by the end of the decade he did so by asking us to reach for the stars and to join in his vision of American greatness. Mr. Kennedy challenged us to greatness. We accepted that challenge not because of the Soviet threat of dominance but because Mr. Kennedy pointed out our ability to meet challenges and lead the free world. If Mr. Obama can do that we can lead the world again.
I would also add that it is as shallow as his understanding of economic theory.

Efforts like this are so important. I've worked in educational programs with both young children and older children from economically disadvantaged backgrounds. These kids are behind the curve before they ever set foot inside a classroom because their vocabularies are much smaller than their middle- and upper-income counterparts. This carries over into all aspects of learning since reading comprehension is required in every subject.

A few years ago I worked with a group of high school sophomores in NYC trying to prepare for the verbal portion of their upcoming SATs by memorizing lists of words and their definitions. It broke my heart to see them engaged in such a futile activity. At that age, the meaning of words should be learned through context, by reading and listening, and not by rote memorization. I exhorted them to read as much as they could. I told them to bring a book along for the long subway rides. I asked them to challenge themselves and pick difficult material. These kids were bright, but their circumstances had conspired to put them at such a disadvantage. I can only hope that perhaps a few of them took my advice.

I don't know what happens in NY; but in the Bay Area, the once-a-year NCLB tests take the average student about 45 minutes a day, generally two days a week, for two weeks. I've administered the tests to grades two through seven. The average child does their best, puts effort into it and then moves on. They don't fall apart any more than children normally do when confronted with challenging work.

We do "teach to the test." What's in the tests is what we are supposed to teach! The state tells us what to cover, and then the children are tested to see how well they got it. It takes an average of 3 hours over the course of two weeks to finish the testing. More in fifth grade because we also test science. (Hurray for that, because some elementary teachers never got around to science - too much Picasso I guess.)

When I look at test scores, the scores almost always reasonably accurately measure how much a child was learning that year. The tests are not at all perfect. Common Core is a huge change in how we teach. Scores will decline while we adjust.

Prior to NCLB testing, there was no way for families to determine how well any school measured up to any other school, even in a single District. With Common Core, we will at last get some idea of how each school measures up against other schools in the entire country.

Not all children are above average. NCLB tests reasonably reflect what children learn. CC will do that in a couple more years.

I could not disagree more. Years ago people thought IVF was unnatural and declared it to be "a dangerous step." Today it is well accepted and recognized for what it is - a medical treatment for infertility. IVF treatment has helped many infertile would-be parents have children who would not otherwise exist.

This is simply another treatment. Nobody is talking about picking the child's eye color or even it's gender. They are simply placing the mother's genetic material into a healthy egg.

Also the statement that there were abnormalities in some of the fertilized eggs is completely out of context. Many fertilized eggs develop abnormalities and as a result, they stop replicating.

We should not let superstition and half-truths prevent us from curing infertility.

In answer to the question, I have (finally) smartened up and cut back on my rental costs, but it did mean moving to a smaller town in a more rural part of Ohio. It has been a mixed blessing. I wonder where the much vaunted free market is in this equation. I knew a couple of builders in Columbus, where I lived before, who did the downtown expensive dwelling thing and ended up in deep financial trouble, but the rush to pricy downtown properties has not, to my knowledge, abated. One of these guys told me that, in retrospect, he would have been better off -- and more people in Columvus would have been similarly better off -- if he'd lowered his sights and built or rehabbed buildings intended to house the less affluent.

Isn't that how the free market is supposed to work -- or have I missed something?

Deserving ... Waltons, Gates, Jobs, NFL players ...

Not deserving: Finance guys at JPM, GS, Blackrock, etc. and Fortune 500 CEOs making more than $10mm as employees, Hedge Fund types, Trial Lawyers, etc. ...

It is important for one to know one's roots and whence one came. The fact is at some point in history all of families were at the brink one step away from oblivion. It is only a matter of how far back one is able to go before discovering their precipice. Billions of people are living this way now, including millions upon millions of Americans. The circumstances for these predicaments can be due to natural forces but political and social forces can exacerbate them far further.

Paul Ryan like most of his compatriots have to look at themselves in the mirror most every day. Whether he sees anything wrong with his image is up to conjecture. One's impact may appear celebrated today & one' legacy may be maligned in the future. Just ask Charles Trevelyan. Even in high school in the Boston area, his name came up in social studies class in the most unflattering light. I can assure you, Paul Ryan does not want to be this guy. Yet that is where he is heading now. The dustbin of history is full of people who thought that they were bright and had something to say. Paul Ryan & today's Republican Party is building itself up to be a laughingstock when children read about them in the textbooks of 50 or 100 years from now. Whatever faults the Democrats have (they have many), they will at least come out looking clean by comparison when all is said and done. It is a particular travesty that a child of the Irish famine forgot his roots. The Irish are far better people than this.

This article is very interesting, but the comments are fascinating.  The Sochi Olympic Games were designed to be the transformational moment when the world is shown a new Russia with a strong leader at its helm.  The price tag, the extraordinary scope of the project, even the place chosen reflected this desire.  The criticism the event is drawing is directly proportional with the ambitiousness of the project.  Do you think our press, the Western Fifth Estate, is going to stand on the sidelines and toe the line at reporting grace on the ice and speed on the slopes?  They are going to look at everything, they will command every angle, they are already primed by the price tag of 51 billion dollars and reports of corruption and Mafia involvement, some of it courtesy of Russia’s own much beleaguered and maligned press.  If the request is for nicer stories – sorry, you’re reading a world class newspaper, not PR fluff.   If you’re Russian – this story doesn't come from any complex of superiority, but rather from the belief that state-provoked human misery should be punished, no matter where it happens, and the powerless may find advocates in the unlikeliest of places.  Who would have thought a little village that no one really cared about would have found itself on the main NY Times page!?

I have seen ice storms outside of the South - Indiana had about 3-4 inches (!!) of ice deposited in the winter of 2010-11 (I can't remember which month). It was the worse ice storm I remembered seeing (I'm 67) but that doesn't mean we never had a worse one -- since, when I was a kid, we didn't get so torqued out of shape with snow, rain, hot days (in the absence of air conditioning), etc.

Some were without power (we were not that year, but we lost power when the temps dropped to -14, for 14 hours -- and survived). We lost power for 3 days one summer (much easier to tolerate, of course, although you lose all your refrigerated food) when a lightning bolt hit a tree in the back yard and a limb hit the (yes, non-buried) power line -- just affected our house, so we were "down the list" for restoration.

I will admit I'm going to investigate a generator this year -- only because, in spite of my age, I'm too soft to tolerate no power if I can avoid it :)

There has been so much exciting science news of late from the Big Bang to this.

In light of all the news, it becomes more and more outrageous that we have to be intellectually assaulted by the doofuses in Congress who, with no shame, espouse that the world is only 6,000 years old, or purport that a woman can “shut that whole thing down.” The willful ignorance of some of those who govern is on display in neon, yet they can exploit a powerful bully pulpit to coerce their anti-intellectual sheep to believe in fantasy, stay uneducated, and vote against their own self- interest.

These Alzheimer’s studies slowly add one more piece to the puzzle, perhaps getting us one step close to a cure. It also brings into fast relief what’s at risk over time the more we cut, cut, cut basic research. The destruction of the anti-science crowd cited above is very real and very scary.

While Alzheimer’s funding was increased this year, the NIH is still dealing with cuts from sequestration It’s time to stop the madness. We must restore our governmental support for scientific and medical research in this country. The quality of our lives and our longevity depend on it.
Let's have random drug tests and semi-annual criminal background checks for all Americans.  Anyone who does't like it can move to Saudi Arabia!

I am afraid that this lady (as many Ukrainians) lives in the world of fantasy. The concluding sentence is a proof of that. They CANNOT win a war with Russia for obvious reasons.

Of course, Putin will have some very limited diplomatic setbacks and Ms. Merkel is not sure whether he is mentally OK but this is not 'winning the war'.

As a Czech who was fortunate enough to come here and lived here since 1968 I remember well the way Brezhnev justified his aggression and, of course, he won and nobody in the West did anything about it.

True, Putin may scale down his grab of Ukrainian territory if Ukrainians fight. Ultimately, however, they will loose and young lives will be lost.

Whether the Ukrainians are united or not is not quite important. The size of their army and the weapons they have are no match to the Russian.

Putin may demand end of the 'coup' in the Kiev and he may get some concessions there negotiated by the West, perhaps Ms. Merkel.

When it was clear that Nelson Mandela was getting out of prison, he was asked where he would want to go. He said most longed to go to where he had played as a seven yr. old and see those places again.

We all long to inhabit places where we feel a deep connection, where there is a strong feedback loop between the place and our hearts and minds. Sometimes, they are drawn from unconscious experiences. Sometimes from the simplicity of the memories they conjure. They can also be assigned when we arrive someplace and feel, suddenly, completely at home: this is where I belong.

In my own case, I could not name a childhood home that was a true home. My father's work required frequent moves (8 schools by the 3rd grade), so my memories are scattered about in a dozen or more locations.

I went to high school in the Reading, Pa., area, so the places inhabited by the characters in some of Updike's fiction are intimate and reassuring. It was also the birthplace of poet Wallace Stevens and, like him, I was occasionally overwhelmed by the sensual beauty of the dark green countryside in early bloom.

There are moments when Texas feels like a true home. Now, as spring comes across the vast state, every native Texas around the world feels a pull toward home, to the gentle, fragile opening of flowers and trees that, before long, will be a land of brutal heat

I am lost in America, finding home wherever it might be found and content to be a long time resident of Maryland

http://terryreport.com

A tender and beautiful piece. As an aging, retired chaplain and family therapist, I observe that a most easily used and abused phrase is: "It's God's will." Presence and "I don't know what to say" can, at least, in honesty, give a fragment of love in a time of pain we can all, sometime, experience. Congressional Republicans released Standards for Immigration Reform that state that there should “be no special path to citizenship for individuals who broke our nation’s immigration laws”, but they “could live legally and without fear in the U.S.”  But they didn’t include a name to describe that new noncitizen status. There are uncanny parallels between Israel's ill-fated invasion of southern Lebanon in 1982 and the U.S. invasion of Iraq in 2003. Both were undertaken to "reshape the neighborhood" rather than as true acts of self-defense; both ended in retreats described face-savingly as "withdrawals"; both resulted in thousands of useless deaths; both wasted vast amounts of money; both left the invaded country more dangerous than it was before and last of all, both events demonstrated the folly and hubris of leaders who thought that they inherited wisdom along with their enormous military power. A little humility would have saved many lives.

This is a fantastic column.

Readers should try to appreciate the role of geopolitical theory - the only manner in which geopolitics can offer a platform of clarity is through simplifying world relationships. No overarching viewpoint can be all-encompassing, any political theory that attempts to be entirely truthful about geopolitical complexity would be the social equivalent of chaos theory. A fully aware world view cannot be translated into a political or philosophical platform - immediately grasping and incorporating the full complexity of human interaction would generate a devastating condition of inaction because the topic be stalled by the infinite particulars that don't fit a model.

Geopolitics is a powerful and meaningful tool - consider the work of Mackinder or Kennan. Of course each provided dramatic simplifications of world relationships, but they were powerful because they were simplifications, they could stand as a script for action. We may not agree with their intentions or results, but we should learn from them.

Mr. Friedman provides a viewpoint that rings true to western sensibilities, is slanted towards western democratic values, and suggests a peace-oriented but prudent scheme for international strategy. The biases his scheme contains are useful and worthwhile, they propel our own interests forward in a considered manner.

Read Mr. Friedman's column with the right approach, I assure you he already understands what lies beyond what he has written.

I don't disagree with Mr. Brooks's sentiment, but it rubs me the wrong way that most of this column speaks only to those with the very most privilege: the highly intelligent and accomplished who are also secure enough/have few enough obligations that they could "engage[] in some desperate lark that made no sense from a career or social status perspective," or be a "cover letter rebel[]."  I'm all for basing hiring decisions on the whole person rather than on stats alone (when I've been the hirer, I've found that to lead to better results, anyway), but concluding that high achievers "either . . . have no desire to chart out an original life course or lack the courage to do so" is ridiculous.  Take my friend who grew up in near-poverty, and won a scholarship to college based on her perfect grades and leadership position in a national organization.  At college, she pursued every "perfect consultant/investment bank internship" she could that would (1) pay her tuition that was not covered by her scholarship, and (2) help to her get a job after graduation, so that she could help out her family and raise her kids in something better than poverty.  To say that a high achiever has "no desire to chart out an original life course or lack[s] the courage to do so" assumes that she has the luxury of not achieving.

I have a thought to share: what's going on with the comments section of the newly redesigned New York Times?
I like to read the comments of other readers on the articles published, and sometimes I like to write one of my own. But when I do it doesn't stay in the order of published comments where I can see how many readers recommend my comment and how many couldn't care less or disagree with me.
But my comments don't stay in the same section. They get added in a separate box at the top of the page, always with one recommendation.
Why?

We still have a season to celebrate Derek Jeter on the field, though his "career built on grit and hustle" may be no match for Father Time in 2014. But who isn't rooting for him to perform one final season-long miracle?

And then he would do well to model Doug Glanville for a Second Act. If Mr. Jeter can find the same level of success in his future endeavors as Mr. Glanville has found with his pen (okay, with his keyboard) following his own Major League career, the Yankee Captain will have once again exceeded anyone's reasonable expectations.

It is beyond debate that this column is a role model writing about a role model. Given the pundits and athletes of the day, what are the odds?

A great Second Act is surely worth more than a sixth ring. But first things first. Play ball!

The so called "free world" isn't free. Not with Wall Street and the 1% running the show. We have no business meddling in Kiev, just as we had no business meddling in Iraq, Vietnam, Libya , Syria , Iran ,etc. we do an awful job as the world's policeman (see above). The Ukraine is in Russia's back yard, just as the Monroe doctrine put Latin America in our back yard. We didn't like Russia meddling in Cuba and they don't like us meddling in the Ukraine .

Ukraine seems heading for a civil or or 2 separate countries. It could well be a bloody battle. We need to keep out, though. We didn't like foreign powers siding with the south during our civil war. And the forever wise George Washington long ago told us to stay away from foreign entanglements. Besides, we need to spend our money in fixing up the US, and making equality our new byword. As a young boy growing up in San Francisco, I remember reading self-congratulatory literature on how CA turned the desert into a food store, moving water from where it was to where it wasn't. The plumbing system of the Golden State is a marvel, built by California taxpayers with the help of the federal government.

The result is that there are no longer any rivers left to dam; the once bountiful salmon fishery has been lost, marginal, heavily irrigated soil leaches poisons into the San Joaquin River; San Francisco Bay has become a sump of agricultural waste water.

For every 108 oz. gallon of fresh water consumed there, 91 oz. of it goes to agriculture to grow (among others) water intensive crops that no sane person would otherwise grow there: rice, cotton, alfalfa, beef, dairy, etc. Moreover, the cheap, underpriced federal water growers get is used to grow crops which the same e federal government covers with price supports and export subsidies.

We have plumbed and re-plumbed California water supplies to the point of diminishing returns and Nature will once again demonstrate its remarkable ability to equalize itself. It is, quite simply, a matter of time.

Income distribution should look like a pyramid, not a space needle. How a CEO became 1000 times more valuable than he was in the 1950s is not because MBAs contain that much more knowledge. It is because the satellite CEO became detached from the rocket that catapulted it into the stratosphere in the late 20th century.
Costco is a better model than Walmart for how pay structure should look, but the detachment of management from labor as a rule is looking more and more distant and lost in space. That is the gravity of the situation.
Perhaps if MBAs all interned as laborers in factories for a semester, they might realize that the pyramid has stood the test of time, while the rocket sometimes blows up and the needle will topple.

We decided to go all in. After a long week of work, we opened the Sociando-Mallet, let it sit for an hour, looked, smelled and tasted the wine,  cooked up a bone-in rib eye with some roasted asparagus, put on my husband's "French" playlist, and finished it all.  Initially, the wine had strong acidity, with a lot of tannin- very parched on my palate.  But the wine definitely cut through the fat of the rib-eye. I worry about the tannins- is there a direct correlation between the tannins and my anticipated headache tomorrow morning?  We only had one bottle!

The Iraq War cut off the second largest oil stream in OPEC. The price of crude went from $35 per barrel to $100. This enabled Putin to refurbish his military, including the outfitting of the Nevsky, Dolgoruky, and Muromets super silent Red October submarines, each carrying enough nuclear weapons to threaten American cities. We also embargoed Iranian oil. Now Putin buys 500,000 barrels per day at low prices and sells it to the west at retail prices. Without the Iraq War, Putin would not be sitting in the Crimea and on the border across from Kharkov and Donyets. The Iraq War was bad for Iraq, bad for America, and very good for Russia.  Now we are at at disadvantage if we try to defend a far away country about which we know little. However, it must be done or Putin will continue his march to the West. Clearly, a land war fought in Ukraine would be difficult for America to wage. However, there are ways to push back on Russian aggression. Take even one division of American troops in Poland and move them to Poland. Increase the numerosity of fighters in the Baltic republics. Also, drop the boycott on Iranian oil (the third largest stream in OPEC), and buy directly from the Iranians. The Israelis will not like it, but I don't bloody care. Their neocon push of America into an unjust and evil war in Iraq caused the Ukraine crisis. We need to stop taking orders from Netanyahu and start doing that which is best for the West.

Putin did not rise to power by accident. What is wrong with this article is its failure to acknowledge that when Gorbachev, who sought to transform the Soviet Union into one more based upon individual rights, sought assistance from the George H W Bush & Clinton administrations to do so Gorbachev & the Soviet Union received “Shock & Awe” privatization & capitalism instead - thereby begetting the Oligarchs who begot Putin.

Many readers seem to forget that Putin received great popular acclaim when Putin publicly tore up the contracts with the Big Oil Companies that had entered into “partnerships” to develop Russian resources because those contracts had been imposed upon Russia by the West using the IMF & were seen as unfair.

If Reagan, whom many Republicans today claim to have been virtually omniscient, saw in Gorbachev someone who could be trusted to move towards eliminating nuclear weapons & cooperative relationship with the West, why did the Rs & Clinton proceed to undercut him?

Romney has now spoken publicly on Russia & states that it was always naive, as with the “Obama Reset,” to view Russia as anything other than an adversary. Reading Prof. Krugman's column and studying a number of the ideas can help us perceive the real truth of what affects the economy, and what could help it. It requires an extended effort to see for ourselves what is needed fro the country to overcome its economic problems. It should not be a matter of just going with a majority slant that sheds no light, but directs indiscreet action. Doing that is exactly the reason our political system as it is, has failed this nation at least in not quickly enough found right legislative solutions, and substituted many counterproductive 'solutions'.

So what I finally gather as what the country needs, is to impose for a limited time, an emergency tax, levied upon all those with enormous assets.
The money should be used for only one definite purpose: to begin an infrastructure renewal program across the land. This would be government money, fully paid by taxes. It would renew the decaying pipes underground that are about to burst. It would make for hundreds of thousands of new jobs at least, for the next few years.

I recently rescinded an offer to buy acreage in western Colorado due to my inability to strike an equitable water allocation agreement with some adjacent land owners who shared access and rights to several irrigation ditches running through the property. It took countless hours of personal research as well as several billable hours to two separate water lawyers to fully understand the rights both currently and as they could be affected in the future by senior calls. It's the obligation of the land holder to understand the nature of his investment, and how it may be affected by the vicissitudes of both time and climate (in)action. I ultimately determined to remain in the (relative) hydrolands of the east, where water is plentiful and farming is conducive to the spoils of fair Ceres.
We cannot exculpate the western farmers from either the sins of their fathers or those of the bureau of Reclamation when they have profited so profoundly and perversely (literally, perverting the flow of rivers to satisfy their own short-sighted needs) when we as federal tax-payers have shouldered the burdens of water projects ranging from damming every major river of the west to desalinization plants that waste megawatts to remove the salts from the water that are introduced to them from irrigating land that should never have been farmed in the first place.

Bevan (and Mark):

It's precisely the studies done by Piketty and Saez that form the basis of what I asserted in my comment was the "gap most often cited". They used data from tax returns spanning decades to determine distribution of national income. They found that national income overall grew by 1.7 percent by 2011 but by 11 percent for the top 1 percent of earners. But their findings are based on pre-tax income reported by tax filers, without transfers and without off-the-books considerations that are almost impossible to calculate anyway. But the impact of these factors is real.

I don't argue (and neither does this increasing group of questioning economists) that there is no "gap", but merely that it's not as large as some paint it. What I argue moreover is that, whatever it is, it's not occasioned by high earners making too much but by competitive factors in labor that are becoming historical and deeply entrenched, that are de-valuing the labor of lower earners. Yet, the ink we see from the left seeks to demonize high earners as a rationale for taxing them more onerously to more fully redistribute what they perceive as a pie of static size.

We need to confront this historical shift and de-valuation, not focus so intently on what the high-end makes. Funding solutions may well require higher taxes on high-earners, but additional simple direct transfers to reduce an over-stated "gap" are not the strategic solution.

Suppose we accept the theory that free trade raises the human standard of living by allocating resources more efficiently.  The theory must still be qualified as follows.  1) Merely shifting production to places where product quality, social justice and environmental protection are lower is not an improvement in the allocation of resources.  America scores only modestly in these categories, but some places score lower than we.  2) Especially in the short term, an increase in the AVERAGE standard of living might consist of an increase for the majority of humans but a decrease for a minority.   Analogy: a much-needed rain might save crops over a broad plain but cause a flash flood that wipes out anyone living near the stream into which the rain drains (mainly).  Truly productive designs usually find a way to dampen local turbulence.  Sadly though, the politician has not been born who encourages us to see such shades of gray, because politicians only see green.

I've been an Emergency Physician since 1996 and the only two patient's I've ordered CT scans prior to being examined were elderly patients with head injuries on coumadin. I did make sure they could say "hi" first though.

I'd like to see where the authors get their data for the statement "For example, emergency room physicians routinely order multiple CT scans even before meeting a patient." From my experience at a level 1 inner city trauma hospital and a suburban free standing ER, I've never seen anyone routinely order scans prior to an exam. We do order too many cardiac labs and ekgs before examining patients, but that is hard to avoid when busy given the time sensitive nature of heart attack treatment. Since we have ultrasound machines, we routinely perform ultrasound scans prior to CT scans in trauma patients.

We do order way too many CT scans for abdominal pain, but given the nature of our malpractice situation, very few physicians have the guts to go with clinical instinct anymore.

In my home state of Illinois, there were almost NO white tail deer or wild turkey in the early to mid 20th century.  Modern conservation techniques, fueled by hunting license fees and later the Pittman Robertson excise tax on all gun and ammunition sales, were able to restore both species to normal populations in most counties of Illinois.  The same process has played out in many other states where human populations depleted the species to near local extinction, and now they are back at near pest levels.  Make no mistake--Namibia WILL save the black rhino through this strategy, and emotion-based anti hunters will have played no part in the success.

The first time I saw Philip Seymour Hoffman act was in "Scent of a Woman"....where he so convincingly played an amoral, spoiled, prep school brat. Even alongside Al Pacino's award winning performance - the character I remember most is Mr. Hoffman's. He fairly leapt off the screen in authenticity! I've followed his career ever since. I loved seeing him hang out, at the Public Theater; just another 'guy' on the street. But NOT just another guy.

He was an all time personal favorite of mine. His performances left me breathless --- I expected great, and greater performances in his future.
Alas, not to be. I'm taking this quite personally........

RIP......."and may flights of angels sing thee to thy rest."
I pray you now have peace, Mr. Hoffman........

If Maidan means anything at all, it's a metaphor for repudiating Ukraine's failed oligarchic past, one that included Timoshenko no less than Yanukovych. That failure didn't just include the embezzlement of tens of billions, but the unwillingness (and totall incompetence) of elites to articulate a credible, post-Soviet, non-ethnic definition for a new Ukrainian nation-state. For 20 years, elites have ruled through alternating, highly corrupt 'Russia Lite' regimes, whether orange or blue, either of which Putin was quite happy with. But Maidan effectively broke the spell, which Putin never anticipated and which shocked him to his core. The message of no more oligarchs, no more secret palaces and tycoons making themselves richer and the country poorer by the day, is just as threatening for Timoshenko, no matter how hard she tries to ride the tiger.

"Yet there’s still an assumption that men will not go to see a woman’s movie, but that women will go to see anything.”

Pretty insulting to the 52% of women movie goers. Almost makes me want to boycott Hollywood (note I said "almost"). But in addition to the "men vs women" power and money struggle in the film industry, I'd throw in another neglected constituency: age. In this year's 9 best films, we see Bruce Dern and June Squibb, , Judy Dench, and (gasp) Meryl Streep among the nominees--all either over or near 60. Wow, is all I can say, wow.

As long as the Oscars continue to reward great performances, there's still hope for us movie lovers. I was impressed by the quality and depth of the roles women (and older men) have been given as films continue to evolve and inspire.

As a woman who definitely not "willing to see anything," that cheers me immensely. Since life encompasses the full spectrum of human experience, including aging, racism, sexism, and sexual politics, I want to see the full monte of emotion. Not just what studio moguls think I want to see.

Before waxing too rhapsodic on Scalia, be aware that he was with the majority on Citizens United and that he and Alioto also added a concurring opinion that particularly affirmed the rights of corporations to free speech. Important considerations, no doubt, but I question which way the causation runs. With regard to strong families, I wonder, does family breakdown lead to poverty, or does poverty lead to family breakdown? Moreover, it is indisputable that children of parents of means have greater educational opportunity than those growing up in poverty, so are the impoverished poor because of a lack of education or do they lack education because of their limited resources?

It seems to me that fighting poverty will strengthen families and provide more educational opportunities. So we're back to job creation, but not just any old jobs. As Mr. Kristof rightly notes many in poverty are pushed into low-paying, dead-end jobs that don't offer a route out of poverty, much less into the middle class. The very notion of "working poor" is a national disgrace. Not every job should make one rich, but they should at least provide enough to get by.

Finally, I would ask a question of those opposed to food stamps, medicaid and the like, if someone is not paid enough to survive without these programs, who is on welfare, the worker or the employer paying a slave's wage?
On an unrelated note, I wonder how much of the Florida prison system's $58 million dollar deficit is due to housing and feeding people imprisoned on minor drug possession charges.

I'm glad to see that the students are reacting to the firing of their teacher and I hope that it will provoke them to take a deeper look at Catholic identity. Perhaps this isn't the appropriate religion for some of these kids.
I attended a Catholic highschool in the mid 90's. By my senior year it was clear to me that I was a lesbian. Struggling to balance Catholic doctrine with my recent self discovery, I sought the advice of a liberal nun who taught at the school. We discussed gay marriage, sexism, and the infallibility of the Pope. She told me that the Pope was only a human, and therefore not all-knowing. She also told me that if the church did not evolve on social issues, it would see a huge decline in followers. She then encouraged me to become more active in the church and to become a voice of change.
I remember thinking, "No thanks" and I left that meeting feeling like a weight had been lifted. While appreciating my teacher's support, I decided I would not be attempting a reformation of the Catholic Church. Instead, I would use my energy to liberate my mind and body from internalized fear and shame. Since then, I have found spirituality and community through other means. And even though I left Catholicism behind many years ago, i still occasionally wake up on a Sunday morning and smile at the thought that I will not be getting out of bed and going to church.

This is exactly my situation for nearly two dozen part-time offsite employees--state-mandated as W-2 even though they set their own schedules and decide how to do their jobs like most consultants. Essentially, this will be bonus time, since currently if they're sick they can just reschedule their work at the client and not miss any hours. I pay well for my industry--minimum $40/hour for almost all work, up to $75/hour--and this is just one additional burden that will lead to my selling business in the coming months--or simply disbanding it, perhaps thereby reducing the income of all of these "employees."

I'm a self employed artist and the ACA has helped me get better insurance coverage for myself and family, but I don't intend to stop working because I have it.  I guess in the mind's of Republicans it's better to have people working than for them to have insurance.  And if they get sick or die because they don't have insurance...how does that effect the work force?

"It isn't books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books.... The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not." --Ray Bradbury, Fahrenheit 451

Books are not innately preferable to TV. A great deal depends on the book. 12 straight hours spent consuming Game of Thrones is probably a waste of time regardless of the medium. Your vocabulary might improve slightly with the book though.

I'd think the same amount of time spent watching documentaries or insightful films would ultimately provide more knowledge and insight. Unfortunately, to Bradbury's point, it's a lot harder to find intelligent television than it is to find thought provoking literature. "Good television" is a time-suck by design. The TV creators are simply becoming more sophisticated in their craft.

Interestingly, the concurrent technological developments allows each consumer more freedom to choose whats valuable to them. The increase in consumption seems a natural outcome resulting from this trend. The battle now being fought is who holds the keys to the content garden? I hope it won't be my ISP.

"Making it harder for people to smoke yields enormous health benefits."

then you should be talking to your government about taxes on tobacco and public bans on smoking and voting accordingly. talking about a profit-oriented enterprise in opinion pages, and even worse about how the ACS should pressure a profit-oriented enterprise, is a waste of time.

let's congratulate CVS for its anti-tobacco stance and hope that it will motivate some people to quit smoking. and if this move will be good for CVS's profits, surely other enterprises will notice immediately.

The Obama Administration is largely correct in its response to Russian aggression in Crimea. We are not in a position to intervene militarily, yet we can't sit by and do nothing while Putin violates international law and seizes territory that he is obligated by treaty to respect. Putin and those Russians that support him must be made to understand that there will be an ever-increasing price for this sort of aggression.

No reasonable adult believes that we can turn Russia into Iran or North Korea with economic sanctions. But the Russian economy was already in a weakened (and weakening) state before this crisis began. With the annexation of Crimea, Putin did Russia no favors. This territory will be a sinkhole for Russian money and resources for years to come - and what does Russia gain? A naval base that it already had? Vast deposits of gold, oil, or gas in Crimea? Please - they can't even produce their own electricity or drinking water.

We can't force Putin out of Crimea with tanks or planes. But we can make this costly Putin adventure even more costly for the Russians - and that is the proper response. Leave room for harsher and deeper sanctions if the situation escalates further and other parts of Ukraine are invaded. Time is on our side. We've won this type of long game before - see Cold War.

Am I missing something? In the op-ed there were examples of medical technicians committing heinous acts which resulted in horrible repercussions for people. I didn't read examples of doctors doing these things so I'm not sure where the overarching policy of "doctor" drug testing comes from.  (Perhaps just a bold controversial statement hoping to garner attention?) If these isolated examples are enough to pursue drug testing of all medical personnel, incidentally including doctors apparently, then why not just everyone with a job interacting with people?  That barista making your morning latte - what if he's actually mixing melamine with the espresso so he can take the ground coffee home?! But whatever, introduce drug testing for all medical personnel. Pay for the extra cost.  I'm sure it will be as useful and productive as the "WAR" on drugs.

The truth as I see it is quite different. I am a woman who owns a small independent restaurant in downtown Atlanta. The servers all make well over $20/hr, consistent with other eateries in the area. They are a vital part of the company and they behave with the authority of this importance. Unlike your portrayal of enslavement, the server is basically an independent contractor who can pick and choose the company they deem to base their business. Their compensation is well over the other restaurant employees because, like me, they take the risk. The server is able to change jobs more freely than most and many talented ones do to climb the ladder. Those servers who make low tips work in companies who serve customers that do not come for service or pay for service. They can gain experience and move on to more demanding server jobs that pay more.
The quality of personnel in the server industry is high because they can make high salaries through tips. If this were to change, you would experience cafeteria-like dining. This is already available for those who choose not to pay tips. The "rip-off" is your choice.

At age 62 I lost my job and for 4 years struggled to make ends meet, and as a result of the real estate market and stock market collapse of 2008, I lost my home and half of the value of my $600,000 pension fund. I'm buried in credit card debt and punished annually in taxes as I have drawn down my pension fund to pay off cumulative debt incurred in paying for housing and groceries and insurance. I receive $1,400 per month in SS which does not cover the essentials - and I mean essentials. But I have not defaulted - every debt I owe has been/is being paid off.

Meanwhile financiers responsible for the collapse continue to prosper and skate free on their manipulations of our nation's financial markets, bailed out by MY tax dollars.

Most of all, I am just sad that America has fallen apart for hard-working middle-class folks, and sadder still, that our government shows no interest in fixing anything. As I maintain, it's a Depression with good PR.
This is extremely sad. He is an unforgettable actor.

Mr. Asimov's wine school is a tempting adventure! I am recently retired, so wine school is just the type of new experience I want to pursue. Smell the roses. Taste the wines. And eat at well as can at my age! I scoured our local wine stores and did not find your selections. Oh, we seem to be in a wine barren part of the country. But I did find a 2007 Haute-Medoc: a Chateau Charmail, which the store manager assured me was similar to the 2009. (He is usually quite good at suggesting wines for me).

I invited two friends over for an evening of grilled lamb chops and spring asparagus, roasted root vegetables, and the wine. Decanted it over an hour before the guests arrived. The cork smelled very sweet and fruity. So I was surprised when I finally tasted the wine just before dinner. It seemed more savory, and very smooth and full-bodied. It seemed thick on my tongue. The tannins were balanced. But as the meal went on, and as we poured the last of the bottle between our four glasses, the tannins became stronger and less pleasant.

Thank you for doing this. I hope to learn how about my lifelong love of wine.

More:

Anyone serious enough to attend "Wine School" should know Bordeaux.

Why '09? I'd wager: it is one of three recent great vintages, the others being '05 and '10; '05 is not as available and is more expensive, even if drinking better now; '10 is available but younger, which is less suited for this exercise.

Haut Medoc is cheaper than other appellations. 2009 Haut Medoc is among the most logical entries to introduce a big audience to quality red Bordeaux. All things equal, we'd be drinking '05 Cos D'Estournel instead. Or 2000 Petrus.

Good 2010's can be had at Costco for less than $15.

Decant. This wine needs at least two hours of air. If you don't have a decanter, use a pitcher. Stemless glasses are most convenient. Riedel is great, so is Cost Plus. It's fine to do a couple glasses tonight and finish it tomorrow, it'll hold up.

I'm fresh out of 2009 so I fired up what I had on hand, a 2005 D'Issan. Drank it with...cold roast chicken. Tight cork, inky stain (both good signs.) Deep purple. Strong nose of fruit (plums come to mind if you must know.) Face melting tannins, as they say (in a good way.) Ripe fruit, deep and dark. Herbs, humidor. Long finish, stained teeth. Impressions: I knew I should've waited. Oh well. "The future's uncertain and the end is always near." A lovely wine.

What else should Mr. Asimov tackle? Champagne. Burgundy. Rhone. Tuscany. Spain. Napa. Sonoma. Paso Robles. Santa Barbara. McLaren Vale. Washington.

I look forward to the next lesson.

It is my longitudinal observation as a taker of many many high stakes evaluations, that test makers, question developers, and testing companies have a distinct Napoleonic Complex. They seem to be bent more on showing the student and instructor what they know and rather than what the student should know. It is my observation that in school evaluation, end of course evaluation, and graduation proficiency, teacher praxis, teacher licensure, medical licensure, clinical competency, board certification, graduate comprehensive exams, flight training exams, and even ham radio exams, what is needed for competent practice of the key points and concepts is omitted in lieu of the emphasis of minutia. We need to rethink all evaluation in light of what knowledge reflects practice, proficiency, and excellence. Not who has the biggest trivia knowledge. False rigor does not equal competency or excellence.

I found high school academic work to be rather uninspiring, and my grades represented that lack of interest. For me, the SAT and ACT provided a valuable opportunity to prove some redeeming worth to prospective colleges. I had a good vocabulary, decent math comprehension, and without any tutoring or much rote memorization (which I abhor) I did fairly well. Partly in thanks to that score I got into the university program I wanted and have been successful in my chosen studies and work ever since. I agree with the author in many ways, but still value the second opinion that these tests provide.

The working poor simply do not have 9 hours to devote to a political system that has declared war against them, unless, of course, we are ordering a hamburger or checking out at Walmart or happen to need our house cleaned or our yard mowed.  I know some of these old men.  They actually feel the working poor have no right to vote or that a poor person's vote doesn't mean as much or perhaps shouldn't even be counted like their vote. After all, they are successful Americans and job creators, while these people have failed at every single level of our educational, political and economic power structure.  Of course, we all know that the system is rigged, but it really doesn't seem to affect us, so we just let it go. In my opinion, we've let our country go.  From this point on, if we don't run these old fools out of office, then we deserve everything we get.
