I am always amused how the NYTimes editors never bother to read their own paper. First Michael Winerip wrote several articles on why VAM was an unfair indicator for judging good teaching. That same day the editors wrote why using test scores should be kept in place. He also wrote how PAR was a better system-a system that didn't rely on test scores yet helped teachers improve or leave the system. The editors ignored that piece and praised the use of test scores for teacher evals. He also wrote how Tennessee's evaluations were seriously flawed, yet the editors wrote a commentary claiming Tennessee should not halt the evaluation system despite its flaws. (Soon after, Winerip was removed from reporting on Education.)

Yesterday the Times had an article about a special program that helps disadvantage students get better grades through both tutoring and counseling. Yet, this paper ignores the many factors that go into a test score. Under Bloomberg, good schools received B report cards. VAM was unable to measure improvement because these schools were already successful.
The editors are so intent on continuing a path that not only hinders students, but public education as well.
Thankfully deBlasio has seen how schools that were improving and had the support of the community were closed under the Bloomberg regime due to an unfair reporting system.

It's time to stop teaching to the test and instead start teaching to the child.

Design changes?  The article you are trying to write is about how the FAA makes design changes either incredibly expensive or almost impossible.  The FAA has virtually destroyed light aviation, and seriously stymied commercial aviation.  ADS-B isn't here yet and it's already completely out of date.  We need to re-examine, or eliminate, the FAA's role in the design and certification of aircraft.  Many small airplanes have more sophisticated information available than some commercial jets do, and the FAA has a policy of not providing ADS-B information to planes that don't have certified and ridiculously expensive (ADS-B out) equipment - traffic and weather information that costs literally nothing to broadcast and will save lives.  We could all own self-piloting planes with current and relatively cheap and available technology if the FAA got out of the way.  They have devastated a once great American industry and pilots are going extinct.

It continues to astound me that anyone objects to providing healthcare to everyone, or wages that allow people to afford a home and provide for the education of their children.

As we struggle to continue unemployment, food stamps and medicaid, for those who cannot find work or are unable to work, those who object to providing for these basic human needs are becoming louder.
I'm also grateful for that--I want to know and understand who these people are--we have all the usual suspects, like Karl Rove who wrote an opinion in the WSJ on Feb 12, 2014.
And we have the people who support him and his ideas as expressed in the comment section of his article. It's in those comments that I learned of the rage, racism, and absolute dehumanization of not only our President, but of anyone who supports him and the idea that everyone deserves healthcare, food, shelter and a good education.
While we've all seen that the election of an African American President has brought out the best and the worst, reading the inhumane comments in response to Karl Rove's objections to President Obama helps me to understand that
the voices of those who are humane are considered the dangerous.
Why is dignity for all dangerous to these individuals?

I lived in the Bay Area for twelve years, arriving in 1976, the end of a long drought. Reservoirs were yielding up their treasures of washing machines, tires, assorted car parts, and gasping fish. By instituting tough conservation measures that restricted lawn-watering etc., we got through, and 1977 saw the return of rain. But memory seems only so long, and a system that catches virtually every drop of rain and snow for transport to remote users, can only have so much capacity. So here we go again. And the Republicans who used to say that cheap energy was limitless, now claim
the same about water. Stupid, Mr. Egan? You betch ya.

I can't believe this is a serious discussion. I don't feel like I am part of this country sometimes, and this is an example.

I'm a teacher. How can I teach my students when our adults behave this way and it is *legally* sanctioned? I hear my teacher voice in my head saying:, "No Johnny, you don't murder someone because they shout at you or toss popcorn at you after you've kicked his chair."

At school we constantly educate our students not to ever fight, to always solve problems with words, to walk away from conflicts, to go to an authority figure if the problem persists.

How can we argue straightfaced to our youngsters that mommy and daddy may legally shoot and kill someone because they were rude to them, but no, little Susie may not throw a spitball at Johnny because he stuck his tongue out at her?

I fear for our nation. And by the way, I am actively discouraging my students from going to school in Florida, sharing stories like this. Florida thrives on its tourism. If their sanity and morality won't prevail, surely their pocketbooks will? Tragic and despicable.

As an Army Afghan War vet it is tough to acknowledge the future that one now sees unfolding in Afghanistan.  General McChrystal said that he thought Afghanistan would fall into civil war once we leave.  Karzai is getting ready for that civil war.  He is preparing the Pashtuns to win it.  The coalition (Napoleon said that if you could choose whom to fight, then fight a coalition) thinks the war is about eradicating al Qaeda and reducing the Taliban.  Karzai has another idea.  It is likely that he is going to offer the Taliban a prominent place in the new Pashtun hegemony over the region.  This shows the degree to which the US has lost control, to how it has been pushed aside.  Instead of the Taliban being crushed they are about to gain legitimacy and become part of a Pashtun victory over the "vile foreigners" along with the Tajiks and Hazara, and Karzai will become a Pashtun hero.  The bitter irony is that this will all be made possible with US supplied weapons, and US taxpayer support.  Pashtunistan will suddenly appear on the maps, and once the intense shooting starts the remnants of the coalition will skedaddle.

Oxycontin/Codeine overdoses may be more in middle-class neighborhoods because pharmacies in poorer-income areas often don't have enough of the painkillers to fill legit prescriptions. Attempts to control prescription-writing in the middle-class areas are resisted by those who suffer from chronic nonfatal pain and fear losing access to the painkillers. The drug peddlers fan the fears.

Of the five New York city neighborhoods with the highest rates of narcotic prescriptions, four are in Staten Island. Drug rings with longshoremen, doctors and pharmacists have been busted in the borough. One Luchese gang member was busted for selling Oxycodone from an ice-cream truck. They stole a surgeon's writing pad and faked prescriptions. Prescriptions for Oxycontin and Percocet almost doubled in the borough from 2007 to 2010; blue-collar work hasn't grown any more dangerous in these years. A patient now can shop around and collect prescriptions from multiple doctors because they can't see a patient's prior history. Foreign online pharmacies continue to sell drugs to people here willy-nilly. This violates federal law but then enforcing the law requires political will.

The 2nd Amendment was inspired by Thomas Jefferson. He was in France when the Constitution was being drafted. He refused to support it unless the Bill of Rights was added. He was the ultimate pacifist. He hated the ideas of a standing army or ocean-going navy. He believed the people should be armed to fight foreign invasion, that state militias could suffice rather than a national army. Those living on the frontier also had to protect themselves against incursions by native Americans. We now have a standing army. And Indians no longer threaten the frontier. Do people who constantly scream about their "2nd Amendment Rights" live in the 18th Century?

Thank you for printing this article. It is a great portrait of an impressive young woman who shows maturity and resilience beyond her years. This will serve her well in living her life and managing her MS.

I was diagnosed with MS in 1999 (I was 24) , but, in fact, have had it since 1989. People tend to advise you to be careful, to take your MS into consideration and modify your decisions based on having MS. However, a young person with MS usually wants to live his/her life to the fullest and pursue their dreams and ambitions, just like someone without MS. Maybe Kayla's running will have a negative impact on her disease progression, and maybe not. The important thing is that she is not letting MS define her. Go Kayla!

Putin will make another grab, with or without observers, if he can. His tactics are that of spy. His troops go in after dark not in the open. Contrary to what your readers understand about our capabilities they are not nil. Our will is not with the game. We don't have to go nuclear, nor do we need to fight Putin in the open: he would lose against NATO air power. He can't afford it politically. We need to find the will to fight a low-intensity irregular war. It doesn't cost much: organize the Ukrainians; get their neighbors in the act; send in raids into Russia to get at the bases causing trouble; keep tightening the "Anaconda" plan with economic sanctions; find funding for alternative pipelines to Europe to compete with Russia; encourage backdoor arrangements with business leaders in Russia to shift to the west --- but don't let them manipulate or become a black market for Putin's interests; bring Ukraine into NATO and the EU; and, organize a defense league of eastern European countries to fight future Russian aggression. Eventually, this will drive Putin and his ilk from power. Then, invite the Russians to join Europe, as Obama, Merkel, and others have tried to do.

This new overtime rule will be difficult to manage as it affects the non-profit world to the same degree as the profit world and there comes the rub. From independent schools to think tanks the hours of most administrators far exceed the forty without receiving extra hourly compensation; but to change the rules for the middle rung would cause alarm for all budgets and create massive layoffs, not hiring. Most operate in deficit land and rely on fund raising for sustainability. As a result of greater compensation due to mid-level administration more work would instead be outsourced to independent contractors and small businesses unaffected by overtime rules.

There is no doubt the salary numbers should be pushed up regarding white collar overtime exemption; however this seems politically motivated not economically sound in a stagnating economy. The real issue is the wide disparity between top level executive compensation and the second and third tier

Can we have a rational conversation about immigration? I don't think it is possible. If someone suggests that immigration laws and limits are appropriate for every country including the US they are called a racist. If someone suggests that we should allow an open door some one screams "stop hem as they come over the boarder".

Unless and until we do away with borders, countries have a right to regulate whom comes in and who doesn't. No one from another country has a right to immigrate to another one. I have no right to simply move to Canada and stay there and then argue that I have stayed here illegally for 10 years ergo you should let me stay forever and make me a citizen. Should countries be compassionate and fair in their immigration policies of course. Should they establish immigration policies that aren't in the best interest of their own citizens, I don't think so.

My point is that we must have a rational discussion about immigration. Calling people racists who simply have concerns doesn't create an atmosphere for rational discussion or telling people that they'd better beware because the demographics are changing which sounds more like a threat to some. Scare tactics don't breed rational discussion.

The difference now is that both sides have nuclear weapons, so that it is unlikely that the western world will recover from the coming war they way they did from the first one.

The assumption here seems to be there's no risk in the stock market. Or is it just myopia? People lose millions all the time. The 1% is not a static population. The real question is what is adequate compensation for risking capital? Without the investment of savings (which everyone works hard to create) the economy grinds to a halt. A low capital gains rate encourages investment. Thinking people on both sides of the isle recognize this.

And at some point the government will have to give up control of interest rates and they will rise to historically normal levels (and the elderly, disabled and everyone else on fixed income will rejoice when they do). Hopefully sooner than later. And at that point we'll really need all the encouragement and incentives for investors that we can generate.

Most people in this world are focused
on the things directly in front of them, finding the resources to house, clothe and feed their families, find jobs and in general just survive. The world seems crazy enough without confronting an immediate disaster In China I asked a few people what was the greatest status symbol possible. they all said to own aSUV. Imagine 300 million extra SUV's on Chinese roads even if only a percentage gained their goal. And yet it is what people want and work for.
If you want to change attitudes about climate change, deeply held attitudes about ownership, status and consumption must change first. We admire the rich for their consumption and priviledge, but when these same well off people tell us to not desire consumption we suspect ulterior motives. And the poor just want to get out of the hole that holds them. Global climate as large as it is, gets lost within these personal needs. What to do? Governments must come together to see the problem, educate the public and institute changes that will affect us all and I mean all. Governments are the only entities large enough to effect such drastic changes and law makers must rise above partisan issues or it is certain that we will rep the whirlwind.

This is more of a political problem than an economic one; until you limit the influence of narrow interests and the ultra-rich in politics and policy, you'll never be able to change the rules to benefit the broader majority.

I'm uncertain at best about the role of unions in today's workforce.

But Detroit's demise was at least as much a result of a smug, arrogant and insular (incestuous?) automobile industry as it was union intransigence. After all, unions did not create a hierarchical and siloed automobile Big 3.

Unions did not design the misbegotten iron aluminum Chevy Vega engine, the exploding Ford Pinto, the rusting Ford Granada and its twin, the rusting Mercury Monarch. Unions did not design the Oldsmobile diesel.

Unions did not design hideous contraptions like the Pontiac Aztek and, well, just about nearly everything the American autombile industry cranked out between 1975 and 1995. Unions did not specify crushed velour button-tufted interiors, padded vinyl roofs and acres of fake wood, eliciting gales of derisive laughter and customers staying away in droves.

Unions did not ignore Ed Deming for over 30 years.

All this dreck, dysfunction and debacle was management and they have reaped the whirlwind, to the regret of Detroit and the UAW.

In my personal experience, most millennial/younger lower middle class folk that I know, and this includes me, are avoiding the big chains in favor for more local or ethical businesses. It's commonly talked about criteria for the purchases we make. Partly because many of us have been wage warriors once or the economy's forced us into side businesses. We once wanted better pay, or any pay, so we're more considerate about where our money goes.

All anecdotal, but:
Farmer's markets and gardens are more popular and grocery stores are becoming becoming secondary. Most of us do this for the experience and unprocessed foods.
Buying used furniture and clothing gives us a chance at better quality for reasonable fees than the crap most Big Box stores peddle. It's sad that well-worn Gap, Limited, Ann Taylor, etc. clothes I find at Salvation Army are better constructed and designed than they are now. Double for furniture.
If it's new, we'd like it to be artisan. We're the snowflake generation, and we tend to be more discriminating about what we buy. A variety of colors doesn't cut it anymore!
We're more interested in hobbies and DIY. It isn't always cheap, but it fills the time with more meaning than corporate entertainment.

Maybe we're adjusting to having less money. Or maybe we're rejecting the Big Box definition of quality. I like to think we're learning to value our community more than our possessions.

Blow reserves his own value judgment on Millenials for his last paragraph by called them the generation of the self.  As though by finding much of the Democratic and Republican parties interchangeable Millenials are betraying the larger society.  But as an Xer, I beg to differ.  The Pew poll is, firstly, a fascinating reflection of how the last distorted decade has played out and impressed upon young American minds.  They may be digital natives saddled with unprecedented student debt and coddling parents, but they are also 9/11 babies who have very different ideas of such precious US items as 'security' and 'privacy.'  And, more dependent on the Internet, they know there is no clear source of truth and no straight path to get there.  They didn't grow up with the editorial team of the NYT organizing their world for them every morning, the way earlier generations did.  When my generation was younger, we were regularly lambasted for being "slackers," detached, and most importantly, not easy enough for marketers to figure out.  We werent consumer obedient the way Boomers were and wanted us to be.  I'm energized, in fact, to learn that Millenials are skeptical of institutions.  There is hope for a generation that wants to forge new paths and create new networks, and rather than being a betrayal of society as Blow wants to suggest, embodies the kind of American impulse that makes the country better.

Good for Australia, and good for Norrie!

Human sexuality is a spectrum. Although it appears to be a double humped curve (most people do indeed identify as male or female), there are absolutely people who are genderqueer and genderfluid. It's not so much that there is a third gender, as there is a broad spectrum of non-binary sexualities that are not male or female. I know someone who is asexual neutrois (neither male nor female). I know someone who is genderfluid- sometimes ze feels male, sometimes female, sometimes something that is neither. I know transgender people. No one faults the rich or the elites for making a gazillion dollars a year. We live in a capitalistic society where certain professions naturally make more than others. No one berates the wealthy because they live in their McCastles with more rooms than Queen Elizabeth could want or need or drive their exotic cars.

No what irks the average person are the perks and benefits these people derive at the expense of everyone else. With their tax shelters, low capital gains tax, carried interest rule and/or low inheritance taxes these people are hoarding their money and not recycling it back into society.

When people can’t find work or can barely cope with their monthly bills, then all that money taken out of the system becomes detrimental. With global competition pushing down wages and a sluggish economy, people sitting on billions could rejuvenate sectors of the economy.

You might say these super rich don’t have to give back because they earned it. Back in the early 20th century after the Morgan’s, Rockefeller's and Carnegie's earned their millions, they suddenly decided they couldn’t take it with them so it became a competition of who could donate the most before their death.

We can only hope today's millionaire/billionaires take notice and contribute back to society. It's the right thing to do...

An examination of your assumptions is required. You first assume voting rights were set up in the constitution as we construe it today. In fact, only male, white landowners had the right to vote in 1790, post constitutional convention, and they got to vote directly for the House of Reps., not the Senate and not for President. But our intepretation of that consitutional right has evolved and thus our voting rights have change in practice a little bit since then,correct? On gun control, you assume the 2nd amendment states that all citiizens have the right to whichever firearms they want, at any time , for any reasons. And that the Constitutional Convention made that absolute, with no possible reinterpretation? Not even for weapons they could not have dreamed of in the one-shot and reload the powder musket days?

So I suggest "it would be good for you" to think about which constitutional rights should evolve in our practical application of them over time, and which ones are fixed and thus not open to evolution, if any. Then restate your arguments.

The West is either blissfully ignorant about the real situation in Ukraine or criminally irresponsible.  Western and U.S. officials are not talking to the shadowy figures who have real influence on the events in Ukraine.   Recently, Oleksander Turchinov, chief of the Headquarters of National Resistance, has announced the expansion of self-defense forces to thirty thousands—a veritable little army.  These "self-defense" units will operate throughout Ukraine.  Andriy Parubiy, who is the main person in command of the protests, has been appointed as the commander of this little army.  Parubiy, Turchinov and the people around them are the real power brokers in Ukraine today.  They have the resources to sustain militant protests or to effect peace. Yet their names rarely appear in the reports from Ukraine or diplomatic cables.  The organizers of this protest movement conduct a very savvy public relations campaign under the pro-democracy slogans throughout the world for control of Western public opinion.  Their plan is to destabilize the current government and put their candidates in power, as they did in 2004, when Victor Yushchenko became president.  The results may be in nobody’s favor.  Ukraine may become a veritable power vacuum with various political forces competing for power.  It could turn into a fertile ground that could be used by Islamic radicals for conducting their terrorist operations against Russia—a fact that Russia simply cannot afford to ignore.

It is startling to read the user comments and see how misunderstood this issue truly is. The controversy is whether Congress purposely accessed classified information it was not authorized to view. What that information was - the detention program - is irrelevant, though the level of passion people feel for it confuses the issue.

Some government agencies, like the CIA, work in secret to keep information protected. Getting elected to Congress does not give one open access to any and all secret documents. Elected officials are granted power by public votes, not background checks. A drug addict can become a member of Congress if enough people vote for them but they could not pass a background check if they applied for a classified government job. Though Congress does enjoy more access to information than the public, it is not the same as an agency employee. Even if you think they should be given the same access, should their staffers get it, too? The article doesn't say that the senators went to the CIA facility to review the documents for their report but that their staffers did.

In my opinion, I don't believe any nefarious action was committed by the congressional committee. It is more reasonable to believe that the CIA employees who created the segregated hard drive forgot to block access to the internal document than believe Congress purposely hacked a CIA firewall to gain access to special information.

While I acknowledge that drug diversion is a problem within the medical profession, primarily in the hospital setting, I am not sure that drug testing is the way to put an end to it. Random testing of employees with access to narcotics will only catch culprits after the fact----perhaps well after the fact. So far after the fact that dozens if not hundreds of patients might unwittingly have been exposed to illness or disease, not to mention denied much needed pain medication.

Besides which, I suspect the problem is much bigger than even the authors would care to admit. Isn't it logical to expect that if there are diversion issues in hospitals, there would equally be diversion issues in pharmacies, 'pain management' clinics and even with home-based healthcare? If the problem is as big as I think it is, we would have to drug test everyone.....every day.

Actually, if you should be testing anybody, why not test the patients who are not getting their pain meds? That would be one sure way to find out.

Beyond all considerations of politics is the simple fact that a woman who serves in our armed forces claims she was sexually assaulted by a man imbued by law with enormous authority over her and many others who are similarly situated.  If true, this is the rawest abuse of power imaginable.  Plea agreements are an unavoidable, if often highly distasteful, element of our criminal justice system.  The sheer volume of cases and the limited resources available to deal with them requires that deal-making be permitted.  But should plea deals be available at all where a General is accused of sexually assaulting a subordinate?  Shouldn't we know the truth?  Doesn't the General's accuser deserve her day in court?  The idea that any sort of "deal" can be struck in these circumstances, except perhaps to protect the victim, should not be accepted as a given.  In the military context, one hopes, neither the volume of cases nor considerations of prosecutorial discretion necessitate cutting deals that ensure that the truth will never be known.

When I was a kid in the 1960s, you could sit in the bleachers at Yankee Stadium for 75 cents or in the upper grandstand for $1.35. That's $5.55 and $9.98 in 2013 dollars. In the latter part of the 1960s, you could go to the Fillmore East and see three great rock groups for $3.50 to $5.50. That's $22.22 to $34.91 in 2013 dollars. But it can cost $hundreds for a ticket to a rock show today and far more if you're forced into the resellers market, which you usually are.

I am from Albuquerque and have a mentally ill sibling, so this article hit particularly close to home.  I have witnessed my sibling being cyclically thrown into one of two places: the community hospital for at most two nights (which can cost in the thousands of dollars by the way), or in jail if  a crime had been committed. Truthfully, the only respite my family has been afforded is those long jail stays.  Many imply it the family's failure in taking care of their mentally ill relatives that has lead to the homelessness and violence associated with mental illness.  But, I have learned that as a family member you don't have the medical expertise necessary to heal, or at minimum control, these issues.  Though the healthcare system had ultimate faults in the past, the systematic deconstruction of long term psychiatric care created an undue burden on our families, the general public, and in the case of this article the police.  We need affordable or free long-term care and living services that protects the public and mentally ill individuals; especially from predatory police officers.  There should be no justifiable reason why a man, with a clear history of illness, is living exposed in the foothills of the Sandia Mountains.  Though the final and ultimate blame lies with the unrestrained officers that shot James Boyd in the back when he didn't pose a true threat (I urge you to watch the full video), we as a society needed to support him in his life.

This is a very thoughtful piece!
The invasion of Crimea is a highly provocative move that risks turning the Ukrainian political crisis into a Cold War-like antagonism between Russia and the West. However, this is not totally unexpected from president Putin who does not like being humiliated and put in a situation with no face-saving options in a crisis that he can not possibly ignore. The West should have taken that into account and not allow the new Ukrainian government pass a law stripping Russian language of its official status in the Ukraine.
We should keep in mind that the Ukraine (as well as many other ex soviet states) exist as independent states in their current borders because of the good will of the Russian people, and the Russian people deserves an expression of good will in return. I suspect that most in Russia would support the ouster of Mr. Yanukovich, had the new Ukrainian government offered a gesture of good will in return instead of effectively disenfranchising the Russian population of the country from their political representation and passing openly hostile legislation.
Ukraine should be integrated into the EU, but not in the way that involves installing barbed wire between Ukraine and Russia. This is not acceptable to Russia and it will not work. The responsibility for the current crisis lies largely on the shoulders of Mr. Yanukovich and the EU, who created a situation in which the ties with Russia and EU integration turned into two incompatible options

All of our categories are based in analogies, as Hofstadter and Sander show in their book, Surfaces and Essences. And all analogies have central and peripheral examples. At the periphery, their boundaries tend to be fuzzy. This is the general truth. So for any two adjacent categories, there is likely to be overlap at their fuzzy boundaries. This is not just true for the living and not living, but for, say, women and men. So we could make an argument that because there are intersex individuals, we're all really women, or we're all really men, because there's not really a sharp boundary between the two sexes.

This argument, always available, usually produces nonsense when followed through. Women and men exist as different categories, even with the fuzzy boundary problem. So do day and night, despite that we could say "It's all day, there are just the shadows of planets in it," or "It's all night, with stars floating there." Fine. But understanding the reality of the day and night categories is essential to understanding life on Earth. It does not improve our understanding to eliminate such categories, and a radical program of doing so would make most if not all of our understanding impossible.

Thank you for saying what needed to be said. We can't legislate common sense and, in my experience living in New York City for decades, it's appalling how many pedestrians (especially youngsters) simply ignore traffic laws and do what they please, often walking against red lights and playing "chicken" with oncoming cars.

We need more "defensive walkers" who have their heads up and are paying attention to traffic, but with the proliferation of smart phones, instead we have more distracted pedestrians who assume cars will make way for them as they jaywalk across streets.

Sammy Eckstein didn't "deserve" to die, but there can be little doubt that impulsively running into the street after a ball is the way most children are hit by vehicles. How many times has each of us heard that story throughout our lives? If Sammy had his head up and was paying attention it's entirely possible that there would have been a different outcome.

Despite the grief Sammy's family is suffering, impulsive, knee-jerk legislation primarily driven by emotion is almost always a mistake. Let's please let calmer heads prevail and dare to step back and look at ALL the factors for Sammy's death, especially when there is no credible allegation that the driver was speeding or guilty of violating any traffic laws. Why do we always look to government and more and more legislation to avoid taking full responsibility for our own actions?

The reason why this new venture could be so revolutionary is because it could change our expectations about how the news should be prioritized. New information, as Klein explains in his post at the Verge, is "not always — and perhaps not even usually — the most important information for understanding a topic." Yet we have been conditioned to value newness as readers and assume that it is somehow intrinsically more important than anything else. This judgment has lead to a crisis of comprehension among the public. As we are bombarded with every new development about every issue, no one explains why this new information even matters.

Reporting about the Affordable Care Act has been plagued by this type of reporting. Every new detail about how the ACA is failing or succeeding is dutifully noted, but more important information such as explaining what risk corridors are or what an 834 is are avoided because it's stale and complex. Instead, reporters just keep publishing more and more as they explain less and less.

Or put more simply and elegantly: "Today, we are better than ever at telling people what's happening, but not nearly good enough at giving them the crucial contextual information necessary to understand what's happened."

The results is people are left with large gaps of knowledge about complex issues and misconceptions that are easily exploited.

The major premise to your argument is that the highest social priority is to prevent the consequences of "dangerous behaviors" at whatever cost is required; and because you're a liberal, what first comes to mind as the means to be used is collective will through the medium of government. Well, if you could make your argument to every American, and I could make a counter-argument that the highest priority is to support individuals in freely making decisions and bearing the consequences, I'd bet a nickel that I'd beat you all hollow. Needless to say, I'm not a liberal.

But I wouldn't stop in my argument with that. I'd continue to argue that it's one of the primary responsibilities of a free press to broadly evangelize why behaviors might be wholesome or "dangerous", and I'd argue that your feet should be held to the fire, in return for subscription fees and other means of payment that afford good compensations to those employed as journalists -- all this as a perfectly legitimate aid to a free people freely making the best decisions for themselves that they can.

So ... how well are you doing at that?

I work in technology and I am also a creative, so you would think I'd be stoked about this exciting upcoming digital revolution. But I'm not. The downside (and there will be a downside) is that I am old and old is bad no matter what job you're talking about. The upside of that is that no one knows I'm old on the internet because no one can see me, and I can lie about it. But beyond age, there are millions of people who need to work who are not digital innovators. They're just ordinary, decent people who need something to do and support their families. Their jobs have and will continue to go to poor people living in India, China, South America and Mexico. And what's left will go to smart young people here, mostly who are wealthy and got into the best schools and whose parents have the right connections. The only upside I can foresee are the trades. Computers can't cut trees, can't repair old cars, can't clean toilets, can't install wiring in an old home, can't blacktop a driveway. So people in the trades need to get smart and start charging their wealthy clients big, big money for their services. That's the only economic equity that is going to happen.

Dear Employers:

Treat your employees fairly. After 6 mos of unemployment, my wife, a former supervisor, was awarded a housekeeping position at a global hotel chain at a rate of $5/hr less than her prior position ... because there are so many jobseekers in our local market and so few positions, $10/hr is what the going housekeeper rate at the non-union hotels has shrunk to, thanks to the vaunted Invisible Hand of the Free Marketplace. But wait; there's more: After she finishes her 3 month "training period," she will be compensated at the rate of $5/room. These are not your typical motel rooms, either. This is an extended stay hotel with multiple bedrooms and kitchens - and, since she has the least seniority of the housekeepers, she has been assigned the wing where guests with pets are allowed to stay, where guests leave their pets in their rooms while they go out to the casinos, and where numerous pet-type accidents inevitably happen. But here's the real kicker: Since they are compensated at $5/room and not at an hourly rate, they get no paid vacation. Many of her co-workers work 7 days a week at this rate in an attempt to make ends meet, so it is disgraceful that they aren't even allowed a little compensated time off.

Your suggestions and caveats to what are obviously white-collar employers are cute, Mr Brooks, but maybe you should offer some suggestions to those employers who basically trade in slavery in the United States of the 21st Century.
If you wanted to be "liberated", join them. Leave your job and start working as a contractor or whatever. The chains you see are in your mind.

Try studying other cities such as Portland, OR that seem to have found a way to train generations how to walk and drive in their city. I have never seen such mutual respect as in that city for bikers, pedestrians and drivers.

Granted, NY is much much larger and "faster" but speed does not have to be the overriding factor, even if the pace of living is that much faster. Every time I am in a cab in NY I feel that I have taken a major life risk because they drive like maniacs in order to get me somewhere fast so that they can then pick up the next fare. Maybe there is some way of dis-incenting speed in the way they get paid.

I also wonder how the bike program is doing. I'm all for biking but would be terrified if I or one of my grown "children" who live in the city would choose to ride a bike there.

All this said, my best recommendation is - and always was - (and I hear the cries now!) - do not allow regular sized cars in the city. Smart cars only, with the exception of taxis, meet up lots at various points on the outskirts where commuters can park and then take public transportation or a smart car/zip car, or in revers, where one can pick up a larger car, if needed to get out of the city.

Here is one possible solution to level the playing field.  All political campaigns should be publicly funded. Give all candidates an equal but small war chest for political television ads. The candidates must take personal responsibility for the content of their ads. No more obfuscation about where the ad came from or who has responsibility for its content.  Outlaw "SuperPACs" and all third party political advertisements.  Give candidates the right to hold unlimited publicly funded television debates so they can speak directly to the American people and let us know what they stand for. See? That was easy!

As a white female from an upper middle class background, I'm glad that those ignorable, but not-so-ignorable comments I experience finally have a name. Jabs like, "you're really cool for a white chick", or, "you went to NYU? That's really expensive, how did you pay for that?"
or from a man at the deli, "well you must be working somewhere, unless your parents are filthy rich," or from friends in high school, "honestly, Alison, we know you live a sheltered life", really bubble up inside you. They are easily passed off, only to be ruminated about later. They make you feel like you have something to prove, or hide, in order for you to be accepted. In the same way that the assumption that a black student got into Harvard because of his race is wrong, the assumptions that my parents are Republicans, my family is "filthy rich" or that I am "sheltered" are all wrong.

Microagression is an especially appropriate term for these false assumptions because of the prefix, "micro", which means "small". These comments are belittling. They make you smaller than what you are, reducing you to the limits of a stereotype. That being said, I think its important that we don't put a limit on the term "microagression" itself. Ignorant comments can come from anywhere, not just from whites, and can be directed at anyone.

We heard a loud explosion at 9:30 am, which shook our condo building on East 93rd Street, some 23 blocks away, not knowing what it was we just assumed that it had to do with the never-ending Second Avenue subway construction below until saw the tragic news reports...

We could only find a 2009 Château Labat Haut Médoc, Les Ramures. On our first sniff: smell of blackberry & chocolate, pleasant. On first sip the wine felt a little rough on the tongue & our mouth became dry- the wine smells better than it tastes! When swallowed the wine feels sharp & we get a burning sensation as it goes down our throat. With food, the first impression does not disappear, the wine remains rough on the tongue, still not smooth & leaves an after taste that is not succulent. Our lips felt almost numb... We assume then that "our" wine's tannin is powerful and stays in your mouth longer than in others. ...Still, we had a fun evening learning about tannin,  texture, savory, the Bordeaux region, the soil, the grapes and just enjoying eating, drinking, friendship. Thank you Mr.Asimov.

FYI, I have a STEM degree with a minor in finance, and I worked in the insurance field. Oh, and my household pays much more in federal and state income taxes than most, including the AMT and the new taxes imposed by the ACA, as well as taxes on any IRA contributions, so I am well aware that money doesn't grow on trees, and that we help to pay for others, whether their behavior is responsible or not, each day. My observation, by the way, has been that those paying the least often complain loudest, as they have less to spare and because they are usually unaware of how much of a subsidy they are getting. An example of this would be someone paying $150 per month for full coverage under the ACA who is nevertheless upset that someone else is getting 'free' coverage. I'm not as blithely unaware as you seem to think. I'd like to see some changes, too, starting with more appropriate (higher) liability insurance thresholds for drivers.

The most expensive (and, certainly in the minds of those lacking compassion, totally avoidable) subsidy provided to those with young children is the payment of medical expenses for artificially conceived premature babies, which can run to more than a million dollars apiece.

I am so saddened and angered by the comments from those saying people should just kill themselves if they want to, and who are we to stop them... that they'll just go elsewhere if one avenue is closed off. Clearly you are unfamiliar--or willfully ignoring--the latest research in this area, which suggests quite the opposite. And clearly you have never suffered the suicide of someone close to you and the lifelong heartbreak that comes with it. My brother committed suicide by jumping (not off the Golden Gate Bridge) three years ago. It's horrifying to me how cavalierly many view suicide, how it's considered unpreventable and these people beyond help. This serves only to further stigmatize suicide, inhibit research in this area, and make life far more difficult for those considering suicide, and for the survivors left behind.

Many brilliant, kind, creative people who are dearly loved are lost to suicide each year. Not every suicide is preventable, but some clearly are. It could be your mother, your brother, your daughter, your friend. Until it happens to you, it's easy to dismiss these lives as not worth trying to save.

The really pernicious aspect of the conservative argument, in the 1840s and now, is that there is a CULTURE of poverty. There isn't. Through my work, and through friendships, I"ve known quite a lot of poor people pretty well, and some are in fact very used to getting by on whatever they can get for free, whether honestly or dishonestly. But invariably they have some neighbors, parents, children, siblings or in-laws who are hardworking, ambitious, optimistic and even inspiring.When you talk about a culture of dependency, you are dismissing whole groups of people, and those groups include a lot of individuals who are the opposite of dependent.

I was happy to find the Bernadotte at our local large-volume wine store.  Cutting to the chase, I prepared an all-roasted meal of lamb tenderloins, red creamer potatoes and broccoli.  I opened the room-temperature wine about an hour before dinner.  At first sniff it seemed soft and pleasant.  First sip registered as more astringent than fruity.  Through the meal the wine seemed to grow in the direction of slightly stony or sour.  I would have preferred something a bit more velvety and soft.

I can't deny the potentially far-reaching unifying power of sports, which is one reason I love both Facebook and the Olympics. But there are dark corners of human nature that are, just like with social media, exposed and enhanced by commercialized sport as well. Especially with men, sport is an arena where unanswered and evolving human cultural questions, for example those about gender roles, race, and aggression, are played out. While that adds to the drama and entertainment value, these dramas are too embellished, edited, hyped, and artificially packaged.

Though I do enjoy sports a lot, and I know it will always be an important and necessary part of our culture, I also wonder sometimes whether we can in future centuries evolve as a species to the point where we can also sometimes find your well-phrased "stoop-to-stoop, store-front-to-storefront soundtrack of our cities", on our own without all the diversion and artificial packaging, i.e. better connections, communal values, civic engagement and dialogue between people. I want to get to the point where social media and sports augment the best of our nature, rather than dominate conversations and sometimes distract from true connections.

This handicapping of the 2016 Republican Presidential candidate nomination process reminds me a lot of some kids I knew in high school. My school had a very good basketball team for few years in the early 1980s. We had three or four guys who could really dominate. For a couple of years we were nearly undefeated. We were a mid-sized high school and won our regional championship a few times. A common lunchtime topic of conversation was which of out local stars would be drafted highest by the NBA when the time came. We all had our favorites and could list any number of reasons the guy we favored would be perfect for the first round.

But then we went on the the state tournament and quickly lost in the opening round three times in a row. Suddenly, every other team out there had guys as good as--and even much better---than ours. Out guys were big fish in a small pond.

Same is true for all of these GOP luminaries. The Republican Party has very little chance of winning the presidency in the foreseeable future. Their base is aging and dying. The Democrats are not very popular with a lot of young people right now, but the Republicans are even less so. Until the GOP can divorce itself from its retrograde stances on important social issues--immigration reform, same-sex marriage, access to safe and legal birth control---it will be a regional party representing the rural voters and the Old South.

None of our players ever made it to the NBA.

i'd like to see the helicopter with a 3000 mile range, plus loitering time. lot of aviation gas to haul there. unlike santa's sleigh and reindeer, long range search aircraft and naval vessels are not relativistic. they are going to take some time to get to the site of the spotted wreckage. 1500 miles, 35 miles an hour, do the math. and any plane that finds this stuff is going to be flying over it at 200mph plus. if this stuff is from the plane and the plane is in pieces in deep deep water, well, think of what they were able to bring up from the titanic, not much stuff at a time. unless they get there before the black boxes shut down, we may never know what happened.

Whether we are newspaper writers or posters with opinions on the writers' articles, we are handed pre-authorship word-limits. I say this while watching the byte-counter up in the corner of this post count down how many I have left to make my point.

As I have just 1235 left, I'll get to it. It's this: I find many, and perhaps most, of NYT posters to be thoughtful and erudite while trying, successfully most of the time, to be respectful and not divisive.

What a joy it is to realize that such people still exist. Perhaps the Comments sections of the NYT is the grandchild of our 60's debates on current events or the even earlier par lour-room discussions of intelligentsia.

Mr. Blow: Please write a book on this topic. You already have the title, which I assume refers to the ground-breaking 1963 book The Feminine Mystique". Some readers may not be familiar with Betty Friedan's early manifesto for women to embrace careers and personal development; it shook up gender assumptions and role determinism.

One of the many benefits of the last 50 years has been the easing of social strictures on both women and men: each more free to become a full person without discrimination, without unequal barriers in the workplace. Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, a qualified law school graduate, was refused interviews by 40 law firms, and worked without pay in a government office.

Women have made their slow, painful way into a more egalitarian workplace. The slogan, 'a woman's place is in the House' (of Representatives) was a sign of the times.
Other countries have had female heads of state; we have yet to reach that milestone.

Men must take their own journey to become full human beings. The 'masculine mistake' is to find strength in braggadocio and quick temper; signs of weakness rather than a person secure in their masculinity.

No one expects men and women to have identical personality traits and personalities.
Each gender has a wide spectrum of temperament and physical strength; women can be strong athletes, leaders; men can be gentle, followers.

Rigid gender roles rob a society of talent and the individual of their selfhood. We all lose.

At my spouse's 50th B-Day Party in 2009 about a dozen of our friends who graduated with us from college in 1979 and 1980 gathered to celebrate. Of the 13 friends 4 are retiring in 2014, as a direct result of the ACA.  All of the 13, including my spouse have been fortunate in our careers.  Now all in our mid fifties, most of us are looking for the next chapter in our lives and the healthcare issue was the only obstacle to leaving our respective employers.  The ACA turns out to be a huge positive game changer for the age 50 plus upper middle class and upper class crowd financially well off crowd.

It's not just governments that spy on your apps. Indeed, one of the hidden sources of income for some apps is the data they collect every time you click on them. Surprise! It is sold to the highest bidder! All this is for commercial or "other" uses.
The real issue is that all mobile devices leak from every corner and give away what we thought was private to those who will pay, or those with the right technology. Most secure conscious businesses require you to check your phones, tablets, laptops, watches at the door so their stuff stays secure.
Why are we not screaming at the mobile device makers for their sloppy security? Why are we not shouting at credit card companies for not embedding chips in cards rather than cheap and insecure mag strips?

Once again the peace process seems to reach a stalemate. Comments seem to blame Israeli resistance, but both sides are equally at fault. Neither has the trust or courage to commit to long term peace and make the necessary concessions and sacrifices.

The problem is not local, but international. This difficult but solvable problem will continue to be a focal point for discord, unrest and global extremism until solved.

The problem needs bold and new ideas, execution and resources. The two sides can't bring these. Relying on them, and their self-interest is futile--they lack the trust, courage and leadership to get there.

Though it challenges concepts of sovereignty, it is time for an impartial and enlightened international community--not just the US--to find a solution, commit the resources and make it happen. How?--Don't know. But since the parties can't do it; and failure to do so risks human disaster locally and globally, a different approach and execution must be found. Shame on the international community, if peace is not achieved, a major human incident occurs in the Middle East or elsewhere, and leaders look back and realize their failure to have sought that bold solution.

It was just a reminder that kindness can be contagious.

This editorial misses the point of how Kerry failed.

Russia won't be impressed by sanctions. Sanctions are a form of blackmail and just as everybody else Putin knows that it is not wise to cede to them as it only invites more pressure. The eagerness with which Kerry embraced sanctions while previously doing almost nothing suggests that Kerry likes the Russian annexation and sees it as a nice excuse to restart the Cold War.

The editorial board makes a similar mistake. If you want to prevent a Russian annexation of Eastern Ukraine the first step should be to make sure that Kiev treats its Russian speaking citizens in a fair way and makes some steps towards democracy (the risk of a right extremist dictatorship are real). This regime was brought to power by the US so the US should be assumed to have some influence over it. The implicit suggestion in this editorial is unfortunately that we should encourage Kiev to undertake any anti-Russian activity it wants and that we should restrict ourselves to protecting them from the consequences of their actions.

Charles, I think you've hit on a major issue seldom discussed: women's unwillingness or inability to successfully navigate the salary negotiation.

I don't know if I'm a prime example or not, having recently retired, but I was raised to be--how shall we put it--"accommodating", "compliant," and "demure" in my conduct in business. Over the years, naturally, I toughened considerably but the one area where I found it really tough was salary.

It's hard not to stereotype when depicting men as aggressive, tough, confident, and macho when discussing salary--while many women prefer politesse and compromise. For me, I think the biggie was lack of self confidence--the feeling that no matter how good I knew I was, I still was lacking in something and thus deserved what they offered, not what I was worth.

I admire the way you're raising your kids and I hope your daughter, the fencer and honor student, continues on her confident path. She's living in today's world where women aren't taught to "work until they get married, " always taking a back seat as long as their man treats them like a princess.

I took fencing in college but was never very good. If fencing is a sport of challenge and quick-witted determination, your daughter sounds like she's well on her way to developing the tools she'll need in the power plays of salary negotiations.

When the Unites States was threatened in the early 60's with Soviet missiles in Cuba an ultimatum was issued and the Russians withdrew. We asserted our national interest. It is obvious that Russia will not take kindly to a new government which might turn westward and threaten its interests. The United States invokes democracy when democratic outcomes are in its favor and denounces democracy (as with Hamas) when it does not. The hypocrisy leaves one numb.

The solution to the Ukrainian crisis is for the new government to guarantee that Russia's national interests will be respected and perhaps accord it special autonomous status.

During Secreatary Rumsfeld's tenure I was a staff officer assigned to the Pentagon. I recieved a dreaded snowflake that contained only two words with a week's suspense and nothing else. I won't mention the two words because they still might be classified. For illustrative purposes, imagine "car--bridge." My boss told me that was the only thing "on my plate." As the days grew closer to the suspense date I felt ike I was breaking out in hives and wished I was back in Iraq on my worst day. I noticed that there had been something stapled to it because of the 2  tell tale paper punctures in the top right hand side of the snowfake. With the remaining 3 days I backtracked the route the document had taken and disccovered an idiot (a fellow officer who is now a general) had removed an article from a Time Magazine article that the Secretary had read that piqued his interest and generated an idea. The officer's explanation to me was because he wanted it for his files--he could have made a copy, right? Like I said, he's now a general. Anyways Secreatary Rumsfeld's thought process between the article he read and the idea he proposed in two words was genius. I have to admit after so many years that the anxiety and stress of figuring the puzzle out was worth it to get a glimpse at the mind of a visionary.

Hold on Professor, signing up people isn’t the same as delivering cost effective beneficial health care to all Americans. Obamacare will always remain a half-hearted attempt to reform our for-profit insurance system, NOT reforming our health care delivery system.
I’ve had the unfortunate experience of actually needing health care services. I have excellent insurance, with Medicare primary and another highly thought of HMO as my secondary insurance. At no time was I able to find out a procedure’s cost up front. I enter our system knowing medical professionals and facilities are paid for doing very expensive things. Medicare is great, but I am nickel and dimed with niggling bills for medical charges not paid by either Medicare or my secondary insurance. When I ask to pay a co-pay up front, I am told I don’t need to pay a co-pay. I learned yesterday from my HMO the reason many medical providers don’t take my co-pay offer is that the refund processing cost is more than the co-pay. So they prefer to bill it months after they’ve delivered the services.
I lived for a year in London and was covered by the National Health System. The NHS works very well with highly competent professionals and timely treatment. It took me 20 minutes to sign-up and I never waited anything time to see a doctor, if fact, I wait longer times in America to arrange an appointment.
I would much, much prefer receiving care in the NHS rather than our bloated, profit driven health INSURANCE system.

How about childcare vouchers instead?  The working families I know do not move because they live close to family, especially grandparents, that provide free and low-cost childcare.  Increased childcare costs for two children can outpace the extra earnings a family may gain by moving.  Also, family-based childcare, especially by grandparents, allows working families to have an essential back-up should a child be sick and cannot go to daycare or school.  Many working mothers and fathers do not have flexible hours or sick leave that allow them to take time off of work to stay with a sick child, and relative can be a lifeline for these parents.  Indeed, in these days of non-union part-time and temporary jobs in right-to-work states, many employers would rather fire employees who take time off for childcare issues rather than accommodate these employees.  I have several married adult siblings in this situation - people that work hard at these types of non-union part-time and temporary jobs, living paycheck to paycheck.  They would never think to move away and leave behind the grandparents because they cannot afford to leave behind the childcare help.  This is a far cry from when our parents were young and both worked teaching jobs that allowed them to move cross-country, where they could count on paid sick leave and union job protections.

I'm always curious why no one has written about the costs of graduate school. The author of this article mentioned that federal subsidized loans for undergraduates have an interest rate of 3.86 percent. Federal subsidized loans for graduate students have an interest rate of 6.8 percent. There are no Pell Grants or other government grants for graduate school at all, and most universities don't give nearly as much aid to graduate students as they do to undergraduates. This makes getting a master's degree or other post-graduate degree risky for students from anywhere other than the top of the income scale.

Medicine has always been a changing profession. My mother's parents were both country doctors in rural Minnesota - beginning their practice during the Depression. Cash-poor farmers often paid in produce or fresh meat, if they could pay at all. I remember my grandmother, in her 70's, being visited by middle-aged people who had just found out that they "weren't paid for" and came to pay their own delivery costs. My grandparents were on call 24/7 and made house calls. Babies were delivered at home, and my grandparents often had to drive out to the houses in blizzards. The snowplow driver, whose many children were delivered by my grandma, would offer his services at these times, plowing a road to the farmhouse . My grandfather died fairly young, but my grandmother fussed about the changes as the years went by. Her biggest pet peeve was the mounting quantity of paperwork she had to fill out. She was among the last generation of the "family doctors", delivering and caring for several generations of the same family. She was even asked to be at their deathbeds, for which she charged nothing - considering it a position of honor. You won't find such physicians these days.

One of the major contributors to the current situation is excessive government debt. The editorial gets it right when it points out the problems of "unfettered lending," the other half of excessive government borrowing.

That is what makes stimulus a two edged sword. Stimulus must be paid for, and the easiest way for our politicians to cover the cost is through government borrowing. And when the bills come due, as they inevitably do, there are far fewer resources available for future spending. Government is spending its money covering the costs - interest and principle - for yesterday's stimulus, and has fewer resources available for the necessary expenditures of today and tomorrow.

Fiscal and economic conservatives are very much aware of this, and it very much influences Republican policy. Liberals tend to brush the issue under the rug, as they borrow more to spend more, worrying too little about the future when the piper will have to be paid.

There are no easy answers of course. But this editorial addresses only one half of a very complicated economic issue. Both halves must be addressed if we are to move forward. The editorial blames Republican fiscal restraint without considering the very real problems that accompany enormous and excessive government debt.

Easy as it is to borrow and spend, we can't keep doing so, oblivious to the future costs. Frankly, the debt of years past is part of why we are where we are today.

If your read the studies cited by Dr. Krugman, they paint a different picture than the one sketched by the selective statistics cited in this column. According to the Rand study, which Dr. Krugman cites, during the period studied, 1.4 million uninsured gained insurance through the ACA exchanges (a far cry from the 9.3 million number being touted here). At the same time, 5.2 million people lost their insurance. The overwhelming majority of uninsured who gained insurance during the period (7.2 million) gained it from employers.

The Gallup study helps to elucidate what is happening here. According to Gallup, in late 2008 during the end of the Bush Administration 14.8 percent of Americans were uninsured. Now the figure is 15.6 percent, but it appears to be getting better. Americans were better insured under Bush than at any time under Obama. In other words, the overwhelming majority of the gains that Dr. Krugman claims for Obamacare are really a function of our slow and painful emergence for recession. As more people become employed, more have insurance.

The real gain in insured from Obamacare, according to Gallup, is 2.1 million (9.3 million minus 7.2 million). Obamacare has disrupted the American medical system and many people's lives in order to insure less then one percent of the American population. You may believe that this is a good benefit/loss proposition, but this is the true case that must be made.

This "water is precious" article hit home for me. My parents (from Oklahoma dust bowl) migrated to Fresno just before WW2. I lived on Fresno farms until I was 11 whereupon my family moved to artificially "green" Los Angeles. I feel like I can see both sides, so I will offer an opinion.
Change is hard, but it doesn't have to be a zero sum game. Just as energy conservation works / saves money / promotes national security for all (weather or not you believe in climate change), water conservation can work and save money for farmers and city home owners. Most of us are not a Valley farmer raising water intensive rice or a home owner with a putting green lawn, but we can still make small changes. My wife and I recently converted our back lawn to a New Mexico style garden, which we water by hand with recycled water. The back yard is a joy and my water bill is cheaper.

The first flaw is citing Mr. Ryan as a deep thinker. Much is made of the value to Russia of the naval base at Sevastopol. Indeed, the Black Sea Fleet is Russia's only warm-water fleet. But it should be noted that the only way to get the BSF out of the Black Sea is through the NATO/Turkish-controlled Bosporus and Dardanelles. This has emphasized the value to Russia of their naval base at Tartus, Syria which would allow operations to be resupplied, refitted and rearmed once out of the Black Sea. Simply put, however, Tartus is of extremely doubtful value due to the instability in Syria and will likely remain so for decades.

So the Black Sea Fleet, for strategic and out-of-region tactical purposes is only a "bathtub fleet" with doubtful value. The Turks will see to that.

Other military assets in the Crimea could easily be transferred to contiguous Russia to the East and would lose virtually no combat effectiveness. So, in truth, the Crimea has little military value to Russia.

This is a most interesting column because it illustrates the dead end that the modern sciences and ideologies have reached. It presents a bipolar, narrowly categorical viewpoint perhaps best illustrated in the System 1 and System 2 model. Underlying this model is an implicit view that evolution has ended for human beings and that there are basically two ways of ‘knowing’ the Rational and the Emotional, and the Rational trumps the emotional. Good for us – Technocrats!
Diana Moses has it right and her insight should be elaborated to the level of common knowledge so that we will no longer have to suffer the trite tendencies of categorical reasoning.
Lori has it right also in her reference to the phenomenological.
Heraclitus argued that ‘all is flux’ and we need to recognise that applies to the nature of ALL Being.
So called Western Science is trapped in a procrustean bed which in essence is categorical and anti-evolutionary. Acceptance of evolution requires that we recognise that ALL is change. For the Physicist this means solving the puzzle of ‘dynamic’ constants; for the Religious it means accepting the contingency of moral values and for both Physics and Religion it means accepting the fact that Being is dynamic and the consequent contingency of truth.
Sorry for omitting the IMHO - I find it pretentious for stating the obvious (except for the H of course which is not generally true of technocrats!).

Here's a funny, simple thing about card security. Why is it that we are continually asked to provide the three digit number on the back? If everything matches up for an online sale, not giving that additional code would be a small degree of protection. If we have to supply it continually, then how does it help? The only thing it might slow down would be someone seeing your card number and using it. In other words, the code doesn't do much at all and using it all the time kinda defeats the purpose of having it.

In Europe, restaurant waiters bring a radio transmitter equipped card reader to your table. That way, one can at least be assured that they aren't cloning it in the back room or adding charges you don't see. Not much, but something.

One of the biggest, easiest scams in America is double charging your card. This has happened to me at least twice, once when buying a pair of hiking boots in Delaware and another time in a 7-11 buying something in Maryland. Most people don't check their credit card statements unless they are unusually large, so double charging is a snap. If the store gets caught, they can just say, "Oh, sorry, we must have made a mistake".

If you can help it, NEVER sign up for auto payments on a card or auto deductions from your bank account. This is a disaster waiting to grab your money.

Here's another fact: once you give your card, a company can force extra charges on the bill, even if you are over the credit limit. Be wary.

It is important to recall that in 1947 the UN was effectively a white mans club since most of Africa and much of Asia were under some form of European colonial rule, much of Latin America was ruled by U.S. client regimes, and even many of the Arab countries were ruled by European-installed monarchies.

Even though the population of historic Palestine was majority Palestinian Arabs the partition plan gave half of the land, including most of the better parts, to Israel. It was a very bad deal for the Palestinians and they were right to reject it as the continuation of a process of colonization that it was.

Even before Israel declared its independence, its armed forces had embarked on a campaign of ethnic cleansing. The reasons were straightforward, the territory allotted by the UN to the Jewish barely contained a Jewish majority. While Israel cites the invasion of the Arab armies as a justification for the forced displacement of the Palestinians, roughly 300,000 were already displaced before the invasion. Another 450,000 would subsequently be made refugees and Israel expanded its territory well beyond the borders envisioned by the partition plan.

While it is true that there was a continuous Jewish presence in historic Palestine, it represented a very small fraction of the indigenous population. The proposition that this presence entitled European Jews to colonize already inhabited Palestinian lands and erase several hundred Palestinian villages from the map is repugnant.

All this talk about cats having their freedom and living a natural life, and blah blah is just fine, but consider this: if you have a neighbor with a well-tilled vegetable garden, your cat may go over there and think it is a giant litter box and use it accordingly. Sometimes when you mention this to people, they chuckle as though it is amusing. If you mention it to a cat owner, they treat it as trivial or come up with suggestions about what YOU should do to dissuade the cats. In other words, the onus is on the gardener to go to a great deal of time, trouble, and expense on the CHANCE that something they try will keep the cats away. I have one question to cat owners who allow their cats to go out unsupervised: would you like feces with your salad?
By the way, I don't hate cats; I have one myself, he is happily ensconced indoors where no one else has to take responsibility for him.

Growing up in Great Neck in a Jewish household and attending Columbia University to get my degree in religion, Prof Doniger's works have been a constant companion, especially since my focus is India's ancient ascetic practices. Often, when asked where in India I learned pranayama (sense-introversion), I get stunned silence when I reply that mystical methods to realize a larger sense of self have practically vanished from India. When I go to India, it's to teach or promote a book, and a small fraction of the population has any interest at all in the wealth of its spiritual and religious traditions. When lecturing in Malaysia to yet more Hindus who knew nothing of their own heritage, one commented, "You are like a bird, Mr. Saranam, eating from the trees we planted long ago but forgot about." Fortunately, the spirit of change is in the heart of modern India. I expect small and large revolutions, both internal and outward.

The comparison with pre-WWII forces is flawed and designed to make Americans think something truly extreme is being proposed. Today we hide the true size of the Army by adding civilian contractors in numbers that equal or exceed the official uniformed count. Imagine an Army that is twice its current size and then make the same comparison.

Compensation also has to be addressed candidly, and not only for budgetary reasons. When the all-volunteer military was first proposed, no one anticipated that military pay and benefits would ever need to be higher than any comparable civilian opportunity for the system to work, but today that is true for most service members. A volunteer force is not designed for perpetual war. It's a sign of a system under strain that the military needs to outbid the civilian world to keep recruiting and retention above water.

While Vesey's intentions seem justified and acceptable by today's standards, we have to be careful to judge history and its full context. If the revolt was designed to kill as many people as possible, it still wouldn't accomplish the objective of freedom but only raise additional fears of a slave insurrection. It's really a situation where there is no clear-cut answer because both options i.e. slavery and insurrection have unintended/intended consequences that result in death and destruction. We can second-guess history in the passage of time, but it's very difficult to understand the circumstances and consequences that Vesey and his contemporaries both slave and free had to face.

"Seventy percent of restaurant servers are women, so effectively when you enforce a policy that says “It’s O.K. to pay tipped workers less than ‘regular’ workers,” you’re discriminating against a job largely done by women and reinforcing the age-old notion that women’s work is worth less than men’s."

Ever think restaurant owners discriminate against men in favor of hiring women to be servers and bartenders? You really think those in the front of the house - primarily women - make less than the primarily-male workforce in the kitchen who are paid an hourly wage far above $2.13. And are you really saying it's sexist to withhold some amount of tip because you get "bad" service? (And why is bad in quotation marks? You think there is no such thing as bad service?)

The reality is much more complex than this column makes things seem. Some servers and bartenders who are paid the minimal $2.13/hr make a very comfortable living (upwards of $100,000 and often much of that un-taxed) and some struggle. But you're trying to lump everyone in together which is simply lazy.

I may have commented earlier but can't find my 1st effort so do it again. We found the 2009 Cantemerle at ABC here in Lakeland at $40. We had it Sunday with a dandy rib eye. Interesting to read WS rating and description of this wine which encouraged me to have a go. rated a 91 I think. I read in a K&L newsletter that Parker rated their 2010 as its best ever and rated it a 94 after finding the '09 great.

I decanted it for a good hour. I found the nose hot and barnyardy with some blackberry or cherry notes. 1st taste was not so great with it being spicy, fairly tannic and short on flavors - certainly not velvety. It did open up some with more fruit flavors but still remained hot and relatively fruity but still no velvet as we had it with the steak. It was supposed to bring on the velvet feel and dark fruit flavors. Maybe it was me but my wife didn't jump for joy either

We have been drinking out of the cellar some 2003 bordeaux's that have been lovely - I think this wine could be much better if aged at least 5 more years as it has the tannins to hold it for many years. Maybe then the fruit will show through with a velvet long finish. For now I wouldn't have it again - I would like to try other '09's to see if similiar with the tannins holding down the fruit flavors.

good course - love to read others comments on this wine - seems 50-50 if liked or disliked!! Always look forward to your columns!!

Republicans stand for only one thing: the ever greater concentration of wealth and power in America.

You might wonder in a semi-democratic system how the Republicans have been so successful of separating the people from their money.

Here's how.
This country is based upon one governing principle: free contract. In such a system, bargaining power is everythig.

What you have, get, or earn, is a function of bargaining power.

The rich and republicans know this. They systematically attack the source of bargaining power of other groups: Unions for Workers, affordable quality education for aspiring middle class, ACORN for the very poor.

Taking away lunches from kids of marginal means reduces the lot of people whose only purpose is to wake up in the morning and provide labor at minimum cost to Corporations and the economic elite. What do they need nutrition for? What do they need anything more than rudimentary education for?

Big money suffers from a big addiction, more power and money. They are junkies. The republican party is their supplier. Like all junkies, they have no problem weaving up all sorts of rationalizations to justify their getting their next hit, fix, pop.

The problem with scientific research, especially in the social sciences, is that much of it is self-serving, unreplicatable, and has effect sizes that decay over time. The research is self-serving in the sense that outcomes are often measured by those who design programs in education, and because this is all caught up with politics, prestige and funding, it creates a prima facie conflict of interest.

Before being taken in by the false idol of scientific research, ask who is doing the research; what is their interest in the outcome; what is being measured; and why have those measures been chosen?
