Stock markets were originally conceived as a means to raise money for businesses. Now they are the tail that wags the dog - publicly traded corporations are expected to feed the finance industry with returns on investment that were once considered usurious. Bloated with all this wealth, the industry is well equipped to create ways to multiply it further.

Annual trades on Wall Street approach three times the GDP, which defines them as mostly unproductive; flash trading can only increase this ratio. Regulators may or may not find ways to bring put the brakes on, but in the meantime, the ill-gotten gains could be harnessed for the national good by the imposition of a transaction tax. A fraction of 1% would do wonders for the national treasury.

If you are going to make a comment on how the railroad industry operates maybe you should at least get the facts straight. There are ZERO Class 1 Railroads in the United States that operate with a single man crew. I would know as I have been a locomotive engineer with CSX for 19 years. As far as track maintenance is concerned it is an ongoing process. I work all hours of the day and night and have yet to take one trip where I have not seen several maintenance employees, be it 3 PM or 3 AM, out looking at or repairing track. As far as the safety features on a train there are several I could list but for the sake of time lets just say there are enough in place that if the locomotive engineer would not take corrective action the train would apply the brakes and come to a stop. As far as the locomotive engineer who "must have caused the accident" while I cannot speak for everyone most of the men and women who are my brothers and sisters in this industry take our jobs very seriously. Could more be done to make our trains, my job, and our road beds safer and better? Absolutely. The FRA is implementing practices (Positive Train Control for one) that are trying to make the industry safer but this all takes time. The carriers spend millions every year to upgrade infrastructure but again there are thousands of miles to deal with and it takes time. Just thought I would point these things out.

I'm pretty sure our culture should try to be cool with certain points of view. But we should also not be cool with other points of view. Some points of view are problematic. Denying people justice is wrong. We should celebrate openness, not bigotry. If someone is saying that one group of people should have a right but not another, that point of view should be discouraged. If someone is saying that we should be allowed to kill animals for our pleasure, that point of view should be discouraged. If someone says we should let women have less power than men, that idea should be quashed.

Being liberal is not about respecting all points of view-- it is about respecting the points of view that are just, fair, and equitable.

Good. We should disengage. Both sides are not interested. The Israelis won’t give up on some of the settlements. The Palestinians won’t give up on the right of return, which would mean the destruction of Israel. They have further indicated that once a deal on Palestine is reached they will move forward with a plan to declare parts of Israel itself (e.g., the Galilee) as Palestinian autonomies or part of the Palestinian state. Under the circumstances it is unlikely that any agreement will be reached. We should stop wasting our energy and prestige on this process. Eventually, the Palestinians will (unilaterally) declare a state, as is their right to do, and will co-exist with Israel without any agreement. There should be a new rule. When a political party, PAC, or candidate criticizes something like the ACA, or anything else, they should be required to offer a better alternative. We as voters should experct more than the negatives being spewed like dark chemicals from an old car's exhaust.

Our nation seems to be in a trance accentuating the negative not only in politics but elsewhere. Candidates find the worst in each other to point out, glumness and discord is prevalent on the news, TV programs that take viewers to prison, and always an integral part of political advertisements.

Personally, I'm disgusted with this political path down the dark side that includes unmercifully crucifying an opponent as if they aren't a fellow human, while, at the same time, being unaware that what matters to voters, or should matter, is a candidate's wisdom, their values, their vision, their goals, how they intend to improve things and whether or not they have leadership qualities.

What does dishing the dirt really do? It distracts from what's important, implies a political party has nothing valuable to run on, and increasingly turns off the very voters they are trying to attract.

Thus we need to as a group, tune out and turn off negative political adverisement and demand to know who a candidate and party is bold face, without distraction.

(a move right out of Nixon's dirty tricks playbook) Calling for a special election for the vacant Senate seat--the one inevitably filled by Cory Booker-- to be held just weeks before the regular election was not only a cynical political move by Christie to ensure that Democrats, including a large contingent of African-Americans, would not be in the voting booth when his own name was on the ballot, it also cost the state millions of dollars. So much for the fiscal conservativeness Christie touts about himself. It's been Christie's own political operatives who have promoted him as the great compromiser, the one who can work with both sides of the aisle, but now we're beginning to wonder how much arm-twisting was required to create that veneer.
The state's largest newspaper, The Star-Ledger, has retracted its endorsement of Christie (if you could call it that in the first place) and Buono is being vindicated. Sometimes things work out.

It's a shame that this article didn't seek any comments from non-white French people. The National Front has not changed over the years; it has only changed its rhetoric. The party has always been fundamentally about returning France to some mythical past where all French people were white and everything was perfect. Thirty-five years ago (when I first lived in France), the National Front pasted "a good Arab is a dead Arab" stickers around Paris. Today the party talks about too much immigration. Rhetoric toned down; message remains the same: "foreigners" go home (wherever that may be).  But, let's consider the facts. Much of France's wealth and glory derived from the slave trade and the colonies. Non-white people have been a part of France's history for centuries, even if many "French" do not want to recognize that. Remember Alexandre Dumas? Hundreds of thousands of Africans (and "Indochinese") fought for France in two world wars. "Immigrants" from former colonies were encouraged to come to France when the country needed their labor, but when their numbers grew and the French economy slowed, they became a "burden". France has yet to come fully to terms with its history, its great cities built on the slave trade, its extermination of Africans fighting for independence, its wealthy magnates who continue to own vast swathes of African land, etc. Americans -- and the French -- would benefit from reporting that actually exposes the fundamental hypocrisies of the National Front.

As to hooking toddlers on soda and Gatorade that is the parents' fault. My son had very little sugary foods or processed snack foods when he was young. Today my son, as an adult, eats less junk food than his peers. Early dietary habits are very important. You cannot completely control what your children eat and after a certain age you cannot control them at all but early teaching helps them to learn moderation.

This is why limiting what SNAP benefits can buy is very important. Believe me as soon as you limit it those small stores that sell the junk food today and rely on SNAP for a large part of their income will stock good wholesome foods. This is not a moral decision it is economical and a public health decision. Better food will limit illness and allow children to compete better and learn better in school.

As a father of a 27 year old adopted son with Duschene's Muscular Dystrophy the thought of the possibility of a cure for future parents and their sons is powerful and welcoming. We have watched our son deteriorate for the last 20 years to the point where he now can only move a couple of fingers. He has a trach and can no longer talk. He is tube fed. The only thing untouched is his mind, a great one. Our Daniel is intelligent and very kind to all. How he has remained so positive in all of this is really amazing.
However, he has suffered immeasuraly. Multiple back surgeries, weeks in ICU, pain meds. and the reality of watching and feeling your life slip away for 20 years is a very difficult path that nobody would choose.
I say if there is a way to prevent anyone else from suffering from this horrible disease let it happen. The sooner the better.

"making antipoverty programs much more generous would indeed reduce the incentive to work..But why, exactly, should that be such a concern?"

The Republicans problem is they've been too successful at impoverishing ordinary working Americans.

Way back in 1980, when Reagan became president and the Republicans achieved ascendancy, America had a large middle class. Back then Republicans could bash aid recipients without worrying about offending half the electorate. Today if you bash them you offend 47% and more as many of the remaining "middle class" are working on contract so they must build into their expectations that they are subject to easy layoffs, thus future aid recipients.

Message aside, Republicans haven't changed who they are: they are for the ever greater concentration of wealth and power.

The way they achieve this is by attacking other groups bargaining power: unions for workers, affordable quality education for middle class, even ACORN for the very poor. No stone is unturned.

"Ryan would have us believe that the “hammock” created by the social safety net is the reason so many Americans remain trapped in poverty" but the real source of poverty is lack of bargaining power.

In this light, Ryan's real objection to public aid is that it gives bargaining power to the poor, which means they are less desperate and so don't have to accept the most degrading wage offered.

They've been so successful that they have to change their message to concern for the poor. Right.

I remember when these alarms were installed. From day one, they made no sense, as they never indicated an emergency, just commuters trying to exit a station. Out of principle, and to avoid setting off the shrieking alarm, I would always exit the uptown #1 West 79th Street station from the turnstile closest to the staircase I preferred. This turnstile is old and very difficult to push. It never seems to be oiled and there is only one, so exiting can take 10 minutes. Alas, out of frustration, even I now exit through the emergency door. I cover my ears until I reach the top of the stairs. It's ridiculous.

And while we are on the topic of subway annoyances, may I respectfully ask all commuters to Keep to the Right when using staircases? Also, put away your phones and don't stop at the top of the stairs (or the bottom) for any reason. If you must fold a stroller, smoke a cigarette, compose a text, whatever, do it to the side.

One last thing, if you are a person who wants to go down into a subway station and you see a sea of people coming up the stairs, please don't push your way down. You already missed the train! Just let the people exit first, I implore you.

Thank you.

While I agree that it's probably wise to stay out of places like Syria, I think this op-ed fails to acknowledge the fact that the US cannot simply pretend it has had no prior impact over the shape of politics within the middle east. Sure, we may be a country that "wants it's people to be prosperous," (a claim that is a bit complicated by the income inequality and fictionalization that has come to define American society over the past decade) but one of the primary ways that America has become- and most likely will stay- prosperous over the coming years is going to be through throwing around its economic power internationally, whether that be through active intervention, or simply through working to create and sustain the globalized success of its companies.

Sure we can't "make good things happen" in other countries- but I also think that it's morally indefensible to pretend, in the midst of an ever more complex and interconnected geo-political chessboard, that problems like Syria are entirely the result of domestic political concerns unconnected to American actions in the broader world.

This just reinforces my decision to reduce the frequency of my mammograms. I had several biopsies in the late 90s-early 2000s, all of which turned out to be benign. They weren't so "benign" in their side effects, though. In particular, my first biopsy turned into a dreadful experience, a surgical marathon of cutting, sending to the pathology lab, waiting, cutting some more, etc. It went on for hours and the post-op pain was awful. I have had no further suspicious findings since my last biopsy and I have decided I can have mammos less frequently and not worry about it. My breast surgeon disagrees, of course.

I also happen to be a nurse practitioner and have these conversations with my patients all the time. Some patients are comfortable having a mammo every 2-3 years, some are not. For all patients, we discuss it, and ultimately it is up to them to do what they wish with their own body. Many, many of my older patients (70 years) no longer wish to have mammograms -- "What's the point?", they want to know. All of this is to say that the world of breast cancer detection is changing and last decade's dogma may be this decade's myth. We shall see.

Being a generalist does not mean that you can't "drill down" or whatever the currently fashionable phrase is. It means that you can learn to be an expert on anything. You do need focus and detail on what you work on. You just have to believe than you can. All it takes is a little time and work.

My father once told me: read everything and believe nothing you read. Figure it out yourself.

That is not easy, but it must be done.

I understand the writer's concerns. However, armed students are or at least were the norm many years ago. In 1965 our high school in a semi-rural area of PA often saw students arrive at school with rifles and shotguns in the back of the pickup or the car. Not to panic! It was either small game or hunting season and immediately after school the students would take their firearms from the vehicles and walk off into the woods and fields behind the school. No one ever got shot. Students would talk about hunting and sometimes openly compare their weapons in the school parking lot, some showing off the new rifle or shotgun that dad just bought them. And it gets better! The school, and many others had a rifle team. Those students often brought rifles to school and placed them into their lockers until it was time to practice. To our knowledge none of our teachers or administrators were armed. Ever! The local police departments also used the school basement rifle and pistol range for practice.
Now I admit that was the early 1960s. The world was different. As students we didn't think about harming our fellow students or teachers. It just didn't enter our minds. However, I'm sure that some teachers, and parents also, wished that they could throw us out a window. There's one other item. Back then our minds weren't influenced by the blood soaked madness of violent video games. We understood the harm and devastation that real firearms could do. We all need a reality check.

I believe another factor in this is that alcohol lowers inhibitions. When you drink, it is easy to believe that you are not too intoxicated to drive, and easy to talk yourself into it not being that big of a deal.

Cannabis does not have this effect to the same degree. When stoned, it is easy to talk yourself out of driving, as you may doubt your skills.

When behind the wheel while stoned, you are also less likely to take risk. You will drive slower, and do your best to be as aware of your surroundings as possible.

Stoned driving is a bad idea in general. The good thing is, that smoking cannabis will not make you more likely to think you can get away with it.

There are those who will always need to bring up Sabra and Shatilla as the epitaph of Ariel Sharon.

Had Ariel Sharon been born in a comfortable middle income family in the USA, he would not have been what he was. He was a man who grew up in a hard country and lived through an era where his coreligionists were butchered without opposition from the rest of the world. He fought for and established a homeland for his people. These people, by 1982, had weathered several wars that were designed to eliminate them again and again. Despite this, by 1982, they had negotiated a peace with there most implacable enemy and had detente with others. Had Lebanon not sheltered Palestinians who routinely raided Israels border and just left the country alone, Israel and Sharon would never have gone in.

If you want to view Sharon through an historical peep hole and denigrate him, you will find a way to do so. You could find outrageous decisions made by Lincoln, Churchill and other wartime leaders who are now remembered and thanked for what they did during war. I will chose to remember what they ultimately were fighting for and thank God that they were who they were, human imperfections and all.

Someone in intensive cancer treatment needs serious, caring, and reliable supportive care. Our medical system provides none of these things. When my husband was in successful cancer treatment, in which I played a very important supportive role, we wondered about other patients we met in the chemotherapy room who were there alone, with no one to help them get home that afternoon after the debilitating treatment, no one to cook nutritious meals that would maintain their weight through successive bouts of nausea, diarrhea, and constipation, no one to ensure that they drink enough water to flush the chemo drugs out of their systems, no way to pay for acupuncture, which is scientifically demonstrated to reduce nausea, no one to help them constantly retain hope throughout the whole long grueling process. Without intense, committed nursing care, it seems it would be extremely difficult to survive, or at least maintain the health necessary to stay on the regimen required to ensure that your immune system recovers from each chemo session in time for the next dose. Timing is absolutely critical for driving down the cancer cell population, rather than letting it regrow beyond the point to which the last chemo reduced it.

Our nation's health care system, which means not only medicine, but also paid sick days, disability leave, child care for dependents of the patient, home nursing care, etc., almost assures failure for those without sufficient wealth to withstand cancer care.

"Does the right of way go to the property owner whose land it traverses, or does it revert to the United States, which had originally conveyed it to a railroad (in this case, the Laramie, Hahn’s Peak and Pacific Railroad) under the terms of the General Railroad Right of Way Act of 1875?" This vicious cycle (higher number of apps -> lower acceptance rates -> kids applying to more schools -> higher number of apps) is out of hand, but no one in the cycle has any motivation to change it. Colleges love bragging about their low admit rates, high school counselors love bragging about number of acceptances (vs matriculations), and so on. It's the kids and their parents that get the short end of the stick: more work, higher fees, and higher stress.

There is an easy fix that would benefit no one except the kids and their parents - restrict the number of colleges that any one student can apply for. With the common application so prevalent, this is very easily done. I would limit kids to five schools, and have them rank them in order of preference. Any kid who does not get into any of the five would go into a "clearinghouse" where colleges with open spaces can find kids, and vice versa.

Colleges would actually benefit from this, by knowing that their school is in a kid's "top five" and in fact knows where in that list they are. College counselors would benefit by spending more time per application per kid. And of course kids would spend less money and less time on college applications, and be less stressed-out from August to the dreaded Jan 1 deadline.

Afghanistan is not Iraq, but its politics are equally opaque to the vast majority of those of us in the west, regardless of what we think we know from our distances.

And Iraq left to its own ways, following our, and their, horrible sacrifices, is not going well in our absence. A young man, friend to a niece of mine, fought in Falluja and has felt about its fate much as I felt in 1975 watching Long Khan Provincial capital Xuan Loc fall to the NVA after all my infantry battalion suffered around in 1969 and '70.

Perhaps if one of Afghanistan's leaders finally signs this agreement and NATO and U.S. teaching forces remain to advise, this will have a happier outcome. But after 13 years of war, and decades of war prior to that, skepticism is advised. We definitely can count on more painful familial separations and deaths and on their being a last man or woman to die.

Unfortunately we have to rely on a people as complicated as all the Middle East to deliver to us the judgement as to whether the last man or woman to die there dies for a mistake.

I notice that a few readers have the same view I expressed in a comment to another NYT article a few days ago. Which is that while most of us feel compassion for all those unfortunate people unable to find work, the continuous extension of benefits is just a band-aid to the underlying problem: lack of enough jobs for everybody. This is THE issue that should be addressed by the government; as many have said, stop corporations from shipping jobs to other countries, mostly third-world countries where labor and human life are cheap. Does an American President not have the authority to do that? If one can take the country to unnecessary wars he sure ought to be able to swing a law making it illegal to export jobs badly needed in this country.

I was chastened by many readers for my perceived lack of sympathy towards the unemployed, as I brought up the point that not all unemployed are facing homelessness and hunger. We do have a system of financial aid designed just to address those cases, it's called welfare.

The prevailing opinion seems to be that these benefits should be extended into the future for an unlimited period of time. Aside from the drain on the taxpayers' money, it concerns me that this issue will be used as a political tool, as it already was: President Obama agreed to extend the Bush tax cuts due to expire in 2011 so the Reps would concede extension of benefits to the unemployed. What is going to be the price for the next extension, and the next...?

I am wise to the antics of big-pharma, my wife and brother work for them, so I never ask my doctors about anything, unless I read about it in the NEJM. (I am not a doctor, just a nerd.) But my endocrinologist (I have type 2 diabetes) of 5+years recommended a low-t gel. About six months later I started to have “urine voiding” and genital pain issues, kidney stones, and unusual kidney studies. So I was sent to an urologist, then another. Two years later and numerous invasive bladder studies, I was diagnosed with BPH and surgery was recommended. I decided to research BPH on the internet and up popped a connection to my low-t gel. I was now on the higher dosage of low-t gel, and the label didn’t say much about BPH. Then I stumbled on an old box of the lower dosage and there it was: over 10% of patients using the lower dosage experienced BPH as a side effect.

The purpose of their demonstration was not to sing an "anti-Putin" song but to protest the strengthening relationship between church and state in Russia.  The church it took place in, Cathedral of Christ the Savior,  was blown up by Stalin in 1931 and the site was turned into the world's largest outdoor swimming pool during the Khrushchev era.  In 1990 the Orthodox Church asked for and received permission to rebuild.  So, the place they choose for this protest is not generally thought of in terms of being the "main" church, but, as a symbol of the rebirth of religious freedom after 70 years of brutal repression.  So, I am glad you found them to be the most "appealing" activists.  Perhaps now you understand why many Russians would not share your sentiment.

I was an NCAA Division I athlete, but not in a revenue sport like football or basketball (I swam). For four years, I and my teammates worked hard in the pool, the weight room, and yes, even the classroom. As there is really no professional swimming outside of a few very talented individuals, most of us took our education seriously and are now doctors, attorneys, teachers, and engineers.
Some of us had scholarships for athletics, some for academics and others had full tuition. I know better than most the big business that College Athletics is and it offends me that some individuals believe that the NCAA and/or schools should pay athletes. Amateur status and the love of the sport is very much alive and well in College Athletics. Yes, a handful of athletes generated millions of dollars for their school. As noted in the article, they raise awareness of the program, donations, and television related revenue. In return, they get the opportunity for an education as well as a national stage to showcase their talents for a lucrative pro career, should they choose to pursue it.
The revenue from the majority of NCAA contracts are evenly distributed throughout the Conference and still other revenue goes to all schools. There is very much a place for athletics in college. I don't begrudge these athletes their success and in some ways understand their frustration, but if you want to be a paid athlete, go pro.

Here's my moonshot Tom. A change in how we do things in Anerica from which all other smart changes must necessarily flow, including energy policy that favors renewables over entrenched interests of oil.

An ammendment to the Constitution that either prohibits private money from all local, state and federal election campaigns (thus ending the "money is political speech" fiasco) OR have strict limits on the amount that can be given to political campaigns.
Throw in a time limit on how long a campaign can last and maybe we can reclaim our democracy and sanity in our national policies.
Lacking that fundamental change to our politics, away from the today's "politicians for hire", all other desirable changes are mostly impossible.

We have one task to do first, change our political reality. Or else we are sunk.

First of all, you're over-simplifying. Agribusinesses are food marketers. Families run real farms - some for over a hundred years. Being self-employed means their retirement and disability is in their land - you sell the farm. The urban developers saw the land (it was cheap for other farmers to buy it) and they snap it up and the arable land- the stuff the healthy food is grown in- is now under houses producing unhealthy sewage and people polluting the environment. Now you have your producers further from the consumer. The further away, the lower the nutritive value. This is why I don't like buying food from overseas. And don't get me started what organic really means. You really don't want to know.
The corn as fuel agenda was pushed by 'green' people as a cheap easily replaced alternative to fossil fuels. Guess what? It costs fossil fuels to produce the stuff, and it's no cheaper. But now our food grains cost everyone more because farmers also need get out of debt to keep the farm and care for their family. If there is no profit you sell the farm.
The Farm Bills are about farmers. Farmers providing a healthy food supply close to their consumers is important. Farmers can't control their working conditions. A farm is not a factory. Get out of the city and visit family farms in your area. Please treat us like educated people when you come and you'll learn a lot.
Our country needs our farms and out farmers.

Thank you Mr. Brooks for a beautiful, thoughtful column. Having lost my wife 18 months ago to a short, brutal bout with cancer, I have learned firsthand the challenge of finding meaning in suffering and loss. The art of listening, of presence, is so valuable to a bereaved person. I've found the sharing of a personal story or connection to my wife by a friend or acquaintance to be quite supportive as well-- even when the story puts me more directly in touch with my pain. Not talking about the deceased because you don't want to "upset" the bereaved can at times increase their isolation. Be present in the bereaved's life, guard against setting up unspoken expectations on where the grieving person "should be" in the process by now, honor the deceased by sharing your connection if appropriate, and let the healing unfold.
My thanks to the Woodwisses for sharing their struggles with all of us.

There is one lesson to be learned here:  The strategy of the Ukrainian revolutionary activists has led to a fiasco.  Their exaggerated claims of transforming the world have ended up with the death of nearly 100 people, the general misery for the residents of Kiev and other parts of Ukraine, the humiliation of defeat, the loss of territory, and the government that these activists distrust and that wants to disarm them.  This is political adventurism pure and simple.  And Putin his given them a lesson in politics.  All they can do now is to blame this on Putin (obviously they do not intend to criticize themselves), Russia, the United States, the European Union--anyone but themselves.  Ukrainians should take a hard look at this revolution and turn their criticism on these militant activists.  Having said this, however, it is worth noting that suspicion and distrust of ruling hierarchies have real causes that operate in Ukraine and other countries, including the United States. Don't forget sleep. Bears "sleep" in a way differently than we do--it's called hibernation, and is like our deep sleep--and obviously much longer.  There are profound metabolic changes in humans during normal sleep, as there are in bears.  I am not the first to suggest that the known dramatic decrease in average sleep hours (a full hour less per night between 1900 and 2000) in developed countries may be a significant contributor to the obesity epidemic.  Sleep deprivation has been shown to promote weight gain.   Maybe we just need to hibernate more in the winter--or better, just get more sleep year-round.

For decades now, it has been fashionable to say that Paul Ehrlich's 1968 book The Population Bomb has been disproved and the whole concept of a population crisis is nonsense. Admittedly, Ehrlich may have predicted disaster a generation too soon, since the world has enjoyed a grace period of a few decades thanks to the widespread introduction of high-yield crops, but the day of reckoning is nigh. An early manifestation goes by the name Arab Spring.

The recent political turmoil in the Mediterranean is primarily caused by too many women having too many babies twenty years ago. The resulting young adult generation is coming of age in a region where the maximum size of the sustainable population is limited by a scarce, finite resource: water. Whereas economic theory can generate resources by the magic of market demand, nature is not so agile. And even if land, water, energy, and industrial minerals were unlimited in supply, and global warming were not an issue, providing good jobs for members of a sixty-year-long baby boom would overwhelm any society.

The conservative backlash against Ehrlich's book, and against the 1972 Club of Rome book The Limits to Growth, has been so successful that any suggestion that people anywhere should stop having large families is shouted down as racist and possibly genocidal, except in China where the one-child policy is giving the world's largest country a fighting chance of having a future.

Dear Tom,

Of course you are correct. We ranch 32,000-acres in the high-desert mountains of far-West Texas. We have free-ranging herds of elk, bighorn, deer and pronghorn, and others. Healthy systems obviously need their predators. Small wolves in small numbers on empty far-West Texas ranges would be good, not bad:

Wolves kill coyotes. Coyotes are major predators of pronghorn fawns; pronghorn are in decline, partly from coyote predation.

Eradication of wolves (and bison/cattle) on the North rim of the Grand Canyon led to one of the historic catastrophes of wildlife “management:” the collapse of the mule deer herd on the Kaibab Plateau. The herd has never recovered.

Restoration of wolves in Yellowstone Park stopped elk from loafing in riparian areas, leading to the recovery of aspen and other plants in those sensitive areas, helping elk, wildlife, and habitat. We can debate how much but it was helpful.

Nature knows best. When viewed over long terms, removal of predators from these complex systems always harms the species being “protected,” and creates many bad, unintended consequences. Predator restoration results in trophic cascade, the recovery of entire systems, as explained in the disputed video, but also observed everywhere it has been tried.

Much more on this here: www.circleranchtx.com

Back in the '90s I was driving a European car (one of the earliest generation of cars with full electronic engine management) which suddenly shut down on the highway at 85 mph, with no warning. Power steering, power brakes, all gone. The car slowed down gradually, and I could still control the steering - it was just harder, but it still did the job. Same thing with the brakes. You have to press hard, but they still work. To prevent the car from slowing down too quickly as I made my way to the emergency lane, I put the transmission in neutral - this eliminates the braking torque of the engine.

I never felt that my life was in danger: a car doesn't simply stop dead at 85 mph, but it gives you some time to move out of harm's way as it slows down.

Sometimes I wonder whether too many American drivers have gotten so used to the soft, cushy servo-assisted driving of modern cars that they don't know how to react when faced with a sudden emergency (either by knowing how to get their own car out of harm's way, or knowing how to react promptly to prevent a collision if a car stalls in front of them).

Let's face it, cars will always break down; some better driver training could help prevent the worst consequences when it happens.

Those people deserve help, even if they do not display hyperactivity (otherwise known as troublesome behavior, the real reason so many kids are diagnosed.)

As one progresses into the seventh, eighth, or higher decade of life, one begins to encounter natural limits.  I am.  But what I can or will enjoy at a meal is not one of them.  At age 78, I'm on the way out, so there's no way I will deprive myself or my friends and guests of the enjoyment of a richly marbled standing rib roast, cooked rare to perfection, or bacon for breakfast, a succulent leg of spring lamb, fresh eggs and fowl, artisanal cheeses and breads, ripe fruits and fresh vegetables, and excellent wines -- all locally sourced -- that may be my last.  My tennis rackets, sailing gear, bicycle, and other toys are, sadly, beloved relics of my past.  But not my joy and abilities in the kitchen.  So buon appetito, Soylent Green crowd, I'm off to visit my butcher and greengrocer.

Animals in the zoo are not just objects for us to use up and throw away like items of consumer culture. They are not cars or washing machines to be disposed of for new models. A zoo is meant to protect animals and to provide them with reasonable habitat, not just to amuse humans or satisfy their convenience. Zoo animals have none of the ability of wild animals to get away -- to kill them is easy, callous, and against the ethics of animal care. What an ugly attitude! The truth is that the anti poverty programs have worked very well, but instead of using them to fight poverty over the years, the Republicans began using them more and more as a way to keep wages low, as a way to subsidize low wages, thus instead of lifting people out of poverty they are increasingly being used to fill in the gap for the working poor and as a way to simply lift people up to the poverty line - a way to make dirt poor wages just slightly more livable.

Thus, we are spending a lot just to bring people up closer to the poverty line rather than over it.

Take the recent argument about the minimum wage. What was the Republican's response to it once it gained a lot of steam? Well, people like Marco Rubio started talking about raising the earned income tax credit. They once again started pushing to subsidize low wages with government assistance. This is what they always do when the debate about raising the minimum wage comes up. Thus as the purchasing power of the minimum wage declines over time, the Republican response is to fill in the gap with more government assistance. Thus we keep spending more to maintain these low incomes rather than lifting far more people out of poverty by also raising wages.

these anti poverty programs work, but they should not be used to replace declining wages - not instead of raising the minimum wage, but in addition to raising - not as an excuse to keep wages low.

There was a very interesting study about views of inequality and right wing politics. They looked at the very wealthy, who tended to support inequality because the wealthy "earned it through hard work".

This implies that wealth creates moral prestige and self-worth and entitlement and a sense of superiority. Let them eat cake - this is nothing new, it goes back to the aristocracies of Europe and the divine right of kings.

Of course, such sentiment is antithetical to democracy, but the USA has always been a kinda democracy (slavery, Jim Crow, monopolies, a justice system that's farcical, politics awash in money, ambassodorships bought and sold, huge bank bailouts but no homeowner bailouts, etc.

The defining characteristic in most human beings who have wealth and power is that they want more of it - and at the expense of others. It's zero sum, b/c the wealth when you get really rich doesn't benefit you more materially. 10 yachts give no more happiness than 8.

But the prestige. The sense of superiority. That's addictive. Going to bed every night with the comfy thought that "I'm on top" is an elixir. But a poisonous one.

The West, the leaders of the West, are faced with painful decisions. Can they, who have deliberately crippled their economic growth by yoking their economies with austerity, can they really ask their people to sacrifice in behalf of oligarchs in their respective nations? Are the people of Germany willing to sacrifice economic growth, their source of gas and oil, to confront Putin in the Ukraine? France? Belgium? Italy? Anyone?
Even the United States will suffer economically if sanctions are applied. Will the deficit grow or will the rich finally have to foot the bill for increased defense spending, and rising oil prices? Americans know that the deficit is the plaything of the rich, who elect (or appoint) leaders who take us to war and give the rich a tax cut, charging the entire cost to the treasury. Does anyone think that we can rally political support to rescue Europe? Me neither.

Trying to view Putin’s actions and the US response through a Cold War prism is, so far, misinformed. The crux of the Cold War was over which ideology, whether a centrally controlled economy and one-party authoritarian rule (under the rubric of Marxism, Leninism, and Stalinism) or a capitalist economy and democratic government was the better method of organizing society. The West prefers the latter, while it seems that the masses in the East, principally Russia and China, seem to prefer a mix of unrestrained capitalism, little opportunity for social and political expression, and much high level bureaucratic corruption thrown into the mix.
The new situation is more like the 18th and 19th centuries when Russian was imperialistic, sought Great Power status, and wanted to extend its control over contiguous territories as a form of self-defense. Putin is going to find out that modern-day imperialism is very expensive for a petrostate. If he was looking to rekindle those good-old Cold War days, he would be offering economic and military assistance to Cuba, propping up North Korea, really building up Syria, and undermining Democratic governments in Eastern Europe. Let’s just wait and see. So far, though, he's doing a great impression of Hitler.

The only thing I objected to in this editorial was the statement that some of Glenn Beck's sins are "beyond absolution". Really?

To me, he's just another media personality, another pundit, another entertainer, another writer, another person who makes his living telling us what we should think. With respect, so is Mr. Blow.

I think the media gives itself far, far too much credit for its opinions effect on public thinking. Although I know who Glenn Beck is, and probably could generally characterize his social and political orientation, I don't watch or listen to him, nor do I read what he writes. The same with Rachel Maddow, whom I understand to be on "the other side." Most people don't!

If we've become divided, if we've become harsh to opinions other than our own, the responsibility does not go beyond our own selves. To attribute it to the effect of an entertainer -- or a NYT columnist -- is both convenient and arrogant. I think our government is out of control because that's what I see in how politicians behave, in the laws they pass, in the work they don't do. I think they have the wrong priorities -- we're content to let people be hungry and homeless all over the country, not to mention the world, while we debate the already strongly-regulated use of carriage horses.

We need look no further than ourselves for the roots of change. To look to Glenn Beck and his ilk -- or to Robert Reich and his -- is shirking our responsibility.

Global capitalism has undoubtedly helped the world's most poor citizens.

Declaring oneself a sanctuary for something is different than saying that one is a nation for something. I think this is the conceptual conflation that risks the shipwreck here. Appealing to how Israel's neighbors declare themselves Islamic states is no excuse; those are not modern states.

How can a modern state formulate itself as "of, by, and for" a specific ethnicity or religion? That is an anti- or pre-modern concept of what a state is. I do not see any way around this.

Except, to painfully separate the unfortunate concepts that has conflated a place of refuge with the institution of modern statehood. A nation has every right to declare itself a state of refuge for a diaspora; but that policy cannot be turned into a charter of a nation. Not if that nation wishes to be a modern one.

Israel is at great risk of isolating itself as a historical anomaly, or at best, a tremendously awkward balancing act. How can any modern state declare itself as having a religious or ethnic preference? It goes against what modernity means at that level.
So because you did it everyone should be able to?

With his approval rating in the 40s, we would love to have Obama up for a 3rd term, if it was allowed. Hillary is a more formidable opponent right now.

Health insurance is probably one of the most glaring examples of inequality. President Obama could probably purchase a family plan for $8,400 or about 1% of his adjusted gross income. Middle class families may pay well over 15% of their income for health insurance. Worse yet, every middle class California family that qualifies for a subsidy is required to place their children into MediCal not on the parents’ policy, and obscene gift to insurance companies. They can sell family plans, cover the parents, and force the children on welfare.

We have an opportunity to create a dignified insurance system where risk is distributed by ability to pay, shared broadly across society, and where no one is required to remain poor or limit their income for subsidies like we have done with fire departments. They never ask for an insurance card to determine payments.

Expanding and improving Medicare will ensure we have excellent benefits with low co-pays, a place where we can see any family doctor we choose and be admitted to any medical facility our doctors recommend knowing Medicare will pay the bills like Australian woman last weekend who pays 3% of her family income for benefits I described.

Winston Churchill said Americans usually get it right after they try everything else, and it'd be wonderful to prove him wrong. Treating health insurance like a commodity were excellent benefits are available only to the wealthy or well connected is unbecoming of our great nation.

SUMMARY: We are adopting a new airworthiness directive (AD) for certain The Boeing Company Model 777 airplanes.

This AD was prompted by a report of cracking in the fuselage skin underneath
the satellite communication (SATCOM) antenna adapter.
This AD requires repetitive inspections of the visible fuselage skin and doubler if installed, for cracking, corrosion, and any indication of contact of a certain fastener to a bonding jumper, and repair if necessary.
We are issuing this AD to detect and correct cracking and corrosion in the fuselage skin, which could lead to rapid decompression and loss of structural integrity of the airplane.

DATES: This AD is effective April 9, 2014.

Agreed. The Malaysians started their search exactly where any other nation would have started: along the known flight path at the point where the plane lost contact. That's an entirely reasonable place to begin. This particular plane's flight path, based on current analyses, is so bizarre as to be implausible (though clearly not impossible). If the Malaysians had started the search deep in the Indian Ocean based solely on the initial radar blips they had, they would have been chastised for that, too. I'm glad they have a PR firm looking after them now since clearly communication and public face is not a strong point, but we should be cautious about faulting them for their approach to the search. Should they have asked for help sooner? Sure. But whatever happened to MH370 is evidently a new situation that aviation has not encountered before, and search protocols are based on past patterns and knowledge. Even when the rest of the world jumped in, it took days to figure out where to look. Leading the way on solving that puzzle would be a tough position to be for any nation, even a politically stable, well-resourced developed nation.

The Abrahamic faiths are largely promulgated by systems of law. The Halakha, Sharia & Canon Law were designed to provide guidance for their practitioners. Human nature being what it is, people try to manipulate the law to their favor. Those who succeed become "the rich" and "the powerful."

One can believe that secular law is divorced from religion but in the Judeo-Christian-Islamic world, laws emanate from Abrahamic sensibilities, at least in jurisdictions in which one or the other of these believers or their descendants predominate. This would even have been true in former communist countries such as the Soviet Union, Poland, Cuba or Yemen.

We refer to Moses as "the Lawgiver." The Commandments were groundbreaking in its time. One must remember, however, that the they were only chapter headings for much more detailed instructions elaborated upon by religious scholars of the three faiths. Were one to follow them literally in our time, some of them may be at odds at our current understanding of justice.

Moses may have been an inspirational figure to the Founding Fathers. In our nation, however, no group has derived more inspiration from his person than African-Americans beginning in the slave era. Martin Luther King captured the sentiment, "I may not get there with you, but I have seen the Promised Land." As with religion & law, one sees in Moses what one wants to.

My favorite treatment of Moses was the TV miniseries "Moses the Lawgiver" with Burt Lancaster. Check it out.

Having worked for a test prep company and being a relatively (<5 years) of a standardized entrance exam I can state that most such tests are not good indicators of success or scholarship. They, like a lot of things, can be gamed if the test taker has the financial resources or ingenuity to do so. In fact, test prep companies are getting better and better at making the test gameable. They use advanced algorithms, legions of former test takers, and connections with the test makers themselves to ensure that customers are able to achieve the requisite score. Of course, the counter argument is that with the # of people applying to schools you have to weed them somehow. I agree with that idea, but I don't think a standardized test is the way to do it - redesign or no.

As a former South African and member of the ANC', who took part in the armed struggle against apartheid, I believe I speak with some authority on what is or isn't apartheid. As an Israeli I also know what Israel is or isn't.

Israel is not an apartheid state. Tom Friedman does not say it is. There is no segregation in Israel, Arabs vote, sit in parliament, can be seen at every level of Israel's civil service, from lowly clerks to to doctors, judges and diplomats. Yes there is discrmination, but it is illegal, unlike apartheid where it was the law of the land. When discrimination reaches the courts, it is banned, the guily parties punished. Would I like to be an Arab in Israel? No, but then I probably wouldn't be wild about being an Afro-American in the US either. However the plight of Arabs in Israel today is far closer to that of Afro-Americans than to Africans in apartheid SA.

The West Bank is a different story. I unfortunately have to admit that there are aspects of the occupation that do superficially resemble apartheid, such as segregated roads, segregated law and justice, and a civilian population living under a military occupation, Nevertheless I say superficially because unlike apartheid, which was envisaged by its founders not only as the permanent state of affairs, but as the desirable one, the occupation is temporary.

The day it ceases to be temporary will be the day Israel crosses the Rubicon and becomes an apartheid state.

I am an American student from an all-American family who decided to pursue higher education abroad in Switzerland. This article mentions a growing number of international students flooding the American applicant pool, so why aren't we doing the same?

In Switzerland, where higher education is subsidized by the government, I am attending one of the top universities in THE WORLD, for $600 a semester. This price does NOT include financial aid of any kind, it is actually the sticker price. Furthermore, I am receiving an excellent education, i.e. world renowned professors, no courses taught by TAs, challenging subjects (no yoga or improv theater for college credit here, sorry), instruction in three languages, and access to state of the art facilities. And I pay EXACTLY the same price as the Swiss, $600 a semester.

I chose to earn my degree abroad because I REFUSE this posh, elitist, hyper-inflated system of so-called academia we have in the United States.

The commenters here who are saying we shouldn't congratulate John Boehner are missing the point. I've decided to continue living in the real world.  And in that world, responsible democracy requires a strong but reasonable and loyal opposition at all times to keep in check those in power.  Tea party Republicans simply do not qualify, which is something that a significant proportion of Americans do not yet grasp.  But other Republicans do.  And not just "moderate" Republicans; you can be conservative without being an ignorant, obstructionist demagogue.   So every time John Boehner stands up and tries to ensure that the opposition stays out of the hands of Ted Cruz, our democracy is made that much more secure.  So yes, I applaud John Boehner.  Not because he's perfect, and certainly not because I agree with his views on the issues, but on this day, he stood between me and Ted Cruz.

In reading Roger Cohen's thoughts on the graveyards associated with the wars in Europe, I was reminded of one such graveyard (Cannock Chase) in Staffordshire England that holds soldiers from both sides. As a veteran I see the futility of war and it's horrors long before I see the glory we wish to find in it. I find the well kept graves there to be such a contradiction to the confusion and mess of battle.

STYGIAN COTS IN CANNOCK CHASE

In Cannock Chase in Stafordshire
Lies them that perished on war's barbed wire;

The rose cheeked youth that begged to smile
Yet facing death, shrunk and shivered, while

Grand masters in the art of war
Decided what their youth was for -

To bleed and scream from shot and gun
Or from the gas cough out a lung;

To shake and quake from fear now dying;
To slip pale-faced, sweat wet while crying -

Mother help me my mind won't work!
Mutter bitte ich bin voller Furcht!

And now they lie beneath the mud,
Having given joy and life and blood.

They rest and rot in Staffordshire
Waiting for the next mass to expire;

And join them in that great GRAND FETE,
When war rapes youth and life retreats.

(over 5,000 German soldiers who died on British soil
during the two world wars are buried in one cemetery
in Cannock Chase in Staffordshire.) d.a.

The fault here is with the breathless immediacy that the media, in particular cable news channels, seem to feel is required for "reporting".  In fact, almost everything we have heard is speculation due to media reports, often from single-sourced unverified reports.  Every day what was "news" the day before is revealed as premature speculation.  Objectively, all we know is that this plane went off communications and radar at a given time in a well-defined place.  The wide search area seems to be based on four tiny data points from a satellite system not designed for the purpose it is being used for.  The plane could well be at the bottom of the ocean very close to the last point of contact, where nobody is looking any longer.  However, I don't know what happened any more than anybody else does, nor will we until debris or "black boxes" or found, if then.  Let's learn to live with ambiguity, and in the meantime concentrate our efforts on comforting the loved ones of the victims.

Fascinating and hopeful study here, although it sounds like it wasn't fun to carry it out; I admit I really don't like the idea of deliberately infecting our primate cousins with a lethal virus, but I guess there's not much way around it.

If this winds up working, and the shot is 100% effective in preventing transmission and has no nasty side effects, then this might be the actual beginning of the end of AIDS. It's pretty clear that we are not going to be able to cure it anytime soon, since it's a rapidly shifting virus and we have never, ever invented a cure for a virus. But if we can prevent new infections, worldwide and consistently, then the number of infected people will slowly drop to zero, and once nobody is infected, in 60 or 100 years, there will be no new infections.

This approach almost worked with polio, but unfortunately the same effect that prevented the elimination of polio may prevent this from working too. That is, the refusal of ignorant fundamentalists to receive vaccines. That's why polio is on the rise again, and that's the main reason to worry that this vaccination will not be able to be implemented completely either.

As an aside, I wonder if GSK744 is from Glaxo Smith Kline? Did some legal work for them awhile ago, they're a pretty upstanding pharma company and if this is theirs I think they deserve commendation and recognition for it.

As an adult, I reap the advantages, and that's a good thing, I feel, looking back on it all.  I wasn't all that smart as a young person, but I was scared into doing the right things. The MD degree is a technical degree, not a scholarly one? Really?

To maintain my license I must document 50 hours of continuing medical education every year. To maintain my board certification, I must participate in Maintenance of Certification (MOC) activities continuously and take a recertification exam every 10 years. I belong to 5 different scholarly associations, subscribe to 4 different journals, read several others on line, look up journal articles on various diseases on a daily basis.

Many of the most common drugs prescribed today did not exist when I graduated from medical school 2 decades ago. Ulcer disease was thought to be caused by too much stomach acid: no one had heard of helocobacter pylori. Endovascular stents did not exist. MRI scanners were just coming on the market. Clotbusting drugs were in clinical trials. Robotic-assisted surgery was science fiction.

No MD can keep up with the medical literature. Medical training has shifted away from rote memorization of individual facts and towards a process of lifelong learning: I was told in med school that 1/3 of what they were teaching me was wrong, they just didn't know which third.

Any doctor who stops learning will in short order be practicing bad medicine.

Medicine, practiced competently, is perhaps the most scholarly profession there is.

The President today made a good point about correcting overtime wage practices that freeze out wage payments to salaried employees who work more than forty hours. In the 1990's I worked for a national company that called many store managers who did everything that needed to be done with minimal staff, "salaried management employees". These workers often spent in excess of fifty and sometimes over seventy hours a week doing what was required to run things with a skeleton crew to save on costs. Finally someone brought a complaint to the state labor board, and the company had to pay a negotiated settlement for back wages. It was very minimal, but it was a step in the right direction.  If wages are indeed going up, it probably is a result of loading up fewer and fewer employees with more and more work, and calling as many of them as possible "management", a short term fix for bottom line demands by those at the top of the corporate food chain.

First of all, I must say that I was always skeptical to Argentina's current government and I deem Peronism as the country's unfortunate curse, an aspect that I shared with Mr. Cohen. However, many of the arguments or premises presented by him are purely opinion with a total lack of factual support or evidence. Assertions such as "Argentina was richer than Sweden, France, Austria and Italy" a century ago reflects his endorsement of the traditional Argentinian myth of the golden age that implies that the country at that time was at the same level with the other great world powers. This is just not the case. Argentina experienced, without any doubt, an economic boom after 1860 and a large influx of immigrants -mainly from Europe. However, the country still lacked much infrastructure, human capital and relied mostly -like nowadays- on its agrarian exports as source of income. Argentina's economic performance became closely tied to the value of agrarian products from that day onwards without the development of any serious industry in the subsequent decades. The reason why the Kirchner couple was so successful was, therefore, due to the dramatic increase in commodities after the year 2002 that enabled the government to replenish their empty coffers and not because of their economic policies. Now that the revenues stagnated while they increased the spending on populist policies and subsidies, the country is facing yet another financial crisis.

Somehow people just don't want to focus on the fact that ACA really is about insurance, not actual care. There is a basic assumption that people who have insurance can get and afford care that will not push them into bankruptcy. Lower wage earners will still be forced into bankruptcy with a minor illness. The cheapest plans still have the highest deductibles, co-pays, co-insurance and other fees. How can a McMart worker afford $250 to get into an emergency room? Then they have their $5000 deductible (this is typical for my state) to meet, then pay for the testing and treatment. Okay, this is admittedly better than this time last year, their insurance card will get them in the ER door but it won't keep them out of bankruptcy.

ACA must be taken forward to a universal coverage, single payer plan that makes basic care a human right. Nobody should be forced into bankruptcy because they got sick. Nobody should go without basic care because they are too poor to pay the copays, co-insurance, and deductibles.

I was a "Disco Bartender" back in the 1980s when the IRS came up with the grand scheme to allocate tips. My employer saw that as his chance to cut payroll expenses, reducing his payroll cost for having me -- and ten other highly prefessional bartenders -- on his staff by about $300 a week each. When that happened our customers became our largest source of income. What he foolishly didn't see -- and attempts were made to infulence his poor decision -- was that in ceasing to be a major contributor to our well being that he became much less of an employer and more like "just another customer." Another direct result of his decision was that the cost of goods sold component -- the "pour cost" -- of our liquor sales number became a moving target and generally was higher. When your staff is cranking out $35,000 in gross liquor sales a night that pour cost is a significant amount. In the end the employer was disappointed that he actually had to spend more on "management" and on goods than he saved by cutting payroll. Another example of "you get what you pay for."

Mr. Friedman’s articles have focused on tough choices and urgency to find a two-state solution. Missing from this discourse is the positive role the international community can play in a long-term peace framework. Hostile boycotts will not advance peace. A different international response is needed—one that reflects a long term vision and sense of responsibility.

To oversimplify, Israel requires security, national recognition and peace; Palestinians require national recognition, economy and peace.

At this point, the international community should acknowledge that the two sides cannot make it on their own. Without help, they cannot build sustainable trust and find lasting solutions to the most difficult issues.

What can the international community do? Speak and act with a commitment to a long-term peace process. Assist with the resources needed to give effect to short and long-term agreements. Replace rhetoric about boycotts with commitments to commerce and to policing the peace. Be honest about the needs and ambitions of both parties. Enter bi-lateral agreements that include incentives for social and economic reconstruction. Text books must be changed and to facilitate national and cultural acceptance on both sides. Security needs to monitored and be matched with structured social and economic interaction.

International support should be sufficient to provide security, support change, and “Give peace a chance”!

Having already displayed an unwarranted sense of arrogance coupled with deep distrust for Iran at the Geneva conference on Syria, the US should avoid another folly of forcing Iran to rethink about its whole course of seeking engagement with the US and West, or its genuine effort to join the international mainstream.  Finally, the US or the anti-Iranian forces should also remember that Iran is not another small third world nation which could be pushed around any way by the Western powers. An internationally engaged Iran, with or without nuclear power, would be a lesser threat to the world than the one forced to live in isolation. Let the Obama-Kerry initiated  diplomatic move, rooted in sound strategic vision, be allowed a full course to fructify and benefit the world.

When we bought our house 25+ years ago in a nice area just outside the city, the neighborhood was diverse. Next door lived a machinist. Across the street was an attorney, an MBTA career guy, and a school principal. Behind us lived a mailman. We were young professionals. It was multicultural in nature too.

Our street was lined with cozy, modest homes selling at around $100,000. Today, the house where the MBTA worker lived was knocked down, replaced with a McMansion, and just sold for $1.295 million. We could no longer afford to live in even our little house in this town. I scratch my head at who can afford these prices?

The knock downs are left, right and behind us. The people moving in do not speak to us except a cursory hello – if that. Money and privilege have taken over at the expense of the “regular” folks who, at one time, could enjoy this nice community and good public schools.

I would give up house equity for housing fairness in a minute. My town may have gotten wealthier and wealthier, but it has sold its soul.

There are extensive studies of the success (or not) of charter schools. Mainly they do no better than regular public schools. Many do worse; a few do better; most have no positive effect at all. Some of the ones which do the best appear most effective because they make sure to exclude the poor and troubled students.

Charter schools are not an educational reform; they are part of an economic agenda toward privatization of all public functions. Once upon a time they were supposed to show the way to educational reform. They do very little of that, but they do a lot to make the public education system weaker by cherry picking students, dumping the ones they don't like back into the regular system and claiming (with no real evidence) that they are the answer to educational issues. It's the educational version of the old western saying, "All hat; no cattle."

And the same people who fall for that are certain to fall for this. Republicans, Democrats--it doesn't matter. People who have no understanding of even the most basic components of research sampling and statistics see this as "reform" and continue to push it. It's a religious belief not a scientific one. We don't just need children with better math skills; we need columnists whose knowledge of social science research goes beyond pop psychology. And no one falls harder for that than David Brooks.

One of the more moving books that I have read is psychiatrist and neurologist Dr. Viktor Frankl's "Man's Search for Meaning." One conclusion he made was that true human growth comes from suffering. While the pursuit of happiness may be a worthwhile goal, actually being happy in every way itself poses a problem. The question is: In what world is the fully happy person living?

I once said tongue-in-cheek that happy people are "useless" people. Sad people have created the most poignant music, the most subtle paintings and the most compelling reading. Angry people have are motivated to change the world, to end world hunger, to promote societal justice, to solve societal dilemmas.

A life fully lived has sad and angering moments perhaps in greater proportion than happy moments. When these happy moments come, they are so much more meaningful for the person that has suffered than for the person who has not suffered. I care about and wonder what became of the sad and angry person.

While what happened is certainly a tragedy and there's much that can be done to reduce traffic fatalities, reducing the legal speed limit would probably not be effective because it would just create more driver frustration, just as purposely mistimed traffic lights do, which might encourage them to speed even more. As much as I favor the rights of people over the rights of cars, we shouldn't disable the entire city because of one terrible accident.

With the possible exception of drivers who run red lights, no one who is careful gets hit by a car. This kid ran into the street to retrieve a ball. It's said that he "looked", but if really looked, he would have seen the oncoming van. And if the light had just changed, how fast could the van have been going?

When I was 8, I ran across the street without looking and came very close to getting hit by a car. The car saw me and screeched to a stop. My immature mind didn't think much of it but I found out later that the woman drove to the corner, stopped her car and sobbed. But if I had gotten hit, it would have been my fault.

What we need is enforcement of current laws: drivers who speed excessively, who don't signal, who tailgate on highways, etc. It's ridiculous to give people tickets who safely go 5mph over the speed limit, but not those who tailgate, cut people off, etc. And maybe we should start giving tickets to pedestrians who cross at red lights, in the middle of the street, etc.

Just one more example of the steady erosion of workplace benefits that have become common in a weak employment environment.

In the last ten years, employees of all stripes have seen salaries stagnate, health care benefits decline, 401K matches diminish, and other indirect benefits on the job disappear. And, during the same time, executive compensation in their companies have often skyrocketed.

Many times, these cuts aren't precipitated by dire financial consequences within the entity; instead, employers initiate them simply because they can...given the weak job market coupled with similar trends followed by other employers.

Not to mention any facts, but I invite anyone to run the following Google search: "U.K. Environment Agency" "carrier bags" and download the whole thing.

You will learn that the disposable plastic grocery bag is, by far, the most environmentally responsible means of carrying groceries. The most common replacement, a paper sack, causes 16 times the water pollution, 4 times the air pollution, and 4 times the greenhouse emissions.

A cloth bag must be used 173 times before the greenhouse gas emissions entailed in making it and shipping it drop below those from plastic bags. And that's not even counting the need to launder cloth bags to avoid diseases they are known to harbor, including e coli and noro virus.

Last spring, my wife and I sat on our front porch and we were lucky enough to watch a mother blue bird push her fledglings out of a bird house.  The mother and her young brood quickly made their way to a set of power lines right in front of us.  My wife and I spent the next hour and a half in a mystical experience as the mother taught her babies how to dive down and hover above the grass looking for grubs.  The existence of God is right in front of us each day, and the gifts he is willing to share with us are right there for the taking.  It takes faith the size of a mustard seed.

There is a broad spectrum of competency among all drivers, irrespective of intoxication with any substance - the 30 year-old with good vision, strength, and reflexes, is markedly safer than the 80 year-old who is relatively compromised in all those areas, or an unskilled, inexperienced new driver.

Likewise, in the rehabilitation medicine clinic, I have encountered a range of competencies among would-be drivers who had had brain injury, stroke, seizures, etc. Objective evaluation of their function is accomplished by a formal fitness-to-drive assessment, which is too long and involved for DUI determinations.

What is needed is a brief, valid, reliable, roadside assessment of driving ability (read: functional neurological impairment). This could easily be developed by clinicians with expertise and a little funding.

As a single mother myself, I can attest that I did not join the ranks of single motherhood willingly.  I stayed with an abusive man because I believed any father was better than no father -- and I paid the price for that thought, when he later abducted my children and all-but-destroyed my mental health and theirs.  Yes, we lived in abject poverty after that.  He refused to pay child support and paid no support for me.  I couldn't work, because my children were too fragile for me to leave in the care of others.  Welfare -- for a university-educated woman who'd been working since she was a teenager -- was a grim necessity.  When we fled Canada, because he was still dangerous, we were homeless, then on what passes for welfare in this country, and, finally, making a "working poor" living with me as a teacher in Florida, where my wages are exactly half of what I used to be making.  My children have suffered greatly from their father's refusal to support them, and from my inability to be paid a wage which is fair.  There are real issues to be addressed in marriage breakdowns.  I hear a lot of talk, but there's no real understanding of the issues involved.

Now that I have recovered from my 5th glass of wine last night, I had two questions I thought might be of general interest..

1. After spending $60 on a bottle of wine, I felt obligated to drink the entire bottle as I have always heard that wine loses it's quality after being opened. Can you preserve a half full bottle of wine without losing flavor? How do you do that?

2. I read the number of comments where tasters were disappointed in the wine. In most cases, it was a substitute Haut Medoc, and under $40. I too have purchased lower priced Bordeaux in the USA in the past and found them less interesting than other mid and cheaper wines from other regions. Yet, when in France skiing 10 years ago, I found that the $50 (restaurant price) Bordeaux were memorable. Do the French keep their better wines in country? Do they only export bad mid to inexpensive wines, and require you to pay serious money to get a decent quality wine outside of France?

Thanks for this fun wine school exercise.

Some will say this initiative is radical and divisive; others will say it's too little, too late. Personally, I'm in the "all of the above" mindset - meaning that I don't view these efforts as a perfect cure, but as an important tool in the equipment box to help tackle these issues. Should he instead do nothing because it's not enough or it's too much??
For those who seem to think Obama has been oblivious or ignorant on these issues, I would encourage you to read David Remnick's recent New Yorker profile. In one section, he observes the president as he speaks to a group of young Chicago males who are in a mentoring program (probably the same featured in this piece?). Those boys are rather awed by the president's ability to relate to their own circumstances - whether it is an absent father, experimenting with drugs, feeling anxious about constrained opportunities, lacking positive role models. All things the president experienced growing up, placing him in a unique position to be able to relate to everyone from young men of color in urban areas to wealthy, arugula-eating elites (haha). I don't see that aspect of Obama as divisive - I think it's a blessing and very useful to have an elected leader who has had such a range of experiences.

And remember: this initiative doesn't mean that young black women are ignored, young white men are ignored, etc. - it's not an either/or, all or nothing proposition! Don't do "nothing" simply because you can't do "everything."

David:

And how is having property that one uses for income different from what wealthy people do today?

The Declaration of Independence certainly was created at leisure, as was Jefferson's service as ambassador to France and as secretary of state. He inherited land and slaves, and those assets generated the income he used for much of his life to become educated, to think and write, and to serve in various official capacities. Ben Franklin is a good example of the exception that proves the rule (but only a partial exception), as his early life was consumed in making money, largely from publishing ventures he started himself as the impoverished runaway from a Boston apprenticeship to his brother. His latter life, however, was dedicated to public efforts and inventions, funded by the accumulated wealth of his earlier undertakings.

My beloved mother just passed thankfully from her endless suffering and misery. She was in physical and emotional pain 24/7. Once a perfect speller, her words became phonetic.
One thing I notice that is not discussed when all these other hypotheses are is Alzhiemers due to head injury.
My mother suffered a severe a head trauma in 1999. In 2001 I noticed something was unusual in her. As her daughter, I saw the small things in her behavior as signs.
She also suffered from cluster headaches over her life time.
I wish more studies were available to better understand and defeat this scurge and I am saddened that even this has become a polical issue.
Don't republicans think they will have this affliction in their own families?

Whether or not preschool is the political flavor of the month, the truth is that early childhood education begins at home. And parents are the child's first and most important teachers. That said though, it's bewildering that training in how to drive a car plus a license is needed before we go out on the road. While nothing similar is common for the most important job in the world, "peoplemaking."

The first five years or so of a child's life are known as the formative years. It's the period of greatest cognitive, emotional, psychosocial, intellectual growth. During that time a foundation is formed. And, depending on the quality of parenting, a child's foundation can either be solid, from which the child can positively function the rest of his or her life, or one with cracks and holes that set the stage for a life of struggle.

Thus the first focus before preschool, should be promoting the idea and need for parent training that would include information about the various stages of development and how to best meet the cognitive, emotional, intellectual and other needs of a child. In that way more children will be well-adjusted and prepared to take full advantage of preschool, as well as, all subsequent educational and learning opportunities.
