There was a world, in fact, there were six million worlds--each of them connected to other worlds. It was a world that stretched from the Baltic to the Aegean and in a remarkably short period of time, nearly everyone in that world was shot, shipped off, starved, beaten to death or gassed. The Jewish world of Europe was so horribly decimated that it beggars belief. Tens of millions of others perished, too--that should never be forgotten. But it was that Jewish world that simply ceased to exist. Walk the streets of Thessaloniki or Vilnius today to appreciate what happens when there is no memory left.  All too many of us can recite the number six million, but this project does literally nothing to light one candle, mention one name, recall one story or show one picture. I find it sad, misguided, solipsistic and self congratulatory. The US Holocaust Museum in Washington did a brilliant job with it's Tower of Life (four walls covered in family photos that stretch up three stories); the Shoah Foundation has secured tens of thousands of video stories of Jews (and others) recalling the Holocaust, and Yad Vashem continues to try to give every victim a name. We can never give them back their lives, but we can work as hard as we can to give them back their stories--or at the very least: their names. Perhaps this book would make sense if it had this written as a preface: They deserved better than to be remembered like this.

Exactly my thoughts (as a molecular geneticist). The fears expressed in this article and by many comments are plain ridiculous. The natural mixture of genes (from different people) created each generation is approximately four thousand fold higher than the inheritance of mitochondrial genes (about 20 genes). In fact if anything the science would suggest it would be better to mix mitochondria from several individuals (mimicking what happens with our chromosomal genes) because any "defect" in one source of mitochondria would be countered by a good copy from a different one. To understand this, contemplate that most humans carry up to seven defective genes that could lead to life-threatening disease but do not because they are rescued by the second good copy inherited from the other parent. This is the underlying basis of the interdiction against cousins marrying in many societies (and the excess of genetic disease in those societies that encourage cousin marriages, eg. the middle east)--because it greatly increases the likelihood of both copies of the gene being the same defective one inherited from their common ancestor. This situation is analagous to what happens with mitochondrial inheritance--since sperm do not contribute mitochondria to the fertilized egg, any mutation in maternal mitochondria can be fully "expressed".
This kind of IVF has to be the most benign form one can imagine because it affects such a tiny number of genes and does not actually alter those genes.

I turned 18 in December, 1971, at which point I was required by law to register for the draft. The moment had loomed before me since early childhood, and I held Lyndon Johnson in contempt.

By that time the "lottery" was in effect, and my number was just high enough that it was unlikely I would be summoned to Viet Nam. But still. A lottery. What kind of word was that? The entire exercise was beyond reason. I quickly burned my draft card.

In 1971 I could not say what I can say now: The civil rights legislation enacted during the Johnson administration will be cited through the ages as proof that democracy works, that the rights of the minority can be protected.

Viet Nam will be viewed, if it's discussed at all, as a dust-up between 20th century capitalist imperialism and Marxist idealism. The arc of history is, indeed, long.

Wow, talk about misinformation. The reliable estimates of what costs the health care system incurs as a result of medical malpractice are mostly in the 2-3% range tops. Yet this commentator throws out a figure "one third" as if there was evidence to support this outrageous claim. And the notion of an abundance of "frivolous" lawsuits is not supported by any reliable evidence. In fact the majority of patients who have suffered an injury due to negligence do not bring an action in the first place - a fact documented in well accepted published studies. . In many states, there are dollar caps on recovery - a trend which exists in few or no other areas of tort law. Yes the system is irrational as awards vary tremendously for the same injury and it is very very slow (punishing victims most of all).
The problem is that every other approach suggested by tort reform advocates has its own set of problems. In some instances there are attempts to find equitable, workable compensation approaches that may work to reduce cost, reduce delays and save the system some costs but not on the back of the patient unfortunate enough to be injured by negligent practice.
And I hope that this commentator, apparently a physician, is more evidence-based when discussing clinical medicine and a prognosis with his/her patients.

This is a classic example of where the legal principle is simple -- until you try to figure out how to implement it. Everyone agrees that violent felons should not possess firearms.

At the present time, there is no means to prevent possession, thanks to the strong political and constitutional opposition to any form of gun control legislation. That then leaves only the option of punishing more severely those criminals who use -- or threaten to use -- a firearm as part of committing crimes.

The mandatory sentence add-on is a blunt instrument since it leaves no discretion to judges when applying the law to specific cases. A smarter system might be judicial guidelines that leave judges with more discretion, but our legal tradition generally does not support the notion of sentence review once it is imposed. Our current system allows the convict to appeal that a sentence is too harsh, but corresponding appeals where the prosecution claims a sentence is too lenient are extremely rare. It is extremely rare to encounter an appeals court that INCREASES the imposed sentence -- the most it might do would be to order a new trial.

Until prosecutorial appeals become more accepted as an integral part of judicial review, mandatory sentences will remain the legislative tool to assure that punishment is imposed -- for better or worse.

When my children were kidnapped and missing for eight weeks, I was faced with the two kinds of "comforters" -- my friends, who actually did things for me, like make me half a sandwich and then made sure I ate it, and those who said things to me like, "It's G-d's will," or "G-d would never give you a burden you could not bear."  Those people who said those statements to me were people I never spoke to again.  As a conservative Jew, I do not believe that HaShem would have tortured my children just to make me "grow."  The concept is hateful.  Thank you for pointing out that these are statements, no matter how kindly meant, that are soul-stripping to the sufferer.  One thing that was not mentioned was that I became reluctant -- even as the city was looking for my children and posters were up everywhere -- to tell people how I was, particularly people who didn't know.  People's reactions to my suffering were painful and I felt compelled to comfort them.  I've never seen anyone address this before; I wonder how the Woodiwiss family has handled it.

My Dad spent almost every morning for several years during his 80s stopping into a McDonalds in Sturbridge, MA for coffee and conversation. Originally, the group met a Burger King but when the price of Senior coffee increased and they were made to feel unwelcome by management, they moved to Mc D's. I was grateful for the friends he made there because he lived out in the country by himself. These people watched out for one another and it provided a bright spot in their day. They didn't linger into the lunch hour and the manager was kind. He had no interest in the senior center but loved this daily visit. My sister and I accompanied him when we visited and it seemed that everyone knew us. This doesn't only happen in urban areas. The interaction is great for these elderly people wherever they live. And many McDonald's have been able to compromise with these individuals so needs are met on both sides.

I agree with commenter who noted that it seemed as if it was in the last paragraph or two of a David Brooks column that his point really resides. Brooks is for charter schools and, evidently, against public employees. So I googled charter schools wondering why rich people were suddenly interested in inner cities.

A site by Jonathan Turley explained a lot to me. There is something called the New Market Tax Credit where lenders to charter school construction can double their money in seven years. It is ,according to Mr. Turley, "used heavily for charter schools". It is a 39% tax credit. You can also get a tax credit on the money you are lending. So some charter schools have to pay in rents and debt service on the loan.

The rent money comes from the state. Maybe some charter schools do not involve building but they do involve rent and I think they rent from existing schools, taking up valuable needed space.

I just think it would be nice if hedge fund managers and bank executives and wealthy people would be interested in inner cities if quick profits were not involved . It sounds like a complicated issue but it feels a little like robbing Peter to pay Paul.

It would be much better if Mr. Krugman would stop being an uncritical cheerleader for all things Democratic, and try to be a more honest commentator.

Let's stipulate that many Republicans have been sensationalistic in portraying Obamacare as an unmitigated horror story. In this, sadly, they mirrored Democrats who presented their own list of exaggerated or unsupported stories to justify Obamacare.

Let's focus on what we now know.

If it works as intended, Obamacare will make most people pay more for less generous healthcare insurance. Many people will face severely restricted access to doctors and hospitals (the narrow networks). Nothing at all has been done to reduce the overall cost of healthcare, while the federal government is responsible for paying a larger share.

Taking the most generous possible interpretation of the figures Mr. Krugman quotes, less than one third of the vast number of uninsured has gotten coverage, and most of those have gotten it from employers - there's no real connection to Obamacare. Meanwhile, at least two thirds of the supposedly uninsurable have declined to get insurance, even though they now have access to it. The number of real hardship cases may have been close to zero.

The risk of a death spiral in the individual market remains. The individual mandate has been waived, probably forever. The biggest reason to get insurance was to have coverage in case some expensive condition developed - this reason is now gone.

U.S. soldiers were ordered to fight an ill-conceived and poorly prosecuted war, and this rear-guard maneuver on the editorial page will do little to alter the outcome on the ground for Afghan troops when we withdraw form the country. I read a similar op-ed about a month ago in the WSJ by a retired Marine colonel, who worked as private contractor for the Afghan troops. But he predicted, without a modest wing of Black Hawk helicopters and also a detachment of several thousand American military advisers, Afghan troops will probably collapse against Taliban insurgents when we leave the country.
But it's a case of too little, too late, when you factored in the ISIS's decisive victory over Iraqi troops in the battle for Fallujah, which may be a watershed moment in the historical narrative for the region. It all looks rather grim. But when things go gone south in a war, it's a case of too little, too late. The "cakewalk" has turned into a cul-de-sac. I saw this happen in Vietnam after the Tet Offensive of 1968. What can you really do or say at this point?

Mental state of the person in control of Flight 370:
The tasks related to the transponder, ARCS and the 7 or 8 keystrokes required to alter the flight path, appear to be carefully sequenced. Not a 'spur of the moment' decision. Careful and deliberate.
This does not seem to be the mindset, of someone who is preparing to drill the aircraft, into the sea. This would seem to be the mindset, of an individual who has initiated the Phase 1 of a plan to take control of that aircraft and it's passengers, and land at a pre-planned destination.

Motive:
These catastrophic events, involving aircraft - strike me as a desire to seek a 'balance of power'. A pilot & his aircraft vs. a government. It speaks of an individual's attempt at 'liberating' (one's self? passengers?). e.g., does the individual believe he is liberating the passengers from a particular government?
The forward planning, suggests that the 'intent' had been forming for a shorter period of time. And the decision to execute this plan, may have been based on a sequence of events that was ongoing and unfolding - with each flight that this individual took. I am speculating that more time, would have been spent 'practicing' the sequence of tasks. That is what a very methodical person would likely do - practice. What was the triggering event, that suggested 'the time is now'? We should look for headlines of any ongoing trials of political dissident or individual(s) that posed a threat to a government.

"I cannot understand why larger businesses feel that paying their CEOs huge sums of money with plenty of perks precludes paying their line employees well enough to live a decent life."
I can offer you a reason. Firms are "rational" institutions devoid of heart. They pay not out of their "kind" or "evil" heart. They pay their CEOs millions because these individuals have relationships that are hard to replace. They may have links in Washington, links with competitor board room, links with large investors, etc. These relationships rake in billions for the firm, so a couple of hundred million as salary is worth it. For example, I can tell you one thing, for sure. The more spending or regulation by the government, the more important the CEOs become, and the higher will be their salary. Check out which industries pay the highest salaries to the CEOs. No, not the IT or consumer product industries, it is indeed the likes of banking, health care, etc.

Excellently stated! GOP "criticism" of TARP elevates partisan games and lust for power above public good. By fobbing off the lie that the stimulus failed, the GOP undermines a powerful economic tool.

More insidious, the stimulus plan was hatched under President Bush himself, among the few things he got right; i.e., the GOP is criticizing its own plan!

Now where else have we seen this trick?! That's right: criticism of the Affordable Care Act, which might as well be called "Romneycare!"

So let's also be honest about where Mr. Obama did fail: by trying so hard to be a centrist, and relying on Wall Street's own to solve the crisis, Mr. Obama did just enough to pull the economy from the brink, and to bail out Wall Street, but squandered a unique opportunity to transform America's economy and our society with it.

Had the stimulus package been constructed as Paul Krugman and other genuine progressives urged, every U.S. boat would have been lifted, not just Wall Street's yachts. There would have been more jobs, higher wages, better infrastructure, and a more robust treasury capable of paying for all of this.

But Mr. Obama lacked the bold vision for this, hewing instead to the lukewarm plan we got. His reward was to alienate progressives and have the GOP stand his centrism upside down, just as with ACA.

This truly is one of history's great "What if's" and will likely be viewed someday as why Mr. Obama was not the transformational leader many thought he would be.

This was a pretty broad swipe at investment - a couple misconceptions though:
- coupon clippers have not been doing very well considering interest rates are less than inflation
- income from dividends reflects income that's already been taxed once at the corporate level (say an average 20% rate) and capital gains may also include considerable inflation. (my relatives just sold property, realizing a significant gain... but quite a bit went to capital gains and considering they bought it in 1987, their accountant told them it was not a great investment)

It's worth asking if there are fundamental, non-policy reasons for returns going to capital instead of labor. On the business formation side, investors are very picky, demand tough terms and it's difficult to find capital: it's in much shorter supply than ideas and teams.

We've got international competition, so even if the jobs stay here, that keeps the prices down in "traceable" industries. Technology also supports winner take all markets - since *everyone* can access the best XYZ products or services through the net, only the very best make it. And there's a big disparity in pay for those companies that do make it depending on the value add of the employee (those people working at Apple stores aren't getting rich).

Finally, another reason incomes are low is because many of us want to buy cheap stuff at WalMart and get the dollar menu at McDonalds.

A comparable study could be done analyzing racial asymmetries with the museum world's leadership ranks. Alas: we know what that report's findings would show.

But since the Times is on the subject now, why not commission and publish a profile featuring the phenomenal Thelma Golden and the energizing role she's played directing the Studio Museum in Harlem? It's stunning that Golden's career has yet to receive the due it deserves from the Times' culture beat.

Put another way, the arts press in the US could--and should--play a stronger role in generating public knowledge about the intellectual visions that women directors bring to the institutions they lead. If it spotlighted those leaders across the institutional category analyzed in this gender gap study, such coverage would be compelling on two levels.

First, reports from those cultural fronts would outline fascinating trends in art exhibitions across the country. Second, such reportage might reverse the apparent data drought that keeps search committees at "top" museums from compiling more diverse candidate pools when vacancies in their director posts arise.

One should think of the actions of the Russian government now as payback for what happened in the 1990s. Are Americans aware of what happened in that decade? Let me refresh you--Jeffrey Sachs and other advocates of "creative destruction" from the USA went into a weakened, traumatized Russia and strong-armed Moscow into embracing a "privatization on steroids" binge that wreaked havoc with Russia's economy and produced levels of suffering there among ordinary people that Americans today can barely comprehend or understand.

And how did Americans react at the time to all that misery in Russia? With barely disguised glee. People like Daniel Moynihan, the Russophobic politician from New York, went on TV and happily pointed out in circa 1998 that Russia's economy had contracted so much that it was then smaller than the economy of Switzerland. Americans were *happy* about the steep decline of Russian power and influence. Do you think Russians have forgotten about this arrogance and triumphalism among Americans?

The brief era of comity and cooperation between the USA and Russia that arose in the years after 9/11 was a facade that masked feelings of deep-seated anger among Russians regarding how their country had been treated by Washington in the decade after the Cold War's end. This is now a case of chickens coming home to roost. The US government could not resist kicking Russia when it was down 20 years ago. Stupid beyond words for Americans to think nothing of it at the time.

I really would like to know how the middle class is being affected so negatively by the ACA that they can't pay the rent.  I can understand individuals but no a full class. Third, absolutely every single law on every single issue causes displacement.  Just see the effect of the proposed farm bill. The effects of a law are at least double:  the immediate effect and the long-term one. The long-term one, better health of the population and less money spent on doctors may be better for the country.  We will have to wait.  Fourth, as I understand, only businesses with 50 or more workers are obliged to offer insurance so I don't see how a "small business" is affected by the law.

I think we need to de-escalate the recriminations over school-closing decisions. In my city, Knoxville, TN, they didn't close early enough in a situation that sounds a lot like this one. They ended up with kids stranded 4 hours later in 20 school buses all over town. One week and another snowstorm later, schools were closed the night before and the storm came later than predicted.

There's financial pressure to keep schools open, but, on the other hand, safety is at stake. I believe they should err on the side of caution and close schools. Sometimes it will turn out to have been unnecessary, but that is the price that we pay for safety in a world where the weather will never be 100% predictable. Think of it as insurance. I have to check my desire to criticize when the snow doesn't come as predicted. It's strange how strong this desire is. The price of safety is occasional closings that could have been avoided. Employers could help out by being understanding if a parent needs to bring a child to work or miss work because schools have been closed. I don't really see any other solution. I don't think the mayor and superintendent are purposely trying to harm or inconvenience people.

Being raised in an inner city neighborhood and attending desegregated schools throughout my childhood has proven to be one of the best things I could have ever been blessed with. I learned to deal with and get along with people from different backgrounds at an early age which proved to be a huge advantage later on in my professional career. Desegregation has enabled me to love and care for people of all races and economic backgrounds and is the one element above all others that has enabled our country to prosper the way we have.

Currently the inequality that we are experiencing is getting in the way of the progress we have made in this regard and we must find a way to get beyond our ills and ignorance so that we can continue on the path of social and economic progress that the Civil Rights Act has afforded our
citizens.

It would be a shame for us to revert into separate mono cultures being that many of us have overcome the barriers that separate us and are currently benefiting from desegregation. More people of my generation need to speak up daily and convey their experiences and positive energy that they have gained from loving all types of people and maybe we could then continue on our path of prosperity that would include not only the poor but the wealthy as well.

One can only go so far in applying the lessons of a 2000 year old parable to modern society, but I think a few things still ring true.

Self-righteousness hasn't changed a lot in 2000 years. There are still plenty of people who think they're more worthy than others - for a variety of reasons - and like to smugly believe it's all because of their special skills and hard work. The family/community into which they were born plays no role and luck, well they made their own, of course.

Secondly, just as the family in the parable was richer because a wayward son returned, as a country, we are all better when everyone is able to participate in the best this society can offer.

Life is not - or at least it shouldn't be - a zero sum game, but I'm afraid too many people see it this way. If you win (e.g., get health care or food aid) then someone else must lose (e.g., pay more taxes). If we spent more time trying to treat others fairly, and less time worrying about if WE were being treated fairly...ah, but maybe I'm moving from the realm of parables to fantasy.

Hi Eric, My husband and I are really enjoying your wine course.  Tonight with our dinner we drank the Domaine du Clos du Fief/Michel Tête Juliénas 2011.  We thought it was a fun, not too complicated, earthy wine.  It was delicious, and we were amazed that we could get such a good wine for that price.  Our impressions of Beaujolais had been from the Beaujolais nouveau, which we did not particularly care for, but this was very different.  As you suggested, we started by smelling the wine.  The aroma was deep, fruity grape, a lively smell.  The first taste was delicious - very smooth, less grapey than the smell, but very lively.  It was rustic and earthy.  It was very smooth, but with character -- not complicated like the Bordeaux, but a serious wine.  It felt alive and vibrant.  It was easy to drink.  It felt smooth in the mouth.  One sip made us want more.  It was a cheerful, smooth wine, easy in the mouth and easy going down.  Our first impression was that we could drink bottles of this.  When I first tasted it, my instinct was, "Let's order a case."  It would be a wonderful wine to serve with aperitifs or at a party.  It made us feel cheerful and happy, like spring is here.  It was very easy to drink.  It felt good from the beginning to the end, and did not change throughout the meal.

My father is an inspiration for all of us--he tried to retire and drove everyone, including himself, nuts. Then my mom found a newspaper ad for a water engineer, full-time (he was in the past an ME and solar engineer) and they took him on at 70 and trained him. He did beautifully until age 79, when he was killed instantly in an auto accident. He also freelanced weekends and was about to finish a textbook on engineering. At 64, I have quite a role model, and the golf model is light years away, but what a precedent I reach toward as I've given up applying for jobs because of ageism and do what work I can on my own at those few jobs close to my level that don't use age as a determinant.

The point of this study is that you likely didn't need treatment if the cancer wasn't palpable upon a manual exam. Not all cancer kills. Sometimes it goes away. Sometimes it grows so slowly it doesn't matter.  We don't know which cancer is which so we treat it all like it will kill you. We disfigure women, we crash their immune systems until they get nasty infections they cannot fight off, and we subject them to time intensive, uncomfortable, painful procedures. We should be jumping at any opportunity to decrease treatment (and therefore decrease these difficult side effects) while maintaining (or hopefully improving) deaths. And I say this as a nurse who sees many advanced cancer patients at my job.

I highly doubt many workers can afford to stop working, solely because they can now get health insurance apart from a job. You can't pay for rent, utilities and food with health insurance. Those who do leave full time jobs are more likely to be workers 62 and over, who could manage without full time employment (freeing their position to younger workers desperate for good jobs), and many of those having health issues themselves that are worsened by the demands of a full time job. In addition, it finally provides an option for the self-employed, who may be holding on to some kind of a job with a paycheck to retain health insurance, while they try to build a business or consulting practice on the side.

I've never understood why health care should be tied to employment in the first place, nor why there is a pervasive belief that being tied to a job is good for you, as if we are all inherently lazy and slothful, and they only way to keep us on the straight and narrow is to make sure we have to work at 40 hour a week job if we want health care. If you are able to manage your expenses by alternative means (a working spouse, Social Security, part time work, etc.) I can think of many productive and fulfilling activities outside of the realm of the 40 hour week--raising children, volunteering, or finishing an education for a few examples.

The future of the concept of suffering?

The human race so far has had difficulty coming to grips with the concept of suffering--difficulty in MAKING USE of suffering. Generally the situation has been that of a person accidentally thrown into suffering and it has been a toss of the coin whether the person has been driven by such to become a greater, fuller, more realized personality.

The human race's inability so far to MAKE USE of suffering, which is to say come to grips with it in a tip of the balance sense--spread the possibility of making use of it in a general and definite sense--has led to the human race rather searching for happiness, general relief from suffering, as if it cannot be made use of at all.

But of course in certain areas of life and in the life of certain fortunate individuals, suffering has been tamed, so to speak, which is to say is recognized as useful. For example the most driven athletes, or members of the Special Forces, or certain people engaged in the arts, know the value of suffering to really bring out what a person is capable of. In fact a certain amount of suffering is necessary for most anyone to begin to grow.

I suspect education and science of the future will become more sophisticated at determining a person's mental and physical tolerance for pain and drive a person to realization. Combination of smart drugs, Zen method and severity, strenuous lessons (school disciplines), physical activity, nutrition. Pain toward ecstasy of being.

I couldn't agree more. My daughter is a high school junior, heading down the D1 soccer path. When I asked several coaches what they thought of her chances I could feel the years of parental pressures and grandiose expectations in their reactions; and their surprise was palpable when I expressed my preference that she play DIII in college!

I wish other parents were thoughtful about this. They yell instructions from the touchlines, berate their kids for mistakes made on the pitch, and structure their days with no time to be kids. I've seen more than a few parents asked by the referee to leave the field area because of their bad behavior.

One thoughtful coach did approach my daughter after she had a not-so-great game and was in tears. It seemed he saw her talking to me, then her tears, and assumed I was giving her a hard time. In fact I had just told her she actually played pretty well, and was just trying to comfort her. But I was glad the coach checked in with her; it meant a lot to me that his priorities were in the right place.

Why is targeted genetic modification worse than other "natural" accelerated breeding methods, like irradiating the seeds or dousing them with mutagenic chemicals (widely used even in development of "organic" foods worldwide: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation_breeding)? If anything, making a specific modification, the effects of which can be predicted and studied, is *safer* than "natural" evolution, which involves allowing or causing a bunch of random modifications that one doesn't understand to occur, planting the seeds, and hoping that the net effect is positive.

I understand and sympathize with objections to the development of herbicide-resistance genes which allow toxic chemicals to be used more freely in modern farming, but rejecting the entire technique of targeted genetic engineering just because it has the potential to be misused is like refusing to use electricity because it has the potential to electrocute you or start fires if used improperly. Direct genetic modification is a powerful improvement on, rather than a radical departure from, traditional breeding methods, and with proper regulation (e.g., ensuring that farmers contain their GMO crops if there are concerns that such crops are outcompeting other local species), it has the potential to mitigate the tremendous environmental impacts currently involved in global agriculture.

So yes, GM could be a problem, BUT it could also be a solution, if employed and regulated appropriately.

I have to say, one thing that rubbed me the wrong way is the insistence on IUDs as birth control. I agree that birth control needs to be more readily available, not just the pill–but IUDs are not the perfect thing some people paint them as. They are extremely effective, but require the user to be very vigilant in checking its position monthly. This may not be something younger people are comfortable with or can do correctly. They can move pretty easily, especially in younger people (speaking from personal experience with two failed IUDs). I don't know many people my age that have had a successful experience with them, unfortunately.

I agree with the sentiment in that portion of the piece, but all birth controls have their downsides that need to be considered. IUDs may not be the best for teenagers and younger adults. Comprehensive education on all forms is necessary–hormonal and non-hormonal.

The ports in the Crimea are Russia's only access to the Mediterranean. The Crimean peninsula is part of Ukraine. Those ports are of critical strategic value to Russia, not unlike the Panama Canal's importance to the US. When there was instability in the late '80s in Panama, the US invaded that country in Operation Just Cause in order to assure that Canal operations would not be disrupted because the Canal was vital to US military strategic interests. It's the same deal for Russia in this instance. Ukraine is unstable at the moment.

Hopefully, the current US administration can be part of some brokered deal which will allow for a more autonomous Ukraine and continued flow of Russian natural gas to the EU. But that will almost assuredly require Russia maintain control of the Crimean peninsula via either another puppet state or annexation. The former would be better.

As a meat wholesaler in New York City, I have witnessed the contraction in the number of packers which has resulted in less competition. This has been a result of several factors which include the tremendous cost of adding interventions in processing to assure a safe food supply. Additionally, economies of scale have made smaller packers unprofitable and unable to compete with larger operations. This phenomenon has forced the smaller packers to either sell out or close. Add in extra intrusive government regulations and the industry is faced with a situation which precludes smaller, independent processors.
The same circumstance is also occurring with meat distributors as small independent jobbers and butcher shops are unable to compete with Sysco or US Food Service. The big keep getting bigger as smaller operations are phasing out.

Forty five years ago I was imprisoned for the act of refusing to cooperate with the draft. At various times during my stay in federal prison, I violated rules simply because of an unwillingness to continually go along with the arbitrary rules of the incarceration so that I could get along. For refusing to line up for count, I would be taken to the hole for 3 days to a week.
I believe I am a fairly same person, but every trip to the hole eventually led me to hallucinations. I can still remember the vivid sense of a monster stomping over the hills, coming closer. Or, of a weird god-like creature in Babylonian headdress joining me in my cell. But, unlike most people confined to solitary, I remained somewhat in control. I could agree to cooperate and be released back to general population. When I began to hallucinate, I also began to bargain to get out of the hole. If I had not, I hate to imagine what the effects would have been to spend months or years in the truly awful confines of a small room, cut off from all but the most brutish human contact. It will drive you crazy.
Perfectly said. Thanks for the laugh.

Ethically this all reminds one of the justifications for maintaining black slavery before the civil war, that it was necessary so the country could have cheap cotton cloth and tobacco. David Letterman is nothing less than the father of modern, post 1980 comedy.

Brilliantly edgy, snarky, subversive, ironic and painfully self aware, he pushed the boundaries of what comedy could be on network television.

I always viewed Dave as the ultimate "outsider" who sneaked in through the back door and never left. He never seemed completely "at home" as the center of attention, so he refashioned the conventions of the talk show to fit his personality.

I loved him because he always seemed so ill at ease interviewing people, he was not smooth like a Carson, not the ultimate cocktail party guest.

He was always a bit cranky and mean, which is why he needed his own show, he was not a fit for the "Tonight Show".

He needed to be his own man, and thank god he did.

Long live David Letterman, the greatest late night host of them all.

I'll miss you.

Two years ago, I lived in midtown. I used to walk by Random House every day on my way home from work. Whenever I was looking to buy a book, I'd have to get on the subway to get down to the Strand or Barnes & Noble in Union Square. I didn't understand why the publishers weren't doing more to promote themselves in some kind of retail literary mecca in their own neighborhood. They seemed the only ones able to afford the midtown rents. People want entertainment and spectacle -- if a party has deep enough pockets, they can spend such money on a retail "experience," if only for promotional purposes. It's not like publishers don't understand promotions and publicity.

I stopped using Amazon years ago because of the way the company has gradually gobbled up culture as a precious thing. As a result for me, books are more expensive, and sometimes harder to find -- and I buy far fewer of them than I'd like -- but that all ends up making me appreciate it more. Cheap culture is what people consume; cheap culture is what people have ended up with. Literature, unfortunately, doesn't fall well into cheap culture--unless it's a magnificent tweet or a gripping blog entry (said tongue-in-cheek).

In our interest in ongoing education, we felt lucky to find the 2009 Bernadotte after hordes NY Times sophisticates raided the shelves of every liquor store within 50 miles. I've been a casual wino & Sophia loves her wine. The idea that we can learn together is great.

The Bordeaux tasting... First, since I'm in a transitional stage in my mouth (7 implants after 11 extractions, instead of other more chewable alternatives, we cooked up a delicous meatloaf garnished with onions, potatoes and peas.

Pre-meatloaf
Aromas - Sophia found it smoky while I settled on pungent. A neighbor, Carmine, stopped by and said he felt the scent of berries.
Flavors - Sophia's word was savory while I went for fruity & dry. Carmine went for woody and then refined it to oaky.
Texture - Both Sophia & Carmine said they felt the tannins and my words were smoky & stiff.

Eating evaluations...
Aroma... Sophia & I both agreed that the aroma intensified as we ate. Whether this was due to the food or simply to the length of time it was decanted, we can't say. However, it was considerably stronger and we liked it.
Flavor... Sophia's was enhanced while mine seemed softer.
Texture... Again Sophia's sense was one of more intensity while I found it both smoother and deeper (possibly richer).

Sediment? Yes, I noticed some as we got deeper into the bottle.

I'd say we both learned a lot from the experience and look forward to the next step in our fermentation education.

We had a challenge finding any Haut Medoc wine let alone the three recommendations. After much searching we finally found a dusty lone bottle of CHATEAU STE GEMME HAUTE MEDOC 2009 for $30.

This was our first introduction to Bordeaux wines. What a treat! This is our report– by two “unschooled” wine lovers.

We uncorked with a little trepidation as we had read in a review that the wine had a “barnyard” aroma. We were pleasantly surprised – the fragrance was good – a slight scent of wet wood - no “fruitiness” detected.

The initial sip (before decanting) was tingly on the tongue and lips – a bit of pepper taste and alcohol. The color was dark red.

We decanted for an hour before pouring our first full glass. The taste was smooth and wet. We thought the wine was acidic, medium body, more savory than fruity (did not detect the fruity taste described by some reviewers). We did not think the wine was overly tannic.

The wine proved to be an excellent match for our dinner – grilled herb marinated lamb chops and potatoes au gratin and continued to improve as the meal progressed. Umm, good! Wine also went well with hors d’oeuvres – cheese straws – and as a sipping wine after dinner. With French Café music in the background, we began at 6pm and finished the last drop around midnight. A memorable evening!

We enjoyed the Chateau Sociando Mallot with a dinner of marinated and grilled skirt steak.  Although decanted and allowed to sit for 30 minutes before dinner, the initial taste was still a bit sharp.  As dinner progressed, the wine tasted more savory and became much smoother.  A second bottle decanted at the same time as the first was even more enjoyable demonstrating a very pleasant finish probably as result of the stand time.  We characterized this wine as not having strong fruit flavor, but did experience a cedar oak hint early in the evening.  Overall very enjoyable with a strongly seasoned meal.

I can't weigh in on whether it is a forgery or not, but the reasons given by the Brown U prof that it is a forgery - bad grammar, repetition of other work, bad writing - aren't convincing. The "author" could have been illiterate and copied, as monks later did in Latin, what others wrote but miscopied. This would also account for the "exact" words used by Thomas, or the oral tradition could have resulted in using the words of Thomas with some mistakes.

As for debating the truth of any of this, we really can't tell much what is fact and fiction about the life of Jesus. Much of it could be along the lines of Kazanzakis' "last temptation of Christ" - stories with various purposes but not necessarily history. The bottom line, however, is that whether Jesus had female disciples or even a wife should be irrelevant in terms of our behavior - the lessons meant for us, along with those of the Jewish bible, don't change, though the times have changed in terms of women being taken seriously in leadership roles.

To my mind, the three elemental political goods that must be in balance are freedom, equality, and order. In the US, the need for order is - thankfully - taken for granted because we have it, and we have it because the Founders recognized the need for it and provided for it. The Declaration of Independence states explicitly that the purpose of government - order - is to secure rights to freedom and equality, and the the Constitution - a system of order - explicitly states in the preamble the goals that system is "ordained and established" to achieve.

In Jewish - and, by inheritance, Christian - tradition, the Noahic covenant, binding on all humanity, includes a commandment to establish of fair and honest courts of justice. Article 8 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights states, "Everyone has the right to an effective remedy by the competent national tribunals for acts violating the fundamental rights granted him by the constitution or by law." It's a scandal that so many are denied what has to be regarded as the most basic human right.

NYT has a short, but interesting article on the real issue at hand and maybe the topic of this post, farming policy. (Maybe the article is longer in the paper version, but I'd have to go outside and get it.)

"Farm Bill Reflects Shifting American Menu and a Senator’s Persistent Tilling"
http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/09/us/politics/farm-bill-reflects-shiftin...

Regardless of climate or energy or water, our agriculture policy is hopefully moving towards better use of the land. To take advantage of areas with good soil and plenty of moisture. Instead of moving water from one region to another.

Maybe we should move farmers instead of crops. About 20 percent of our total electricity generated is used for pumping water around. (btw, the energy put into reverse osmosis, a common desalination technology at this time, is for driving high pressure pumps.) Meanwhile, we're increasing electricity generations with shale gas. We'll be selling shale gas to Europe and Asia soon. Shale gas extraction is expensive and limited in extractability. Food prices are dependent on shale gas based on electricity and fertilizer manufacturing. For some reason, it seems like our best and brightest don't have a plan. Or if they do have a plan, it's not in the interest of those who aren't considered the best and brightest.

As an Indian, I have always been a little ambivalent on the issue of banning a book, because it offends religious or other sentiments. This is not the first, there was the Satanic Verses, a book about Shivaji etc. On one hand, one subscribes to the liberal view of free speech, but on the other hand, one also realizes that we live in a developing country where passions are easily inflamed. If there are riots, and a hundred people are killed, is it a fair trade-off for the right to free speech. Liberals typically say yes, but try asking people whose family members are killed in those riots. Free speech is good, but you need other things to be in place as well. You either need a population that appreciates, respects and wants it, or you need to be able to back it up with good of law and order. I'm not sure India is there yet.

The view I think is correct on this issue, is Michelle Goldberg's in The Nation:

"At the same time, though, a CEO is not an ordinary employee—he or she is a leader and a symbol. If employees believe that their leader disdains their families and rejects their values, it damages morale. From within my world, most of you miss the point. Creativity is a value, and to be creative one's underlying values must support the value of creativity. Our system of valuing must be congruent. Consider how we evolve and transform, values- and process-wise.
In earliest years we favor emulation; we copy the surrounding world, dad, mom, teachers, god. He said, she said, therefore I do and say. Hierarchy-premised construct, our earliest domain of learning, creativity not compatible.
Later we struggle against heavy odds to value equality and questioning, a fundamentally different domain of learning in parallel. Creativity is compatible, can flourish, but only through the fundamentally more mature process/domain of learning (DOL).
Culturally we are not "there" yet, too much in love with earlier learning. 1st DOL delivers power to groups; 2nd DOL delivers power to self. Self then takes transformed learning back to groups -- IF they will listen. Both domains are needed, but in 50/50 balance for flexible power. Comparisons FROM 2nd to first is how we choose best quality in the moment. I view part of maturity as the separation between domains of learning, while separation occurs as we learn how to switch in preferred behaviors.
Last points: violence is a naturally evolving value in our 1st DOL, while in our second domain, violence cannot evolve. Similarly, a belief in God can evolve within 1st DOL, whereas a belief in self as ultimate authority occurs in 2nd DOL.

The article, and most of the comments, completely miss the point.  The Northwestern football players aren't asking for money.  They acknowledge that they're already compensated with full-ride scholarships worth about $60,000 per year.  They want to organize a union to be able to negotiate over working conditions--things like practice schedules and workout schedules that are now dictated by coaches, often to the detriment of the athletes' academic aspirations.  And they want better long-term health care.  These young men are putting their bodies on the line in a sport with extremely high injury rates.  Some suffer debilitating injuries while in college; some of those injuries persist long after they've left college, in some cases for a lifetime. Others suffer brain injuries from concussions that may not become debilitating until years later, long after the university has disclaimed any responsibility for their medical care.  Recognition that they are employees would at a minimum require the university to pay into the worker's compensation system and make the players eligible for worker's compensation benefits, and a union would give them the ability to bargain for long-term disability insurance benefits.  Others are eager to depict this as a fight over cash compensation for college athletes, but that's not what the Northwestern football players are seeking.

I had the Sociando-Mallet over the weekend with a delicious rib-eye in a bordelaise sauce. After decanting 2+ hours, an aroma of blackberries was evident straight out of the decanter. Once poured into glass, however, the fruit almost disappeared and the oak dominated. I felt as if I was smelling a handful of saw dust.
On the palate, there was a hint of sour rather than sweet blackberry fruit but most of it was masked by the astringent tannins. I detected the bitterness, if not the flavor, of a green bell pepper. While very tannic, the wine was also quite acidic, but not too much so.
During the meal, the blackberry fruit was just a touch more evident. I would not describe the wine as sweet or fruity but I am not sure I would say it was savory either. The tannic aspect of the wine was its most prevalent feature even if it diminished slightly with the meal. The acidity appeared to increase with the meal and gave the wine a fresh feeling despite the pervasive tannins. A hint of spiciness also appeared toward the end of the meal that was not noticed earlier.
Despite the fact that the wine did not seem ready to show its true potential, I enjoyed this exercise immensely and look forward to the next bottle. I think it was wise to instruct us to focus on basic elements like whether the wine was sweet or savory and tannic or acidic and I will continue to do that. Searching for flavors like nutmeg and tobacco in wine, while interesting, is probably not the best way to start.

Kevin,

A privately-held corporate legal structure is a thin veil separating the underlying business entity from its owner(s). In this sense to say that the owner can have religious beliefs but what he owns cannot - is a distinction without a difference. He should have the right to do with that which he owns as the Constitution guarantees.

To accept Ms. Greenhouse's reasoning is to deny the Amish the right to school their children in accordance with their beliefs. If you allow them this right, what won't they demand next as their special right which you or I might deem harmful to their children's interests?

Or how about conscientious objection? If you allow one person to avoid the draft (when we had it) based on beliefs, the result is to harm another at the margin, who will need to risk his life in the conscientious objector's stead.

Ms. Greenhouse's logic ultimately leads to a reductio ad absurdam, in which the Constitutional free exercise guarantee effectively is nullified by way of comparisons spiraling downward to an abhorrent pit. If you can deny women contraception based on religious belief, why can't you refuse to hire blacks or Jews or, to take Ms. Greenhouse's example, gays, or...

The answer, obviously, is that the Supreme Court exists in important part to make distinctions and draw the line where required.

Obviously it's the Court's job to make distinctions and decide where to draw the line.

I question the colloquial concept of redistribution. Conventionally, redistribution means taxing - taking part of "what one earns" - and spending. So when the word "redistribution" is invoked, it is associated with a negative emotional sense; they're "taking my money".

But I argue that all economic systems are 100 percent redistributive. The inputs are, crudely, work and capital. The outputs are income and products. The formula that translates inputs to outputs *distributes* the benefits of the activity.

Now, Professor Reich demonstrated that the formula has changed over the years (link follows below). From World War II until the mid 1970's, income was broadly distributed, median pay marched alongside productivity. Since that time, essentially all productivity gains have translated into income for the top. This is a stark example of the distribution function changing.

Recent work by Thomas Piketty (his book "Capital in the Twenty-First Century" is due out this month) suggests that the flatline distribution of the most recent 40 years is the norm for capitalism, and the 1940's-70's version is a historical outlier, caused by uniquely disruptive global recession and war. If this is true, it is fair to ask whether so-called "free market" capitalism is at odds with America's founding desire to secure the blessings of liberty, if such blessings are to be experienced by all Americans.

This Republican plan reads like Obamacare, but with some added sweeteners for the insurance companies and considerable added costs for the victims --- er, insured. It amounts to a partial rollback of the ACA instead of the complete one that the Republican-controlled House voted for over 40 times.

The Republican desire to replace the insurance subsidies with tax credits is typical of them. For a family with median income of around $50,000, or lower, a tax credit is of limited value, since often it could not be entirely claimed. On the other hand, those in higher brackets could claim the full amount.
Taxing 35 percent of employer-paid insurance would partially compensate for this, but nearly everyone would take a hit. Supposedly, Republicans are opposed to raising taxes?

Given this misnamed alternative, the ACA is clearly preferable. But we'd be best off to scrap the whole business with insurance companies and go to single-payer "Medicare for All." There would likely be at least a 30 percent reduction in our total national medical costs.

Education is more complex than just learning how to read and write and do some math; in other words, it goes far beyond 'instruction' in school. It may not be applicable in the U.S., but in Bolivia, as parents use their children in the fields (they routinely remove kids from school during harvest), it was found very useful to pay parents a small stipend...as long as they allow students to attend school uninterrupted. Now, if we encounter  student absenteeism due to financial constraints, or even if present in class but with an absent mind for lack of food, that may be solved with relative ease. Society is indeed a living laboratory, valuable input may result in valuable output. Or not. Worth the effort of course.

My grandma made gefilte fish from carp. I remember them swimming in the bathtub before she killed them (broke them backs with a sharp slap against the side of the tube). She also stuffed the forcemeat back into the fishes heads. This must be a traditional recipe; I was served it in Israel 40 years ago, but I rarely see it today.

Carp is really THE authentic gefilte fish, but it is not to American tastes. It is a very gamey, strong-tasting fish. That's why we switched to whitefish -- it's bland. It's like a McDonald's fish patty, smooth and flavorless.

Nobody in my family is willing to do all the work of real gefilte fish, we are eating the jarred stuff per usual. It is not in short supply though it has gotten a bit expensive in the last few years.

We are all prodigals, as Christians, as we are all sinners. The Pope, when asked how he thought of himself, responded: "a sinner."

That being the case, what can it even mean to 'have done everything right'? Does someone graduate from high school without parents who have devoted themselves to us, without a high school to go to, without being in the world in 2014 & not 1914 when few graduated from high school? "We all stand on the shoulders of giants," as the saying goes & no one is in a position to say they have 'done everything right' by themselves.

Which is what the father in the parable tells the good son.

There is no 'deserving' son in this tale, only one who knows he is a sinner & one who does not. God's grace comes to both, — both undeserving. It is in the knowledge of our unworthiness, our sinfulness, that we can humble ourselves to serve others, for the bounty we have has come to us in spite of our blame. The younger son has learned this lesson. Has the elder?

I was a loadmaster with the 19th Air Commando's. They seemed too busy working their lush rice paddies, fishing or maybe playing with their kids. It seemed an idillic life, yet one find day all that was left after B52's carpet bombed was scorched earth. Johnson was the monster who lied us into that phony war. Except for the young men, mostly black, who were drafted, we were all, maybe a few reluctantly, guilty of crimes against humanity.

I have a dog in this race, as it were, because a year ago we bought a new GM car, first time ever, on the strength of the "new GM" and their new models. I was receptive to finally buying American, and the Buick Encore really fit the bill. (It actually has much less North American content than the Acura it replaced, but never mind.)

So this crisis has both given me the willies (Would GM tell me if my car was going to kill me?) but also made me realize that the fact of the GM bailout gives me an even stronger sense of a stake in GM. On one hand I feel duped of course; if the Cobalt crime (yeah, it's a crime) had come out a year ago I'd be driving a Toyota. But even more, I feel that GM has already been agreed as too-important-to-fail. We all invested millions to keep it going. So we need to make it work if we can.

We (i.e. our government) need to REQUIRE that Mary Barra 1) take responsibility for changing GM in response to this crime, 2) specify, in appropriate detail and within a reasonable timeframe, what changes she is going to make 3) establish factual benchmarks of progress, and 4) make regular reports against them, with criminal liability for telling the truth.

If they still can't make both a decent car and a decent profit after that, then I say let them sink. It turns out, the bailout was *not* GM's near-death moment - this is. Either GM demonstrates it can become a decent company - or it's dead.

I didn't ask my doctor doubt  low T., he asked me. In discussing my depression and lack of energy with him--he is a urologist-- he asked if I'd ever been tested for testosterone levels. I told him I had not, and didn't know the first thing about it. That weekend he sent me an email, telling me my levels were dangerously, off the charts, low. I see a urologist regularly for an unrelated condition. I had also recently been diagnosed with depression and was newly on meds. But somehow it just wasn't doing the trick. I thus began the treatments, which slowly brought back some life into me. Today, I give myself shots every two weeks and still, it is intermittent at best and not a cure all. I am in my late 50s and a bit overweight, but at the same time extremely athletic--I ski, cross country ski, lift weights, do yoga and sweat-inducing cardiac exercises 3 or 4 times a week. I'm back working out regularly when a year ago I had a hard time motivating myself to go for a walk. BTW, my wife buys all natural food products, much to the chagrin of my wallet. And no, I don't feel exploited at all.

Let's see. We have 8 million people in NYC, perhaps 5 to 6 million of them crossing streets on any given day, this against hundreds of thousands (at the very least) of vehicles operating on those same streets. So, 176 pedestrian deaths in 2013 comes down to about one death every two days - and every two days 10 or 12 million folks take their lives in their hands by crossing streets against maybe over a million cabs, buses, trucks, automobiles and bicycles. Sounds pretty safe to me. We had more than double that amount of murders in NYC last year, and city officials are falling all over themselves to congratulate each other on that figure. Maybe we should try bringing the murder rate down to 176 and raising the pedestrian death rate to 342. It certainly makes sense from the standpoint of the numbers involved. Don't get mad, folks, it's just a joke, but in an age of government regulation of 16-ounce soft drinks and wanting to close schools every time two inches of snow are predicted, it's no wonder we are talking about ticketing jaywalkers. In WWII military planes were equipped with beepers that were constructed to submerge at the depth of the deep sound channel,where the sound velocity is a minimum. Because sound “rays” always tend to bend away from regions of higher sound velocity, a wave directed upwards from the sound channel axis will be refracted back down again – and a wave directed downwards will be bent upwards. Thus, sound paths from sources in the deep sound channel weave back and forth across the channel axis and – because they become “trapped” in a deep ocean layer away from the surface or bottom – can travel long distances with minimum attenuation.  Thus shot down pilots could be quickly found.  Could such device be put on contemporary planes?

One very dry year by itself cannot be blamed on climate change, but the longer-term trend in California and much of the West is toward greater warmth and dryness, and that's a likely result of increased global warming. Climate scientists have a word for it, "desertification," and that's what appears to gradually be happening in much of the West. The Sonoran and Mojave Deserts of SE California, southern Arizona and New Mexico, are gradually expanding northward.

California's elaborate water system was built when the climate was generally wetter and population and agricultural development were smaller. The increased population and development are straining the system even in "normal" years. But the climate is slowly shifting away from what used to be normal.

One possible solution, short of abandoning farmland, is a massive desalinization program, using water from the Pacific. But little has been done other than a few pilot programs. If California wants to prepare itself for a drier and hotter future, it should give high priority to such a program. The severity of the current drought should provide the needed impetus.

"Would we become a society where the mothers in the 1% pay the 99% to carry their babies to term; some slopes are indeed slippery."

Oh, nonsense. The overwhelming majority of women (at least, those who want kids) want to carry and give birth to their own child whenever possible. Many infertile women mourn their inability to experience pregnancy and childbirth, even if they end up having children by other means. It's a deep-seated desire for many women.

Surrogacy has been around for a while now, and it's typically used either by same-sex couples or in cases where a woman can't physically carry a pregnancy to term.

I haven't seen ANY evidence that otherwise physically able women are hiring surrogates, because they just don't "feel like" going through pregnancy and childbirth. And I really don't see that happening in large numbers, ever-- it's just not human nature.

I also haven't seen any evidence that surrogates are more likely to abuse drugs or alcohol (or otherwise fail to take care of themselves during pregnancy) than other pregnant women. If anything, they tend to be pretty well educated women who enjoy the process of pregnancy and are altruistic enough to help out another family-- they're probably MORE likely to take care of themselves than the average US mother.

And so what if those babies end up being bottle fed? So are plenty of babies who are born the "traditional" way, and they're perfectly fine.

With the exception of the third (teaching + research) track, the idea of a 'tenure for teaching' track has been suggested many times before. What's new here are the clueless throwaway lines like:

"If research professors didn’t teach, administrative duties wouldn’t impede their work."

Um, no, in fact, admin duties (committee service, budget reconciliation, etc. etc. etc.) have nothing to do with teaching, and many result entirely from research.

"Replacing adjuncts with tenured teachers would cost more, but there are ways to offset that, perhaps by funding more research with grants."

Most research, especially in science and engineering, is already paid for with grants. [Competitive external] grants to do research are budgeted for research, not teaching. Grants do not 'free up' money that could be spent on teaching activities; most grants actually lose the University money, via either matching funds or indirect costs. In addition, the total [national] pool of grant money is basically fixed.

We are big University of Wisconsin sports fans and attend many football games each fall. I believe unique to UW is the fact that three sports teams (football, basketball and hockey) make money for the school, which I don't believe is the case at most other schools. The reason these teams kick-in to the school's coffers is the simple fact that fans attend games. A work stoppage on the part of any team would kill attendance, and not long thereafter, profitability. Those who are in favor or unionizing college teams need to pay attention to what has happened in professional baseball, and so often in the corporate world. Players and workers cheer when their union bosses negotiate higher pay and economic benefits, then cry when attendance falls, or when their jobs leave town.
Give some thought to how this would translate to college athletics, and it's easy to see how damaging this brand of organized labor could be.
Don't blame the ACA for the fact that you have a bloodthirsty boss.

I was pleased that you chose a Sociando-Mallet as one of the three Bordeaux. In 1985, when I was just starting to buy wine, I was seduced by Kermit Lynch's description of the 1982 Sociando and bought a case. The salesman told me to cellar it until at least 2000. What if I want to taste it now, I asked. "Open a bottle, let it breathe for three days, and serve it with wild boar." We skipped the cinghiale but opened and enjoyed a bottle when my parents visited for our wedding that year.
I went back to Kermit the next year for a case of the '83, which he described as Mozart to the earlier wine's Beethoven. Over the years, we've drunk the wine on rare occasions. After Asimov's article, I found one last bottle of '82 and several '83's, so I invited a few wine-drinking friends over. Both wines were still superb, the '82 earthy and sublime, the '83 more fruity and fresh. As for price, the '82 cost me $72, the '83 $98 - per case! Truly a wine I will never forget.

Thank you for this Op-Doc. I thought I was the only one who found these alarms both troublesome and painful.

I have a condition called hyperacusis. This means I have a hyper sensitivity to certain frequencies and volumes of sound. Many loud and/or high frequency sounds give me a great deal of physical pain. Exposure can also cause a worsening of my condition. I find the emergency exit door alarms excruciating. The sound they make is the most painful sound I experience in New York. This is not an exaggeration.

My condition was caused by ambient exposure to loud, high frequency sounds. I'm not a musician nor do I work in an especially noisy environment. I'm just a resident of NYC, and at some point over the last 14 years my exposure to loud ambient sounds damaged my ears sufficiently to leave me suffering from this condition. I may have a genetic predisposition - no one knows - but my hyperacusis is very real and very painful.

I think it's difficult for people who don't experience pain with sound to empathize with those of us who do. My best friend told me that for many years she though people who covered their ears in the presence of noise were being whiny and childish. It had never occurred to her that they may experience sound in a different what then she does.

If we cannot remove the alarms, could they be softened into a range that is not so loud, high pitched and damaging?

Sometimes it's not apathy, but fatigue. I have been active in politics since 1964 and have never missed an election since my first in 1972. I am a veteran in a military family. We choose to live our lives as explorers, not as profiteers.

But I'm tired. Tired of hearing my brother-in-law, an Annapolis graduate, spout Fox News nonsense. I'm tired of having our language manipulated so that the Estate Tax becomes a Death Tax. I'm tired of turning on the TV and hear a politician described as "pro abortion". I'm tired of fighting to be heard over the megaphones of the wealthy.

I'm tired.

I want to pass the torch to a younger generation, but the politics of the last 30 years has made them cynical and they don't believe their votes matter and that all politicians, left and right, are identically corrupt.

And who can blame them?

I'm tired of caring for my wife, stolen from me by Alzheimer's, and using up all of our savings and retirement. I'm tired, but can no longer retire.

It's not apathy that makes me tune out the ugly politics of the day. I care.

I'm just tired.

This is very damning. If the production of the switch changed sometime in 2006-07, that means the problem was known and a correction was implemented. A recall should have happened then and there.

If those defective switches were used after the change was made, that is even worse. Parts are not manufactured a few at a time. The customer (GM) puts in an order for a zillion at a time to reduce production costs. I would venture to guess that GM and/or Delphi were holding a huge inventory of bad switches and wanted to use them up instead of junk them. If that happened, that is even worse.

I am deeply saddened to see how these events are unfolding as I sincerely want GM to thrive as a bedrock of US manufacturing. But corporate greed and pressure for profits apparently had infected GM management just as it did the Wall Street Banks. Financial malfeasance costs people their money, but manufacturing malfeasance can cost people their lives. I'm an engineer and am doubly disappointed that none of the engineers who knew didn't blow the whistle on this. No job is worth someones life. Very sad. Very sad.

Let the market decide. No one company, not even Google, is in a position of buying out connections end-to-end. Sure, Comcast has gotten itself a bigger portion of the access network aka the last mile, but there's a lot more than that i.e. the first mile, and the several thousand miles in between.

Viewed objectively, Comcast's business moves make perfect sense. They are in the access business, so what's wrong with getting more access business? Give me a break! Would there be a fuss if McDonalds bought Burger King? Would that cause potato farmers in Idaho to get wary? If as a result, burgers costed more and some of us of switched to chicken, others turned vegan, would that be bad? Of course not!

Let the market decide. Mr. Wheeler got his photo published in the NYT and Google got it's press release (I'll admit I like this version of Google Glass better). Now let's move on.

I'm a healthy 73 yr old on Medicare. My income is very tight. I've always done what was right, saving for retirement. With interest rates so low, I'm in a tough situation. All my medical costs are going up and my insurance premium, my copays have gone up drastically. My cap has gone up from $3500 to $6500. I'm now extending Dr visits from 3 months to 6 months, and splitting pills as much as possible. All my drugs are generic. All my friends are in the same boat; costs going up drastically. This is an effect of ACA that is being ignored.

Also, Medicaid costs are covered for first 3 yrs; after that, states will have to pay 10% of its cost. With so many signing up for Medicaid, many who can't pay anything, and research published in NYTimes indicating people newly signed up for Medicaid using the system more than before they had insurance, the states will have a greatly increased burden to cover. They will have to either raise taxes or cut health care services. ACA will have a greater negative impact on costs than we now see. It's just common sense, covering more sicker or poorer people is not free; costs will go up and taxes will have to go up.

The term "big data" is useful as a marketing tag or to hype an approach, but conveys nothing accurately or specifically. The use of techniques and approaches using the large scale analysis of very large quantities of data is automatically neither good nor bad and has no easily identifiable number of problems associated with it. It is a new approach made possible by new tools and apparently already joins the nonsense lexicon of opinion pages and headlines, other familiar examples are, cancer cure, futurist, tipping point. It ought to be unnecessary to point out that data, big or little is neither good nor bad, it just is.  Hyping it, or what one does with it, is just marketing, or (self)-promotion.

Thank you, Mr. Nocera, for writing this column. As a civil service therapist, I can attest that what you write is altogether too true. In my 25 year career, I have watched the public resources for the chronically persistently mentally ill shrink to the point where humane treatment where all the needed care is provided is a rarity. What we have is a patchwork of band-aid services that sometimes work but often leave gaping wounds uncovered. Notable examples I have seen in recent years: a paranoid woman who chose wrap herself in newspaper in a dumpster to ward of the cold at night, because her delusions told her that her board and care providers were going to harm her; a 61 year old gravely disabled psychotic woman who was released as 'stable' from a too-brief hospital stay to homelessness in below freezing temperatures, causing her to rapidly decompensate and end up back in the hospital; a severely schizophrenic man charged with 2 counts of assault with a deadly weapon, declared mentally incompetent to stand trial, who was ultimately released from state mental hospital to his elderly mother's custody, with no medications, referrals or follow-up care plan in the community.

Humane treatment, not. Horrifying cases of lack of responsive treatment walk through my treatment doors on a regular basis. Those of us who work in the public sector do the best we can, get burned out by the lack of resources, but still keep trying to help in a system that is seriously broken.

Even the head of the UK's then Financial Services Authority (the lead regulator of the financial system) said in 2009 that large parts of what banks do are socially useless.

The issue is that banks want to be left alone to do as they please, yet resist with all the strength they have - with their political contributions and revolving door lobbyists - the complete separation in ownership of 'normal' banking from their investment and trading activities - because the deposits they gather form a cheap source of funding not only for their lending activities but for their 'casino' operations. Keeping these parts together within the same conglomerate contributes to the too big to fail government subsidy, too big to manage, increased systemic risks and results in a 'heads I win - tails you lose' situation (private gains/socialised losses).

I am afraid pointing out the socially useless activities benefiting traders and having no or a negative economic effect will not change things much - as the issue is that the political system is too much in awe of bankers (such as the god-status of Jamie Dimon), too much in the pocket of their lobbyists, too dependent upon their political contributions and too wedded to the discredited laissez-faire philosophy - and the Supreme Court surely is not helping.

Tom Friedman's characterization of Iran's current attitude toward Israel is both crude and inaccurate. Iran has never threatened to "destroy Israel." This is a piece of cant that has been repeated so often that it constitutes "truth by repetition." Mr. Friedman's piece uses a cheap rhetorical ploy to make his point. It is indeed "cute" to juxtapose Adelson and Iran and thus play to mistaken cultural stereotypes.

Iran has championed the Palestinians and their mistreatment by Israel. It has also defended the Shi'a population in Southern Lebanon that has been attacked in over-the-border raids by Israel in violation of international law. If Israel would resolve the Palestinian issue, Iran would gladly resume diplomatic relations with Tel Aviv, since Iran has no quarrel with the Israeli people, or indeed with Jews. It may be that Sheldon Adelson may destroy Israel by promoting crude right-wing politics directed at the Palestinians, but Iran would applaud the granting of equal rights and independence for Palestinians, and this would effectively end Iran's objections to Israel.

A final point: Iran conducts considerable sub rosa trade with Israel through third parties, and Iranian Jews (and indeed others) can travel to Israel via third countries. The large Iranian Jewish population in Israel are still Iranian identifying with Iranian culture and civilization. There is far more that unites Iranian and Israeli society, but the Palestinian issue is a continual obstacle.

The transponder should include a high overcurrent safety fuze internal to it so it wouldn't burn up if a big problem happens within. But it should also be made impossible to shut off between takeoff and landing -- from wheels up after takeoff to wheels down for landing, or something similar.

I suspect the missing airliner was landed somewhere in or near the Andaman Islands. The airliner's location information via ARCS being used to generate two possible arcs of travel after transponder shutoff could have been generated for some time while the airliner was parked on the ground after a wheels-up belly-landing in a shallow area near a small island's beach, or in a flooded remote rice paddy.
