A native NYer here with a first-hand view of the last half of both the Bloomberg administration & the nascent de Blasio one. I'm a liberal Dem with sympathy for the de Blasio agenda, but oh brother, is the stage being set for giving progessives a bad name! As some noted, to turn policies into reality, actual management or legal skills are a must, but many of the appointees (and the Mayor's Office itself) are currently experiencing quite a shock at the reality of what they've undertaken. It's already getting ugly. While some appointees do have experience, many were marginalized or out of power for a decade or longer, and their style seems to be to roll back the clock...but not in a good way.

From the inside, we've seen little interest at the highest levels in general good governance concerns, respect for conflicts of interest rules, the importance of good urban planning, or the quality-of-life issues, like public parks, that were the hallmark of the Bloomberg administration. Instead, many agencies are being forced to pull down their job postings so de Blasio's campaign staffers can have their pick of important managerial and legal positions regardless of their experience or suitability. A return to past bad practice!

To the extent that "progressive" means "progress," we NYers just replaced the most progressive mayor since La Guardia with a hack with no advanced degree...in law, public administration, or in anything else that matters.

Your assumption that Obama is to blame for the current state of the economy is a false one. You can't rationally blame Obama for lackluster economic growth when the GOP House has rejected every jobs bill he has offered. Obama has asked Congress repeatedly to fund infrastructure repairs to fix our decayed bridges, roads and airports, and every time the House does nothing.

You also can't rationally blame Obama for the job-killing budget cuts the GOP has forced through Congress.

The GOP has intentionally resisted any efforts to grow the economy solely for political reasons, not economic ones, so the real blame belongs with them.

That said, your average voter knows little about economics and the limits of Obama's power to grow the economy without the help of Congress, so it is not surprising that he takes the rap for the weak economy. Obama has also done a poor job of educating the public about the causes of our weak recovery, so in that sense he is to blame for the public's view of the root causes of lackluster growth.

The rich are making more money now than they have before. This is working for them exceedingly well. It's all about getting the most, now, now, now!

The touted Mike Lee proposals have problems not discussed in the article.  First, the tax reform package is clearly aimed at married couples with children in the middle class so who does it benefit?  Based on the latest census data, they account for less than 20% of the population who by all standards, raise children who are most likely to succeed.  It provides little tax relief to the working poor couples or the single parent households who are much more at risk to raise children who will not succeed.  Second, a centerpiece of higher education reform is widening the state's ability to set accreditation standards separate and competitive from the current system.  The major problem with that idea is the logic.  If states or outside sources create an accreditation standard in their small geographical area, how does one evaluate the higher education across the country and compare one institution of higher learning with another?     Third, transportation reform in his bill depends on reducing the federal gas tax and giving the states flexibility to decide whether to raise their state gas tax to make up the shortfall.  Given the current anti tax climate, the likelihood that states would raise their gas taxes to make up the shortfall for the federal dollars they now receive is very small.  Further, what about the federal highway system?  Would states put the same amount of money into repairing and maintaining that system?   I doubt it.

I am not totally convinced that the ACA is the only element that is contributing to the current changes in the practice of medicine. There are powerful economic and technological forces at play here. Including the emergence of big data on the medical horizon and wall street money entering the hospital arena.
Doctors who rely on referrals from other physicians are pretty much done as the big hospital are progressively scooping up all the primary care doctors and creating monopolistic directives to refer "strictly within the network". For example I have witnessed many cardiology practices evaporate overnight. Most cardiologist had then to capitulate and sell to the hospitals. For many of these doctors, joining the hospitals gives them an initial relief. But it is short lived as the new reality of becoming corporate employees may be difficult to adjust to. I am not saying that these changes are good or bad for healthcare: we will wait and watch. What I think is important is to make sure that many of these physicians caught up in these seismic changes do not become demoralized or alienated. When I attend conference on medicine and technology and managed care I see very few doctors. All I meet are young and dynamic people from the finance and technology industry: it almost feels like a new "dotcom" boom: new applications and networks being developed every day. The role of the doctors in this context is to provide the data and to execute the algorithms. Sad.

This is really something.  Since Newtown there have been 33 more public shootings.  When Newtown happened, it seemed like a true turning point for the country.  Surely we would address gun regulation after so much horror and tragedy.  But this has not been the case, and the incidents have become even more commonplace, one could even say, off-the-cuff.  This is where we are headed.  And yet the resounding cry is still that more people should be armed, not less. The judge's conclusion that the Texas law (prohibiting withdrawal of life support from a pregnant patient) doesn't apply to Mrs. Munoz because she is dead is reasonable. It resolves the tension between that law and Texas' recognition of brain death as death.

With deepest respect to Mrs. Munoz and her family, this situation opens a broader question about the balance of rights and interests around dead people. For example, people who need organ transplants don't get them because we have a shortage of organs. Does that mean the state should take organs from dead people against the wishes of their families (or against their own wishes if expressed before death)? Society has said "NO." Is this the proper balance between the rights of the dead (who actually have no rights because they are dead) and the interests of the living who could benefit from the organs? I don't know, but society has clearly answered "YES" because consent to take organs IS required.

The case of Mrs. Munoz is a more immediate version of this question. There is not just the potential for an unidentified person to benefit from a deceased's organs, but an identified life (the fetus) who could have the "benefit" of keeping her dead body functioning.

I think the judge was correct. It was Mr. Munoz's right to make the decision: he is Mrs. Munoz's husband and the father of the fetus. A wrenching decision like this was his to make.

RIP Mrs. Munoz, and G-d bless her family.

To Robert Mitton: I perhaps spoke too strongly when I said that there are "established side-effects" -- I honestly don't have any expertise in this area. But there are definitely *some* studies that show adverse psychological and physical effects (for a summary, see this: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long-term_effects_of_cannabis). My point is that we are uncertain at this point--certainly not certain enough that I would want to administer the drug to my child.

To Frank DeCoster: I have no connection to big pharma. There's a dilemma though: On the one hand, we need science to determine if a drug is effective or not; on the other hand, the people funding much (or most?) of the scientific research in drugs are the pharmaceutical companies, who have a financial interest. It's a tricky situation, but I don't think it makes sense to dismiss arguments merely because they "smell [like] big pharma".

Non-compete clauses (yellow dog clauses) are somewhat tricky, for the reason that it is against public policy to prevent a person from making a living. For this reason California does not recognize a restriction on an employee from quitting and going down the street. Other jurisdictions do, to one extent or another, but no jurisdiction will (because of the public interest inherent in the employee maintaining gainful employment) prevent the employee from working in his field.

Nonetheless, care should be taken when being hired that the confidentiality provisos and IP provisos be carefully drafted, and looked over by an attorney before being signed. A little precaution at this point can save a great deal of grief at the other end.

As one who has written on the Russian emigre thinkers in Paris between the wars, I wonder if one really can drag Berdyaev into what Putin is saying & doing, or for that matter Solovyov, who lived in the 19th c. Solovyov was for the reuniting of the churches and while he saw Russia having a special role in this, was not an extreme political thinker. If anything Berdyaev was for freedom, and was a friend and collaborator of Mother Maria Skobtsova, who hid victims of Nazi oppression in her houses of hospitality and died for this in the camps.He was an enemy of fascism. Illyin is another story. He had to flee France because of his sympathies with the Nazis. Antoine Arjakovsky has brilliantly examined the rich and open attitude of the so called "Paris School" of philosophers and theologians, the Russian emigres in Paris in The Way: Russian Emigre Religious Thinkers and their Journal, Univ. of Notre Dame Press, 2013. If anything it would appear that Putin is selective about his sources for Russian empire and the vision of "Russkiy mir" or Russian world of influence.

Actually, we may NOT be able to do better than McD's. Such places have existed since the beginning of human society. Older people always collected in a warm or shady place, watched the younger people go about their business, offered advice or chided them, often acted as the local pre-school. In my great-grandparents time, it was a place behind the stove in the local mercantile in winter.. in summer it was on the porch. My dad's chosen group hung out at a local golf course. Often groups centered around the parents & former owners of an establishment. My mom preferred the food court at a local mall (now gone), She liked watching the people pass by. Seniors in my area preferred a local park (now taken over by homeless) or a local race track (now gone).  Now, it's all corporate, all business... but more than that. People now look at older people & don't want to be reminded of their own future, should they live so long.  Older people are bothers... reminders... in the way. They need to be pushed off into some unseen place where those who are not old can go visit them if they feel like it, which they don't. While your mother may have done well online, most older people (I'm getting there myself), physically need the human interaction of human beings of various ages. Often all one really needs or wants is to people watch, a senior center with free Internet isn't going to fill that need for most people.

The fallacy here is that we have a "poverty problem." No, we don't.

40 years ago when I was in college studying to be a CPA, I was in poverty. I would have been included in the stats as being "poor." I lived in this "room" in the basement of a house, the place did not even have a bathroom; I had to go to this other part of the house for those functions.

But the rent was $60/month, I could afford that.

And then, I got my accounting degree, got a job with a Big 8 and then I was not in poverty, anymore.

There will always be a classification of people called "poor." As Thomas Sowell has written, do not look at statistics look at individuals. If you do that you can see what really happens is that people are constantly moving in the economic sense. There is no such thing as "America's poor," except in a statistical sense.

But then Lyndon Johnson came along and instituted this "War on Poverty." Which translated into giving poor people $money. And look how that has turned out, almost 50 years later; we still have poor people after spending $Trillions and $Trillions.

We should stop all of these programs for the poor. It is not helping. Just look at the 50 year history.

And we should stop all of the programs for the rich. Farm subsidies, bailouts, flood insurance that list goes on and on as well.

Government should be out of it all.

Give people some credit. I survived poverty and became a CPA. Others can too, if you just treat them as people and not statistics.

Every carbon emission reduction action we could be taking seems to have at least one other significant benefit unrelated to climate change. And virtually all are already happening elsewhere in the world.

More fuel efficient, lower emission cars also are far cheaper to operate and easier on the lungs.

Getting rid of coal power generation means less asthma, less mercury pollution and no river killing ash piles. Other energy sources like natural gas are cheaper and some, like solar and wind are getting there.

Reducing cattle production will reduce morbidity and mortality. Smaller and fewer portions only, vegan diets not required. Vast savings in fresh water for feed and beef processing are another benefit.

HS rail is far more comfortable than car or plane travel, less expensive and you don't have to arrive 2 hours early.

The list goes on.

We paid $68 for our free-range organic turkey last Xmas, and it was incredibly tasty, as well as a completely different shape than a factory-farmed one. It made multiple meals, plus a huge pot of stock/soup, so it amortized out to be fairly cost effective, since we wasted nothing.

The idea of pipelines to solve water problems is simply too expensive and politically fraught, as some of the other replies to this article demonstrate. There is enough water generally everywhere there are people, and most importantly, farms. What is needed is a comprehensive set of laws that allocates both the surface and connected groundwater supplies so that every user knows what their reliable rights are and if they want more reliable rights, they know who to go buy them from.

Lack of integration of ground water supplies with surface water right allocation systems creates a tragedy of the commons where the true value of the resource is not reflected by use. Courage is needed in state legislatures to overcome the entrenched interests that lobby for continued free use of the finite resource of groundwater.
The truly sad part of all this is, there are people who still support Christie! I mean really - wake up people!

I am a recovering addict who has been a Registered Nurse for 23 years and has 16 years clean. I have always been surprised that at the very least when there is an egregious medical error that staff are not drug tested. After reading the 2 prior posts, I felt the need to point out a couple of things. First, the author of the article made a point to say that we need to treat addiction like the chronic disease that it is. I agree 100%. Even nurses do not understand the disease of addiction and can often be judgmental. Second, no matter which type of clinician is practicing that practice always involves patients who put their well-being and lives in our hands.  How would you feel if it was your mother who had been infected with Hepatitis C because an institution chose not to drug test. I am not sure what the best way is to implement more frequent drug testing for healthcare professionals but there is no doubt in my mind that we have a sacred obligation to give our patients safe care.

What about those of us who already have heart disease or have a terrible family history? My husband's mother, aunts and uncles grew up on a farm, eating natural foods and fats and were not overweight because of the hard physical work. All of the five men were dead by fifty and the women before their mid-sixties. The men smoked, but how much more time would not smoking have bought them? Ten years?

In light of that family history, my husband didn't smoke, exercised like a demon and still nearly did a fatal face plant during a run. After his bypass surgery we've stuck to a low saturated fat, whole food vegetarian diet and he's done well for twelve years. He still exercises like a demon.

Isn't it possible that some people have bad genetics with regard to certain fats? They live long enough to produce offspring and then die. Maybe someday we'll be able to find genetic markers and quit making blank statements about which foods are "good" or "bad" for everyone.
Kudos to Obama for taking this on.  And more kudos if he sticks with it instead of just using it as a photo opportunity.

We tasted a 2009 Chateau Beaumont Haute-Medoc. It accompanied a bison burger with caramelized onions and an heirloom tomato. Prior to eating, dark cherries were prominent for both of us in both smell and taste. A slight acidity and stony-ness/earthiness accompanied the dark cherries after the first taste.

When we tasted during the meal, it seemed to lose its initial characteristics but retained the dark cherry taste. We believe that the tomato helped mask the subtle tasting notes. What we found was that after we finished our burger and were comparing notes on our tasting experience, the earthiness became the forward flavor and the fruitless became less prominent. (It became more bland, in our opinion.)

If we were to score this wine, we would give it 3 out of 5 stars. If we were to wait a year or more, we might give it a higher score.

I am becoming more concerned about Putin's activities in Russia. I'm in my early 50s, so I grew up aware of the Cold War (and remember struggling while typing a paper about Kruschchev on a manual typewriter.) I didn't pay much attention to the Cold War because I was a kid and cared more about Lennon than Lenin. When I became a history major, I focused on American History, particularly race relations. I was happy to see the end of the Soviet Union, and noticed that Russians began emigrating to America, but didn't focus on what it all meant.

So now here we are, in 2014, with a Russian threat. And I worry about how the President is going to handle it. Yet I trust that this President will not get us into World War III. For a good portion of my life, the spectre of nuclear war was there. Then after 9/11, it was terrorism that we all feared. Now everything old is new again and Putin is center stage.

This is a time to come together as Americans and rally around our President the way we did after 9/11. Because right after 9/11, I said that I would rally around Bush -- and I'm no fan of his -- because I was and am proud to be an American. Ideally there will be some kind of diplomatic agreement with Putin but I fear that Crimea is not going to be his last attempt to grab land. From what I read in Time Magazine, he longs for the old Soviet Union. So why wouldn't he want to try to recreate the past?

Stand strong, America. Hopefully this will not result in war.

Putin won't quit. He wants the breadbasket of Ukraine and he will get it in the end. He has plans to be the next Czar of Russia and nothing as trifling as Ukainian independence will stop him. Any "common core" is an attempt to impose one narrow point of view. It's Chomskyesque - the manufacture of consent via propaganda, masquerading as objectivity. Understandably, those who disagree with the values being propagated - whether on the right, left, or center - are going to object.

Not very long ago the "shared values of the community" *were* propagated - those of the ruling community, with a canon limited to dead white males. Families had a common core, and they read the same book and talk about it. That book was the Bible - which, it was taught, "containeth all things necessary to salvation."

Now a new ruling community wants to "hand down" - propagandize - *its* values. Nationwide.

The core is "diverse" only because "diversity" has become a selling point - but that diversity is an illusion.

Endless,

If you want to have universal federal standards for everything, including education, that's fine. (That's not the same as what you initially suggested.) But you would have to change the constitution so that there is an actual democracy in this country.

"Ending state's rights" also means that states don't get a vote not proportionate to their populations, so we wouldn't have the Senate and the Electoral College as currently constituted. If you can achieve that, I would be comfortable with you getting a federal carry permit.

Thank you for this. As a regular volunteer in our public library's children's section, I have had a hard time finding "charming" stories that feature minority kids just as kids. There are historical stories about black kids escaping slavery, and asian kids in kimonos with dragons on the silk, and native American kids in traditional garb, but those are not the imagination-expanding type of books you describe. Corduroy is one lovely book with black characters just being people. Unfortunately, it stands out not only because it is so beautiful, but also because it is so rare to see a little black girl in a role every child can relate to. It was one of my two (white) sons' favorites.

I have wondered if it might not be possible to reissue some traditional books with black or asian characters in the place of the white ones. Nothing says "Fancy Nancy" has to be white, or Nate the Great. After all, little black kids don't only live in urban settings, and little hispanic kids don't all live in barrios.

Living in a college town with a large body of foreign graduate students bringing their foreign children into our schools, my children grew up in a miniature United Nations environment. It is very strange to not be able to reflect that diversity in our library.
Well said !

From the fall of Gorbachev to the 2d coming of Putin, American administrations have tried to relegate Russia to the trash heap of history. We seriously underestimated the staying power of the communist party's muscle.

It should be obvious by now that "communism" per se, as a governing ideology, doesn't mean much in Russia or China for that matter. Political parties there are merely a means to organize and stroke the will of the people in support of the ruling oligarchy. Who, despite their tendencies to act more like Columbian drug lords than statesmen on a personal level, for the most part appear to be genuinely proud of Russia and defensive about western efforts to marginalize Russia in world affairs.

No matter that Bush II could see into the soul of Putin I. or not. No matter than Obama believed he could reset relations with Russia without recognizing Putin's stated intent to re-establish Russia as a world power alternative to the United States. and China. Our leaders have been wrong to ignore that Russia views itself as a world power and will act as a viable and powerful alternative to US policy demands.

'Obama and the Democrats had a window to enact a better health care reform that would have been better for the nation and better politically in the long run because we'd all be living the benefits of it.'

Um, no, they didn't -- at least not on the terms you dictate. Between Senator Franken being seated late in the session and Senator Kennedy's death, the window was quite narrow. There were two Senators in the Democratic caucus who made it publicly quite clear they would not support even a public option, let alone anything approaching single payer.

Do the math -- at the time, it took 60 Senators and 218 House Members to pass a law. Those numbers did not exist for single payer in 2010. Or within my lifetime. (I was born during the Kennedy administration.)

The House, with only Democratic votes, barely passed the ACA, and only after rolling back a few things.

The ACA is flawed, but was politically achievable. It accomplished something Presidents had been trying to do for 97 years.

It was forward movement -- progress. Letting the good, or even the better, be the enemy of the perceived perfect is bad governance. We've had way too much of that from the side who wanted no reform and no victories at all the President.

Forward.

Forget the salt; put down sand and drive (and walk) carefully.

As a practicing scientist I find my 'revelations' in greater understandings of the world around me. As a teenager using psychedelic drugs I 'concluded' that I gained different perspectives on everyday matters that I was normally inured to and had not noticed. Despite this perspective, however, there really isn't a Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds.
Low sugar and fatigue combined with modest altitude hypoxia (were you coming from sea level) could have easily caused your hallucinations. Regardless, all matter that you see and feel is manifest energy, as Einstein so famously determined. Were you experiencing this energy on a different level. Perhaps.
But I have had experiences that, as you, remain inexplicable to a hard-core pragmatic scientist such as myself. These involved communicating specific things between myself and another person (usually under duress) that I can only attribute to bizarre electro-chemical links between certain close people. Inexplicable, so far. Mystical, depending on your definition. Intriguing, you bet. Requiring a 'religion'. Nope. But if you consider the near-singularity before the Big Bang as some sort of unifying religion, I can believe in that.

What many commenters seem to forget or want to ignore is that the Internal Revenue Code says in section 501(c)(4) that the non-profit organization must be "operated exclusively for the promotion of social welfare." Unfortunately IRS earlier distorted Congressional intent by defining "exclusively" to include "if it is primarily engaged in promoting in some way the common good and general welfare." Exclusively was watered down to primarily.

But all the commentators and IRS itself should note that the existing regulations state "the promotion of social welfare does not include direct or indirect participation or intervention in political campaigns on behalf of or in opposition to any candidate for public office."

Those who think 501(c)(4) gives them a right to publish attack ads against candidates better read the existing law, and the scandal is that IRS has not enforced the existing Code and regulations and allowed the distortion of social welfare organizations into political attack groups.

What you are labeling the deep self is really the pure self. With the right upbringing every single human can become pure. It is the culture that adds the phony self image that creates a shallow personality on top of the pure self.

In America we bring up our children on the belief that each child is the best. This creates a phony over confidence that leads to a whole lot of problems in life including greed, jealousy, unhappiness etc. All character traits that are missing in 'deep' people.

Another false belief we cultivate is, 'I can if we think we can'. Confidence is essential but not enough to succeed but this belief tends to produce over confidence which is again a negative and harmful trait.

Most grow up to become dual personalities. What happens is that the brain projects its own personality and the mind its own. The mind knows while the brain understands. The core self is an effortless projection of the brain and as in the case of the majority the phony self image projected by the brain runs into its own created troubles it is the mind that struggles to undo the damage.

The Professor ignores one aspect of the historical backdrop to Kennan's thinking. When propounding his containment thesis, Kennan did so during a time of a strong US military, and a combat veteran President (Truman) who believed in taking an unapologetically tough stance with a despot like Stalin. Truman thought Stalin a bully and treated him accordingly. Kennan's approach tacitly assumed an ultimate recourse, failing all else, of decisive use of sustained US military force. Our current policy, that if we use force at all, it will be limited, surgical and brief, is much different. We may be less effective when speaking softly if our adversaries don't believe we carry or will ever use a Big Stick.

Reading about space always reminds me of when I was a child and would sleep walk.

It was mysterious, fascinating and frightening. Just like space.

Had the weapons and materials remained in Ukraine, the current standoff with Russia might have taken on far more dangerous dimensions." Or, alternatively, Putin would not have invaded. Which is why the Iranians will not agree to give up a capability to produce nuclear weapons. And why some factions in South Korea are urging their government to acquire same. And why the Saudis and Egyptians might be tempted should the Iranians go nuclear.

Mr Obama's vision of a nuke-free world is a dangerous illusion. Regardless of what others might argue about fairness, our possessing nukes while denying them to most others has mostly preserved the peace for 70 years. Were we to eliminate them entirely, the first nation who can surreptitiously produce one would have a huge advantage. Which is precisely why in that case someone eventually will.

It seems uncommonly trusting of Japan to simply hand this over. The assumption being that, should China attack it, America will come to the rescue in any and all circumstances, while were Japan to develop nukes, it would be almost a certainty China would not attack. A credit to our reliability as an ally and the value of our nuclear umbrella in preventing dangerous nuclear proliferation.

This article appears only to address the situation in built-from-scratch NYC condos. There is another admittedly complicated species, resulting from a non-eviction plan conversion . A rental building with rent controlled (now very rare) and/or rent stabilized apartments can be "converted" to a condominium through a highly regulated process of offering the apartments for sale via prospectus. Typically they are offered to existing tenants at a seriously discounted insider price and to non-residents at what is intended to be a market price. The catch is that the non-resident buyers cannot evict the current residents of apartments that they buy; those residents retain their well-protected rights as rent stabilized tenants. The conversion plan can proceed when as few as 15% of existing tenants sign up to buy. All of the apartments are sold, but any number of the outside sales may be to entities controlled by members of the "sponsor" of the conversion, aka the seller. This can make the subsequent governance of the condo "interesting" and very different in ways good and bad from a more diverse ownership .

PS. We bought in early 2006 in a non-eviction plan at an insider price in what has turned out to be an increasingly desirable Queens neighborhood. So far, so good, on balance.

People still drive cars that were made during the Jim Crow years. There is no more institutionalized racism (explicit voting restrictions, separate water fountains, separate schools. etc.) That's the good news There is still, however, a great deal of more subtle racism, and even some not-so-subtle. What was done over a period of hundreds of years cannot be undone in fifty. I figure it will take at least two more generations for the wounds to heal, long enough for those who were there, and their children, to die. Harsh? Absolutely. But realistic. That kind of pain gets passed on for a couple of generations before it dissipates.

The important thing now is to preserve as much memory as possible, as a lesson for those who will have no personal memories of what those times were like. If Mississippi wants to build their own version of the Yad Vashem, more power to them. And if segregationists and racists want to add their own voices, so be it. After all, segregation would not have lasted as long as it did had not supposedly reasonable people been convinced that it was right. The generations to come can read their words and laugh at how idiotic they are, and remind themselves never to believe such nonsense ever again.

It's good to point out the Republican falsehoods that attempt to undermine the ACA. But when that dust is cleared, the fact remains that having insurance doesn't give you affordable care. If your household income falls at the median of $52,000, and you have an employer-based bronze plan for your family, you still have annual out-of-pocket expenses at the ruinous rate of about $12,000 a year.

If you have no existing debts, I suppose it would take a while to go bankrupt from racking that amount up every year. But a median-income household with children IS likely to have other debts: one or two car payments, a mortgage, not to mention the desirability of saving for college and retirement. If you consider access to life-preserving care the most fundamental of rights, as I do, "insurance" is a grossly regressive tax.

Inequality of opportunity is very real and brought on by the policies of administrations you have supported over the last 3 decades, starting from the sainted Reagan. This must change or our society may implode. Nobody wants that!

Clearly, when trade agreements are set up between countries of similar standards of living, economies, labour, environmental and patent right standards(Canada, some European countries), they generally speaking, can work OK. As we have seen, time and again, the problem lies when trying to set up these agreements with emerging markets which incorporate little or none of the above conditions. In addition, when all this started and when we were moving, somewhat reluctantly, towards a global economy, the party line was lowering tariff barriers and increasing trade would raise the standard of living for workers in these new markets so they could eventually start buying products made here. Even today after 20 or more years of NAFTA a worker in the Ford plant in Mexico is earning a fraction of what his counterpart is in either the US or Canada, so what was the point?

Unfortunately, for the most part, all it did was allow corporations to move to these low regulatory, low wage markets thus driving down wages and all standards, to ultimately, vastly improve their bottom lines at the expense of millions of jobs here.

As Mr Edsall stated in his column, one must ask the question as to how do you possibly negotiate complex regulatory agreements with a country, for eg. Vietnam and have them continue to operate in an "above board" manner and who monitors these commitments?

My business requires me to be concerned for client and personal security. I cannot believe what the author is paying for security, and what is being overlooked. Use StrongVPN and you can use any open Internet connection as your connection is encrypted. The side benefit is that no ISP knows where you are going. My cost is about $79 per year. Yes, you have to know how to configure it and there is a slight delay as your connection becomes active. Some will say that this can possibly be hacked, but an L2TP connection set to only connect with maximum encryption is more than enough if you are not a high value target.

Next use a personal certificate to encrypt your email, almost free, and can be used with Outlook. If you use any email like gmail, yahoo, AOL, you get the idea, you are a fool. Either pay for an email service or get your own domain name server, total cost $80 per year.

If your computer gets infected with something, it is your fault. Any decent antivirus and having a clue what not to click on should be novice level understanding.

Finally, what is not mentioned is theft of your equipment and what happens to the data. You can use a free program such as TrueCrypt to protect the drive contents. The computer can only be wiped and system reloaded if stolen. Use MS SyncToy, free, to duplicate your data across a few machines and you are safe.

Use no smartphones or tablets except Blackberry for sensitive stuff. They are the only secure system.

Representing the government's view, Maurice Newman, the chairman of the Prime Minister’s Business Advisory Council.  
 
Front page of the national paper The Australian.   
 
QUOTE 
In his marvellous chronicle of human gullibility, "Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds," Charles Mackay wrote:  “Men, it has been well said, think in herds; it will be seen they go mad in herds, while they only recover their senses slowly, one by one.”   
 
It’s a pity Mackay did not live long enough to include anthropogenic global warming in his list of popular delusions.  
 
There has been none bigger.   
 
Australia, too, has become hostage to climate change madness.   
 
For every green job created, two to three jobs are lost in the real economy.   
The scientific delusion, the religion behind the climate crusade, is crumbling.  
97 per cent [of models] were wrong.   
The climate change establishment, through the IPCC, remains intent on exploiting the masses and extracting more money.   
 
The climate change delusion is a gigantic money tree.   
It is a tyranny that, despite its pretensions, favours the rich and politically powerful at the expense of the poor and powerless.   
 
But the madness of the crowds is waning and, as Mackay writes: “Punishment is sure to overtake them sooner or later.”

It is very possible Edaugh... My wife got an excellent promotion that required us to move to where her company's headquarters is located. My company did not have any open jobs in the new city. 10 months later I am still looking. I have a degree in Economics, 10 years professional sales experience and have grown my territories between 10-30% growth year after year. I have a lot of the exact qualities and success employers are looking for which is why I had 8 interviews with fortune 100 companies during my unemployment. I have reached the final interview with every one of them. So why am I still unemployed?

No it is not that I cannot close, you do not achieve 10-30% growth without an ability to close. There are a few reasons which I cannot move around. The main culprit is these companies are filling positions from within. Internal employees are killing my chances, which is a good thing if you can get into one of these companies as job security would be a nice luxury. And when I pursed a job with lower qualification standards the hiring manager felt I was overqualified and would become bored.

The real problem is the creation of new jobs. The job market is moving heads around and not creating new positions. It's unfortunate for someone like myself who has a lot to offer but nowhere to bring my talents. And I am trying diligently: I have 2 recruiters and check job boards daily of 26 companies I am qualified to work for. Unfortunately there is just a lack of jobs.

The yearbooks for my school in a small town in Texas are a true treasure trove of information. Through the 50's until I graduated in 1963, particularly in the 50's, girls disappeared There they are in 10th grade playing basketball, cheerleading or writing stories for the school paper and you to go look them up in 11th grade or 12th grade and they aren't there.

What could have happened to them?

They are the girls who had the misfortune to get pregnant and in 50's and 60's rural Texas, most young women would not have had the financial means or savvy, to either pay for or know how to get an abortion. In fact, it wasn't an option. It was the worst thing that could happen to a girl. And, that 10th grade cheerleader, who never managed to finish high school because she had a baby was always remembered for that.

A big part of the problem in my area (Montgomery AL) is that as late as Monday night, meteorologists were saying clearly that the ice would not hit until noon Tuesday. As a result, schools and businesses, reluctant to close before absolutely necessary, announced they'd be open Tuesday AM, and close at noon. But nasty weather hit hours earlier, about 9:30 Monday morning. My experience was typical: I went to work Tuesday morning and within an hour after I got there, when it became apparent things were worse than expected hours sooner than expected, was sent home when our offices were suddenly closed at about 10:00. Samer thing happened at my daughter's school, which had announced (on Monday) they'd be open until noon on Tuesday, then suddenly after opening onTuesday quickly closed at 10:00 with little if any advance notice, and sent everyone home.

Fortunately, I work about a mile from home, and my daughter got home quickly too. In Birmingham, 90 miles north, it seems the same thing happened but people got caught further from home, and got severely jammed up as a result.

Southerners and their cities & towns are ill prepared for icy weather. But it was more: a combination of inaccurate weather predictions, and schools & businesses riding fuzzy weather forecasts too close to the limit because they were reluctant to close when it might not turn out to have been necessary. Had they announced on Monday they'd be closed on Tuesday, things would have gone MUCH more smoothly.

Except that Ukraine has to do all that it can to block the Russian moves WITHOUT starting a shooting war. Russia want that in order to justify their final invasion which they will inevitably win (Ukraine is just far too outnumbered).

To date, Ukraine has shown remarkable restraint. In Crimea, they have ignored threats and deadlines to surrender their bases while also not shooting back when provoked. It's a clever strategy of forcing Russia to make the first move and thereby surrender what little semblance of international support it may have. It is working, so far, in that the Russian army and militias have remained unable to take control of the military bases.

Ukraine can not win by force of arms, but it can win by embarrassing Russia to the world until the world eventually begins to provide the support Ukraine needs in order to survive. It remains to be seen whether its strategy will win.

I was 12 when President Kennedy was assassinated. Until then I was pretty sure the world's problems had been solved  by the U.S. during and after WWII, but the assassination shook my juvenile worldview. I was casting about for something solid to hold on to, and then the Beatles landed in New York. Call it silly, call it childish, but the Beatles and rock 'n roll got me through those awful teenage years. They're still getting me through some rough times today. It was solid enough to nourished my soul. I can never thank them enough.

"in monetary policy as in so much else, what’s good for oligarchs isn’t good for America"

Is that really true? Suppose you implement a special graduated tax on incomes over $500,000 and you use that to provide a tax credit to households in the bottom 25% earning less than $30,000. These low income households aren't going to hold on to much of this money, so where does the money go? It flows back into the pockets of the 1%.

So, the first order effect, at least, increases the welfare of the population without decreasing the absolute wealth or income of the top 1%. Yes, there may be a 1 year lag between the time the income is removed to the time it is returned.

Meanwhile, the economy would grow by about 3% ($500 billion of increased annual spending in a $15 trillion economy -- your figures may vary) due to increased spending in low income households. That improves hiring and some of the transfer taxes are replaced as the low income households receive wages instead. [The top 1% can also raise wages instead of using a transfer tax.]

So in year two, the transfer tax goes away and the top 1% control a 3% larger economy (3% greater wealth) with a 3% larger income.

What's good for the oligarchs is good for America. The oligarchs just aren't all smart enough to realize it.

House insurance models as to fire are based on actual data, not speculation or conjecture and they operate at fantastic levels of accuracy. Climate models on the other hand operate at less than 2% confidence level. They have various methods of payment, including monthly - don't like your carrier or the price, shop a new one and change.

Callender's projections are far closer to reality than the IPCC or Hansen or any like-thinkers, and less hot, despite the greater carbon you describe. Solar harmonics too are far closer to actual data than the IPCC or Hansen or any like thinkers.

If climate science is about predicting trends, and the track record for said predictions is terribly incorrect, that speaks to the quality or veracity of the predictions or even the projections.

Till this is admitted and addressed the entire enterprise is simply an expensive, invalid, thought exercise.

When I lost my job at 48 years old and it seemed my career was gone, I was extremely distressed. Although I never had thought of suicide before, I had a fantasy of jumping off the Gloucester bridge in Massachusetts. It was a beautiful spot and I was sick of struggling. It seemed so easy to just end it all. How did my life go from marketing manager to cab driver? Every time I drove by I thought of it, but I would never do it. A friend of mine in a similar situation was not so strong. He didn't jump off a bridge, but maybe if he held on a little longer things would have changed for him. Desparate Moderate: A wise government realizes that when too many people become poor and desperate without any way to improve their lot that the vast majority of people won't be content to just lie down in the street and die like dogs. A wise government realizes that desperate people will do what the desperate poor French people did in their revolution and behead (or kill by another means) all of the rich, elite and powerful in and out of government. A wise government realizes that extreme poverty among an increasing portion of the population is politically unstable and dangerous.

After all, it reaches a point where the poor outnumber the cops and military, plus too many in the military and law enforcement are either poor themselves or have friends, neighbors and relatives who are. So it reaches a point where the cops and military won't defend the wealthy, elite and government officials against a bloody revolution. That is what a wise government knows.

So yeah, if the elite and powerful in this nation want to maintain their lives, let alone their lifestyle, they better make sure the government throws the poor enough bones to keep the poor from staging a revolution. So that's the government's role in all this. You can either be "charitable with other people's money" now, or you can watch a revolution destroy the wealth in this nation and institute a new government that you might not like living under. Assuming, of course, that you survive a revolution.

I taught in an offshoot of the Bard program mentioned in Keller's piece. It was one of the most exciting classes I've ever been part of: the students were highly motivated to consider the same big liberal arts questions we discuss on campus. Many of them wrote articulate essays examining the pressures that had led to their incarceration. Several have since been released and entered college programs. While they don't have internet access, they have computers that allow them to search reference sources and write papers. Our Center for Prison Education has inspired our students on campus to work for social justice and against the hideous commercial forces to build more prisons that many of these comments mention. Those incarcerated had the odds stacked against them from birth; they were movingly grateful to the teachers who responded to them as fellow human beings. We all need more of this.

Yeah it is Joe.  Likely problem is that lack of ice covering the arctic in the fall leaves more heat available in the North Pole area and more moisture available for more snow in Siberia.  This weakens the what was normally strong circumpolar winds and weakens the jet stream and lets it meander, which it's definitely been doing more in the last few years.  A weak, meandering jet stream leads to persistent, recurring weather, and to cold air spilling further south.  But it's not all that cold, it's not record cold as cold air has always occasionally spilled south.  But Alaska is record warm.

Left unsaid in the whole debate of whether universal pre-K is the fact is really necessary or even benfeficial. I have seen no peer-reviewed studies cited demonstrating a lasting value from universal pre-K. it is simply stated as a given (secular gospel?) that universal pre-K is a good thing. In fact, the closest available data, based upon Head Start results, indicates that any benefits in terms of improved performance fade by third grade when the students outgrow the initial skill advantage and natural talent and ability start to play the primary role in academic achievement. Additional, there have been analyses indicating that New York City currently is not filling all its available pre-K slots - contrast that with the waiting list for Charter schools, which the Mayor finds "abhorrent". It would be nice to see the facts so that the voters and public could make an independent and informed judgement on the issue, rather than having to settle for the latet political gossip.

As a person with a disability and also a disability advocate, I apparently had a different reaction to the story. What was missing from my reaction that others experienced was shock. This is, of course, because my life revolves around becoming aware of things like this, and things like this happen all the time.

Additionally, I am not shocked because I live the life of a severely, visibly disabled person everyday. I cringed each time a townsperson called these men "boys", partly because I know what it's like to be treated as an eternal child. People who treat you this way do not know how offensive they are being, and will bristle when called on it. It's strange, for a country that values individual independence so highly there are a lot of people who don't understand that those of us with disabilities value it, too, probably even more than they do because we have less of it.

An easy, daily takeaway: instead of automatically helping a disabled person you believe is struggling with something, ask them if they need help -- and LISTEN to the answer, and respect it, even if you start to get that feeling in the pit of your stomach that says you are a horrible person if you don't help. It may be hard to watch us struggle, but it's often the struggle that makes the payoff sweeter. The key here is to respect the disabled person's independence. A lack of this respect can - and does - produce stories such as what's in the article.

Mr. Hill, I'm not "blaming" the west for this, just pointing out that our interventions and our encouragement (to a point) of popular uprisings has not been working too well lately.  Ask the Syrians and the Egyptians, or the Libyans and the Afghans.  Like it or not, Mr. Putin holds a strong hand here and he has quite a lot of history -- which our politicians and press are ignoring -- on his side in dealing with a region that has only been part of the Ukraine for sixty years, and that by Soviet gift.  The "jackbooted thugs" you refer to are in a region where there were mass demonstrations and calls -- by a local government as "legitimate" as the one in Kiev -- for Russian intervention.  That's what we said would happen for our troops in Iraq, but it didn't.  We can beat the war drums over it or give Mr. Obama a set of red pencils to draw some big lines with, but we will only look weak and ineffectual.  Who does that help?  I say, accommodate the Russian move as an effort to maintain order in a transitional and uncertain moment, and work together to shore up the authorities in Kiev in a way that doesn't make the Russians feel encircled.  Putin will only play that move to his advantage and we'll be shown up to be paper tigers.

"...the fiancée... said that Mr. Dunn had not mentioned to her in the night and day they spent together before his arrest that any of the teenagers had a shotgun."

I was on a jury once where the accused had shot a kid who came on his land. His main defense was he shot at the ground as a warning and the bullet must have ricocheted off a rock. The ballistics guy, while very skeptical, could not absolutely rule it out. The shooter was convicted on a less-than-murder charge. My argument to convict for murder was that this "shooting at the ground" story was not mentioned to the police on the day of the shooting. Mr. Dunn did not see a shotgun. It would have been the first thing he mentioned, to anyone.

What a lovely column. Losses, whether deaths or illness, eventually hit us all. At some point, we too might be the Woodiwiss family, enduring some unthinkable we never imagined we'd have to face.

The lessons Catherine presented made me nod my head over and over. Particularly the point about 'little things,' and small kindnesses that can be far more appreciated than a one-time grand gesture. For those suffering injury or major bereavement, after the initial shock the simple fact that someone is thinking about them makes a huge impact on their psyche.

While not in the category of the Woodiwiss family, I'm dealing with a "new normal" following a serious fall in France that left me with 6 fractures, undiagnosed by French doctors. Near constant back and neck pain are my new normal, and while I look somewhat the same (only shorter), I'm not. But the one thing I will never forget are all the friends who called, offered rides, and simply expressed presence.

Few, except a few tone-deaf relatives, said "you'll get over it" or "my back hurts too." I think the difference between a true friend and just a well-meaning one is how much they allow you to own your situation.

Pain and loss are hard enough to deal with, without feeling forced to "put on a happy face" or be something you're not, just to make another person feel more comfortable or freer to talk about themselves. And I think that is what Catherine Woodiwiss means when she urges others to allow one to simply "be."

That the Crimea is even part of Ukraine is an accident of history - one more line on a map that makes no sense on the ground. No way will they let it go, and they have the support of a majority of the people who live there.

What the area really needs is another civilized divorce like that of the Czech Republic and Slovakia. The alternative is an ugly civil war and a region even more destabilized and fragile politically and economically.

Let Russia have Crimea; Ukraine might very well think good riddance. They will have enough trouble trying to figure out how to form a new government without trying to hang on to neighbors who want nothing to do with them.

Cry me a river. I graduated with a master’s degree (on the heels of an undergraduate degree) in 1988 just as the junk bond market collapsed. I was underemployed or unemployed for at least three years, piecing together freelance work and using leftover scholarship money I had saved to pay for catastrophic health insurance. It was tough going and depressing. My parents were emotionally supportive but because they were poor, they could not provide a safety net. What did I do? Got up every morning and looked for work, took freelance writing jobs that came out to about $3 an hour, and taught a college class as an adjunct for a thousand dollars a semester. I’m now a college professor teaching undergraduate upperclassmen and you know what? They are more resilient, entrepreneurial, interested in the world, and harder working than I ever was. The rest of you may feel sorry for the millennials, but I don’t. I think they are going to save us all.

Most of those who are inclined to vote for a candidate who supports the ACA weren't going to vote Democratic anyways. Unfortunately, the White House extension allowing people to keep sub-standard policies looks like a cynical and desperate ploy.

As for economic issues, the Democrats clearly have the edge and they need to use megaphones to promote it. Increasing--and especially indexing--the minimum wage is not only the right thing to do, it's what the public wants. The GOP recognizes that their country club, elitist approach to helping low income people (e.g., by not doing so) has fallen flat and hurts their image. However, Paul Ryan's approach to poverty issues is not only dishonest (which appears to be his defining characteristic), but is yet another example of his party's meanness. He apparently seeks to help poor people by making them more poor.
"Every nation has the government it deserves." - Joseph de Maistre (1753-1821), 1811

The Democrats made two gigantic mistakes to get health insurance reform passed. First, they did away with the public option. Second, they allowed states to opt out. Both of these things were done to win votes.

There is a lesson here. Though it would have been nice to have passed meaningful reform in Obama's first term, the goal should be to only pass legislation that will work, or that has a chance to work. We would have been better served if Dems didn't make compromises just to pass "something" because instead of still having the health care issue on their side, they gave Republicans the issue and the opportunity to point at a law not working well (despite the fact they did all they could to prevent it from being implemented well) that they have demonized.

We'd be better off in the long run if there was no deal without a public option. Then Dems could be campaigning on health care reform now as premiums continue to skyrocket with less and less coverage, and more people went bankrupt without coverage as they did without the ACA, and rallying the public for a public option, or gasp, a single payer Medicare expansion that would end the health insurance industry.

Let's face it.....it's easier to brand Ryan a racist than take a deep, hard look at the seemingly intractable problems of the inner cities. I've seen no progress in fifty years and would bet in another fifty the same circular, ineffective dance will still be in full swing.

So many comments miss the real socio-economic issues at play here. How are people supposed to afford health insurance after being released from prison when employers legally discriminate against felons? Over a million incarcerated individuals were charged with nonviolent drug possession offenses. Some were self-medicating their own mental illnesses probably caused by the horrible (and arguably inescapable) poverty that has befallen so many communities. Many of these "criminals" so many commentators are demonizing were just trying to put some food on the table. Perhaps they shouldn't have sold or done drugs but think about how few opportunities they had. Their public schools are underfunded and those that actually finish HS can't get loans to go to school because their parents aren't creditworthy. Education and upward mobility are basically nonexistent opportunities in many places in this country. The system is broken and failing these communities; The least we can do is help place them on the path to recovery by ensuring their basic human needs for medical care are met once the nightmare of their unfair persecution by the war on drugs is over.

Surveys indicate that an educated, skilled work force is at, or near, the top of priorities listed by employers. Walker, however, has made massive cuts to the UW System, which has resulted in significant losses of high quality faculty and staff. Some faculty retired early to protect their benefits from proposed Walker policies. Too many "stars" left for much better positions at other universities. In fact, other institutions are raiding the UW for talent. Class offerings have been reduced, or worse, replaced by revenue-generating courses. Result: A world-class university system is reeling and at risk.
Perhaps these cuts to education, including K-12 and tech schools, reflect one important reason why Walker has not been able to attract new jobs to the state at the level he promised during his election campaign. Quality education is the basis for a strong economy; other countries know this, we have lost our way.

First let us address some facts.

College student athletes on scholarship get an opportunity to get an education that it is highly unlikely they would not get otherwise. I went to a world class, extremely expensive private college in Southern California on a scholarship.

College student athletes get academic supports that the average student does not have access to. We had paid professional tutors accompany the team on road trips and we could access these same tutors any time, day or night, we have difficulties.

I went on line to the archived Northwestern class schedule for Mr. Colter's sophomore year, surprise I found that the Chemistry course was offered at three different times. So yes the staff probably did discourage him from missing practice but they did not stop him from taking the class.

Yes, college student athletes have fewer freedoms than the average student. But those freedoms come at a cost. Student athletes graduate on average 90% of the time. Joe College Student only graduates 30% of the time.

Student Athletes graduate with zero college loan debt. Joe Average College Student has between $30,000 and $200,000 in student loan debt.

It should also be mentioned that 80% of all college sports programs make no money at all. Football and Basketball does make huge amounts of money, most of which goes into the general scholarship fund.

Maybe we should look at the entirety of the sports program before we throw the baby and the bathwater out.

Why do we have this mass amnesia over the extra 7.5% FICA that wage earners and their employers have to pay into the general treasury every paycheck? For the self-employed, it's more obvious, but it is also a chronic brake on hiring.

That money is not taken from earnings over (approx.) $110K/yr, dividends, capital gains, or rental income. 90% of us are paying this tax, supposedly in exchange for "enhanced Social Security benefits" with no defined date or beneficiary of those phantom benefits. It is assessed in the name of the Social Security Administration, but it flows directly to the general treasury in exchange for an annual bond from the Treasury to the Social Security Administration.

Bush, Jr.'s first act after being appointed President was to go to the SSA headquarters in West Virginia, open the file cabinet where those bonds are kept, and throw them on the floor, saying they were "just paper."

Why doesn't anyone pay attention to this? It's like a bank robbery in broad daylight where nobody bothers to stop the robbers.

"... those born to men age 45 and older had about twice the risk of developing psychosis"

If the risk of psychosis for those age 20-24 was 2%, that means that the absolute risk to those aged 45 was 4%.

Wouldn't it be a good policy for the Times to start indicating absolute risk as opposed to the alarming and possibly inaccurate relative risk? Many people will misinterpret this article as meaning that older fathers have a serious risk of passing serious mental health risks to their offspring. Possibly it means no such thing ... but the Times has chosen to conceal, rather than reveal, a key element of this story.

I too am annoyed by the panhandlers, especially on the subway when they go into their act as soon as the doors close, but it appears that the overwhelming majority of them are mentally impaired or alcoholic. They are not criminals. Very few seem to be well people who have fallen on hard times.

It's a City of 8.5 million people and naturally some unfortunate people will fall into this category, so while we appreciate that the nuisances are eliminated we also need to get to the root cause of the problem and offer some treatment and decent alternatives to those afflicted. We will not get 100% positive results, that's impossible, but we can certainly help some of these folks and, at the same time, to be honest, allay our feelings of guilt and pity because at least we're doing something other than just carting people off to the slammer.

to Steve Mumford:

Not only morally wrong, but inhumane, practiced widely in medieval times and before. Tortured person suffers not only from inflicted pain but also observing his /her torturer, and the torturer loses his/her humanity in the process and becomes a monster.

Currently the law requires people who use any app or purchase anything through an on-line system have the right to opt out if they do not wish to have their data shared. The law should be changed so that any personal data must be retained in a secure fashion unless the person has already decide to opt in.

If it is not the N.S.A. or marketing companies, it's going to be Iranian or Chinese intelligence agencies or crime organizations who are going to collect this private data. If it can be accessed, it will be.

What is needed is very sophisticated encryption and very active efforts to detect and to find the sources of all hacking into private and governmental systems. This means that the N.S.A. et al will have to work a lot harder and spend a whole lot more money to do their jobs, but it will restore limits upon what the people in the secret government can do, far from good accountability.

What there needs to be is a constitutional amendment declaring, once and for all, that money is not tantamount to speech, free or otherwise. The notion that money equals speech is a legal absurdity - generally speaking, notwithstanding talent or disability, just about everyone has the same ability to speak or write to express an idea. But money is a finite resource that only some people have in large enough amounts, and this decision and Citizens United guarantees that speech will now be a resource available only to those who can afford it.

A constitutional amendment to stop this insanity is necessary if we want to remain anything resembling a democracy.

Obama's best option is one that I don't see him advocating for - that is, articulate a big vision for the country, including changes in the tax system that would make doing business in America the path of least resistance while bringing back as many manufacturing & service jobs previously relocated overseas as possible, and then running on it against a Republican-controlled House in 2014.

What these last five years have demonstrated is that, when left to its own devices, corporate America will not do the right thing for ordinary Americans. It will sit on piles of cash, compensate its executives as if they were royalty, and still seek to outsource or eliminate through automation every last job they can.

Raising the minimum wage to $10.00 is tantamount to rearranging deck chairs on the Titanic.

But is this President first willing to take on the Republican-lite wing of his party, that wing of the party completely beholden to corporate interests, and who routinely do their bidding rather than representing the interests of working men and women?

Many commenters here seem to believe that "innocent" and inadvertent utterances that promote stereotypes should be forgiven because no offense was intended. I disagree. Some arguments for letting these things pass sound too much like the old "It's too big a problem to solve, so let's just throw up our hands and do nothing because nothing we do will make a difference." There is also the victim-blaming argument echoed by bullies throughout time: "Toughen up," which does nothing to address, for example, stereotype-fueled hiring bias.

We can either make excuses for complacency, and ignore the harm that our collective contributions to stereotyping do to others, or we can try changing the societal status quo (for the better, imho) by objecting to such utterances (preferably politely than accusatorily), making people aware that some of the stereotypes they "inadvertently" perpetuate tacitly condone a society where a multitude of groups have fewer opportunities because of unconscious systemic bias.

On a recent weekend night I met some friends at a nice restaurant. Upon being seated, I noticed a group of eight people -- attractive, well-dressed twentysomethings -- in a booth next to us. Every one of them was deeply immersed in conversation. Not with each other, but with some disembodied text voice, a voice located perhaps in the next neighborhood, perhaps in the next state, perhaps in the same booth. Their thumbs were pecking away; their brows were furrowed; their smooth faces were gently illuminated by the light from the screens of their smart phones.
Not all of them are wealthy, and not all are Republicans.
How many of those "ordinary people" who built up million dollar fortunes worked at Walmart?

Unfortunately, for the last decade or so, Republicans have been doing more than slowing down the train; they've been rolling it back. Voting rights, women's rights, public schools, public service unions, the very notion of a public commons safeguarded by a democratic government are all under heavy and successful assault by Republicans. The Democrats have offered scant resistance and too often have taken the money and betrayed their constituents.

There may be a demographic tsunami coming, but it is not at all clear that the will of the people matters for anything anymore. Large majorities of Americans support increased social security benefits, a higher minimum wage, an end to our endless wars, investment and job creation in this country, a sane response to climate change, and the heavier taxation of corporations and the obscenely wealthy rather than cruel austerity.

So why don't we see any of these wonders? Because none of these popular policies have a chance when every branch of government has been captured. Corrupted by cash, with gerrymandered districts and packed courts to issue rulings equating corporations with personhood, the Republicans have been able to rig the game and the Democrats have followed behind, dining on the scraps.

The Democrats have a major problem in the number of districts they have conceded to the Republicans, Our state filing deadline was Monday, and I have NO Democratic State Legislative candidate or State Senate or Congressional Candidate to vote for. NONE. And "they" want me to work for and campaign to keep Mark Pryor in the Senate.

It's difficult to generate enthusiasm without those down ballot candidates who make so much of a difference at the local level.

I just returned from three months living in Rio. For years, my Brazilian-born husband and I have been saying that the U.S. and Brazil have reversed direction over the past decade. There, a huge increase in the minimum wage and strengthening of the safety net created a new middle class in one of the most economically unequal societies in the world. Meanwhile, here at home, we have been rushing toward an economically polarized society. I certainly hope the lack of jobs, wage stagnation, underfunded education system and lack of opportunity here do not create a population of favela dwellers as decades of abandonment did there.
And we don't need the far-right Hoover Institute to tell us what we need!

Creativity happens when it happens. When I was in high school and college, all my friends and teachers assumed I would become a professional writer. They spoke of novels, screenplays, stories in the New Yorker. Fifty years later, if I see them again, they ask, why? And I shrug: I can't do it on demand.
And looking at the average TV sitcom - which is written to formula so exact I can often recite a laugh line a half-second before the actor delivers it - I can see the formula. Disney's formula is obvious. So is the formula for any Hollywood tentpole movie.
In politics, as in the arts, relying on insight rather than mechanical formulae would mean far less product. Many members of the chattering classes, like many screenwriters, would have to get real jobs. But to paraphrase from an actually creative work, wouldn't be much there, but what's there would be cherce.
One dissent, though: Common Core. Creativity requires a solid grounding in knowledge and technique. Creativity is the sculptor; but knowledge is the clay.

I am and I have done gas work. Here in NY, specifically Manhattan steam is already used for heat. The steam is the byproduct of electrical generation and is pumped into many buildings. This is an extremely expensive thing to do. The only thing you save is the cost of gas. The infrastructure is more expensive. Geothermal is not usable everywhere. In Manhattan and the Bronx for example, hard rock is in the way. In other places you have to go very deep. Also when a street is replaced in Manhattan all the utilities do get replaced. But there are many miles of roads in NYC and as you get closer to the end of Manhattan the island gets more narrow but the underground infrastructure is more. Open up a street there and it looks like spaghetti.

Currently there is a program to replace oil burners in the Bronx and Manhattan but they are replaced with gas. Gas is fine and very safe. The article gives examples of gas problems but does not mention elecrical fires, which are more frequent.

I agree whole-heartedly that we don't just throw money at this issue and walk away but I disagree with the writer as to the experiment that is outlined.  How do you knowingly and purposely give some an advantage and others not.  Look, we know that some things work and the author points that out, i.e., building blocks and a warm environment, reading to them and playing rhyming games, so lets give every child that as a start, then beyond that, try different things with different groups and see what works best over time.  I think it's morally wrong to set up an experiment with children, predicting at the outset that one group is going to gain an advantage.  I disagree that a controlled experiment is necessary to get it right.  Would anyone want to be the parent of a child in the control group?  Or years later being one of the control group children sitting in your jail cell reading about this great pre-K experiment that was done last decade and look what we discovered?  The experiment also has the feel of a bunch of rich, educated people experimenting with disadvantaged people, giving some opportunity and others not.  "Yes, Franz, just as we predicted, these children over here ended up in jail much more frequently! And as expected these over here were much more likely to climb out of poverty and become successful!  Our experiment was a success, let's have a toast!"  Really?

According to the US Census, there are roughly 100,000,000 US citizens under the age of 24.  Put the two together and we conclude that 30 million Americans under the age of 24 have been arrested.  That's equal to the population of 4 or 5 states -- Washington, Massachusetts, Indiana, Arizona, Tennessee have about 30 million inhabitants.  This is evidence of outrageous over policing!!  Add some race prejudice and Mr Blow's argument is clear. But the foundation is a police culture out of control.

We are learning from the ACA. First, it is unreasonable to expect affordable health plans from for-profit insurance companies. Second if people have a choice of keeping money or paying for health insurance a large number will prefer to keep the money. The only reason that most people have insurance is that it is paid by their employers before they get their hands on the money.
Second, the article makes it clear that there is a huge pool of individuals who have not been taking care of their health and need to start seeing doctors now. We needed something like the affordable care act to get these people into clinics hospitals and doctors offices. In this the affordable care act has been successful.
Third the affordable care act or an improved version of it must cover the entire country uniformly.
There is a fourth fifth sixth etc., I hope other readers will add to the list.

Since problems have been discovered regarding wind turbines (death of eagles and other birds, for example, and complaints of noise) why is it that we seem to have turned away from a well-established clean source of energy: solar panels? In Germany, a subsidy program has encouraged the installation of solar panels on every home in the entire country. Which leads to a question, no doubt related to the oil/coal/natural gas industries: why are solar panels so incredibly expensive in the United States when compared to other countries? Given the infrastructure of our country, gasoline powered cars will be with us for awhile. But imagine the pollution decreasing effect of hundreds of millions of solar panels on houses across the country. It is even possible to sell excess production back to the mainstream energy companies, thus further reducing reliance on coal/oil/gas.

I say take away the outrageous oil subsidies and redirect this money to subsidize solar panel installation on homes across the land.

As a final note, I have never seen a discussion detailing the many options for reducing personal and corporate use of energy. Plenty of technology already exists on the market (timers for heating/cooling, etc.) to easily reduce/redirect energy usage during times when it is not needed. As individuals, it is difficult, if not impossible, to exert a significant amount of control over our electric energy sources--but each of us can control our own usage.

I grew up in NYC and have lived in Atlanta over 20 years.

People in Atlanta poo-pooed the traffic jams related to the GWB closings -- how could that be any worse than a typical Atlanta rush hour! What wimps to make such a big thing out of it! They had no way to know, to understand, the impact.

Now people in NYC are doing the same thing towards Atlanta. This was *not* just a couple of inches of snow. It was a layer of inch-thick ice on every horizontal surface, with up to a couple of inches of powdery snow on top.

True, Southerners aren't great drivers in inclement weather, and flurries have been known to close schools. And no, we don't have the capacity to clean streets rapidly, though after 2011, Georgia is now pretty well prepared to plow and salt.
