@Rtbinc. I don't think the danger is in keeping a gun - unless you don't store it safely, in a safe. The danger is in the bullet coming out and hitting you. And that is not in any way proportionate to whether the "discharge" is accidental or not accidental: if the gun's barrel is pointed at you, the result is the same regardless of intent. So, what's your point? Guns don't kill people? People kill people? Pools kill people, stairs kill people, so we should just let up on the concerns we have about both accidental and intended gun discharges? Did you read the article? The evidence is overwhelming, more guns = more deaths.

It seems that most comments are strongly against Ackman. I'm more neutral. I tend to agree with him that Herbalife is a pyramid scheme and immoral -- quite a bit more insidious than it may seem, in part because it has been more or less accepted into the mainstream. But a company that is highly exploitative and preys on the naivete of people who are vulnerable is a problem.

As to Ackman's actions, he is not being sneaky. On the contrary, he is very upfront and that is partly why he has taken a big hit on this. He made himself a target.

On Wall Street every day people buy stocks and then sing their praises, trying to help improve perception and by doing so give them a boost. All Ackman is doing is the flip side of this. Plus every single short seller, and most Wall Streeters are at times, go around badmouthing the stocks they short. It is very commonplace to short stocks that you think have accounting issues, and once you have your position, you are free to share your opinions on why they are a house of cards. All business as usual on Wall Street. So what he is doing is not outside of the typical Wall Street bag of tricks, it is just a slightly different twist on a grander scale. Sure, many would say that shorting any stock is unethical, but there are many counter arguments to that. Short sellers actually tend to provide stability to stocks by providing a counter-balancing effect. When a stock is tanking, it is the short sellers who are buying to cover their positions.

Some of the negative comments about Emily's choices remind me of my own experiences - as a teacher and also as a parent - with children with behavior problems. That Emily has run away 4 times shows that her home life has difficulties, but this does not necessarily mean that her parents are uncaring or abusive. Many children are rebellious and make poor choices at 15: that's why we call them "children" and don't consider them fully responsible for their actions. Presently, when children have emotional problems and parents need help, there are very few resources for them - beside the police and the court system, who usually become involved when things have gotten bad enough. Our family, middle-class and suburban, had a lot of difficulty getting evaluation and treatment for our child with ADHD and behavior problems. I can only imagine what it's like for poor, urban families. I'm glad that Emily was able to get treatment when she was found. I only wish that other children could get help more easily before they find themselves in her situation.

Welcome to snowstorms New York. The exact same thing happens here in Chicago, and the complaints are exactly the same. "Why hasn't my street been plowed yet?" "Why has that street been plowed and not mine?" My guess is in New York, just like Chicago and everywhere else, there are a finite number of snowplows, and a specific budget for their operation, including paying their drivers and filling them with fuel. So some streets get plowed first, some get plowed last, and in a large city, it'll take a good bit of time between the first street and the last street, and the people who are waiting for their turn, no matter what neighborhood they live in, are going to be angry that they weren't first. Short of employing a massive fleet of snowplows and operators to position themselves on every block to remove the snow the minute it falls, someone's going to be dissatisfied.

We found insurance again through Kaiser, but with both of us having pre-existing conditions it was expensive. Now it is substantially cheaper, thanks to President Obama and the ACA. And they will never be able to drop us.
And since we're all being so anecdotal, here's another one. A friend had insurance through Blue Cross and last fall got a premium increase up to $850.00 per month. He dropped them and went to the ACA web site. He found a Kaiser plan for $150.00 meaning he got a raise of 700 bucks a month.

The demise of Alt-Weeklies is a sad thing, as they provide a view of local events and politics that is lost in mainstream media. Bloggers can replace some of it but the lack of editing and journalistic standards often turns them in to rants. But let's be honest about the "why" the Alts are dying (and many big papers too). It isn't some "corporate" plot or takeover, it's the loss of revenue from classified advertising to Craigslist and other sites. That was the donkey that carried the load for all of the content stuff and it got replaced by a better vehicle. This isn't new and what is disturbing is that over a decade since this became known there is still a real absence of new revenue and business models to foster what once made the Alts a necessary part of many city dwellers week.

Kind of tiring to see people continuously fretting about the Republicans and their leadership holding the rest of the country hostage. Yes they do, and yes this is frustrating no doubt. But you know what, this is an election year, and this country is still a democracy, so the people have it in their hands to make a change. We've had the same problem in CA, when work in Sacramento ground to a standstill and the state almost went bankrupt. The most recent election fixed that and returned a solid majority in both chambers to one party. Since then, CA has been on a spectacular road of recovery. So rather than ranting about the Republicans in the House and Senate, you need to find a way to convince enough voters that change is needed, and have them enact change via the ballot box.

This concept of having to ignore religion,  national origin, gender and sexual orientation to be fair and complete also should include exclusion of mental illness, primary or secondary language, education level, intelligence level, marital status, etc.   Why not require that terrorists and those intent on killing, kidnapping, raping, etc., sign up in a registry, including fingerprints and DNA samples.   It's funny that there are on TV/cable at least 5 or 10 series involving FBI profilers.   Thing is that profiling is a form of actuarial statistics and pattern recognition that increases the probability of identifying an unsub or perp.    It is of great concern that the pattern over the last several years has been to weaken America's ability to intercept criminals and terrorists before they act to kill Americans in the name of PC and unrealistic standards of civil rights.  The drafters of our Constitution could not envision 911's, cyber-terrorism, identity theft, machine guns, nuclear bombs and radiation and mass killings on the order of millions.   No one is suggesting that we repeat the kind of wrong done to Japanese Americans during WWII, but we are compromising American national security by throwing both science and common sense out the window by ignoring groups that have extremely high association with crime and terror.

I sincerely hope that the dogs are PovoDog are spayed before being put up for adoption. If Russia is anything like Romania half of them will end up back on the streets once their adopted families decide they don't have the space or  money to care for a pet. Cull is an ugly word, but it's a practical, solution to the problem, and much quicker than just spaying the dogs and waiting a decade or more for the last of them to die. Having been menaced by stray dogs on a regular basis on my way to school as a kid, and having heard of children mauled to death by packs of strays, I have very little sympathy to spare for dangerous wild animals roaming city streets or for the journalists and activists who block efforts to solve the problem. All the stray dogs in Russia aren't worth one human life, and if the quickest, most economical way to make sure they don't harm anyone is a shot of poison, so be it. The tone of this article--the poor, sweet puppies!--just illustrates how easy it is to pity these animals from a distance. But walk past a snarling, growling pack of strays every day and you'll see things differently.

Raising kids is the hardest thing I've ever had to do. People in this day and age are completely unprepared for it, and because of the way American society is structured, people have few of the supports people in the past had, yet the expectations placed on parents and kids are higher than ever. Parents are gripped by anxiety that if they can't provide the very best for their kids, their kids may not succeed in an intensely competitive society. It requires tremendous personal and financial sacrifice. In most cases parents are doing the best they can - and they don't always handle every situation perfectly. I cut parents  - of young kids especially -  a lot of slack. In Europe, people with small kids get to go to the front of the line. They get a seat on the bus. And so on. As it should be. We are all together in this - even those of you without kids - we're part of a society. When I come back to the States and get the comments you never get in Europe about your rowdy kids disturbing someone's meal, or accidentally stepping on someone's foot, etc. all I can think is that Americans are a selfish, mean-spirited lot. Just so you know, I really don't care if my baby's crying prevents you from enjoying your latte. We're perpetuating the human race here! If anyone has a sense of entitlement its you whiny kidless folks who want total peace and quiet all the time and have zero empathy.

The rent-a-judge system for well-off litigants in Delaware is just the latest feature of a system of laws and courts in that state which are consistently favorable to corporations. Just as North Carolina relaxed its environmental laws to favor industry (see today's Duke Power NYT story), Delaware for decades has been the domestic Grand Cayman for corporate laws and litigation. Corporations throughout the US are created in Delaware; they get the pro-business protections of Delaware law, such as laws that compel arbitration and mediation and disallow litigation; and they may insist in their corporate agreements that they can only be sued in their home town, Delaware, under Delaware's laws.

Why do Delaware's sitting judges like this new system? Lately, judges have been leaving the bench in NY, where I've been a litigator for 45 years (and once had the always insightful Prof. Resnik as my star pupil at NYU Law), in search of more income. Many join the large firms that offer the services of former judges to mediate and arbitrate sizable disputes at rates that hover around $1000 an hour. JAMS, the largest, has an 8-page list on its website of federal judges who resigned the bench, even though they had lifetime tenure, and are now rentable from JAMS by pecunious litigants. http://www.jamsadr.com/files/Uploads/Documents/federal_Judges.pdf Burnishing your resume while on the government payroll seems to be all the rage.

My friend was very determined not to get back in trouble, and a very smart person.  He managed, with no capital, to start a small service business, & succeeded. The term "religion" is bandied about so loosely and broadly that it no longer has any specific meaning (if it ever did), certainly not enough to serve as a basis for legal decisions. A person's choice to use or not use contraception is a moral judgment. Somehow, all moral judgments have become conflated with religion, making religion the chief arbiter of morality, as though no moral consciousness could exist outside of religious dictates. The time has come, I believe, for reexamining the use of the abstract term religion in all legal matters. There is an urgent need to specify the precise meaning of that term. The legal profession is notorious for its meticulous wording of the smallest points, but that precision gets lost when it comes to the abstract term of religion.

I agree with your last statement. However, he's right about men who make stuff vs men who just push money around. With regard to making stuff, Ayn Rand's error was that she forgot that Dagny Taggart didn't build her railroad - the people she employed built it. Nor did Howard Roark build his skyscraper (all he accomplished was to blow one up). Bricklayers, masons, steelworkers, miners, thousands of people built those railroads and skyscrapers. Dagny Taggart never even punched a ticket. Howard Roark never drove a nail.

In Rand's defence it should be said that she was voicing an extreme reaction to an extreme circumstance -her father was a small businessman who lost everything in the Bolshevik Revolution - and to say she was very wrong is not to say Lenin was right, quite the opposite. It takes a grievous historical disaster to produce derangement on the level of Ayn Rand's. (And of course when collectivism worked in her favour, she sucked on the public teat shamelessly, sneaking onto Social Security and Medicare under her married name. The final ironic nail in the coffin of her philosophy is coffin nails - she was a staunch advocate of cigarettes against the nanny-state warnings of their evils, and often her followers waved them about as torches - amusingly depicted in Tobias Wolff's novel 'Old School.' She died of - wait for it - lung cancer.

I felt sick reading the horror of pig being forced to cannibalism in an American factory farming.

I am sure most of the world would have without hesitation turned in to vegetarians if only the slaughterhouses had glass walls!

For me hailing from India where vegetarianism is largely practiced and the country which can take great pride in the origin of Jainism, the news is even more revolting.

Jainism is an ancient faith which challenges the comfortable – and near-universal – assumption of human precedence over other creatures. Ahiṃsa is a fundamental principle cornerstone of ethics and doctrine in Jainism meaning non-violence, non-injury or absence of desire to harm any life forms. Vegetarianism and other non-violent practices and rituals of Jains flow from the principle of Ahiṃsa.

This seemingly abstract philosophy assumes a great significance when we keep hearing this kind of horror stories.

The great genius of Albert Einstein was apparent when said “that the vegetarian manner of living, by its purely physical effect on the human temperament, would most beneficially influence the lot of mankind”.

This apt observation makes more sense now than ever before.

Broadband service providers are essential utilities and as such must be regulated.

Electric utilities deliver the energy we need to operate everything and broadband utilities deliver the digital information that everything operates on. Both are needed to keep our society up and running. Without that broadband pipeline open, business and production will shut down.

Government has always understood the critical role that electric utilities play in our society and so do the utilities themselves. Cable companies do not. They began as providers of entertainment. Since their inception, they have morphed into providers of the crucial digital pipeline. People can live without HBO, but cut them off from digital communications and most things will grind to a halt. The connection any business has with the world is made through that pipeline. Commerce cannot function without it.

Because of the nature of providing that pipeline, only really big companies can install and maintain it. That's why we let electric companies function under the umbrella of a regulated utility. Cable companies must then be held to the same standards. Market forces can never provide the customer competitive pricing under these conditions and never have. We split ATT into 8 entities and now they have recombined into 3 that are larger than the original. Yes, stop the merger, but change the laws so these companies must answer to the public just as electric utilities have for over a century.

If money is the determining factor in who gets to kill a rhino, a moral door is left open for anyone who might feel that their need of money justifies the killing of rhinos. Namibia is a world apart from most African countries where the population crush of desperately poor people living side by side with animals in equally desperate circumstances make enforcement nearly impossible. I’m pretty sure what choice a starving villager is going to make given the opportunity and having the moral wriggle room that selective killing allows.

In any event, the math doesn’t make sense to me either. I probably shelled out a 100th of what the hunter paid for his rhino shoot so that I could enjoy Namibia’s wilderness. I can’t believe a well-made public relations program couldn’t have attracted another 99 people to come to Namibia with their cameras and experience what has to be one of the last, great wild places on earth. Furthermore, given the expanse of Namibia’s wilderness, I find it hard to believe his rhino couldn’t have been relocated to a place where he wouldn’t have been a bother. There were no rhinos within a 100 miles of where I visited.

Lastly, the writer’s logic seems to be the same one that allows gas guzzling behemoths on our highways. If you’ve got the money, that gives you the right to things that make life less pleasant for others. I'd like to see that practice stopped right along with rhino killing.

I'm scared of and frustrated by doctors.

I was a healthy weight throughout childhood and well into adulthood. I exercised and varied between fit and exceptionally fit. I ate in a healthy manner.

Then, in the late '90s, I ended up on antibiotics for nearly two years for rosacea, and began to have frequent sinus and ear infections. Serious weight gain began. Between 1997 and 2012 I estimate I've been given nearly three years of antibiotics, for rosacea and sinus/ear infections. Over that time I gained an overall 98 lbs. (much more if you count the ups and downs of dieting & losing 35-40 lbs, then gaining after antibiotics, then dieting, etc.).

In 2006 I read the NYTimes Fat Factors article (http://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/13/magazine/13obesity.html) and started incorporating probiotics into my diet. It helped when paired with a "vegetarian Atkins", chemical free diet, but antibiotics would wipe out my efforts all too easily. Writing from Michigan... A bipartisan group of judges, lawyers, and legal advocates are trying to convince Michigan Attorney General Bill Schuette that the Supreme Court decision does apply to Michigan juveniles sentenced to life without parole. Schutte wants to deny them new trials and any chance of freedom. I volunteer in Michigan's women's prison and have gotten to know many of the women sentenced to life without parole when they were juveniles. Many come from very troubled families and communities that have been/are under great stress with very few resources. Very very few educational opportunities or resources of any sort for those sentenced to life without parole (not much left for those with shorter sentences either...). Michigan's highly segregated communities and dramatic disinvestment in education, mental health programs, and resources for battered women and abused children have taken a huge toll. Michigan has also recently halved financial support for the Michigan Prisoner Re-entry Program, a highly successful program which helped former prisoners live successfully in their communities after release. Recipe for disaster --- people living in communities without access to quality education of any sort -- lack of role models and opportunities... End up back in those communities where a criminal record makes it ever more difficult to secure a job, housing, or education.

We had 2009 Bernadotte with roast chicken, potatoes and cauliflower. We decanted it. I took a small taste right out of the bottle, and my impression was that it was harsh with overpowering acid and tannin. We double-decanted for 6 hours and then took our first taste, and were astonished to find that the harsh-edge had gone off the wine. It had a smooth blackberry flavor, with definite acid, followed by tannins at the finish. The balance of acid to tannins was still shifted to acid, but the sensation is pleasant. There is absolutely no sweetness, just a flavor of blackberry fruit, with a hint of currant-berry. The wine was not heavy or grainy, just relatively light and smooth and flavorful, with a zing of acid. Then, we noticed that an impression of "cherry" joined in with the blackberry. I don't know if it was just a slight warming of the glass with time, but the addition of the cherry to the blackberry made the wine very enjoyable.
As we started on our meal we noticed right away that the acidity of the wine simply went away, as if the chicken meat had actually neutralized the acid. This left the blackberry-cherry flavor, followed by the tannins. To confirm this, we took bites of potato and cauliflower, and sampled the wine again, and we did find that the acid was not neutralized by the vegetables. The result was as if we were having two different wines with our meal; both were pleasant companions to our meal.

It's really not that hard, or expensive, to eat healthily. Bags of rice, beans and pastas that would last a person a week are less that $5 in total. Vegetables to go with that for a week, for one, can be had for $15 (head of broccoli, head of cauliflower, bag of carrots, two sweet potatoes and some onions and garlic are about that). Add some oil or butter, bread, and a dozen eggs for another $10 in total, and you're set for $30 total for a week for one person (I've eaten like this, sometimes for years, and yes, no meat in the shopping list--been vegetarian, and healthy, for decades). Problem is you have to prepare and cook it, and its not as easy, or as tasty to some, as the junk that's out there. For some, it's just too boring to eat this way. But still, it's an individual's choice to make, not the government's.

We need to stop calling this an oil pipeline.  It is a bitumen pipeline.  What is bitumen you ask?  Bitumen is an even less refined form of petroleum than crude oil.  It sinks in water (like the Kalamazoo river or the Oglala aquifar) and must be dissolved with toxic solvents and heated to flow in pipelines.  This makes it far more dangerous than standard crude oil and produces dirtier fuels, which is why these fuels will not be used in the U.S. because they are too polluting.  That is why they will be exported completely, making money for Koch refineries but not adding at all to our energy security.  The risk is all ours (and the environment's) but the rewards go to the climate deniers bent on destroying our democracy and countries willing to develop by sacrificing our climate.  A bad deal to say the least.  Just say no to bitumen and no to a pipeline that serves only the interests of other countries and greedy energy companies.

Yup. There are two things I told my students when I taught introductory economics in California: water shortages in California are both inevitable -- and unnecessary. Inevitable because of the absurd under-pricing of water to favored users, and unnecessary because California has plenty of water, it just needs to use it wisely as with the drip irrigation mentioned by Bittmann and the crop choices mentioned by several commenters. California is no more running out of water than the world was running out of oil in the 1970s, another example of under-pricing leading to artificial shortages.

The second economic principle is illustrated with my saying "don't grow bananas in Alaska". It's elementary comparative advantage: do what you're good at, and don't do what you're not good at. The alfalfa example above is a good one, as is cotton. And there's also rice: does it make sense to flood rice paddies in a state with a semi-arid landscape? Don't grow bananas in Alaska, and don't grow alfalfa in California. There are smarter crop choices.

I work for a truck manufacturer.  Our customers demand the most fuel-efficient trucks they can get because it increases their bottom line. It's enlightened self-interest for the truck manufacturers and their customers, the trucking industry, to increase fuel efficiency.  And since new U.S. heavy trucks already meet the strictest emission standards in the world -- near-zero emissions of particulates and nitrogen oxides since 2010 -- greenhouse gases are the next target.  Best way to reduce CO2 is to reduce fuel consumption.  The costs for all of this will -- new technology minus the savings of increased fuel economy -- ultimately show up in the cost of goods purchased in this country.

Is transformation always positive? Who decides if and for whom a story was inspirational? I would also ask what algorithm measures "high-value," a relative concept not limited to monetization. My fourth question is have you ever considered that what is "inspirational" and "high-value" for your company or for your clients might (just might) be not merely disruptive but highly destructive to others now and to you in future? Many might find inspiration and high value in a story about the misuse of big data being so disruptive that no business or industry any longer assumed it needed a human VP for Research, for instance. Sure, they may still include line items in the budget for research and a VP to oversee research operations, but the future lowly worker who holds the exulted title may do little more than maintain the machine, unless this future VP is just a machine running the other machine.

I do see an alternative, however. Somewhere someone is, I hope, working out a way to employ the millions upon millions of humans across the globe whose economic well being is disrupted by the disruptors. These hoped for analysts may even be using big data to do so. If not, the disruptors may be surprised by bevies of Black Swans. History shows us that words like "transformation," "inspiration," and "high value" denote and connote highly relative differences of meaning. For instance, mobs often react to the disruptive, transformative, inspirational, high value of heads on pikes.

Addiction disease is progressive, and progresses whether actively using or not. Often, after even decades of sobriety, relapse leads to death. There is a link between disease progression and relapse, and why it often leads to death after a protracted abstinence.

I question whether society has it right that abstinence is the ultimate goal. Many LEO's and moralists have only one solution: seize, prosecute and imprison. They ignore their impact on the problem, ensuring the black market continues ($6 heroin?!?!), scaring doctors into withholding medicine for those with disease, forcing diseased into the black market. They ignore the impressive reductions in mortality and crime in Portugal's decade of decriminalization. And they decry the moral bankruptcy of those with the disease, while ignoring that the disease itself is a vastly common affliction - whether heroin, alcohol, tobacco, caffeine, gambling, or sex.

This disease is widespread. It has genetic and environmental components. And it's an evolutionarily stable: people, including Mr. Hoffman, survive long enough to produce offspring. And like cancer it's not going away any time soon.

Perhaps we should ignore the suggestions of law enforcement. We have tried it the moralis'ts way for some 40 years now. Isn't it time we step back and look at harm reduction, instead of harm creation?

Under the Affordable Care Act, employers no longer have life and death power over employees in health matters. Say what? Besides the health issues, the much older parent throws the entire circle of life out of wack.

These older parents get to raise a couple of children. Great. What about grandchildren? What about great-grandchildren? In my observation, the older parent is lucky if they even get to see a grandchild born. But many of those lucky ones - while reasonably healthy - simply can't manage the energy to take a grandchild out for an afternoon or spend a weekend with a toddler even if they're alive to do so. And great-grandchildren? Forget about it.

It's easy to play with energetic kids when you're 60. When you're 80? Different ballgame.

I learned a great deal from my grandparents and great-grandparents, and it was a blessing to have them around or to go visit. It's a shame so many offspring of the children of these older parents will never know what having either type of relative is really like. It's also a shame that the offspring's parents often won't have their parents around to give the type of practical and emotional support many grandparents have given for generations.

Now you have no choice but to use a single number that thieves can re-use anywhere. Big picture, Big data really is good for us all.

I mostly trade stocks in relatively small size, so overall I agree that having the HFT guys around to provide a tight market and quick execution for my limit orders is a very good thing. Like any speculators they help both to provide liquidity (at least when markets are acting normally) and bring the prices in different exchanges/markets closer in line. I am concerned that they do create a very complicated and intertwined market and I question how much liquidity they will add when "bad things" happen. The NYSE specialist is always around to make a market, to buy a stock when everyone else is selling. We obviously can't look to the HFT folks for the same.

Also, what exactly does "Flash Boys" tell us about the institutions that are now complaining? Isn't it their responsiblity to notice that their trades aren't hitting the published bids? Why didn't they figure out they couldn't rely on their brokers system to function better? As far as I could tell, all they really need do to prevent front running is to go to one exchange at a time, or ensure they hit all at the same time. Isn't that relatively easy for them to do?

It wasn't so long ago that I was paying $50 commissions for trades with at best a 12 cent bid/ask spread. The world of stock trading is so much better. There are clearly some improvements to be made in as system as complex as this one, but calling the whole thing "rigged" is surely over the top if not rank deception.

Yes, sure, understanding of course the changing the US Constitution is becoming rather a mute point these days.

But in even in the good old days changing the US Constitution is an amazing onerous undertaking, It's not something that can be done quickly, it takes years even when it is successful, and that was by design:

"The United States Constitution is unusually difficult to amend. As spelled out in Article V, the Constitution can be amended in one of two ways. First, amendment can take place by a vote of two-thirds of both the House of Representatives and the Senate followed by a ratification of three-fourths of the various state legislatures (ratification by thirty-eight states would be required to ratify an amendment today). This first method of amendment is the only one used to date. Second, the Constitution might be amended by a Convention called for this purpose by two-thirds of the state legislatures, if the Convention's proposed amendments are later ratified by three-fourths of the state legislatures."

When we bought the first Chevrolet Citation in 1980, GM touted it as a revolutionary front-wheel-drive family car. Instead it was an X-body deathtrap that went into a circular skid whenever the brakes were applied in wet weather. The car was in the shop more than it was out, for that and other problems. Through it all, the dealership and GM never acknowledged any defect, insinuating that it was the way we were driving the car that was the problem. In these pre-internet days they led us to believe we were the only ones. We were able to rid ourselves of the car when the hand-break came off in my husband's hand on a steep incline. He survived, but the car was totaled -- and so was any future relationship we would ever have with GM. For the past 40 years, we would not even rent a GM vehicle. I am not surprised that they figured out the bottom line this time as well -- cheaper to cause a few deaths than to fix the problem.

In 1971, Bobby Seale and Erica Huggins of the Black Panther Party were on trial in New Haven, Ct. After a long, tense trial, the jury retired to deliberate. After a day without a verdict, it became clear that it would be awhile in coming. Those of us working with the Panther Defense Committee organized a vigil on the New Haven green, which was right in front of the court house. Someone had Pete's number in Beacon and called him. He was in New Haven in about two hours. To this day, I have a great photograph of me holding a microphone for him singing to the crowd of a few thousand people. The jury was out for four days and eventually deadlocked at 11-1 for acquittal. All charges were then dropped and Bobby and Erica walked free. It was a great victory. But my most cherished memory of that time was holding the mic for Pete. What a good person.

Maybe I'm just cynical [wait; is that acceptable vocab for the new SAT?] but it seems to me that this is a strategy to keep the SAT relevant to the anxiety-ridden college process.

Fifty years ago I was a junior at James Madison HS, one of the good middle-class schools in Brooklyn. Almost every one I knew attended Stanley Kaplan's prep course or some other SAT prep. My parents didn't have the money or the inclination to send me there, so I just didn't take it. My SAT scores ended up close to 1600 anyway, because I was a reader. As one person commented, you don't need money to succeed.

But test prep is an extremely lucrative industry. So once again, when it comes to questions of education, the bottom line is really the bottom line.

For decades both private and public college athletic departments have run minor-league teams under the fiction that the players in the major sports are "student athletes." As a former college professor, I can tell you that football players and basketball players are anything but in most cases. And the money that big-time athletics "bring into a University" results in a net loss when the salary of coaches, tutors, special training facilities, and venues (stadiums, etc.) are taken into account.

If there really was a "student athlete," his or her team participation would constitute an extra-curricular activity instead of the other way around. That's one model that universities could adopt (like Chicago).

Alternatively, universities could franchise their athletic programs as minor leagues (baseball does this), lending their logo for a royalty. That would avoid the corrupt sham that "college" sports have become. And the football players and basketball players? Don't look now, but most of them only play in the hopes of playing in the "majors" and making big bucks.

The unfortunate truth is that even if the US or EU wanted to aid the people of Ukraine--and I'm not entirely sure that they do--there's not really much that they CAN do, short of risking a full-scale military confrontation.

Russia is too large and resource rich to feel the pain of economic sanctions (at least immediately). And even if it did, political power in Russia is held not by the average Russian citizen (who is most likely to suffer the effects of such sanctions), but by the oligarchy and ruling elites, who are already so obscenely powerful and wealthy, they frankly couldn't care less. And even if the sanctions did extend to the ruling class and oligarchs, they already have too much invested in Putin's escapades to risk pulling their support right now.

Diplomatic isolation is likewise unlikely to coerce compliance. I mean come on, after 70 years of being the world's most reliable "diplomatic boogeyman," the Kremlin is already quite accustomed to being vilified and mistrusted. The only people who sincerely believe in Russia's benevolence are Russians--and even, not all of them are completely sold.

If the West does nothing, it may embolden the Russian government to further acts of overt aggression. And sends a message that they can do whatever they like, whenever they like, and suffer no consequences for their actions.

But although the West may not like it, the absence of any options or evidence to the contrary, seems to indicate that is already very much the case.

This NYT editorial references work by Prof Terry Hendershott at the Haas School of Business, UC Berkeley:

http://faculty.haas.berkeley.edu/hender/

His extensive body of market research looks at changes in liquidity, inventory, and trading costs in relation to HFT. In a forethcoming paper:

High-Frequency Trading and the Execution Costs of Institutional Investors (Terry Hendershott, Jonathan Brogaard, Stefan Hunt, and Carla Ysusi), Financial Review,

One insight that I gained from the paper was that front-running is parasitic in thinly traded stocks, but not particularly useful for high volume stocks.

Actually, it does mean that she will get GSS. Gertman-Straussler-Scheinker, like most of the genetically heritable prion diseases, os autosomally dominant and has 100% penetrance. If you have the gene, you will develop the syndrome. In this case, we're not talking about a gene that might increase risk of disease developing, we're talking about a gene that will kill everyone who inherits it. Unpleasantly.

Short of her being run over by a car tomorrow, Mrs. Kalinksy will die a slow, delirious, demnted death as her brain function is destroyed by accumulating amyloid plaques.

Further, we're not going to find a "cure" for this kind of disease without the technology to resequence a living person's genome in its entirety -- which would be a technological jump akin to someone from the paleolithic waking up one day and building a fission reactor. The only option we have for curing these autosomal dominant diseases is by removing them from the gene pool. On the spectrum of responsible use of genetic sequencing, sex selection may be reprehensible and elimination of "may cause" genes is potentially problematic, but sparing your children (and the gene pool as a whole) diseases which are horrific, heritable, and invariably fatal is not only responsible, its laudible.

While I am certainly not a fan of El Mundo, it must be said that Pedro J. Ramirez has over and over again played an essential role in the Spanish media, keeping an independent editorial policy through thick and thin, and doggedly chasing after corruption scandals from both the right and the left. Corruption is, after the devastating level of unemployment, without doubt the most severe problem affecting Spain at present. That the country's most assiduous publisher of corruption stories has been fired due to political pressure is a sad day for Spain. That it has happened due to pressure from Mr Rajoy, who in any normal democracy would long ago have been forced to resign (along with half his government) to face corruption charges in court, should come as a wake-up call to all of El Mundo's faithful readers - who until now, have also been faithful voters of Mr Rajoy.

I am curious why so many people insist upon maintaining Israel as a Jewish State. Surely the more general goal of liberal democracy is to support open societies with respect for minorities and insistence that those cultures within nation states are guaranteed full access to the law. Hence, support for Israel as a Jewish State is an exception to the general goal.
Presumably the argument for exceptional ism is an historical one, based upon the suffering that Jewish people faced over nearly 2000 years of diaspora. Yet no one can doubt that today millions of Jews prosper in Europe and the US. Should those successful Jews be forced to choose between emigration to Israel or remaining in the West at a cost of accepting a similar drift of the law in their adoptive countries (most often countries of their birth) toward similar states of religious exclusivity? Philosophically the argument in favor of a Jewish State in Israel leads to just such a dilemma.
The decades long occupation of the West Bank and Gaza raises another question. How long could it possibly be morally acceptable to permit such occupations without calling for full citizenship and rights for the occupied?

I live in Los Angeles, and I think the law is great! I used to try to remember to bring the cloth bags, but I would usually get out of the habit after a few weeks. Peter Czipott is one of the few commenters I've read here who seems to know something about zoos and animal biology.  Marius wouldn't have EXISTED at all if not for this zoo.  And I don't understand why people are so distressed at his having been eaten by lions--don't lions in fact eat giraffes in the wild, especially vulnerable members of the population?  With reference to the lions, don't male predators in fact attack and sometimes kill each other in a competition to mate?  Nature is not sentimental, and I wonder how many animals in the wild reach old age; that makes me think that the Danish idea of giving the animals a "good" life as opposed to a "long" life deserves some respect, if not necessarily agreement.  It is not thoughtless, sadistic killing, and there are not an infinite number of zoos ready and willing to take on whatever animals other zoos have too many of.

I think that the psychology of Wall Street traders follows that old dictum that it is hard to get a man to understand something when his salary depends on his not understanding it. I don't see Wall Street as a lot of evil people, but as a culture in which it is very convenient and profitable for people to gloss over the moral elements of what they are doing. Saying that they are "smarter" is an easy way to justify immoral behavior. And making bankers work 80 hours/week immerses them in the culture so much that they will lack the perspective that they might otherwise have from experiences outside their field (not to mention justifying the mythology that they "just work harder" than others.)

But seriously, Mr. Brooks: "If market-rigging is defeated, it won't be by regulators, it will be through market innovation in which a good exchange replaces bad exchanges"? Who is going to demand the market innovate? Not the people earning a lot of money and power from the current system. No, it has to be an outsider, and it has to be legislated. I might add that this is exactly the sort of task the government is supposed to do: protect the little guy (meaning the everyday investor) against the big fish who have infinitely more resources. The government is supposed to be the "resource" of the everyday citizen. That is why we have police and a justice system, remember? So rich people can't just buy the justice they want. No "market system" can replace the social compact.

Here's a possible upside: the reason we call these slimebags the 1% or the .1% is not just because they have so much more money than other people. It's also because there are a lot less of them than there are other people. The thing about a democracy is that it is numbers that count, and the 99% or 99.9% will always win against those creeps. When you frame it that way, the larger problem is not that rich people are being allowed to use their money more easily to swing elections one way or another. The main problem is with us, the 99.9%. We are intellectually lazy. We deliberately keep ourselves ignorant and uninformed. And worse of all, we do not turn out to vote in droves unless there is something really dramatic to vote for. If we, the unwashed masses, insisted on utilizing the wide diversity of information sources that can now be found easily and at relatively little cost on Internet and elsewhere, and if we saw it as our firm obligation and commitment to come to a reasoned decision about every electoral choice and then to actually get out there and vote for those choices, then these cynical over-rich would-be eminences gris who seek to control things to their own benefit would become largely irrelevant.

I think most would accept that prolonged periods of isolation in prison cause great "social pain"; and while many, left to themselves, would distinguish between physical and social pain, finding out that they're roughly equivalent in the suffering they cause probably wouldn't be surprising.

But is that really the point? There is, literally, no legitimate justification for inflicting physical pain on someone already locked up for crimes -- I challenge anyone to cite such a justification. But the justification cited for prolonged periods of isolation is that the inmate, for whatever reason, poses a significant threat to others if left largely in the general prison population. On its face, that sounds pretty legitimate and not at all a gratuitously cruel imposition.

Yet it's charged that the criteria by which assignments to isolation are made can be arbitrary and more a matter of maintaining convenience in managing a generally unruly population. That argues for better controls over initial assignments and a very jaundiced eye on very long confinements. But it doesn't argue for throwing babies out with bath water.

In the end, long-term incarceration under ANY terms is a removal from society and loved ones and must be very painful, regardless of the relative extent of the pain inflicted. I don't know if we're wise enough to seek to place on that line the precise point of acceptable pain. I'd focus on making sure that every isolation decision could be defended rationally.

In scientific community an introductory question "Where are you from?" means the field or the institution you are affiliated with and not a geographic location.

The lab where I earned my PhD employed Israelis, Arabs, Iranians, Americans, Germans, Croats and Serbs and others. And it was a small lab. Funny too.

Perhaps critical thinking, free of religious, nationalist and generally tribe-oriented prejudice has something to do with this. Or maybe it is just the fact that most real scientific problems don't care where you are from.

One reason I enjoy doing science is precisely because I always share a lunch with almost as many nationalities (etc) as there are chairs at the table. The rational enterprise has always been a refuge for those who wish to go beyond the tribal instincts, without having to forget about their tribe - or their cuisine.

Those who build bridges by simply not caring about the differences will always be seen as traitors, while those who spread mistrust about "the other" will always be seen as loyal brothers and sisters. This is the human tragedy.

The President's speech really changes nothing. A group will discuss whether it is possible to move the phone number collection database back to the phone companies, but they will still be searchable there under the same terms as today. And the President's promise to only search the database with court permission still does nothing to prevent the FISA court from issuing blanket permission immediately.

It also doesn't even address bulk collection of GPS and tower location information, or email and other internet data and metadata information, even when encrypted. It does nothing to address blanket collection of all financial transactions. It does nothing to address weakening and then breaking encryption standards used to protect banking and all other electronic transactions. It would do nothing to prevent the NSA from changing your phone's baseband firmware so that even when shut off, your phone could be reporting its location.

In short, it really does nothing.

After checking a few of my local wine stores with no luck, I found the 2009 Chateau Bernadotte at Sotheby's Wine on the Upper East Side in NYC. I was happy to see that it was on sale for $26! Upon asking for the bottle, the two clerks gave each other a look that gave me the impression many people were asking about the same wine.

I opened the bottle and let it breath in the glass for about 15 minutes before tasting with some brie cheese and crackers. The short breathing time was clearly evident in the first taste - harsh tannins and fruit up front with a very dry finish.

After letting the wine sit for another couple hours, I tasted it again with dinner- dill chicken with potato latkes and a wilted spinach, strawberry and goat cheese salad. This time the flavors were much more subtle and the wine had a much smoother taste, making it more enjoyable to drink, however still not my favorite tasting wine.

The next day I tried the wine one more time and it was much better than the two glasses I consumed the day before - even smoother and more balanced between fruity and dry. Usually the wine I drink tastes worse the next day, but it seems like this wine, most likely a product of the vintage, continues to get better with additional aeration.

Very excited to experience new wines and hear responses from others around the country and world! Thanks Eric!

Huge empathy for this, and it's deeply helpful for all the least happy reasons. After two years of an awesome launch of our business in 06 and 07, the broader economy beat us up thoroughly beginning at the middle of 08. We tried relaunching in 2010 and just burned money doing so. But in January of 2013, we took our business - selling 24K/year memberships to big companies for a suite of information and advisory services, seen by many as nice-to-have but not essential - back to the marketplace and the relaunch worked. Most of 2013 was fantastic, and we're on a new, pretty-well-balanced keel. Except for December. And January. And February. We have a longish sales cycle, so maybe things are just taking longer to close, but net business is off the great pace of most of last year. March should be a rebound month - like Paul's business, we have a sales funnel that's pretty full; other signs of disaster from lingering memory are absent - but we just won't know till we close, or fail to close, some new sales. I bet the weather hurt us too, but there seems to be some mojo in all this beyond analytical grasp. Two good months, and it'll take discipline to remember. . .

A little discussed contextual issue is increased, rapid development in some areas which results in a huge increase in pedestrians and vehicular traffic (delivery trucks, cars etc) in areas which were not designed for such.

For example, people & vehicle traffic has exploded downtown, around Beekman,Fulton,William,Nassau. The streets are really narrow but in just a few years, residential luxury development, hotel development and Pace Univ. development has resulted in massive number of people and vehicles including construction vehicles,taxis (new hotels), and school buses for new school in Gehry building, not to mention Access A Ride for people trying to get to/from hospital that has been there for years. It is not uncommon to see people (many seemingly Pace stidents) to walk right in front of cars that are moving!

Similarly, Broadway & 66th & 65th Street with Century 21, Apple Store and luxury high-rise development. So many more people, including more tourists. Incredibly, though it is a red light for them, more and more pedestrians stand in the street on Broadway blocking buses that are approaching the bus stop.

While editorialists oppose the construction of the Keystone XL pipeline into the U.S., the tar sands oil will be purchased by Pacific rim nations elsewhere. If Americans are unwilling to accept tar sands oil to improve "energy independence" from a reliable source, Canada has more than its share of willing buyers able to pay market rates. The "light sweet crude" from Libya and Saudi-Arabia may be cleaner and of higher quality, but the question remains whether it will be available in the midst of a crisis, or Arab imposed boycott.

Canadian-American relations are not of such a disagreeable state that an oil embargo will be imposed in the wake of political disagreement. Can we say the same of Saudi-Arabia and other Middle-East sources? This is a case of the U.S. environmentalists cutting off their noses to spite their faces. The adverse repercussions of this idiotic decision may not be immediately obvious, but when oil from reliable sources becomes unavailable in the midst of a crisis, as it did in 1973, it will hit home very hard!

Finally, the central teaching of this story has been illuminated! The story is not so much about the 2 sons, but about the father. In fact, it might be better titled "the Prodigal Father," for he was prodigal in his love, mercy, generosity, and the flaunting of accepted standards of right and fairness.

Interestingly, the 2 sons can be thought of as two sides of one man. If you consider the preceding parables you will see there are 100 sheep, then 10 coins, and finally, you would think, 1 son. But instead, there are two. Perhaps the author was making the subtle suggestion that all of us have some of both "sons" in us, that we can be licentious and self-righteous, impulsive and rigid, repentant and harshly judgmental. While it is not explicitly stated, my sense is that just under the surface of the text lies an invitation to respond to our "brothers and sisters" in ways that echo the prodigal father.

Please stop attributing the myriad Medicaid sign ups as "beneficiaries" of Obamacare. Those who were previously eligible to become clients have now done so, which they could have previously, but the administration has included these in their rosy numbers of how many people have been "helped" by Obamacare. Their number also include the re-enrollment of existing Medicaid recipients who just happened to renew their coverage through the new website. In plain English, these numbers are phony.
This new Medicaid expansion is the result of the federal government dangling the cookie of absorbing the cost for the first three years, but from year four on, every state which makes this Faustian bargain with D.C. will be, from that point on, totally responsible for all costs, while Washington continues to heap regulations and requirements on them for what their plans must or must not provide. Medicaid expense is so onerous that it now consumes a quarter to a third of the entire budgets of many states, and that percentage will absolutely increase over time to the point where it's predicted to consume up to half of states' entire budgets. This is progress? This is "solving" the healthcare crisis? Gimme a break!

I understand that this zoo and others in its European network treat animals differently than zoos in the USA. But I do not think that a public zoo no matter where it is located should put pure breeding practices above animal care and protection. Maybe they are practicing good science, but disposing of healthy young animals who don't fit into their breeding scheme is ethically troubling. I've long thought of zoos primarily as animal sanctuaries and secondarily as educational vehicles. An animal may be "genetically useless" for a particular zoo but breeding is not the only purpose for an animal.
Greed, greed, greed, greed, greed, greed and not caring for your fellow human beings. Did I mention greed?

I am a teacher and a dean at an elementary school and in a city full of educated people I am appalled by the fact that anyone believes that a reputable Pre-K can be funded for an entire state starting with only 100 million dollars in the first school year.
The student teacher ratio for four year olds is quite different than for Kindergarten. Furthermore, you will need to hire and develop qualified teachers at the proper ratios to ensure this is not glorified daycare. Cuomo offering $100 million for Pre-K, in a state that has nearly two million children under the age of 5, (based on the 2013 US Census) is laughable at best.
His tax cuts to businesses and the wealthy in the first year far exceed the proposed budget for Pre-K for the entire state. De Blasio's proposed tax increase which amounts to less than $1000 on the top earners will ensure that New York City has one of the best public Pre-K programs in the world, which would benefit people at every socio-economic level since all wealthy children are not admitted to private schools and attend public schools. At the G&T school where I am employed at least 30% of my students come from wealthy families, so rest assured wealthy people benefit greatly from good public education.

He plays games, and he's not shy about pressing an advantage; but he's not dumb or over-confident, either. He takes ground carefully.

Let's hope not, but all this really just happened over the last 24 hours. If we see those goose-stepping soldiers, what, precisely, will Mr. Obama do about it?

Mr. Putin knows what he'll do, which is what he did with Syria and Iran, after issuing red-line warnings: punt. Leaving Ukraine as firmly back in the bear's embrace as Georgia. Heck, we'll probably even get another snarky lesson on "exceptionalism" in the New York Times.

But you and Owen Matthews could have a point. In making an argument that he serves as a conservative bulwark against western relativist values, Putin offers a beguiling message to the populations giving him the biggest headaches today: Islamist jihadists. Who more "conservative" in values could there be, who have waged war against the west and us specifically since before 9/11, largely for the danger they believe we represent to their belief systems and manners of governance?

This is a very dangerous man, and a very smart one.

The problem we have with him really is that we don't have anything he needs or wants, and we make no efforts at all to develop such assets.

Russia cannot relinquish this important military base so to expect them to do so is naive.  Think of its strategic importance as similar to that of Gibraltar and why Britain could never relinquish control of that territory.  For this reason the instability in Ukraine forced their hand.

Universities are supposed to be places where the accumulated knowledge and wisdom of scholars is passed on to the next generation, but most universities have become research institutions where teaching is a nuisance job that most researchers resent taking up their time. So it's not surprising that they give teaching short shrift.

Research brings in big money to a university through grants, contracts, and copyrights, and helps establish a university's reputation. Good teaching, on the other hand, rarely enhances a university's reputation unless, perhaps, a professor writes a widely used textbook.

Perhaps Adam Grant's excellent suggestion might be workable at some universities, but schools looking for more money and more prestige are unlikely to be willing to give teaching more support. That's unfair to students, who pay dearly these days to get an advanced education and who shouldn't have some of their tuition siphoned off to support the school's research establishment. There should be a requirement at universities that receive federal money (and that's practically all of them) that student tuition could be used ONLY for teaching excellence. That move alone would help improve teaching standards at universities.
The correct diagnosis does matter.  So why is it when I read your diagnosis I hear a very warm wind blowing through the logical gaps in your conclusion?

I ride the subway frequently enough to recognize some of the panhandlers. Although it has become an annoying trend over the last few years, arrest seems heavy handed. That only overloads the court system with people, many of which suffer from mental illness. There are however a few infamous panhandlers who beg for money using children, and infants as a begging prop. I'm always amazed that the police turn a blind eye to this particular act. Is this not some form of enslaving children into emotional prostitution? I think perhaps the children of adults who use these tactics should be reported to DSS for abuse of minors.

People - don't diss ebooks ! Of course, until a few years ago I also had heaps of paperbacks filling my house, when I was still living on shore I could get them easily and I had room to store them. Reading was and is one of my favourite passtimes since I picked up my first childrens book at the age of 5.
But for the last 7 years my husband and me have been travelling and living on board of a sailing boat. Getting good reads was really difficult, in book swaps aroung the world one gets nothing but trash, I'm sorry to say.
Now we have swiched to ebooks readers and whenever we find internet access, I download a couple of books for our collection. I remember how happy I was, when I could buy the newest book of my favourite Swedish author online while being in Bora Bora ! Another thing I appreciate about ebooks: They never carry the moldy smell of a paperbook which has been sitting around in a damp environment (certain boats)for a long time !
Hail to the ebook, it makes the life of bluewater cruisers so much more fun !

Excellent article! And it just scratches the surface. Today's friends, for whatever reasons, are tomorrow's enemies or vice versa in an infinite array of possibilities.
And in the course of all this ethnic-religious-national-tribal musical chairs there is one point to remember: life is cheap in the Middle East.
There is one exception, although you would not know it from this newspaper and that is Israel. Yes, Palestinians, terrorists and otherwise are occasionally killed by Israeli forces and Palestinians, terrorists and otherwise, still kill Israelis from time to time, and there have been bloody wars, but this is a drop in the bucket compared to the massive slaughter that has gone on and still goes on in the Middle East.
Anybody who would seek to manage contradictions in the Middle East or to twist arms until white smoke signals a peace treaty would do well to read this article and I hope Mr. Kerry reads it first thing in the morning.
He might get a framework agreement of sorts, but the underlying contradicitions will make his framework and any Israeli-Palestinian agreement tenuous at best and fleeting at worst.

This is particularily true with healthcare in America. Set aside the Medicaid debate; conservatives object to the ACA's subsidies that help individuals purchase their own insurance policies. However, they don't object to the tax right-off (subsidy) that corporations get when they providing employee healthcare. They don't object to the outrageous fees that doctors, pharmaceutical companies, medical equipment companies, and hospitals insist on charging us, even when the exact same thing can be had for much cheaper in Canada and Europe. In many conservatives' opinion, some people just don't deserve healthcare. Personally, I've noticed they first present this as it would be great if everybody could have healthcare, but as a nation we just can't afford it. When I've countered that it's simply a matter of priorities since we clearly decided we could "afford" two wars and a bloated Pentagon, that's when the true feelings are revealed and the diatribe against the lazy and undeserving begins.

We are usually a product of where raised. Most beliefs originates from our families and culture. However, now days everywhere people seem purposefully manipulated through government and corporate control of the media. We are lead to believe that here in the West, Russia is evil and in the East, they deem America as evil. Nonsense, most people are not evil, but a product of upbringing with biases created by the greed of governments, state enterprises, and corporations. It is not about conspiracy, but greed, which connects the global economy and disconnects people from cause and effect.

As  libertarian, there are very few issues on which I agree with the Times's editorial board. But on the matter of the mentally ill, we agree 100%. One of the few legitimate jobs of the State is to care for those who cannot care for themselves, both from an absolute moral standpoint and from a utilitarian basis. The mentally ill fall into the latter category, and frankly the former. These people are sick. They need help. They are not criminals. They need observation, and possibly medication. It is such a small price to pay to assist these folks - for their own good, and ours. There are so many things the State spends money on that the private sector could easily -- and morally -- bear. But the mentally ill should be duly and humanely cared for by the state. Such a modest investment, and very much worth the spend. Morally and financially.
What on earth does one thing have to do with another?

The United States has at least $14 trillion national debt We can no longer afford to provide more than $225 billion every year in corporate welfare--tax breaks, subsidies and other wasteful spending--that goes to some of the largest, most profitable corporations in America.
One of the most egregious forms of corporate welfare can be found at a little-known federal agency called the Export-Import Bank, an institution that has a budget of about $1.4 billion a year and the capability of putting at risk some $18.5 billion in loan guarantees annually. More than 80 percent of the subsidies distributed by the Export-Import Bank goes to Fortune 500 corporations. Among the companies that receive taxpayer support from the Ex-Im are Enron, Boeing, Halliburton, Mobil, IBM, General Electric, AT&T, Motorola, Lucent Technologies, FedEx, General Motors, Raytheon and United Technologies.
The great irony of Ex-Im Bank policy is not just that taxpayer support goes to wealthy and profitable corporations that don't need it, but that in the name of "job creation" a substantial amount of federal funding goes to precisely those corporations that are eliminating hundreds of thousands of American jobs.

I don't care what this "study" says. My daughter--age 32--was diagnosed with breast cancer after having a truly exceptional doctor read her mammography with her highly honed skills.

Additionally, this same doctor became suspicious in one of her readings of my wife's mammography that something appeared to be not quite right. A biopsy was done and "irregular" (though non-cancerous) cells were
discovered--so my wife's future tests will be watched with the utmost care.

This so-caalled "study" reminds me of the current controversy over whether PSA tests for men are worthwhile or valid. Well, as one who has a rather high PSA and who has had 3 biopsies of my prostate gland over the past decade, I can attest with regard to all the cases cited above that the testing that has been done, the concern with which our excellent doctors have handled our circumstances and the awareness that has been raised, have all been extremely valuable and helpful.

In none of the cases were tests given frivolously or unnecessarily. Every procedure was discussed, mulled over and decisions were intelligently made. No rushes to judgment occurred.

So, "study" on if you wish, but I will continue to be guided by our highly professional doctors, not some "catch-all" assessment made by bureaucrats or groups who have their own agendas.

I have mixed feelings on this. Given the potentially tragic outcome, it's quite easy to view the family's actions with unsparing criticism and condemnation. And personally - it's not something I would've done myself, nor would I have been cheerleading a friend or family member embarking on such a journey.

On the other hand: it is so easy to look at this scenario and instantly pass judgement on the parents for taking such an enormous risk with such young, defenseless lives. But when I consider just a handful of articles I've read recently, about parents who skip out vaccinations - putting not just their own kids at risk, but other people as well - or people who encourage their sons to play football or do MMA despite growing ample evidence of significant risks, or when I see countless kids without bike helmets, on the side of busy streets...well, talk about risky behavior. Perhaps it's easier for people to process and evaluate what seem like smaller risks (oh, he'll just do HS football; oh, she's really healthy and who gets whooping cough anyway?) even if they aren't, truly, smaller at all. It's quite easy, and understandable, for us to condemn these parents for what I personally think was a foolish, ill-considered (mis)adventure. But it's not as though many of us aren't also taking calculated risks every day; they just aren't so spectacular as to require an oceanic rescue.
No matter what happens next, I hope little Lyra recovers well and is healthy soon.

Droughts in California are cyclical. I have lived here my whole life and droughts happen every 5-7 years. It is not the end of the world or the end of agriculture in California. There are reports of El Nino coming this summer which may bring extra rain next year. It is good to encourage water conservation but it is important to recognize that the California is a semi-arid region and the drought is caused by a lack of rain, not human error or over consumption. Cattle & other crops have been raised for years in California, drought or no drought. Leave agriculture alone! If you want improve water use in California, encourage commercial landscapers & home owners to plant drought-resistent plants and ban homeowner associations from requiring lawns in front yards.

Mr. Brooks' latest column is hypothetical and hyperbolic--perhaps more indicative of his rich imagination than facts. The problem with it is, that one can not be sure if the evidenced lack understanding of Russia is genuine, or a playing to an audience.
Russia is an incredibly complex country of over 100 ethnic groups, 27 official languages, 4 officially traditional world religions-with 30 million Muslim Russians living in the country that spans 9 time zones. It is also part of a 1,000 year-old traditional culture that is shared by a number of its neighbors, including Belorussia and Ukraine. In that kind of diverse and complex context, a drive to organization, order and stability is wholly understandable, and necessary. If one looks at the recent record of the country one sees a constant and consistent program of reforms that have modernized and improved the life of the country, its institutions, and the people. Pensions have grown, poverty has been significantly reduced, a whole host of institutional reforms--from the military to the recent streamlining of the Academy of Sciences, have been proposed and implemented.
Russia is far from a perfect country, mistakes have been made; but, on the whole, in 34 years the country has gone very far in overcoming the negative aspects of the previously failed state. Today's Russia is the freest, most prosperous, and best governed state in its long history. That is no mean achievement among fair-minded people--it would be lauded.

The situation with college admissions is that earning a coveted spot to top tier universities is not a right if you do not meet a certain GPA or test score. Ivy League and other prestigious private colleges turn away valedictorians every year. If a public institution does this to a valedictorian, it is at risk of more scrutiny. However, if you aren't an exceptional candidate, don't expect any admissions committee swoon over your application.

Fisher's case for UT-Austin (which I would call a top tier national university) was weak; she did not graduate in the top 10% of her class, and her test scores were only around the 30th percentile. It's also hard for me to have much sympathy for her as she graduated from LSU, another good school.

Today, many top tier public universities are turning away as much as 80% of the applicant pool every year (look at the UC's!), and thus admission is not guaranteed anymore. These universities attract a talented student body: science bowl champions, musicians, class presidents, and NFL prospects. And if a top 10% high schooler with high test scores earns a full scholarship to his or her state university, then why not take that opportunity when many private universities do not offer merit based scholarships? With more top 10% high school graduates taking these spots, it will just naturally decrease the availability for everyone else.

Just as we have a National Transportation Safety Board to objectively investigate plane crashes to keep them from happening so often, we need a National Immigration Safety Board to objectively investigate immigration disasters like granting asylum to Tsarnaev and Todashev.

My father was in Federal prison. We are Jewish, but he wasn't religious when he began to request kosher meals because the food was better. I looked down on him for this. He then did other religious activities in prison for brownie points (e.g., to look good at parole hearings), and I looked down on him for this. To his credit, this person who was not religious before prison is still, more than 20 years after release, religious. It is not religion itself that impresses me, but I recognize now that he found something in prison that indeed began with insincere reasons for a kosher meal.

That said, the food was so egregiously unhealthy--even kosher--that he left prison after seven years with a cholesterol level over 300.

We need to give all prisoners better food. For humane reasons and for financial reasons: we pay their medical bills as well.

Yes, wheat is an incredibly valuable food source but modern wheat is already a hybrid created by Norman Borlaug in the 60's to resist wheat rust.

Monsanto has developed new techniques that use traditional cross-breeding procedures and then use modern DNA profiling equipment to look for the required genes. I think that this new procedure is the way to properly engineer crops.

I do take some issue with this op-ed as claiming that the drought in the west is a perfectly valid reason to toss away all of our hesitations about GMO wheat. It just seems too convenient to me. I find the "natural gas leaks" wars very frustrating because most of the people who engage in them fail to understand a very basic thing: methane is oxidized into CO2 in the atmosphere with a time-constant of roughly 2 years.

Methane when it is released is a very powerful greenhouse gas, but it doesn't last all that long and then it becomes the ordinary greenhouse gas, molecule per molecule.

The point of all of this is that the calculations of how serious methane releases are assume continued production and release. And in the near term, that's surely true, other than what can be done to stop leaks.

But what about 50 to 100 years from now? Hopefully by then mankind has managed to reduce CO2 fluxes low enough that the climate can start to recover, methane production should be shutting off. CO2 will take more than 1000 years to return to pre-anthropogenic levels. Methane goes away almost instantaneously in comparison.

What about the Intelligence Community Comprehensive National Cybersecurity Initiative Data Center----or the Utah Data Center, as it's known more commonly? The president's call to end N.S.A.'s bulk data collection seemingly only applies to telephone calls, but at U.D.C. the N.S.A. has recently completed building a facility outside Salt Lake City that will collect exabytes of data.

How much is an exabyte? Enough to wrangle in everything, I mean everything, that Americans perform electronically: complete contents of private emails, cell phone calls, and internet searches. If a megabyte were the equivalent of our solar system, then an exabyte----actually, many several of them----would be equal to the entire universe.

So, stop collecting phone call data? Who makes phone calls. Anyone who's anyone knows that any young terrorist worth his or her ideology doesn't make phone calls anymore. That's like the government telling us that they'll cease and desist reading everyone's Western Union telegrams. Uh, gee, I feel so much better.

Yes, the subsidy will be reconciled at the end of the year when you file taxes.

If you've not received a subsidy and are due one, the entire subsidy will be refunded to you. If you've overestimated your subsidy (ex., your income turns out to have been higher than estimated) and received too much, the overage will come out of your refund. If there is no refund, there will be no repayment obligation (as the law now stands). If you've underestimated the subsidy, the amount due you will be refunded.

I decided to open up the Bernadotte the other night even though dinner (turkey stuffing and green beans) was likely not the best pairing for the occasion. After pouring, the wine smelled fruity for only a few minutes before the fruit aroma disappeared completely. The fruit was only mildly evident in the taste which was more savory than sweet. Both the acidity level and tannins were pleasant as compared to the Sociando-Mallet where the tannins were still rather harsh.
As I ate, it appeared that the wine became just a little more tannic but not to any significant degree. At the same time, it seemed that the salt in every part of my meal was highlighted. Interesting!
The second glass again revealed the fruity aroma that I previously noticed but, this time, it did not disappear so quickly. Perhaps I should have decanted first but all of life isn't planned out ahead of time. When I spied some brownies that were left on the counter, I decided to see how well they would taste with the wine. While the brownies did very well following a sip of wine, the wine did not enjoy the same company. Following each mouthful of brownie, the acidity in the wine appeared to rise to a level that was not at all pleasant. It was the most obvious experience, good or bad, that I have ever had when it comes to pairing food and wine.

I'm concerned that rape culture won't be able to be healed if we only focus on ending impunity without solving the pathologies of sexual violence. This is not merely an issue of empowering women and punishing men - those Indian judges, and countless others, who believe that a woman's clothing is an invitation to rape are essentially giving up their freedom and saying, "Your appearance is controlling my mind rendering me helpless to subdue my sexual urges."

Ah yes, land use. Here's a topic, not restricted to the U.S., that won't go away any time soon. My own inclinations are yours Mr. Egan, that humanity has an intellect that can collect, process, and consider the evidence of existence, and render right actions leading to more likely positive outcomes.

For instance, south of Oso, in the river valleys fed by Mt. Rainier, have been installed warning systems to attempt to save tens of thousands of lives in the event that Rainier unleashes, as it is won't to do without warning, enormous lahars.

But try to tell a landowner they can't develop, or a builder they can't construct because of slopes, soils, water, wetlands or even contaminants and you'll find yourself subject to immediate attack.

We've become a society that insists on both being allowed to do what we desire, and a society that insists on placing blame when our desires result in tragic outcomes.
