About fifteen years ago, on a sunny, mid-week summer afternoon, I boarded a Metro North train at the Spuyten Duyvil station on the Hudson line.

I was on the way up to see the guy who made and repairs one of my instruments.

I boarded the train, walked into an almost-empty car, put my instrument up on the rack in its case, and sat down.

Suddenly -coming from the seat directly across from me - I heard the sound of a banjo.

I looked over, and was greeted by a smile - which I immediately returned because he made it all so natural and easy.

We chatted for a few minutes and I told him about my instrument - which peaked his interest and curiosity because, as he told me, a member of his family had just taken it up and was trying to learn how to play.

Our conversation drifted naturally to its end, and he turned back to his banjo - softly strumming and singing.

He would have been perfectly happy to talk more, had I wanted to carry on - but I realized that it wasn't necessary for us to talk to each other in order to continue sharing our company together.

I arrived at my destination and, as I stood up to leave, he smiled at me again and we said goodbye - wishing each other well.

As I walked the few blocks from the station to the repair shop, I felt as if - on the one hand - I had just spent a few moments with an angel...but on the other hand...I had spent it with someone who embodied the true spirit of everyman.

Thanks Pete. It was a great ride.

The fundamental problem of conservatism thought today is that it fails to understand three very fundamental things:

* resources are finite and the world population is bumping up against them sharply. Conservatives think exponential growth in resource consumption can go on forever

* the "casino theorem" -- in any winner-take-all zero-sum betting game the player with the most resources has an exponentially-increasing probability of being the one to take it all. Societies are like friendly poker games -- there must be redistribution to avoid having the game end.

* the purpose of democracies and the purpose of rational social economics is to avoid redistribution by revolution or civil war.

All too often conservatives want to believe that because they are advantaged, God and reality must favor them, and create ideologies to this effect.

Here in Big Bear we have no competition for access to data whatever. My house was built in 2005 and only the electric power and Charter TV cable come in. No additional traditional phone 'landline'.

So, in order not to depend on my cell phone, I have to subscribe to charter for about a $100 per month while NOT watching any TV at all. There is NO internet only service available, I have to pay some $50 per month for TV I do not watch. That includes a DVR programmed to record ABC nightly news but nothing else.

So, I technically do NOT watch TV, only 30 minute of the nightly news from the DVR skipping over all commercials. I can easily eliminate even that - the New York Times is more than adequate in their news coverage.

Is that the future? Probably for more remote areas. The article, however, suggests that even in the cities where there supposed to be some competition, it actually is also none.

It suits the giants like Comcast, Time Warner and Charter just fine.

Carol, you are very much in the majority when you believe that earlier diagnosis will always improve medical outcome. It is very scary to accept that doing nothing can sometimes be equal to or better than doing SOMETHING. But consider the following: If a lethal breast tumor with no effective treatment would kill my patient ten years after it begins growing and she is diagnosed at year 2 by ultrasound, she would live eight years from the time of diagnosis. If she is diagnosed at year 7 by feeling the lump, she would live three years after diagnosis. Ultrasound seemed to prolong her life by five years, but in reality, she would die at EXACTLY the same time - ten years after the tumor began growing. Conversely, if the tumor is highly treatable, she would be cured by year 10 whether she was diagnosed at year 2 or year 7. In both examples, earlier diagnosis did nothing to change real outcome. For those few women where earlier diagnosis and treatment MIGHT actually improve outcome, their benefit must be carefully weighed against the physical, psychological and financial harms that other patients will suffer from over-diagnosis and unnecessary treatment. The benefit for a few might be harmful to the many. Women are not alone in dealing with this type of dilemma: Screening for prostate cancer has created similar problematic choices for men. Our emotional response is very strong. Unfortunately, it almost always tells us that earlier diagnosis is better - even when it isn't.

Chateau de la Chaize Brouilly 2011
Part II:

Second Glass: As my mother and her friends wanted split pea soup and corn bread for dinner, I doubt that the wine had a chance to shine, but it was interesting to note that it did not clash with the food, and served as an enjoyable accompaniment. Third glass: the wine had a chance to reassert its character with desert, namely fruit with brie cheese, and a small piece of salted, chocolate pretzel. It was here that I realized how serviceable the wine had become, blending its easy, enjoyable companionship with enough depth to sustain interest. It was the perfect houseguest. I look forward to trying it again with tonight’s menu: crab cakes, grits flavored with white cheddar and cream, and sautéed green beans (I think that it would go better with grilled scallops, but my mom’s guests wanted crab cakes, so I’ll accommodate). I t will probably fare even better with grilled chicken or burgers this summer.

In 2010 there were 11,078 gun related homicides and 73,505 non fatal gun shot wounds. After a decade in Iraq, almost 5,000 Americans were killed and nearly 35,000 wounded and the majority of Americans concluded that enough was enough. Yet every year, more than double those numbers are killed or wounded with guns right here in the US. And the fact is that states that have more guns have more gun homicides and countries that have the strictest gun laws have far, far fewer gun homicides. So much for the argument that more people with guns create a safer community. Yet, while the majority of Americans do not own guns and the number of households with guns are decreasing, the NRA holds the nation hostage because of their vast resources and power and because most of the pols cower before the might and money of the gun lobby. Depressing and shameful.

Here in New York, we have quite a number of different constituencies, each with slightly different agenda: "the .1 of 1%", "the 1%", the municipal unions, and finally, what I'd call "the rest of us".

It's that final constituency, "the rest of us" who are tired of being asked to pay more for less, tired of having to endure subway and bus service cutbacks coupled to higher fares (all in the midst of a punishing recession), tired of hearing one story after another of policemen receiving pensions based on deliberately engorged overtime pay (instead of their stipulated base salary), etc.

In a city with limited revenue streams, controlled by a Governor and legislature hostile to higher taxes (but addicted to corruption, at least in the instance of the legislature), something has to give - and to be blunt, "the rest of us" have already given more than our share.

In the old days, progressive politicians routinely emphasized "good government" - and I sincerely hope that Mayor de Blasio adopts this stance, inasmuch as a traditional liberal would assuredly never be reelected in New York if his policies ultimately endangered the fiscal health of our city. Been there, done that, still vividly remember the old Daily News headline "Ford to City: Drop Dead"...

Reality can sometimes bite, but reality is all we have. The municipal unions have a much better than deal than the rest of New York - and they would do well to count their blessings instead of viewing themselves as "victims".

Canizaro's plan would've killed this city - would've focused efforts on creating a Disneyworld with canned culture. Canizaro's plan would have made developers quite a few coins while eliminating the people who make this city live and the people who make this city's culture fresh, everyday.

Mr. Bender is correct, the people of New Orleans rebuilt because we want to be here. We're plenty aware of our difficulties. We're plenty aware that this is a city unlike any other.

And we're still here.

I disagree with this editorial. This unprecedented transfer of wealth to the 1% has suppressed spending, jobs, and wages for all but the wealthy. It is responsible for the current recession as well as increasing income inequality. All economic data support the negative economic effects on the overall economy of Fed activities during the past five years (e.g. see graphs at http://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/09/15/slackers-at-the-fed/). It should come as no surprise that unelected private bankers would focus on wealth transfer to the 1%, and the wealthy should indeed thank Bernanke et al.

This conflict is the inevitable consequence of Russian and American expansionism. There is no longer any ideological basis for the conflict, simply the drive to expand influence and power. The US wants to dominate the world as the only superpower, while Russia wants to return to the superpower status of Soviet times. We are fortunate this struggle is taking place in Europe and not in Asia, or we would have the complicating factor of Chinese expansionism to contend with as well. This is indeed reminiscent of the period before WWI, when German expansionism confronted a declining British and French imperialism and a rising USA. The hypocrisy and arrogance of both sides in this conflict is incredible, not to mention the stupidity of anyone following them down the path to inter-imperialist war.

This column is indicative of much that is wrong in our current political discourse, that is, the insistence on either/or, the endless false choice between deeply partisan sides. I can't speak for Montaigne or Johnson, but as for myself, I can embrace both self-improvement and self-acceptance simultaneously, and as a practicing psychotherapist, I find that those that work toward change from that perspective are often the most psychologically healthy.

In modern, political terms, which is what Mr. Brooks seems to be alluding to, I fear that the rigidly "Johnson" type could be the very same figure who leads a great nation like ours into the darkness and morass of endless wars like Vietnam and Iraq: men so bent on their own beliefs, which I would argue is borne of out a dim self awareness, that they believe they can exercise control over the world around them through "ardor" and their sense of "virtue" -- just as they do with themselves. As we know, that approach doesn't often turn out too well.

what's left to buy and then by whom?
the fragile few-supported boom
the profits in the bank
who do they have to thank?
not us, unable to consume.

This was not a Hubspot pitch. I have no relationship with Hubpsot other than I'm a customer. I didn't say that Wordpress was the problem, I said that my supplier and designer was the problem. They never provided training and were almost impossible to work with.

I moved to Hubspot because of their integrated solution that was easy for me to use. My primary focus is servicing my clients, not designing and maintaining websites.. The solution I choose allows me to have a reasonably good site that can be maintained with little effort.

You can do the same things with Wordpress I do with Hubspot. For me, having everything in one place and not having to research various plug ins and programs is a big plus. Like many small businesses I have very limited time for maintaing and updating my site. I find that it's been easier for me to use the Hubspot solution than using Wordpress.

I'm sure that there are those who are more sophisticated and like the mix match capabilities of a Wordpress site. I don't have the time nor do I want to spend the time learning various programs that would be necessary for me to do this.

Like all tech solutions, there are several ways to get to the same place. The road I choose was a combination of research and taking a path that worked for me. I've seen plenty of really good Wordpress sites that are very sophisticated. It's a great product and I again want to emphasize that my issue was with my designers and not the product itself.

On the plus side. it's not as if they took the kids to the zoo
to watch a giraffe being butchered. DIfferent cultures?

While many on this site advocate cutting off aid to Israel, they would do well to consider what the consequences of such a policy would lead to. According to the Congressional research council in a report by Jeremy Sharp April 11, 2013: “The United States has provided Israel $118 in military assistance.” Read the US gave American military contractors over $100 billion since 1948. For example Israel will get US government grants of $2.75 billion to procure the F-35 America’s latest stealth technology fighter. But that money is not going to Israel, it is going to Lockheed Martin, the plane’s producer. Cutting military aid to Israel would hurt us more than the Israelis. It would also reduce our leverage on Israel which is reliant on our continuing supplies; we do hold a check on Israeli military activities.
While the current Israeli government is the least good partner the Palestinian have had for an agreement, the Palestinians are also not thrilled with our peace initiative. They have ejected better offers, most recently the Clinton plan was rejected by Arafat in 2000. At issue is America’s and Europe’s interest in putting a permanent lid on the problem by going back to the 1967 borders (the Clinton Plan) but most Palestinians perceive that as a sellout, they want a return of Palestinians to Israel, an unacceptable demand to Israel because it would in short order turn the Jewish population to a minority in their own country. In other words it would end Israel.

Many of the commenters would do well to read Jim Corbett's wonderful books on hunting man-eaters. Corbett had a great respect for tigers. His books make it clear that except for very unusual circumstances, tigers don't eat humans unless they [the tigers] are injured and unable to hunt their usual prey. And a tiger won't attack a human unless she [for it's often a tigress protecting her cubs] feels threatened. I've visited both Corbett and Bandhavgarh and seen these beautiful animals up close. I've also met Belinda Wright, who has single-handedly done more than anyone else I know of to protect tigers from being killed by poachers. [Traditional Chinese medicine is a major consumer of tiger parts.] I'm sorry that this tigress has killed people, but the situation described in this article sounds so much like what happened in Corbett's time. I hope Sandjay Singh is successful, but please, let's not let this tigress start a general war to eradicate tigers.

It is amazing in retrospect to recall the end of the Soviet Union with barely a shot being fired.  It took exactly 25 years for the built up tensions between Moscow and its former satellites to finally explode in gunfire and bloodshed.  The U.S. has intervened militarily in every country within our sphere of influence in the Western hemisphere where--real or imagined--it has seen its interests threatened--from Cuba to the most insignificant sleepy island in the Caribbean; can we really now expect Russia to stand by while the West urges on the expansion of its influence to the very border of Russia?  Most governments would long ago have called out the military, tanks would be rolling through the streets of Kiev to put down the insurrection.  The suspicion is inescapable that the Ukrainian government would do the same if, and this is a very big if, it could trust its own army to follow orders.  If they can not do the job, we must entertain the real possibility that it will be Russian tanks that get the job done.  And that will be a very dangerous day for the world indeed.

I don't know who came up with the idea that corporations are benevolent entities that create jobs to distribute wealth, but they should share what they are smoking. Corporation are formed to create wealth, not to distribute it. They are solely for the purpose of building something for the founder not to provide employment or anything else. Employment and wages are a by-product of these entities.

I didn't start my businesses because there are unemployed people everywhere. I need to earn a living and I can do it best as the owner of these companies. In my businesses I work for other companies, who need what I offer, and they pay me to provide it. We exchange my skills for their money. It's a fair and equitable arrangement. They don't hire me because I need work: I have something they need.

This whole share the wealth and tax the rich is all econo-babble. If you took all the money in this country and divided it equally among all the citizens, it would only take a few years before it was back in the hands of those who already have it. We don't teach fiscal responsibility and wealth management, we teach credit and mismanagement of money. In fact this is our religion: Buy now - pay later and pay forever.

In between the "climate change deniers" and the hard core U.S. green lobby are the practical people - we accept that there may be global warming from man made activities, but there is not a thing that can be done about it and we had better figure out how to work around it. The vast majority of people in the world do not live in the U.S. or Europe. They don't care or even know about global warming. And most importantly, we can't make them care about it. Here we can pass laws that make people stop using energy inefficient light bulbs, and that makes some of us feel good that we are doing our part, but it doesn't actually make a difference.

I grew up in a family where politics was a regular topic of discussion at the dinner table and family get-togethers. (And we had liberals and conservatives, but the conservatives were Eisenhower types who scoffed at the sort of people the GOP elects today.) We children were supposed to be not heard during these debates, but it was an education. National and local, issues and political figures were dissected at length during these times. Our family had subscriptions to both local newspapers (whose editors were in total opposition to each other), attended political speeches, watched conventions on TV--our parents didn't care if we liked it or not, they thought we needed to know about it.

By the time I turned 18, I felt like I was ready to vote.

Many people I know--well-educated adults--did not have the benefit of this training. It is easy to forget how steep the learning curve is if you are starting from scratch. My accountant told me that politics is "all Greek " to him. He thinks they're all lying, and can't figure out how to sort it all out. He owns a business, has a family, and has little free time. So he doesn't bother--or, in some cases, goes along with his more ideological accountant buddies and votes GOP.

So vote--and talk to your children about why you're doing this.

One of the most successful experiments in early childhood education was the Carolina Abecedarian Project conducted by the University of North Carolina in the 1970s. The project provided wraparound services (education, health care, family support) to 111 children from birth to age 5. As noted in "How to Get More Early Bloomers," also in today's NYT, the project produced significant and enduring results.

There are three major challenges. First, the expense. The 2012 Kids Count survey estimates that 6,000,000 children below the age of 5 live in poverty. Even at a modest $10,000 annual cost per child, the annual cost to serve all eligible children would be $60 billion.

The second, even bigger challenge, is to maintain high quality services when the programs are brought to scale. There is ample evidence that as programs expand from ground zero, maintaining the same level of staff commitment and quality control becomes increasingly difficult. As the researchers on the Abecedarian Project noted, the founding staff members were passionate about their work and their roles as trailblazers. They cautioned policymakers not to expect this same level of passion or similar results in a scaled up program.

The final challenge will be to gain support for an initiative where results take years to manifest themselves. As Obamacare has demonstrated, Congress is considerably more adept at attacking the first bump in the road than taking the long view.

We started this wine club in conjunction with the Wine School and it consists of three Walkers and a Hatfield.  After a search of the internet, we found the Chateau Bernadotte 2009 in a wine store about a half hour away in Delaware.  Dinner was Poulet Basque -- a sauté of chicken, peppers, onions and tomatoes.  Initially, we found the aroma to be of black cherries and other fruit.  After a while in the glass, that aroma changed to smoke from a wood fire.  The taste was on the savory side, which we found surprising considering the fruity aroma.  Over time, the taste got more woody.  The texture was of medium tannicity (not as tannic as a California cabernet, for example), with a nice balancing acidity.  The texture smoothed out as we drank it.  The consensus was that the wine paired well with the meal.  For comparison, we paired the Bernadotte with a much cheaper Bordeaux that was more in line with the price we usually pay for wine ($13).    It was a 2012 Chateau Bellevue.  We found it to be more watery and more bitter with an aroma of sweet butter.  Let's say it enhanced our appreciation of the Bernadotte considerably.  All in all, we consider our first outing of the wine club a success.

The biggest problem with orthodox religion is not that it tends to be "judgmental", etc. The real problem is that religion demands adherence to "facts" that are demonstrably not facts and clearly contrary to our actual observable experience. The more orthodox you tend to be, the less wiggle room you are allowed. Otherwise, by definition, you are not orthodox.

Jesus said, "Blessed are they who did not see, and yet believe." What might He have said to people who can, more or less, clearly see that we evolved from apes, who can see and implicitly prove the world is very old, there was no flood, and that "miracles", in general, are pretty easily explained. Even on moral issues, most don't believe homosexuals are evil, that women should be subservient, etc... and the explanation for why bad things happen to good people just rings hollow. What do you say to the people who are aware of the myriad of historical abuses delivered for religious purposes?

There is no answer that can be taken seriously by a serious questioner. So, two options present themselves if you intend on maintaining faith... either you take a scalpel to belief and amputate all that is inconvenient, outmoded or disproved (stoning, food prohibitions, etc.) in which case you get to generic spiritualism... Where God is a place holder for things we wish for or don't yet understand. Or you go the cognitive dissonance route and believe whatever you're supposed to believe (hence the hostility).

I disagree with those who say that this doesn't have any carry over to our understanding of human metabolism.

Non-pathogenic insulin resistance is a phenomenon that has also been observed in humans before. Humans in a fasted state can develop insulin resistance in their muscles so that the body preferentially shuttles blood sugar to the brain. I think the phenomenon has also been observed in pregnant women on a low-carb diet to ensure that the fetus gets enough nutrition. I'm surprised the article didn't draw attention to that, it makes the connection to human metabolism much more apparent.

It's possible that humans would store excess calories as fat in the summer to prepare for winter, but I'm not totally convinced. Dr. Jaminet at Harvard has suggested that humans would likely store excess calories as muscle tissue. There was a great study that controlled for calorie intake and amount of exercise and compared a high protein to high carb diet (Effect of dietary protein content on weight gain, energy expenditure, and body composition during overeating: a randomized controlled trial, Bray et. al, JAMA 2012): the high protein diet ended the trial period with more added muscle than the high carb diet, despite no difference in the anabolic stimulus of exercise.

High performers also perform well on standardized tests. Only low performers have a problem with it.

All of us who are just poor schlubs with normal incomes, mortgages and taxes are now effectively eliminated from political participation. Yes, we can pound the pavement, make telephone calls to get out the vote, and write our Congresspeople. But how can we complete with Sheldon Adelson and the Koch Brothers? My $25 bucks to the DSCC is a pitiful amount compared to the tens of millions doled out by the oligarchs. This gets them air time in favor of their chosen toady--effectively their employee in Washington--and they get their telephone calls answered and their meetings any time they wish. They also get the legislation that favors their increased profits supported. Since they can now buy 218 Representatives if they wish, the desires of the rest of us, even if we are in the majority as we are on so many issues not favored by Republicans, now are ignored by our legislators. We might as well be living under the Articles of Confederation where only property owners got to vote. I have never been so disheartened about the future of our democracy. Bad times are ahead, and we will look back to April 2, 2014 as the day when they started for good.

Many people are eligible for an early retirement with a defined benefit pension. Similarly many had Social Security bridge payments planned which provided an equivalent payment, paid by the employer, to early social security payments up to age 62. Again, unless there was a contract involved (generally for hourly employees) these were not guaranteed regardless of all the social contract rhetoric.
When the paid medical for early retirements (pre-65/66 years of age) was removed he reason many remained working was to receive health insurance.
Obamacare offers this group an out. Although some may not be happy with the prices they have to pay.
But no one should assume all these jobs will be backfilled, at least in the US, as many have commented in the last week or so. The companies that offered these sort of benefits have a propensity to off shore the positions of the retirees.
While Obamacare is providing "options" to the early retirees the taxpayers, sorry, the insurance premium payers are paying for it. At least some group is coming out ahead with Obamacare in addition to the medicaid recipients.

Way too many commenters are relishing the schadenfreude of dubbing Sen. Feinstein a hypocrite because of her historically vigorous defense of our out-of-control security apparatus, and there is a kernel of substance there.

But this is not about one Senator, not personal, and not political. There is a significant difference between supporting, from the cloister of Congressional committees privy to state secrets, such controversial practices as the NSA's data-collection programs, on the one hand, and tolerating for one minute the possibility that the CIA has turned its clandestine efforts on the Congress of the United States to thwart a much-needed, overdue investigation into the agency's tactics and to further a cover-up of extremely serious wrongdoing by agency personnel.

Spying on foreign leaders and ordinary Americans is one thing. A rogue agency spying on the branch of our government tasked with its oversight is quite another. It is far more sinister, the stuff from which dictatorships grow.

Sen. Feinstein, my Senator, knew she would be ridiculed as a hypocrite by partisan critics who pounce on anything with the potential to tip elections or diminish a political brand, but she had the humility and courage to call out the CIA on the floor of the Senate and prompt all of us, the president included, to pay attention to what surely looks, if not overtly criminal, constitutionally unacceptable.

I'm getting tired of seeing prescription drugs get blamed for everything. Mr. Hoffman acknowledged he suffered a heroin addition throughout his life. Did he abuse pain killers? Probably. But suggesting the causal relationship that pain killers led to his heroin death rather than his heroin addiction led to addictions to more drugs is wrong. No doubt people abuse pain killers. Guess what: these people always find something to abuse. Bath salts, cough syrup, pain killers, illegal drugs, etc. I know it's not easy finding the balance between having a product available for those that need it and restraining it from those that don't, but I believe that availability for those in need outweighs the alternative. Instead of always making some legitimate product the scapegoat for people's bad behavior, lets place the blame on those who form addictions. Their mind might have a predisposition to addictions, but others in society should not be punished (by overly restricting medicines) because of their short-comings.

Anti-nuclear fear-mongers and climate-change 'deniers' are cut from exactly the same cloth. They both ignore science and facts. I've thought for quite a while that environmentalists could make a lot of progress by educating themselves on nuclear power, which is the only approach likely to have any effect on climate change, especially given the developing worlds need for cheap energy. As the article suggests I think 'conservatives' are made less dogmatic about climate change if they see those concerned actually suggesting a solution which has a chance of working.

A lot of this is just the usual tribal influence of human beings. We figure out where our tribe stands on something and that is what we support. In this case, if we simply appeal to science and demonstrable facts, both sides can overcome this prejudice to some extent, and we may actually be able to move toward a solution.

Whatever is happening in the 'West' we can be thankful that China and I think India as well 'get it' and are embarking on major building programs for nuclear power.

Twenty years ago I saw Pete Seeger crossing a street near the University of Minnesota. He had a concert that evening and was walking to the venue with his banjo slung over his shoulder.  In a time, both then and now, when so many flash-in-the-pan celebrities travel via self-serving entourages, here was one of Americas greats, whom I rank right up there with Walt Whitman. He was saving some money, getting some exercise, and strolling along without drawing attention to himself.  Today, they day of his death, someone will probably say, “they don’t make them like that anymore.”  I think Pete Seeger would say the opposite. “They make people like me all over the place, you just have to have your eyes open to see them.” In our time of battling politicians rather than statesmen, and of news entertainers rather than journalists, and a culture that celebrates money rather than art, it may be hard to find people like Pete Seeger, but I think he’d laugh at that idea. They’re out here; you just have to be ready to see. So don't worry, Pete Seeger remains such a vital part of America, he is always going to be with us. Just take the time to look and to listen.

"And he [Obama] trusts himself to use these powers more than he did the Bush administration.”  Herein lies the problem.  We have no idea who will be elected 4 or 8 or 32 years from now. There is no guarantee that future presidents won't use the NSA data for blackmail and wholesale suppression of dissent. It is not clear where this issue with "microaggression" is going. Are they really aiming for a pure, non-offensive society? Where there is diverse culture, there will be friction and misunderstanding. More often than not, this leads to creativity and progress. I am Asian and grew up outside of Boston, the only non-white in a 1500 student school. Yes, there was plenty of misunderstanding and "offensive" remarks. But most were made by people with good intentions who did not understand my culture and experience. I had compassion and love for them and sought to educate them when I could. To me growing up in that environment, I suffered my share of pain but overall it was a great experience that enriched me. I encouraged people to express whatever stereotypes they might hold because it creates an open environement for open mutual learning and respect. I became quite successful as a doctor. Now I travel the world with ease. Everywhere I go, I still experience my share of misunderstanding and at times prejudice. But overall 90+ percent of the people in the world means well. I spend my time learnig from them rather than withdraw into isolated victimhood. I find the "microaggression" analysis to be counterproductive because it discourages people from expressing their views(however ignorant) for fear of being accused of being labeled "racist", "insensitive". In the end it can create hidden feelings of frustration and mistrust.

As one who has worked in college admissions and college placement at private and public institutions, I am rather baffled by the comments which appear to be generally informed by personal experience rather than rational analysis of the mass of data regarding the fairness and effectiveness of standard tests for college entrance.

Very little evidence is presented that these tests have any predictive value. 850 colleges manage to select a freshman class without requiring ACT or SAT (go to FairTest's website for a complete list).

Search for "cultural bias," and there is plenty of evidence of supporting that claim. As well, these tests are not designed to be taken by anyone with a learning disability, and a search for successful folks with dyslexia will give further weight to the case against requiring such tests. The SAT and ACT have a very narrow definition of what it means to be "smart" or to have the potential to succeed in college, let alone, life.

We also know that these "required" tests are expensive especially when multiple testings are needed to ensure reliable results. Anyone in the bottom quarter of household income (c. $25,000) is hard-pressed to pay the per test fees, let alone pay for a test prep course.

Can anyone justify using a test designed to identify America's best and brightest that produces results that can be doctored by anyone who is white and rich?

Sense of community is something that is built over a person's lifetime. This doesn't mean it doesn't start from a young age--quite the contrary--but formative experiences can make or break a person's impulses to community.

For all that millennials might not trust strangers as much as prior generations, I think they tend to accept people as not-strangers somewhat more easily than previous generations. Their marked willingness to take people on their own terms instead of the phobias of the past make them much more cosmopolitan.

Yes, we have seen breakdowns of local community institutions. Yes, this is a problem. However, the best way to build a local community is to support the underlying social infrastructure--the health and well-being of the people, easy access to spaces to meet and so on. The video arcade and small bookstore of the 1980s and 1990s have mostly gone away, the church of yesteryear is less trusted than before, and most restaurants don't want a gaggle of teenagers or twenty-somethings sitting around for a couple of hours if they don't keep consuming.

Really, rebuilding modern community space would be nice.

At the same time, it would help if we didn't have so much media telling us to fear the Other. If you teach people to fear others, they are less likely to reach out to other people.

These seem like basically good, loving parents, though I cringed a bit when I heard them talk about culture and cultural perceptions. Fundamentally, I believe culture is a fluid, living thing, not something you can hand someone in a box and say, Here's your culture. Along those same lines, I don't believe in any inherent culture: just because someone "looks" a certain way or has a certain last name, doesn't make them something. Coming from an immigrant family in the US, I understand that deeply: I will never be the person, culturally, I would have been had my parents never left their native country.

Further, the type of parenting that these women promote is perhaps even more heavy-handed than had the girls grown up in a Chinese American family. Maybe they would've known a bit of the language, the food, etc. but it would probably be superficial and as the generations pass, perhaps nothing. Chinese Americans are no different than Italian Americans, Mexican Americans, and others in their superficial knowledge of their ancestral culture. That's what happens in the immigrant USA.

Nevertheless, I sense the dilemma here: these parents don't want to "fail" in some way, say down the line, if one of the girls expresses a sense of regret over not knowing her ancestral language, etc. So, it's a catch 22 in some ways: the parents want to do the right thing, but when they talk about it, it just sounds imbued with stereotypes and fundamentally misled. Good luck!

How do you deal with the plans' incentive to order fewer necessary tests and treatments? The only solution is to require coverage for services of any licensed provider, and of any devices and pharmaceuticals prescribed by any licensed provider.

A lot of feed back on this. My thoughts are of lost opportunity. In 1981, 6 months after undergoing heart bypass surgery at age 48, I was laid off from my job. It was a good job for a single woman, good salary, a place to live in a fine community and company provided-health insurance. I suddenly found myself without all three. I was desperate.

1981 was not a good year for career opportunities and finding housing without an income was equally difficult. But my first priority was actually health insurance. As a result, I took a minimum wage clerical job which did provide health insurance at an affordable rate...no pre-existing problems. At least I was pretty sure I wouldn't die from the lack of medical care. Although I eventually returned to my previous field of work, my choices were limited, my future pretty much dimmed by that time...

I live near the nature reserve of Barton Cove, in Western Massachusetts. Some years ago, several mute swans arrived. At the time there was a prolonged, and intense debate as to whether they should be allowed to stay.
Eventually, a decision was made to let them nest.
Their numbers have increased, but these beautiful, and majestic creatures, live perfectly amicably with other avian species.
I cannot imagine the area without them.
Oh, and this winter, I watched as these huge birds broke through the ice. The much smaller bird species watched too. Soon there was water for all the birds to swim, and feed in.
I think mute swans coexist better than most humans!

Two issues you pretend to address, but miss. First, you suggest poverty is caused by shortsighted behaviors on the part of the poor (high school dropouts, single parents), yet while you accuse liberals of confusing correlation with causality, you are not immune. Kids from impoverished households don't have the support structure to encourage them to stay in school, and lack of job prospects for parents (especially young fathers) can encourage abandonment of the family. I'm not excusing these behaviors, but there are reasons (besides a lack of individual initiative) that make it difficult for children from impoverished families to break the cycle of poverty.

Second, while not all minimum wage earners support a family, many do. And while an individual may avoid working a minimum wage job through self-improvement, someone will always be working those jobs. And why shouldn't a full time job be enough to live on, regardless of the skills required to perform it? Increasing the minimum wage has two positive impacts; it raises up the lowest earners and it improves the economy overall because of the increased demand created by the additional spending of those whose wages have been raised. Demand creates opportunities for investment, without which capitalism fails (as has been seen in this economy when corporations sit on piles of cash instead of investing it).

The ugly truth behind pet care is that if the prices get too high, many owners will let their pet die or euthanize them. You have one very lucky pet.

Your overall complaints is that the cost of human medicine is really high. And you would be correct. The insurance is really exposing many people to the actual cost of a lot of treatment - it isn't their fault. We as a society have let medical prices spiral completely out of control over the last 50+ years, though medical care has never been cheap.

The ACA is a "one size fits all" package - because very precisely tailoring of coverage creates groups that are a lot smaller and the actuarial tables won't work out.

And, yes, the ACA does free people to pursue their dreams and not be chained unduly to the corporations. Because one big thing the current ACA offers that your old plan doesn't, is that if you got truly ill, like contracted cancer, the insurance company cannot yank your coverage. Your old plan that you miss because it was so inexpensive, would likely have foudn technicalities to deny you coverage if you truly had become ill - forcing you to sue them to regain your paid for coverage, if you had survived long enough to walk your way through the court systems, and the hopsitals would have treated you without an ability to pay.

Nigel, everyone else in society assumes huge costs when our fellow citizens die early, get sick too often, and otherwise suffer from their "free" consumer choices. Health care is largely driven by hospital and MediCare costs for smokers, for avoidable cancers, for toys and machinery that hurt people, for unsafe cars, for drunken drivers, etc. That's why we don't allow such "freedoms."
Our ERs are filled with victims the public pays for, but now after a decade of government attempts to control lunch choices and eating habits, our kids are going to live and work longer as the propensity for obesity is reduced. For adults, there is less hope, since millions of nice people are hugely overweight and thus doomed to poorer health -- doomed by "free" choice, the way drunken drivers are. Someone will have to care for them, pay taxes to give them the help we must, produce what they can't, and support the kids and the partners they leave, solve the damage some cost. Every "free" choice is fun, some kill. John Donne said it: "No man is an island..." Our common humanity forces us to care for our sick. Should it not make us attempt to prevent sickness? Europe in general is a far different culture than America when it comes to work and leisure. Having spent extended time in France and Portugal, I have seen that attitudes are different. Long lunches in France are common and wine is expected as part of the meal. The August vacation in Paris is like a wartime evacuation with careful instructions given on who may rush out of the city at a given hour to try to avoid a complete jam of traffic heading south. It is a model of coordinated madness.

One of the evolved purposes of the schedule in Spain is to allow people to spend much more time in group settings with close friends and co-workers. The long dinner with friends, whether male or female, it could be a healthier way. Life is lived with a group, not in isolation. One has less time to obsess about work, personal accomplishments and failings. Identity becomes partially bound up in the group, not the self.

The Spainish way allows men to escape the pressure to be more domesticated in the home, to avoid becoming subsumed by the responsibilities of house, children and spouse. In this country, we would see this as unfairly moving those burdens from the husband to the wife. Yet, how many men here decide to escape those responsibilities by divorce as soon as the kids are grown?

In general, people in Europe and the UK tend to see work as part of life, not life itself. They don't seek merely balance between the two, but to banish work mentally by pleasures and vacations.

I am fully on board with celebrating the success of enrollment in ObamaCare and the benefits which many, many people are already deriving from the ACA.

However, with all the relief of seeing the worst predictions after the disastrous rollout having been avoided, we should be aware that there are still huge hurdles to be overcome.

The first one is the upcoming election this year, were some credible signs are indicating that the GOP may take over the Senate in addition to maintaining control of the House. Although it is unlikely that an outright repeal of the ACA is in the cards even then, there are innumerable roadblocks the GOP could implement to ensure their goal of making the ACA fail.

The others are the many problems built into the ACA itself. The fact that the requirement to have insurance is rather half-hearted, so that a very adverse pool of insured may still develop, thus raising the cost of the program. The other is the reliance on for-profit insurance companies, who will be motivated to continually find ways of denying coverage, especially if they happen to have insured a high risk, high cost pool.

Once again, America chooses to ignore the multitude of functioning models for universal health care from around the world. The worst case scenario is that the ACA may collapse through its inherent flaws and the continuing relentless GOP obstruction. The best case scenario may be l that universal coverage is never achieved, and costs remain high by world standards.
Proving that people are not as uninformed as they seem, just maybe a little slow to catch on.

Speaking from personal experience, I would say the problem Prof. Grant outlines is right on. I attended a small, top-notch liberal arts college where teaching was the primary job of all faculty members, and they did a great job of it. They lectured, ran recitations, graded papers, and provided feedback and counseling. Research was conducted to supplement their teaching, and certainly was not the primary basis for tenure decisions. Research grants contributed a trivial amount to the college's funding.

Then I went to graduate school at a mid-sized university. The impression I had was that research was their main objective, and teaching was an onus placed on them in order to maintain the university's status as an "institution of higher learning". Graduate students were a source of cheap labor, and took on the more mundane tasks of teaching. Professors who "taught" usually just stood in front of a class and recited lecture notes. TAs graded papers, ran recitations, and did most of the real teaching. They were hardly prepared to be teachers, but in many cases did a better job than the research professors they worked for.

I don't know if Prof. Grant's proposed solution will work in practice, but it certainly deserves consideration.

I understand that the notion of "natural monopoly" has gone out of fashion. It also perfectly describes the "access network" - all the infrastructure that connects residential and small business customers to a central office (head end in Cablespeak). Competition in a market that is a natural monopoly is an oxymoron.

Here's the problem. All that infrastructure is a hugely expensive capital investment. Operating expenses are nothing to sneeze at either (even with the cost cutting that leads to less than stellar service). Worse, the lion's share of that cost is in passing homes, regardless of whether they take service. There is no revenue generation until the billing cycle AFTER the residents of a home subscribe. And each new entrant dilutes the revenue base for all competitors. Incumbents also have the advantage of existing rights of way, pole attachments, underground duct and structures, which are limited resources and are costly to develop anew.

All of which means that overbuilding existing infrastructure is a generally lousy business plan. With such high barriers to entry, vigorous competition is not possible.

Commentators right and left appeal to competition, as if this were a classical free market. It isn't. And without competition to impose market discipline, all that is left is regulation.

Here is the result when you allow an already compromised society to have their way.

So many comments proclaim their fears of future administrations misusing the data – data that does not in and of itself violate the Constitution – to impose some sort of “police state”, as being grounds for disallowing their very collection. Fears of a rogue administration is not adequate rationale for hamstringing a legal program that has, we are told (and have no reason to disbelieve), achieved success in interdicting terrorist acts. Those data are essential to the President achieving his oath of office, to protect the nation.

Of course these data can be misused. So can your detailed financial records held by the IRS, or personal health information submitted to the government-required health insurance program. Those are many instances where not only are data vulnerable to misuse – but where submitting those intimate data is mandated by law.

But we have a system designed to detect and punish rogue administrations. It is call “checks and balances” and is the foundation of our very form of government. Does it work? Sure does. Think Nixon.

The data collection by the NSA is legal. It is Constitutional, Its use continue to be monitored, by the legislative branch that authorized it, by the administrative branch that implements it – and by the judicial branch as well. So perhaps what we are seeing in Crimea (and other parts of eastern/southern Ukraine) are fascist elements among the Russophiles -- egged on by all those recent Russian "tourists" -- basing their opposition/attacks on the specter of fascist elements among the Ukrainian nationalists -- fascists of one stripe (supported by Russia) against fascists elements of another. It's the "Care Imperative."  Caring for children, the elderly, households, organizing social functions: all these fall disproportionately on women, all are unpaid.  Yet society needs these functions done - not women, society. This disparity of formal employment 'discrimination' has been noted elsewhere in developing countries where women do not have the time to get more education or engage in the training that might improve their job prospects.  Why? Because they spend their time doing what society needs but doesn't pay for: raising the next generation, feeding people, taking the elderly to doctors.  So women earn less, advance less, have less power. Until either (1) these unpaid jobs are shared equally with men, (2) communities meet the needs (childcare, for example), or (3) this care work is paid, then women will not be able to attain equality in the formal job sector.

Unable to find a Sociopath-Mallet, I opted for a 2009 Chateau Malescasse Haut Medoc. I made rib eye steaks in a grill pan. It was a warm spring evening, and the wine was around 65 degrees.
The aroma (and the first tastes) were fairly closed. Eventually it opened up to be a surprisingly full-bodied, black currant fruit wine, with some underlying herbal notes. There was some acidity, some juicy zing, but I picked up more on a smooth, mouth coating glycerin, with licorice flavors. This wine was about balance, lovely dark fruit with a great tannic finish. The flavors of the wine and the steak seemed to urge each other on to glorious heights neither reached on its own. I have not drunk many Bordeaux since the prices took off disproportionately to my income in the mid-'90s, and I was thrilled at how good this seemed. It also had a sense of place--Bordeaux. Easy to say knowing what it was, but I'm sure I would not have mistaken it for a California cabernet. Something about the way the elements were nicely integrated in its youth.
When I took it out of the refrigerator two nights later, when it was more like 55 degrees, it was flatter--had lost some of the acidity or zing in the texture. Still detected licorice and glycerin.
A very enjoyable start.

This love and leave investor frenzies are rocking the economic boats. We need some damping effects.
Like a restraining ratio of capital flow in and out of a country.

If investors suddenly withdraw money, but get the money paid back over a timeframe, depending on the economic health of the country, they propably would be more cautious and would seek more long-term investments. This also would provide some leverage to the country, similar to a low rate government bond.
But of course countries and investors prefer bull markets, and they will be reluctant to restrain hot money. That's why such a timeframe should be provided by the typical investor countries. Something like TARGET2 (Trans-European Automated Real-time Gross Settlement Express Transfer System), but with a time factor.
That would propably have the positive effect that hot money is more reluctant to cross borders. Positive because - i think one reason for the global malaise are investors intentionally rocking the boats and to scram in the right moment, that's how they try to make money. If this option is crippled, they have to choose different means - like domestic investments. And then the money would remain in the countries where the wealth has it's origin.

And for Turkey, they had more than a decade of robust growth. It may be overvalued, but they only thing they should fear is fear itself, that investors bail out because of a little setback.

Any policy that chases "full employment" is destined to fail.

There is absolutely no economic rule or logic, that a given economic system needs to produce *exactly* the same number of jobs as the total work age population who desires to work. The very notion of trying to match two completely unrelated numbers is ludicrous.

The economy will provide exactly the number of workers that are need to satisfy internal and external demand, given all the economic constraints. In fact, we may advance our technology and production capacity so much, that it is like that less and less workers are needed to produce all the goods and services we can possibly consume.

History is replete with *the only viable solution* to excess workers. Migration. Be it the Irish and Italians migrating to America, or the Japanese migrating to Brazil, or Michigan residents migrating to Texas, or Greeks migrating to Germany. Workers who can't find work in one economic system need to migrate to another one.

Our economic policies should be about encouraging productivity improvements, production cost leadership, skills, entrepreneurship, and demand, so more jobs are created in the US than in other economies.

But there are no guarantees.

Can't find a job in Michigan or New York? Move to North Dakota (2% unemployment). And don't claim it is too hard to get on your car and drive 1,000 miles. Millions upon millions upon millions of immigrants, including our forefathers, crossed oceans in primitive ships.
Tolstoy you ain't.

Naloxone is essential but is not a magic bullet. The duration of action is much shorter than that of heroin: There is still a risk of death from a heroin overdose when naloxone wears off after 1-2 hours  Repeated doses may be needed and close monitoring is required - and should be done in a hospital.   Our laws still drive users and potential rescuers underground.  More lives could be saved by decriminalizing possession (but not the sale) of heroin, making treatment for addiction much more widely available and affordable - ideally free -  and allowing regulated distribution by physicians and nurses to registered addicts.  Despite abundant evidence of a failed strategy, and thousands of lives wasted, we insist that addiction is entirely a moral problem best dealt with  by law enforcement and incarceration.

It must have been 1997, or just after (I only know that because I read this article just now), that I read The God of Small Things and was moved to go hear the author speak at what was then called, "A Well-lighted Place for Books" in San Francisco. I had really admired her novel, not only for the story of family decay and caste prejudice in India, but for the shear poetry of it. She wrote beautiful, intoxicating sentences. I had no idea what she looked like, so it’s hard to imagine how weirdly shocking, almost off-putting, it was to sit with fifty or so people listening to one of the most strikingly beautiful women I had ever seen read from her work. (Intellectuals aren’t supposed to be so good-looking!) This story in the NYTs has reminded me of the tremendous impression she made on me 17 years ago, and it makes me lament the harsh treatment she has received in her own country. I may be imagining that I can almost see the effect this has had on her in the accompanying series of photos. I am happy that she has returned to fiction and I look forward to reading her new work.

Pete played a concert in Ithaca NY on an extremely cold night in the winter of 1970 at a small hall holding less than 2,000 people. At 11PM, a security guard came onstage and whispered into Seeger's ear. Pete went over to the sound man (sidestage) and exchanged a few words, then came back to the microphone. He announced that the concert hall was officially closing but the sound man said they could set up a PA system outside, and would the audience like to continue outside. The audience cheered, so we all exited to the bitter 10 degree (F) winter night. Nearly 1,000 people stood freezing for more than 40 minutes while the equipment was being set up. Pete came back on and sang for nearly an hour more until almost 1AM in the cold winter air.

Farewell, Pete.

Darwinian natural selection is discredited as an explanation for the vast majority of human behavior. The core idea, the very essence of Darwinism, is reproductive success and the struggle for existence. For millenia humans have decidedly NOT been maximizing their reproductive success---witness the existence of contraception, abortion, or indeed any other activity which distracts from reproduction (namely almost all of culture). Do you know ANYBODY whose first priority is to have the biggest family they can ?

If this essential feature of natural selection is not determining human behavior, why would we expect things like altruism to be Darwinian in origin ? It's just slavish obedience to materialist dogma to think so---it just HAS to be true, right ?

In any case, show me evidence---ANY evidence---for the existence and mechanism of altruism genes in humans.

I was born in 1938. Both my brother and I had mumps, measles, chicken pox - no whooping cough, fortunately. We had our throats painted with argeryl (sp?) for strep throat.

I had all three of my sons vaccinated with all vaccines available. Unhappily, my oldest contracted "German measles" (no vaccine at that time) and before he was diagnosed we spent the day with a woman in her 2nd month of pregnancy. I notified her immediately of the diagnosis and she had to have gamma globulin shots to try to prevent damage to her unborn child if she contracted German measles.

My mother came down with polio the month after Pearl Harbor. She was lucky - as a result of the polio she had muscle atrophy in her left leg and limped to her dying day at age 82, but she could walk, drive, garden, and lead a normal life - barring the 3 knee replacements in her right leg, which was overworked to compensate for the weakness of her left leg. Many of the friends she made during her lengthy hospitalization for polio weren't so lucky.

I remember pool closings, movie theater closings, etc. during polio scares. And when the Salk vaccine came to Chicago I was first in line with my sons for the vaccine.

Anyone who risks their children's health or other children's health because of belief in disproven theories and web-based nonsense is, in my opinion, not fit to be a parent.

Where do you get the idea that the divestment movement against Israel has anything to do with "polite, country-club" anti-Semitism? Academic, liberal opposition to Israel is consistent with their general worldview.  To the extent that there is any non-rational, "prejudiced" element to it, it is a prejudice against white, Western people in conflict with non-whites -- white Westerners are assumed to be the bad guys (which they often are, but anyways).  The same people who oppose Israel and support the Palestinians also were anti-apartheid in South Africa militants, while they often worry much less about oppression perpetrated by non-Westerners, like Arab or Turkish oppression of the Kurds.  Do you think that makes them "politely" anti-Dutch (South Africa)?  Many Jews, including myself, generally share this ideology, and in fact criticize Israeli behavior, and many more would if Israel wasn't a Jewish country.  I wish more of us were more sensitive to hypocrisies and complexities.  Non-Jewish academic liberals are much more likely to believe anti-Semitism is a thing of the past and thus not worry about it than to be anti-Semitic themselves, "politely" or otherwise.

I live in rural VT, about an hour north of Rutland ( I am using my sister's NYT account). Our bucolic community had recently been terrorized by a rash of daylight break ins  committed by heroin addicts. When one of the junkies was caught, and police found his home filled with stolen merchandise, dozens of homeowners appeared at the bail hearing, begging the DA to make his bail so high he would not get out. I would much prefer addicts were able to get inexpensive legal heroin than having to steal $500 a day to support their black market habit. The prohibition against heroin and other drugs causes more harm than the drugs themselves. When was the last time you heard of a drive by shooting or burglary over alcohol? Would you rush out to try legal heroin? Me neither.

I will be interested to see how the police's killing of protestors plays out in the courts. National and international courts have a spotty record in prosecuting such cases. The Egyptians prosecuted Mubarak but I am not aware of a UN investigation of El-Sisi. Former President Saleh in Yemen hasn't been charged. In South Africa, two years ago, and in China as a regular practice, unbelievably, it is the demonstrators, rather than the police who shoot at them, who have been charged. And, in the Sudan, while no charges have been brought against the President for the recent killings of protestors, he has been charged with genocide-- the only such charges ever brought against a sitting President.

Clearly, politics play a large role in the charging decision. But some deposed leaders are charged and some are not. And, while most sitting leaders are not charged and some charge the victims. one sitting leader has been charged.

My guess is that prosecuting Yanukovych is not in the cards. But dozens of Ukrainian demonstrators died, and somebody needs to answer for that.

Exclusion of Russia from G8 is a necessary step. However, Russia never took G8 seriously because its interests belonged outside this select club of nations. In today's world G8 has lost its relevance because G20 has emerged as a more effective organization. G20 is defined by not only the most-wealthy organization but also by the most population of the world. Third world countries view G8 as the reminiscent of the colonial past. Therefore time has come to completely disband G8 and focus on G20 to create a new world order.

I have a feeling that when G8-1 holds it's meeting somewhere, Russians will be meeting with China, India, Brazil and South Africa. It appears that Russia has a bigger audience in the game of theaters. Many, if not most, auto manufacturers have found a way to make recalls profitable. The vehicle owner goes in to have the recall problem corrected, then receives a call telling them that while making the needed repairs, the mechanic discovered a different problem that needs immediate attention. In my case, a small leak in the coolant reservoir (which I suspect was swapped by the mechanic), and the hoses associated with the reservoir. The estimated cost was $280. I bought the parts, genuine factory replacements, on line for less than $40 and completed the job in less than 30 minutes. If I'd been familiar with the task, it wouldn't have taken me 10 minutes.
Beware. Know your vehicle well when you take it in for repairs. I suspect even the most reputable shops often use this slight-of-hand to increase profits.

I have spent many of my formative years as a child, adolescent and young adult on Staten Island and all of my 20 years as an addiction therapist on the Island as well. Addiction has been a force on the Island for years. It holds the distinction of being the boro with the highest rate of teen alcoholism and also has high rates of other problems associated with addiction like cigarette smoking, infectious disease and liver disease. The reality of addiction is that it is caused by biological, psychological and social variables. However, the first two variables (biological and psychological) can be mitigated by the last one. I ran drug prevention programs on Staten Island for over a decade. They were simple… you provide a book, a musical instrument, a drama play, or a ball along with some invested adults between the hours of 3PM and 9Pm and you offset the age of substance use initiation. If an adolescent does not use substances regularly before age 18 years the chances they will have full blown substance dependence as an adult is exponentially reduced. The epidemic of death and pain we now experience was a sleeping giant that was awakened in part by a medical system that perhaps did not understand addiction when the giant could not be fed via a prescription it went to a more direct form. Despite the sad facts of this issue, Staten Island remains a place of tenacity, resilience, desire for recovery and therefore a place of hope.

Suspending four year olds will sound outrageous to some, but sadly to those of us who have spent time working in public schools, it is quite easy to picture. So many very young children are growing up with serious trauma that goes unaddressed. It is be impossible for some young children to contain themselves and behave "appropriately" in a class setting without assistance from a trained expert. Often the behavior exhibited by the adults in a child's life will offer no guidance as to how to treat other children, adults or physical space. This is a direct result of poverty. It may not be that anybody is giving up on four year olds but that schools do not have the resources or the training to work with kids with severe behavioral issues. It may be impossible to keep the other children safe. Schools need to be re-imagined as community centers with therapeutic and health facilities to address the needs of all the children.

Is this op ed a joke? How can cutting the required EFC cut college costs? Does the author think higher education financial aid is an entitlement?
Who is going to make up the difference at the vast majority of colleges that don't have huge endowments? States? The federal government? Maybe upper-division students can teach those in the lower division. Will all college courses now be taught on line? Will we just let the colleges that don't have large endowments close their doors? I love movies. I have taught film studies and there are some movies I can watch over and over again for the rest of my life: "Chinatown," "Philadelphia Story," "All About Eve," "Love With the Proper Stranger," "The Verdict."  I have come to fully appreciate, however, how searing on our society's consciousness, movies have been.  Some still believe that there was something benevolent about slavery, because they can cite the great Hattie McDaniel as Mammy in "Gone With the Wind," as an example.  Most thought nothing of the age disparity between Audrey Hepburn and Gary Cooper in "Love in the Afternoon" and Grace Kelly's stunning and youthful beauty matched with Gary Cooper (again) in "High Noon" or with James Stewart in "Rear Window." If an older woman is matched with a younger man, as in "The Graduate," when Anne Bancroft's Mrs. Robinson was teamed with Dustin Hoffman's Benjamin Braddock, the woman is depicted--in all her animal print glory-- as preying on the innocent--no one thinks twice about it.  But, in fact we do: the images we see in the movies have a lot to do with how we see ourselves.  Positive, fully developed women, like the ones I see in real life don't show up much in the movies.  It's not unimportant to have movies do some of the work that still needs to be done in the women's movement, to have women depicted as who they really are: human--with all their strengths and flaws depicted--and not just as extensions of men or somebody's mother.

The best negotiating stance when a hostile party who sees negotiation as a a zero-sum game:  simply listen.  (This is basic training in handling irate customers in any business environment).  If they want to talk, you let them talk.  You listen.  Once they finish, you tell them you are very glad to have heard what they had to say (which you are....).  You then hang up.  You wait.  They wouldn't have called you if they felt they were in a good negotiating position.  They are waiting for concessions or 'conciliatory gestures'.  You are cordial, but you give them neither.  He who speaks first, loses, as they say in any negotiation training (or sales training) course.

If I'd done what I wanted to do at 40 - taken a low-paying position in the public interest or labor sector - instead of being practical and taking a high-paying position that better protected my family - I'd be a much happier person right now.

Instead, when Pete Seeger died last week, I cried not merely for Pete, but for my own life, which I feel that I have wasted.

If you want to sing hip hop, sing hip hop. If you want to be a labor organizer, be one. If people tell you that you are impractical or are having a mid-life crisis, tell them that better a crisis now, then regrets when it is perhaps too late to embark on the road that you didn't take.

In a previous lifetime, I helped maintain ["run"] a large government software system of national importance.
... Based on my experience, the underlying problem at the N.S.A. was not one of getting access to various files that were stolen, but who "cleared" [gave access to] those who maintained the software.
In order to "keep things running", the N.S.A. gave Mr. Snowden access to many files [probably all, in his capacity of Systems Administrator] in their system. This was based on their belief that he would act in the national interest, that is, according to specific laws governing the handling of classified information.
Presumably Mr. Snowden was investigated thoroughly by the FBI and possibly by other agencies before he was given access these files.
Mr. Snowden turned out to be untrustworthy.
The moral?
... If and when the N.S.A. or any other agency gives the wrong people authority to maintain their systems, any information in those systems will be subject to theft and disclosure.

I visited McNally Jackson for the first time over the weekend, when Harriet Scott Chessman and Priscilla Gilman read from their works. Many of the smaller independent booksellers are community gathering points for events. So sorry to see them dwindling from the landscape. My hometown, Springfield, MA, no longer has any bookstores in the downtown area. North of us is a plethora of independent booksellers and a couple of Barnes & Nobles. The independents struggle to survive. Yet, they are the place to go to meet authors, find specialty books, and get great customer service.

A few months ago I was having a conversation with a friend about how much sense of loss was really appropriate for the death of celebrities we didn't know. Initially I thought, why should someone care so much about some rich famous person who never knew they existed, and not the hobo down the street who died of liver failure? But then it occurred to me that although there were many celebrities whose passing didn't exactly move me, I have felt the loss of some celebrities who died, and to varying degrees. I realized it was proportional to how much said person enriched our lives, and how much or how little that was is personal for everyone. That said, I'm devastated by the loss of Philip Seymour Hoffman. I've laughed and I've cried with the characters he's breathed life into for nearly two decades of my life. I'm hard pressed to imagine a more relevant or talented actor. He'll be sorely missed but never forgotten.

Does anyone here really think that this tit for tat /rub my belly and I'll rub yours/ is not standard fair at every level of politics and every party.

The real story here to me is more how privacy is falling to technology on every front sometimes for better sometimes for worse. Fields that depend on privacy for functioning but require immense amount of communication are at highest risk like diplomacy and politics.

There is a new level of accountability now that emails and internet communication is our new way of doing things and video/ audio recording devices lurk in every corner.

We have not yet fully learned that there is no such thing as secure internet communication period. From Snowden to Weiner to Christy to Romney the underlying dynamic is the same. Nothing new is happening it's just that we the common man or even amateur sleuth suddenly have access to privacy breaking tools that were only available to the highest levels of government.

Initially we may think that total transparency is a good thing until we read studies about how much daily lying and half truths go into a functioning marriage. Functioning politics and diplomacy are even more dependent on this type of stuff. What is the right balance? Time will tell, or you'll soon start to see a lot of crashes between carrier pigeons and the new amazon delivery drones.

I write from the Gut Microbiota for Health World Summit 2014. Many of the world's foremost researchers and clinician/researchers from 47 countries have reviewed/discussed the data on the impact of the intestinal bacteria on human health. Readers should know that the basic science (mostly animal models) strongly supports a role of the microbiota in multiple dimensions of human health ranging from obesity, hyperlipidemia, osteoporosis, autoimmune disease, anxiety, autism, allergies, atherosclerosis and even cancer. Well written articles like this will help awaken patients, health professionals and more researchers to an entirely new interdisciplinary science with incredible promise. Likewise, just as with new guidelines that limit use of blood transfusions to when they are absolutely needed, we should all consider deeply what constitutes appropriate use of antibiotics.

The Malaysian 777 jet performance is very similar to 3 UK Comets which also fell out of the sky 60 years ago during  "normal" flights. When commercial planes get up to altitude, the cabin is pressurized like a balloon. Stress analysts know that with the corners around windows the stress from pressurizing  is amplified as s so-called stress concentration. They essentially came down with no warning as the fuselage precipitously popped like a balloon.With the Comets, that finding was conclusively made. Today with computational methods, one would think that should not be possible. But it was reported that the plane was operated in a corrosive salt water environment which might have accelerated the process.

I say this as someone who started sailing at age 15 and completed a circumnavigation at age 27. Later I started my family.

Roy is an icon, a philosopher and brave beyond words. Deb's beautifully written piece highlights Roy's extraordinary qualities. To be a woman, alone and so fearlessly outspoken is indeed, to demand respect. The lively discussion that follows here is testimony to the ability of both subject and writer. At the NY launch of the paperback edition of The God of Small Things, Roy was asked how she managed to get the voices of children so clearly. Her response was something I frequently quote: "Children misinterpret the world so accurately." She has a voice that is needed, in a world that still discredits the disenfranchised including women, children, the poor and the uneducated. Philosophers make the status quo uncomfortable for those who cannot countenance change. Arundhati - I wish you strength and courage on a difficult road that has chosen you.

The assertion that this president is militarily weak against our enemy is misapplied. The president doesn’t lead a charge with lance and shield; instead he directs it be done by the good men and women who protects us all.
A president is only as strong as the American people who are willing to stand behind his actions. This was clear in the recent Syrian near catastrophe, which was avoided because the American people had no inclination for another military misadventure. Our interference in Syria would nearly been as illegal as what we now accuse President Putin of doing.
Russia-Soviet Union has made aggressive moves during nine of eleven recent US presidential terms, and as long as it is near their “turf”, does not involve our vital interests; there isn’t anything substantial we will engage in to stop them.
At some point, the hysterical barbs which are directed at this president have the American people as their real object, for it is they who have no interest in, or stomach for, new foreign crises. We realize full well there are too many new mistakes to be made without repeating the old ones.

- Reports from prisoners who had been released from Gitmo.
- Documents released by Wikileaks.
- Documents released by Edward Snowden.
- The School of the Americas in Florida, which among other things teaches army officers in allied Latin American countries how to torture people.

The ruling does not upend base limits on contributions to candidates in primary and general elections, correct? The limit is $2,600 per candidate.
