I think one of the reasons that the ACA has been able to be batted around in the polls and easily manipulated by the republican horror stories is that not all people are really invested. The majority of people with health insurance have employer health insurance and they have no vested interest in the ACA or incentive to learn about it. I work as an independent contractor for a large corporation and the employees there know very little about the ACA and/or believe the horror stories in the news. So these people if poled would be skeptical of the ACA - but mostly they are just not interested because they are not personally affected. I think the people who devised the ACA made a mistake of not including everyone in the program.

There was never a "hysterical" approach to facing the climate crisis. So there is no post-hysterical approach to climate progress to be done. We've been trying to reason with skeptics regarding the need for action on addressing climate change. For true skeptics, reason may work since they are capable of changing their position on this issue. But the deniers are beyond reason. No amount of evidence, physics, temperature data, consensus, or obvious effects on plants and animals can change their minds. I've discussed these things with these people for years--no progress is ever made with them. I'll give an example of their lack of reasoning from a different discussion I had last week. We were discussing voter ID. I said they were unnecessary because there was very little evidence of voting fraud. The other person said there was rampant fraud in her state. I asked for evidence, but none was forthcoming, I made my point again with more links to research showing little to no voting fraud. I asked her if she might be willing to change her stance in light of the fact that she could provide no evidence of voting fraud and I could provide evidence that there was very little. She said "no," she would not change her stance. but she said I should change my stance. If there was significant voting fraud, I just might change by stance on voter ID laws. This conversation could have easily been about climate change...or just about any issues of our day. Makes you want to pull your hair out.

It is not always simply requiring ID but the requirements to get an ID that impede people from voting.  My mother is turning 91 yrs. old in a few weeks.  She has voted religiously her whole life, and she has voted in North Carolina since 1980.  She will have to get her original birth certificate and a utility bill and go to the DMV in order to get an ID with which to vote.  She gave up driving years ago and her passport has expired; but expired IDs do not count.  She is as sharp as ever mentally.  There are multiple laws to protect accessibility to the disabled, but these laws actually deny accessibility (to the polls) to those who are only disabled by age and their expired IDs.
Better Question: Will Ukraine become the Germany of the Second Cold War?

My father, an Omaha Beach veteran, would roll in his grave if he could see how many hoops his 90yr old widow had to jump through in Texas in order to get an i.d. card so she could vote.

Every legislator and commenter to this article who thinks that the issue is not a big deal should visit a few nursing homes, in which many of the oldest residents are either WWII vets or widows of vets. Many are on medicaid, so to pay the fee for a birth certificate much less locate an advocate to help in the process is a brick wall.

My mother's ability to vote was lost when her driving i.d. expired. Her state rep's office told me she could use a gun license. I explained that old people in these homes are not allowed to pack heat. The excuses they gave for the law were mind numbing. Mom even talked about 'practicing' her driving so she could qualify again for a license and become a real person again, i.e. be recognized by the State of Texas. She is in a wheelchair, can barely hold her head up, and has terrible eyesight.

My parents were from the 'greatest generation.' The politicians who are passing these law limiting voting should visit a few of these folks, while they're still alive, and be made to look at them square in the eye.

I know what my mother would tell them: I can't believe we fought a war so you could be free to take away people's ability to vote.

Interesting this is printed and interesting comments. I'm actually involved with the MLB team naming issue. I am not a Native American/indigenous person so I do the work as a human being. I have asked all MLB team owners and the commissioner for an open conversation and one is needed. It can be ongoing, respectful and thorough.

What are possible solutions? Rebranding, an obvious first choice, happens all the time. Donations of coats to peple freezing--still a reality of friends I have on tribal lands--only the smallest beginning. Venting greviences has a place but is not a solution. As a woman I can claim the largest historical grevience list in the world. Stubbornness belongs in kindergarten It does not change tomorrow.

This is not a tribal issue. This is not a sports issue. It is not even an economic issue unless the owners are themselves afraid their marketing teams are not up to the task. This seems unlikely given their egos and their resources. This is not an "always been" issue as every team has had name changes, all sports. It is a human issue, a simple issue of arrogance. "I AM RIGHT" screamed (usually) from the stadium seats and demonstration lines and social media and editorial pages as here.

Updating and replacing the country's infrastructure is critical to the well-being of the United States. Not only the visible physical transportation infrastructure, but also our energy and communications infrastructure.

And yet this issue gets very little traction with the public. In my opinion, this is largely due to the fact that a lot of the public views this as a cosmetic upgrade. The president needs to clearly explain to people how upgrading our transportation and communication infrastructure keeps our businesses competitive. The president needs to communicate clearly that this is the sort of national program that will create thousands and thousands of jobs. And why not - appeal to national pride. There are third world countries with more advanced infrastructure than ours, not to mention the fact that other developed countries have left us in the dust. Appeal to our desire to be number 1.

At the breakup of the Soviet Union America promised that NATO would not expand eastward. We reneged on that promise and Poland joined the military alliance known as NATO. There was an ABM treaty with Russia that the US decided to let expire despite offers from Russia to expand its coverage. We promptly began to militarize space and under Obama started to place star wars systems in Central Europe. The pretext that this was to counter a missile threat from Iran was laughable.

We've sought military bases in Central Asia and sought regime change in Iran, again on Russia's southern border. Any first rate grad student could have predicted that this constant process of encroachment was at some point going to draw a negative response.

Russia is violating international law. But isn't it ironic that this is the major claim of the US after we've directly or indirectly invaded a half dozen country's in the last thirty years? The first step in defusing a crisis is to acknowledge the interests of the other side. This does not require us to agree with those interests, but it establishes a framework for negotiation. Anyone reading the Ukrainian situation carefully can see that there are clear openings, beyond the media posturing to defuse this crises.

Ever since Edward Snowden revealed the existence and extent of the NSA surveillance programs, President Obama stated that the American people should have an "open debate" on the issue.

The truth is that open debate should have happened soon after President Obama was sworn in on 1/20/09. The problem is we still don't have access to 100% of the information required for an open debate. We have information that's been put out there, either because the government released it (with portions held back) or Snowden revealed it.

So it's more of a skewed, one-sided debate, with the Executive branch and NSA privy to 100%, and the rest of us privy to less than 100% - how far less is any one's guess.

I certainly hope the president doesn't try to split the baby by coming down right-in-the middle - as is his nature - giving a bone to each side (the left and right), but really not significantly overhauling/dismantling the national security apparatus that has overstepped on personal rights and privacy.

Actually, there has been plenty of disruption--just not of the kind you're talking about. Let's start with white flight and then move on to corporations moving to suburban "office campuses" taking with them their tax dollars as well as the tax dollars of all those people who move from within the city to the new suburban locations. In many industrial cities, the heavy industry that filled tax coffers have either gone out of business, severely downsized, or similarly moved out to suburban locations. Further, increasingly large non-profit hospitals and universities have taken more and more city land off tax rolls. In some states (Pennsylvania, for one) the growth of divided, limited access highways since the '60s has also made it easier for people to live outside local taxing areas while continuing to hold paying jobs within them. One of my husband's former subordinates bragged that she and her husband were smart to live beyond the city limits so they incurred no wage taxes. However, since the two of them worked for non-profits, neither they nor their employers were contributing to the costs of providing municipal streets, traffic control, emergency services, or any other amenities that are available to anyone living, working, or visiting within city limits. In many cities, all those "disruptions" have led to a downward spiral--as fewer businesses and people pay taxes, taxes rise for those remaining and services deteriorate, encouraging yet more to leave.  Disruption aplenty.

This article and the studies that it discusses suffer from a flawed or at least questionable assessment of cause and effect.  Are couples who spend more time alone together happier for that reason, or do couples who are happy in marriage CHOOSE to spend more time together because they enjoy each other's company?  Are marriages between partners who are materially better off happier and more stable because they are materially better off, or are people who are materially better off more likely to get married only because they have found the right partner but otherwise wouldn't consider marrying anyone?  And there was no qualification of the 45% divorce rate:  the rate is so high because of serial losers at marriage, people who get married and divorced two, three, four, or five (like a friend of mine!) times.

Worse than insufficient choice in physicians is insufficient choice in hospitals in plans. With four hospitals in the immediate area, the only in-network hospitals in some of the ACA-compliant plans offered were a minimum of a 45 minutes drive with no traffic -- and this in a heavily populated, high-traffic, congested part of the country.

Two of the hospitals in the local area were recently purchased (along with more than a few medical practices) by a medical insurance provider who popped up after the ACA was introduced. There's clearly profit in cornering a local market: The policies offered by this provider do not cover any more than other plans, but the plans they offer are more expensive. Where are the regulators on health care monopoly?

We did get sold a bill of goods with the ACA. Premiums are not affordable unless subsidized, as anyone over the age of 45 can attest. Co-pays for many services that plans used to include to make them marketable have skyrocketed. There's a lack of choice in medical care that did not exist prior to the ACA. One can only hope that the ACA is a prelude to a single payer system that will truly offer affordable and convenient care to everyone. This is what Dr. Emmanuel should have fought for in the first place.

Most of the comments here argue over who is most entitled to claim the mantle of victim. In other words, we have learned nothing and are incapable of learning, which perhaps is why subsequent horrors have and continue to happen.

What distinguishes the Jews as victimes, about one half of those who died in the camps and killing centers, is that the more historians understand Germany under the Nazis, the more they understand that the extermination of Jewry was a national purpose and policy of Germany in going to war.

Germany literally went to war to kill all the Jews in the world.

In setting up the machinery to do that and in killing six million Jews it also caught six million others in the apparatus of death, which became so useful to eliminating others Germany deemed unworthy.

But their deaths were by circumstance, not from national purpose and policy as were those of the six million Jewish victims and that is what distinguishes the Holocaust, the Shoah, from all other genocide.

It was not an expression of racial, religious or tribal hatreds -- all too terrible -- but the national policy of what had been the leading European state and is again the leading European state today.

That's what makes it so unfathomable and sets it apart from all the other crimes and horrors in history.

Victimization does not need to be argued over. It happened.

Does the history of Europe indicate something intrinsic about white people?  I speak of the Hundred Years War, the Inquisition, the burning of heretics, World Wars I and II, the Holocaust, the "Troubles" in Ireland, the Balkans in the 1990's, etc,. etc. and sickeningly etc.

I'm not sure what, if any, intervention I would support. But the idea that we should intervene if only some opposition was pure enough makes me sick with the hypocrisy of it. The Syrian opposition remained peaceful for months and months, was mercilessly slaughtered by its government all that time, and was given no help whatsoever. Then, when extremists had had ample time to flood in, Obama spouts nonsense about red lines and doesn't follow up anyway.

Meanwhile, the Ukrainian opposition IS democratic and pluralistic, IS implementing an inclusive government, and IS seeking ties with the west, and yet you continue to write "if, if, if..." I really don't think any lip service should be paid to helping foreign democratic movements when the reality is that we are "only" willing to help the imaginary perfect people that never come- perfectly peaceful, perfectly willing to be slaughtered, perfectly liberal in their political views, etc. And this is not even to mention that all "perfectly" democratic European countries have substantial right wing parties of their own (France, Austria, etc. anyone?) I am Russian and lived in Russia in 1990s. The Yeltsin’s government was incredibly corrupt and incompetent. Many people were not getting paid for months. But government officials were getting filthy rich. American officials approvingly called them "the young reformers." Oligarchs plundered Russia's resources. They were admiringly called "baby billionaires." Corruption and chaos in Russia didn't matter as long as Yeltsin did not insist on having independent foreign (and, for that matter, domestic) policy.

Most Russians will see economic sanctions as punishment for daring to defend Russia’s interests. If you think your country’s independence is at stake, you are willing to pay a high price.

Consider the war in Vietnam. The US lost that war to a third-world country. Why? Simple: The Vietnamese were willing to “pay any price, bear any burden” to unify the country. The US could not match that, and for a good reason: there was no vital national interest at stake.

I have not seen a convincing argument that something truly important to most Americans is at stake in the Ukrainian crisis. Why escalate a fight if you are not willing to bleed?

Talking to young children alone will not fully prepare them for kindergarten or high achievement. Children raised in affluent families who expose them to 30 million more words than poor children by the age of 3 usually do a lot more than talk. Playing learning games, reading books, and taking trips to the library, these are just a few ways that more chatty parents provide additional educational opportunities.

I founded 10 Books A Home to provide low-income families who live in high poverty school boundaries with a service that has been used for centuries: one-on-one home tutoring. Our volunteer Role Models visit children at home once a week from the age of 3 until they begin kindergarten. And, in order to receive our free home tutoring service families must agree to participate in three ways: 1. Participate in every lesson. 2. Practice skills with their child between lessons. 3. Engage in family reading. In this way, we simultaneously prepare children for kindergarten while encourage dynamic forms of parent involvement.

Right now, we serve primarily Latino children, many of whose parents do not speak English. And, our lessons are only conducted in English. What I can say from our 2 short years offering this program is that it works. No two families are the same. No two children are the same. Being ready for kindergarten is complex, too. One-on-one home tutoring is flexible, adaptable, and, so far for our Learners, is readying them for school success.

I'm not so sure that younger people don't recognize the problem, I think it's more that younger folks are more committed to trying to work within the political system to undo the threat rather than marching in the streets. Among other things, they've discovered over the last decade that perfectly legal peaceful protests get you pepper-sprayed, beaten, in at least one case run over with motorcycles, vilified in the press, accused of rape, murder, and terrorism, and ultimately shut down by force. And then the people with real political power still ignore you.

By contrast, voting and other efforts within the system have in fact made a difference: Younger people are a big part of why Obama is president instead of John McCain or Mitt Romney, gay marriage is legal in a lot of places, marijuana is becoming legal, the wars are (slowly) winding down, and Elizabeth Warren is in the Senate. The reason you aren't getting the sense of rebellion that you might have 45 years ago is because younger Americans know they have older allies and are working with them to slowly but surely change America into the country they want to live in.

And that's exactly the outcome the GOP fears and is reacting to. It's a bit like a child in a grocery store who doesn't get the candy he wants: They'll scream, they'll annoy everyone, but ultimately lose.

I worry about some of the assumptions that go along with this, especially that obesity should be treated as a disease with a therapy that we can develop. With discussions of the "obesity epidemic" it is no doubt that people are after drugs to address the issue, but this misses the point: obesity and weight are side-effects or symptoms.

Similarly, why is it that the bear is considered obese when it is heavier? If it is, by definition, healthy for the bear to weigh more than it does in the summertime, doesn't the notion that obesity is a disease (which requires treatment--or an evolutionary adaptation, I suppose) fall short? Why is the baseline not the larger weight and the summer weight studied as the anomaly?

It's easy and all too common to get confused when it comes to what to treat in the case of obesity. When we talk about it as a disease, it's almost logical to deal with it as such and to come up with therapies. While losing weight (on a individual level) and managing the factors that contribute to an overweight or obese population (on a broader level) are harder than coming up with a band-aid to put on the problem, I've not lost hope that we can address the "epidemic" from the ground up.

They're only a minority because few people are informed on the issue. When you do look at the details, you realize wow, this is terrible policy. Of course, there's some good to the standards--that's true of any set of standards. But officially, you can't cherry pick, or limit testing, because states signed on without seeing them or considering the consequences. To say, "No thanks, we'll just take them under consideration as we evaluate our own curricula" is to risk serious repercussions. Districts are understandably afraid. Also, many districts simply don't have the resources to do the testing, to retrain teachers, or to review and replace curricula in every subject area. It takes money to buy new textbooks, to buy all the material items needed to do more hands-on engineering projects (Science standards)--but many districts have been cut to the bone financially. The tide is turning very quickly as people who are paying attention are realizing just how problematic CC is.

I don't disagree with you on the need to let kids who want to shunt off towards the technical trades rather than the academic track. We need this and we need it badly.

Where I disagree is having New York do it on its own. In my opinion, this needs to be done on a national level and not piecemeal. We need to make sure we have the infrastructure to move in that direction with technical high schools being established and community colleges that are ready to receive technical students who want to further their technical skills. We also need to have industries on-board with this, collaborating and providing apprenticeships and career tracks that will ensure these graduates' careers in the long term.

Frankly, given today's complete lack of interest in investing in the long term by politicians of a certain bent and big business in general, I don't see this happening for decades.

But we need it. Badly.

Having a spouse who lost his job in sales just over a year ago I absolutely sympathize with Mr. Gorelick. He is like my husband and many other long term unemployed people I know -- that is to say, willing to take on any job to support his family. My husband was very successful in his sales positions but as has been said no one wants to hire a 50 year old. Sadly, he cannot even get a job at Menard’s, Home Depot, or any of the other chains he has applied to! Funnily enough he has gone back to his musician’s roots and is able to eke out jobs here and there. I am fortunate to have a job but it is not enough by itself to support a family of four.
I have no hope that he will ever return to sales in his former capacity. I have no faith in any of our politicians and, as someone who has always treasured the right to vote and never missed an election, I find myself wondering “why bother”? No one wants to help the middle-quickly-turning-lower class. The stress on the children is what hurts the most. We try to hide it but the tension is palatable. And there are so many of us, with so many more to join our ranks. I wish Mr. Gorelick the best for he and his family. I imagine that he, like our family, would never have thought to find ourselves in this position after working for so many decades as a valuable, contributing member of society.

Years ago there was a horrid event in which a car plowed through a wonderful street market selling fresh vegetables and fruits in Santa Monica, California. A number of people were killed. In the court case that followed, a judge ruled that there should have been a better barrier at the entrance to the street, something that made it completely obvious that no one should attempt to drive down it. What I conclude is that some sort of solid barrier should be put across a street when there is a street festival or other large gathering in a street. If cars had been parked across the street in Austin, for example, the driver would have hit the cars and likely been unable to continue. People still could have been hurt or killed if they had been in front of the parked cars, but the numbers would likely have been lower.

As it turns out, Austin, where I once lived for a few months, has a history of these type of mass injury events. In two of the cases with which I am familiar, judges ruled that the drivers did not act irresponsibly, but were simply reacting to fear of the crowds surrounding their cars when they accelerated into people. In both cases, people on the street had been either attempting to confront the driver or otherwise pounding on his car.

Has SXSW gotten too big for its host city? A better question to ask, I think, is whether any city can safely have large on street gatherings and, if so, what stronger measures need to be taken to ensure safety.

I remember when this fragment was discussed a few years ago. Back then, it was mentioned, this was a fragment and the sentences were not complete. That is; words/letters were cut off.

All that has been proven is that this fragment was created between 400 and 800 AD. Also, that there is a partial quote from Jesus;

What we have is this.

... My Wife ... she will be able to be my disciple"....

There is no context. As the Gospels indicate, Jesus spoke in parables and used examples. Fro all we know, he could have preceded with with, "I am not married, but if I were,..."

As we do not have the whole document, making assumption that Jesus was married cannot be be a proven fact by what is contained here.

This could have been a fragment about anyone who lived in ancient times. You cannot draw a complete historical context, and facts, from what is written here. This is like assuming what were all the Ten Commandments by only having "Thou shalt not" and "Thou shalt".

So, those can speculate as much as they want, but until more fragments are found, and context determined, then this really does not prove Jesus was married.

It is clear that a subset of countries will need to take the lead in taking actions to reduce emissions and increase the capacity of the biosphere to absorb more carbon dioxide. This will have to include the United States and Europe, but also major countries like China and Brazil. This can be achieved by a grand bargain based upon mutual gains.

The commitment by a number of countries to reduce short term heat trapping gases and black carbon is moving forward and includes both developed and developing countries. It is addressing health effects as well as climate.
REDD+ is a leading component of any international agreement on climate change. It is the first step of what could be done to remove carbon dioxide more rapidly from the atmosphere and store it. Yet to come is Climate Smart Agriculture being instituted by FAO and World Bank that will increase productivity and store carbon in soils. Mobilizing the desertification convention could remove additional carbon dioxide while restoring degraded grasslands. Sustainable Energy for All, an initiative of the UN Secretary General and the World Bank could make a major difference in providing low carbon sustainable energy services in developing countries. China is moving to address deadly air pollution that will reduce coal use and/or initiate carbon capture and storage. As the report acknowledges, many cities and states and provinces are finding ways to reduce emissions.
Success will require multiple venues and not just UNFCCC.

Interested in an unregulated exchange free from government taxation or intervention? Join a bartering group and exchange your services for others’ services based on time. Need a plumber? Trade for something you do well for something your plumber needs. My mom once traded two of her famous pecan pies for having a house moved. Both parties feel they got the better end of the deal.

Bartering clearly won’t pay your utility bills or taxes, and will not solve large monetary problems now any more that in did 100 years ago, but at least you know what you’re getting, who your dealing with and why.

Bartering only works in the real world, though, with actual people doing necessary things. It is not useful for online gaming, Amazon purchases or offshoring ill-gotten gains. It’s not good for people who have trouble dealing with the complexities, messiness and occasional discomfort of face-face human interaction.

It may, however, help unemployed individuals keep their skills up to date by continuing their work, albeit not for cash; it may help you get things done you might not have the money to do and it may help to build stronger sense of community as well.

When considering the abstract nature of currency, it may be useful to consider what exchange is really needed for – the betterment of human lives.

Much is missing from this story, particularly the way Spain looks at life.  Spaniards work to live, NOT live to work as so many Americans do.  Everyone has a job, but rarely do you hear a spaniard ask, 'What do you do for a living?', the first words out of an Americans mouth when meeting someone.  Spaniards also value vacations, normally taking off an entire month, usually in August, to unwind and recharge.  During a normal work day, traditionally a grandmother is out in the morning, buying fresh vegetables and meat, preparing an incredible lunch where the whole family comes together in the middle of the day to have a wonderful meal, share their day, rest, maybe make love in the middle of the afternoon, then back to work.  Anyone who lives in NYC sees what the 9-5 schedule does to people who are exhausted most of the time, sleeping on the subway, walking around in a trance.  The rest of the world should be embracing the spanish model where quality of life, time with family and friends, enjoying the smaller things in life is not sacrificed to being another cog in the wheel, living ones life to produce for others.

The Rwandan condition is also the human condition; it just seems more heightened because they live in such a tiny, landlocked country with a population that is still too large for the land to support. In times of stress, even the richest societies in the world behave this way.

And despite the popular idea that Western colonization produced all of these bad/human tendencies in Rwandan society, the truth is that this attitude of compliance (and of pitting people against each other by a central authority) goes all the way back to the 19th century and beyond before the Europeans even arrived. Rwanda was one of the most politically sophisticated kingdoms in pre-colonial Africa; the kings made sure the trains ran on time, so to speak. So, let's look at Rwandans as humans first, victims second.

Lessons for Rwandans are lessons for all of us. Genocide is basically the rabies of humanity, to which we are all susceptible to by varying degrees based on conditions. (Ever notice that most genocides of the 20th century - Germany, Rwanda, Cambodia - all arose in landlocked countries in the aftermath of previous wars?) The definition of genocide is unimportant compared to acceptance of the reality that it is a social disease of all humans. There have only been more or less virulent outbreaks of it.

It all has to do with identity! The recent horror in Kansas is only the latest example of how we all suffer when bigotry rears its ugly head. Because of our human frailty, some of us feel the need to identify with something larger than ourselves. Whether Judaism, or its progeny Christianity, one understands that much good has been introduced and demanded of their adherents. As Passover is celebrated and Easter is fast on its heels, many will find time to think about the good men can do. And that gives hope to us that our better demons will prevail despite us. Much of religion attempts to put order into the accident of existence. The realization that we are the product of the accident of birth ought to give us the humility to lead righteous lives full of compassion for our fellow human beings who didn't luck out as we did. We don't need 613 rules to live a meaningful life. Like Thoreau a few simple rules could have a lasting effect if they were felt deeply like love. David thought less is more when we talk about material things. His focus was on the spiritual where sensitivity helps us understand that we must obey the laws of nature whether we wish to or not. Man is a member of a large family which includes all of us, Jews, Christians, Hindus, Moslems, Atheists and whatever. I agree that we ought to have a compulsion to honor and respect those in our family who are different as well as like us. Happy Passover and Easter to all my religious fellow human beings!

In short, some people avoid bad decision not because they expect good/nice things to happen to them if they make good decision, but rather because they saw first-hand the disastrous consequences of the bad decisions and they don’t want to live through that again. Why that does not work for everybody – I have no idea. Once you grow up poor, why would you ever do something so threatening to your life prospects as getting pregnant outside of a super-stable relationship?

The "overborrowing" you mention is, in most cases, the fact that private debt - from the banks - had to be taken on by the taxpayer.  Turning private debt into sovereign debt - as has happened in most European countries - has had a terrible effect in many ways, not least the problem of "moral hazard": how many bankers are really worried about crashing their firms again? They know they won't go to jail and the taxpayer will bail them out. There hasn't even been any meaningful regulation of the banks.

When my third grader took the test (it's inaugural year), the five month long preparation period was nothing short of nightmarish for its emotional stress. From what I can glean, her teacher was so anxious about how her class would do, she spent endless hours coaching them on the necessity of "doing their best" and singling out on practice tests all those with higher scores (in violation of privacy rights).

My daughter began having nightmares, tantrums, huge self esteem issues. She was a high performing student already fairly driven and this put her over the edge. She had to get in school and private counseling. This was disturbing enough, but worse was hearing other 3rd grade parents say their children were mentioning self harm in relation to the testing. You read that right. I brought this to the attention of the superintendent and school board but was dismissed.

Interestingly, the first afternoon after the first day of testing when my daughter came home -- she was fine. She was back to herself. All these stress symptoms left and never came back. She saw the tests were no big deal -- long, boring, but just another poorly written test.

The problem had been her teacher who could not sideline her own career anxiety and contextualize the relative unimportance of the tests for the individual students.

I will not opt my child out. This year my child and her current teacher are both clear that these tests are irrelevant time wasters.

I think this parable has played out its useful narrative in its comparison to today's class divisions. The difference is; in the parable the sons get equal shares: this has not and will not happen in our society today. I also feel that those on the receiving end of the prodigal assembly line, those  who reap the benefits of others' labors, are ethically compelled to give back to society in order to provide a surrogate 'bounty ' for those who never received their share. This is neither about redistribution nor entitlement on either side but a mutual interest in the common good ( in the parable the good of the household and it's microcosmic representation of society at that time).If the parable is taken to its deeper level, isn't this the message that the father was ultimately trying to convey as well as the individualism which Americans value so highly?

The foundation under all of this angst about the SAT is an American cultural trait that causes us to sincerely believe that if we really, really, really want to be President, all we have to do is try really, really, really try hard, and we can be.

This hate directed toward the SAT is largely because it purports to distinguish between us, to proclaim that some of us have the right stuff and some of don't. If we were to admit that there is such a thing as innate ability that separates us, then we might have to admit that even if we try really, really, really hard we will never be president, or go to Harvard, or be like Mike.

To believe that seems anathema to us, because fundamental to the American psyche is the ideal that we succeed not because of talent, but because of will. No matter that we can't run very fast, throw very far, or hit a baseball very often, we believe along with John Fogerty when he sings, "Look at me I can be centerfield."

Parents usually accept their children implicitly, no matter the behavior, which, when less than exemplary, is attributed to adverse circumstances and not to the individual per se. Additionally, that parent is exercising another gift, the gift of love, that is all-embracing and all-forgiving...as you depicted. I would remiss not telling how difficult that 'forgiveness' is, when recklessness (a crime, drug use, willful joblessness) of a relative or 'friend' affects our own well-being or comfort. No mercy, in our judgment, until contrition and change in his/her ways occurs. Your predicament of 'blind' forgiveness and inclusion, so he or she can see themselves worthy of trust, and become useful in society, is a more radical approach...and likely the right one. But please do not discount its difficulty; and do not take for granted our ability to use our heart and be magnanimous in adversity of their own making.

Gerald Ford was never elected president. He was never even elected as vice-president.

And yet, somehow, he became president.

Imagine that.

Now, imagine the same thing happening in Ukraine.

A corrupt and criminal president is removed from power. His political party dissolves and takes down the Prime Minister with it and is replaced by the same parliament that was there when Yanukovych was president.

Many times throughout history, non-elected leaders have had to take over their respective governments for whatever reason.

In the case of Ukraine, it was because the president raided the national treasury, changed the constitution illegally to give himself more power and, lastly, ordered the cold blooded murder of protesters on the street.

Those all seem to be very valid reason for removing someone from power.

There are no real cyberattack options here, unless we mean to do something else too that the cyberattack would support.

While we could not find the wines suggested in your column, there were several 2009 Haut-Medocs available at a local wine shop in Chicago. The staff was helpful & suggested that we could find one of the wines at a location in the suburbs. Was not up for a drive to the burbs so bought a comparable bottle , as well as a Haut-Medoc of an older vintage to compare since the 2009 vintage is drinkable but will benefit from more aging & different years, different qualities. We paired the wine with veal scallopini and the results were very nice. Opened the wine about 20-30 minutes before the meal and let it breathe. It was very smooth. Couldn't help noticing the flavor of the wine changed when drank with the veal. The veal flavor seemed to benefit from the pairing with the right wine as well. After the meal was over we finished the bottle and the flavor seemed fuller than when drinking with the meal. Certainly one of the better Bordeaux choices I've had over the years. Along the way to this bottle I learned a lot from reading online and talking with the wine merchant. Within Bordeaux the Haut-Medoc is a cabernet dominant blend while on the other side of the river the wines are merlot dominant. The fact that I prefer the Medocs says something about my specific wine preferences. At any rate, the wine school is a good idea. I only wish that it were once weekly, instead of once monthly. Looking forward to our next session.

I graduated from high school in the early 60's and jobs were not plentiful, the ones that paid well, were rare.  You were middle class if you  cleared $100.00 per week take home.  You could buy a new car every 4 years, own a home, and go on vacation one or two weeks in the summer.  Most of the people I graduated with could not get a job that paid that well, and many went into the service.  It was not a rosy time as you picture.  Yes, if you were 40 and had one of those jobs, life was good.  But for the young, getting paid more than $1.50 per hour was a great job.

We all know what suffering is. It is easy to define. I think it is less easy to describe happiness. What is happiness? Happiness is fluid, I think and perhaps the best definition would be "the absence of suffering". I know there is delirious happiness as when one gets married, has a baby, wins a large sum of money, but happiness, on-going happiness, a state of being, how do you describe that?
One would hope one is happy most of the time. One would likewise hope one is not usually suffering.
Is it possible to find some degree of a state of happiness even when suffering?
Maybe suffering also needs to be defined.
Is happiness a usual chronic condition?
Is suffering a chronic or acute condition, one that is not always present?
Is there an in between state between happiness or suffering?
I know what suffering is. I am not sure I know what happiness is.
So maybe that is why people are less likely to talk about happiness moments than they are to talk about suffering moments.
Perhaps the opposite of happiness is sadness, rather than suffering.
I think I can be happy and not even aware of it. However, I don't think I can be suffering and not aware of it.

A large part of the problem of growing inequality should be laid at the feet of the Federal Reserve.  Since 2008, the Fed has cut interest rates all the way to effectively zero, while at the same time engaging in multiple rounds of quantitative easing (a euphemism for buying bonds with money created out of thin air).  As the stock and bond markets have soared, interest rates on money market funds or savings accounts have been driven to nothing.  As a further effect of QE, prices for food, energy, and housing have increased, which disproportionately impacts those who spend the largest shares of their income on these basic costs of living.  The sooner the Federal Reserve stops QE and normalizes interest rates, the better.
